review_content: Somehow haven't rated this before now. Dry roast, creamy head and dry finish. Hint of old leather and some light bitter but. Black pour with great head and lacing.

Took me a while to come around to this one, but the stout flavoring quickly grew on me. Has a bold feeling, goes great with a plate of wings. Almost has a burnt taste to it, but strangely not in a bad way. Not for everyone, but great for enjoying and sitting down enjoying the flavor, not necessarily for crushing them down.

Hits your tongue with massive prune, coffee, and leather flavors. A bit drying afterwards. Medium carbonation. Good roastiness. Not as smooth as regular Guinness, but more flavorful. Pretty dang good for $3 on a cloudy, cold, fall day.
Wonderful coffee like smell, bittersweet taste, rich dark color, and wonderful palate.

Watery mouthfeel.
Roasted coffee taste.
Slightly bitter.
Weak foam.
Drinkable.

Keg at Hoohah Cafe, New Orleans, LA on 28/06/2008.  The description of adding Guinness wort into a pale ale mash doesn’t sound too tasty, but a height of industrialised production.  Either way, it doesn’t really taste much different to the European one, and might have been nicer out of a bottle than the dreaded nitro keg.  Not too bad, though.

Deep brown colour with medium beige head. Aroma of roasted malt and caramel. Taste is mild sweet, with some smokey hints of wood, coffee and bacon. Light to medium body, high carbonation, bitter end. It seems very new, since it is brewed in Tijuana, Mexico. Not so different from the draught can and bottle, slightly lower quality, but good overall.
The Guinness I regularly stock for drinking and recipes. Makes great brownies too. Only Guinness I like better is Foreign Extra stout.
Bottle in Manhattan, New York. Oh, this has the roasted barley taste unlike the Extra Stout in the British Isles or Europe. Not that different from the draught Guinness, except more ABV.
My First Love (beer love), I realized I was not the common drinker, my first step towards styles and variety, enjoying more my senses rather than the “non-senses” of getting wasted...
On tap at The Napper Tandy bar in San Francisco, California. Black aroma with big beige head. Bitter roasted malt taste with dry aftertaste.

Poured from bottle and it’s a dark coffee color with a head the color of coke fizz. The taste is bittersweet and finishes smooth despit it’s thick texture. The head disappears quickly but leaves good lacing on the glass as you drink. Another fine beer from Guinnes!
Dark black color creamy tan thick foam head smell of coffee dark chocolate dried fruit taste dark coffee bitter hops at the end

Poured from bottle into Tulip
L Jet black with dark beige head
S Coffee, slight hint of corn syrup 
T Coffee, Chocolate, Caramel, hint of vanilla 
F Well Carbonated, medium bodied, a little bit of bitterness on the back end.
Overall an old Faithful beer, not the best of stouts but widely available and pretty dang good.

Bière bue en bouteille Couleur ébène.  Petite mousse beige disparaissant rapidement. Au nez, malt grillé. Au goût, maltée acqueuse avec goût de résine et de bois brûlé. Je me passerais volontier de cette bière.

From 12 ounce bottle to wine glass	
Sight: Black, dark brown on the edges when held against the light, medium dark tan foam	
Smell: malty, nutty	
Taste: low bitterness	
Overall: Very good beer ok to repeat not look for

Bottle at home for end of SNF surprised hasn’t rated prior. Nice dark pour big frothy head. Nose is roasted malt and light licorice. Tastes of toasted malt, light coffee grind, earth, licorice and some cola. Fairly bitter and dry.
Pours oil dark with roasting on the nose tobacco and bakers chocolate palate with oily finish
First beer that got me into some really good stuff love the notes of coffee taste
Bottle. It pours black with a tan color head. Roasted malt aroma. Dry taste. Good.
Surprinsingly found this one at the nice Beer Store in Gloucester, sweeter and smoother than the original version. I like. Made a very bad impression after having a super Imperial breakfast stout
Dunkelbraun, cremige stabile Krone. Stärkere gebrannte Röstaromen, intensiver Kaffee. Antrunk Kaffee und Frucht, etwas schlank.

Six pack from Market Basket.
Solid dark brown in color with a thin tan head that persists. Rich roasty coffee aroma and flavor with hints of dark fruit earth and touch of tartness. Tasty as always.
Aroma contains Roast malt character. A little chocolate is in the aroma as well. A ton roast, burnt, charred notes. Biscuit is present thought out. An acrid bitter tinge on the finish.

Great beer, pours very dark, almost black, but not quite. The head is slightly brown (but not in a bad way) it is thick and flavorful, adding a-lot to the experience. The body is full and rich, with a nutty flavor.

I highly recommend it.

Bottle. 

Close to pitch black but I can see some red hues, nice off white head of foam, and even with the foam shrunk to a fine layer, there's good lacing. 

Roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee aromas abound. 

Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, light coffee, all nicely balanced. It's a Lot L so it was bottled in December. At 4 months, still a treat. 

Mouthfeel is great, screw the nitro, and very drinkable. One of the standard bearers of the style.

Bottle.

Dark. Tan head. Wet cardboard. Corn chips with some malt & bitter. Insouciant beer drinkers will find this acceptable.

My first beer. My first stout and now many hold up to Guinness when found on tap. Dark black color with a malty, almost slightly burnt malt aftertaste but it isn’t offputting. Very smooth beer. I can drink it all night while hanging with my friends.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is the first stout that I ever tried and it is still the one that I compare all other stouts to. I would love to travel to Ireland and get this magical brew fresh from the brewery but until then I am happy with enjoying this from the bottle here at home.

Bottle poured into a tulip glass, black with small tan head, which left good lacing,  Roasted malt flavor with coffee, some dark chocolate, licorice, molasses, pepper, raisins. This is a good stout would recommend to my friends.

The classic foreign version of Guiness. I don't even bother with the export draught/draft. This has the muscle, but I always wish Guiness here in the states was anything like the stuff in Ireland, which is completely magical. The Irish Guiness in Ireland is like mother's milk, a very creamy head, a stout that washes down in a magical way and has full, thick body. For some reason this beer is almost always pure acid by the time it gets to the states. The bitter hops, maybe? It's not the same stuff, maybe it's an Irish law.
Pours a dark brown to black with a khaki head. Aromas of chocolate and malt   Tastes the same with a little smoke. Thin mouth feel. But overall not bad.

1/12/18
With Abby while watching Return of the Jedi. Poured from bottle. 

Opaque dark brown with a substantial tan head. 

Nose is heavy on sweet, dark chocolate malts. Notable caramel and coffee present as well. Smells like a great stout. 

Taste is similar. Heavy on chocolate with roasty caramel malts and lots of coffee coming through. Noticeable bitterness from coffee and earthy hops brings a nice balance to the malt sweetness. 

Palate is medium body with a dry, bitter finish. Coffee/hoppy bitterness really come through after swallowing. 

Overall, this is an excellent, classic stout. What a stout should be and doesn’t try to get too fancy. I’m a big fan.
Watery beer. No pleasure. Maltiness, it is boozy for 5%. Thats all for what i know for this brewery and this style. Just a commercial brew. Wasting money.

I kind of liked it but it wasn't one I would tend to drink but I'm not sure why. A pretty well-balanced beer leaning towards the hoppy side. Very mild carbonation. It has a long, slightly bitter finish. very late in the finish I get a slightly metallic taste that lingers

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ciemne, niejprzejrzyste. Bardzo ładny lacing. Lekko kwaskowe, delikatna goryczka w posmaku. Zapach palonych ziaren kawy, trochę pietruszki?

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nice smooth after work hanging with friends kind of beer. Smooth, creamy and easy drinking.

Go to daily beer. Always like it. Easy to get at grocery stores in Metro D.C.
Far superior to the draft beer, which is rather flat and not very complex. Extra stout Foreign is better too. Whole Foods has it.

Just a no nonsense stouter version of the basic Guinness. I wouldn't go crazy trying to find it 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber from Kroger’s. Close to black and opaque, medium bodied. Roasted malt nose. Taste is bitter chocolate, malt and hops, with hops dominating the finish.

Rich black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, & some dark fruit; Flavor of roasted malt, hops, caramel, and some chocolate; Finish is slightly bitter; Overall, pleasantly surprised - pretty decent.

A thicker Guinness. Slightly sweeter up front and more roast in the aftertaste. An upgrade over the original; I'm looking for this beer on draft, preferably nitro. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Opaque dark with thick frothy head, that refuses to dissipate. Roasted coffee/malt aroma and taste, with dark chocolaty aftertaste. A lot more flavor than the draught, but also much heavier. A definite classic, that has been my go to beer for many years.
Bottle. Dark, malty, cacao and bittersweet chocolate. Slightly bitter taste and leafy.

At BJs. Soft dry classic bbbbbbvvfgggggffgghhgffhhhggcdghbvcdghjvcfhhbvghjfftyhhh

---Rated via Beer Buddy

Piana nie najladniejsza, szybko opadajaca. W aromacie dominuje przyjemna gorzka czekokada. Smak palonej kawy z wytrawnym finiszem i chmielową goryczką. Piwo poprawne i bardzo pijalne, choć mogloby oferowac mocniejsze doznania zarowno w aromacie jak i smaku.

Deep dark brown coloured body with a large, soapy light brown head, about two centimetres tall, that leaves a pretty ugly lace on the side of the glass. Aroma of cream, milk, lactose, light malt, nuts and very little else - mellow in the nose. Light to Medium-bodied; Assertive cream, milk and lactose flavours throughout with a lot of nuts, earth and malt, but the lactose and cream are very evident, even on the end. Aftertaste shows a lot of milk, some earthy malt and toffee sweetness coupled with a touch of light cherry and fruit flavours near the end - nice and subtle. Overall, a smooth and very mild stout with a thinnish body and showing only a touch of complexity from fruit, compared with the majority of the taste - which is all about cream and lactose with some small malts. I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased by my Uncle Larry on the Eastern Shore of Virginia in 2016, sampled at home at his house here in Pungoteague, Virginia on the Eastern Shore in his honor on 15-January-2017 - RIP Uncle Larry.
Black with a yan head. Aroma is hops and roasted barley. Taste is slight chocolate and roasted barley. Slight slice aftertaste.

Flagship for stouts in my book. Certainly the first I ever had. Strong in most ways. Opens with a dark black appearance and a dark tan head that slowly leaves. Little carbonation. Unusual scent, sort of sweet, fruity and grainy. Heavy taste. Molasses. Raisins. I have moved on. Like the really strong, high alcohol content of the newer stouts I have recently tried. Actually I think Guinness is best as a black and tan. Now there you go.
Very dark with a finger white head, this beer radiates a soft scent true to its style. The taste is thin and not lasting but easy to down while also filling. Good beer overall.

This was the first stout I remember trying when venturing out from, Coors Light, Blue Moon and Shock Top, Then it captured my attention like a slap in the face that beer could be this powerful in style. Now that I have traveresed an array of the dark beer spectrum I come back to Extra Stout with a bit of dissappointment. Just as Guinness is lauded for they make a glass look sexy. The appearance is rich dark brown in color with a soapy/sudsy tan head. Drinking on down the lacing on the class is genoursly coated. On the aroma I get a quick whiff of roasted malt that leads to a slight plum character. The taste adds more emphasis on an earthy and slightly plum flavor. The mouthfeel is a more medium bodied, denoting that it is low abv for the style. The finish is roasted malt, a bit of smoke and dries the palate without being harsh.

In the glass it is a chocolate brown with a large bread. Aroma has roasted malts and bitterness. Taste is pretty smooth with mild bitterness and some sweetness. I taste some roasted malts. Pretty good finish.

Pours dark but thin with a large fizzy head. Smell is fairly faint but pleasant enough. Mouth feel is a little thicker than I expected from the pour, but still too watered down for a stout. Taste is not very strong, but smooth with a just a little bitterness. There are better stouts around, but I?d definitely drink this again.

11.2-ounce bottles in a pint glass. Compared both this and Guinness Draught side-by-side. Compared to Draught, Guinness Extra Stout had a thicker head, and a deeper, richer roasted aroma and taste. While both are good, I do prefer the Extra Stout. A little heavy to drink with a large meal, but on its own it is one of my favorites. These particular bottles say it was brewed in Ireland, not Canada, although I have had both.
Roasted malt aromas, some espresso too. Taste is roasted malt, cola, slight star anise, espresso finish and after taste.
Nice roasted malts smell. Black in color. Taste of roasted barley and espresso coffee notes at the end that tend to linger. Full body and love the carbonation. Finally a guinness for me. Nice work.

Pours dark with a thick tan head. Smells of coffee, chocolate and nuts, bitter. Finishes medium with a bitter kick.

Perfect for a cold day!

I have always enjoyed this beer. I think it is one of the best widely abailable stouts. I always drink this right out of the bottle. Has a real dark chocolate taste with a bitter finish. I generally do not like stouts, but this one is always tasty and relatively light.

Bottle. Pours black with a massive beige head. Good cling. Aromas of chocolate, gypsum and dark drugs. Flavors are gypsum, unsweetened dark chocolate, bread, and slight fruitiness. Dry as dust. Clean moutfeel. All-time classic stout.

1pt 6oz bottle. Pours clear black with minimal tan head and moderate grayish-tan lacing. Aroma of roast malt, chocolate, dark coffee. Taste of sweet coffee, malt, chocolate, quickly turning sour of grapefruit, long-lasting sour coffee taste. Would buy again.
De geur is al heel divers, met chocolade en gebrannde mout erin en de smaak is zeer goed, zeer rijk, terwijl ik normaal geen fan ben van stout. Dit is een aanrader
I had it from the bottle. The taste is chocolate, caramel, coffee, and bitterness. It has a nice full and creamy texture. This is a nice and simple stout.

Bottle says it’s made in Ireland. Pours black, huge tan head. Aroma is dark fruits, plums, raisins, almost winey.Flavor has a bit more cocoa, some hop bite on the finish. Mouthfeel is smooth, somewhat light.

Bottle. Nearly black pour with a tan head. Aroma is dark fruit, mostly grape and raisin, touch of chocolate. Taste is grape and raisin as well with a touch of roastiness, very simple, but also dry, balanced and easy-drinking.

Aroma: much more caramel-oriented aroma as opposed to the coffee aroma you get out of a Guinness Draught, reminds me of a slightly toasted flan dessert. 
Appearance: almost black and opaque with a long lasting tan creamy head.
Taste: slightly bitter but overall well-balanced with the malt richness shining through.
Palate: medium-full body, with a rich, creamy, pleasant mouthfeel.
Slightly richer than Guinness Draught.
Pours black with a thin tan head. Roasted aroma. Bitter dark chocolate roast flavor. Very thin feel in the mouth.

Bottle that said "drink from the bottle ". Poured anyways. Dark brown, tan head. Light coffee, toffee aroma. Burnt/roasted malts, tame slight bitterness, faint mouthfeel. Formerly a more interesting beer in old-school times , less so now with all the craft availability.

Bottle at home to the dome. Pour is hazy brown with a small tan head and great lacing. Husky, cocoa, toasted malty, bready, straw, and licorice in the aroma. Taste is roasty, nutty, husky, corny, some cookie malt, toffee, earthy, and bready. Light mouthfeel with high carbonation. Bleh.

Sets the standard for all Irish stouts. Pours black, great cream head on nitro. Aroma of roasted malts, choc and toffee. Taste is always the same and great Mouthfeel is too light for me, but who am I to knock Guinness.

Still the benchmark for what a dry stout should be. Pros: Beautiful black color and, on nitro, a voluminous off-white head and creamy mouthfeel; nice, if light, roasted notes. Cons: Pretty light flavor; love-it-or-hate-it sour characteristics. Overall, a solid stout that I’m always happy to order when I’m out and about, but easily overshadowed by a lot of the world’s more flavorful, aggressive stouts.
Every now and then I get an itch for a heavy coffee like after work adult beverage, when a traditional lager won’t cut it I go back to the Extra Stout and I am always pleased.

A bit richer than the original guiness and also a bit smoother. I love a dark beer and this one fits the bill. 

 ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

12 oz Bottle -- Pours black with a thin soapy light brown head. Aromas of raisin, chocolate, fig, brown sugar, black current, and toast. Not overly sweet, with a long bitter finish. Pretty lively carbonation.

Originally rated on 8/15/08.  (i was a big fan back then) Upon checking my inventory i couldnt belive that i hadnt reviewed this one. I used to be a huge guinness fan until they moved production to canada a few years ago and the quality (to me) dropped off. Anyway this is the only guinness that i still occasionally buy. A dark black body, minimal carbonation with a thin head, Mouthfeel thick and creamy. Flavor of malts and a little chocolate. Good finish, still a top notch brew.

From a bottle. Roasted coffee aroma. Classic dark stout appearance with an off white, well retained frothy head. Taste somewhat similar to regular Guinness with stronger roasted black coffee notes. Medium bodied and more malts in the finish.

Great beer, looks like a beauty queen! A good beer with friends or watching a late night show of got

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Old , good Guinness. Perfect appearance, balanced taste. Coffee , roasted malt , moderate bitterness....
Aroma ok with roast. Great black color. Nice carbonation, but real real water lean. Tang like on aftertaste. Better than most macros but way better stouts out there.
You folks reading this all know what this tastes like. What surprises me is how different this is than the draught. It’s better imo.

Re-rate after a bottle purchased in Birmingham, Alabama.  Original rating 7/15/2015, score 4.1>Pours a very dark brown. Thick pillowy tan head. All kinds of lacing.

Aroma is of dark roast malt. Coffee and chocolate are in there too, like you would expect from a stout. There’s something else too, can’t quite make it out.

Taste is good. A little watery. An excellent balance between hops and malt. It’s bitter, it’s sweet. But it’s not too much either way. It’s almost a head to head matchup between chocolate and coffee and having a draw.

Mouthfeel is medium, not exactly what you expect from a stout. It’s watery. It finishes a little bitter. It’s a little lower in alcohol than I expect from a stout. But still, it’s super drinkable.

Overall, it’s excellent. A very drinkable stout. It’s iconic, but this is made in Canada. I’m a little disappointed. Still, very tasty Certainly worth trying!

Aroma: roasty, chocolate, coffee, 
Appearance: Dark amber/brown, brown head
Taste: roasted malt, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish, 

One of my favorite stouts

Bottle gifted by my cousin (to your health!) poured into a glass mug.
Wish I had a bar next door with Guinness on tap so I could compare to a draught but here goes...Aroma - roasted malt and brown sugar. Ap - dark with a tan head - no surprise here. Taste - 70% roast malt, 10 % hop bitter, 10 % bitter chocolate, 5 % roast malt-cherry, 5% - other? Palate - smooth but also carbonated at the same time. I have a home brew stout aging in the basement and will add an edit to compare it in about another two weeks.
Bottle. Much better than Guinness Stout draft! Medium hoppy aroma with actual discernible carbonation. Balanced hoppy taste. Slightly bitter finish.

12 oz single bottle from Mile High Wine & Spirits. Black appearance with a light brown head and lacing. Aroma of roasted grain, wheat, bitter chocolate. Similar flavor with a mild roast bitterness and a light dry, lingering finish. There is just something off about it.  No thanks.  Pairing: Dropkick Murphys - I’m Shipping Up to Boston

Bottle @ Butcher Block, Sarasota, FL. Dark, rich, chocolaty aroma. Tastes great. A tiny bit too bitter on the palate, but the overall deliciousness negates this. Overall, a tasty & refreshing dark brew. Just disappointed it’s not brewed in Ireland.
A pleasant dry stout. Nothing crazy good, but good none-the-less. Something to drink when there isn’t much better.

Whiffs of chocolate, coffee and some detectable hops. Great espresso bite with some chocolate coming beforehand. Lingering dry finish with espresso and hops closing the door

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a black from a bottle with a thick khaki head. No nose to speak of, perhaps dampened by the pillowy head. Flavor is of mild coffee, maybe a little cherry jam. Dry in the mouth, overall I feel the mouthfeel is where this beer stands out comparatively, other characteristics are kind of meh.
Deep black pour with a frothy, tan head. It has a sugary sweet aroma with mild chocolate. The medium body has smooth texture, sweet taste, and a dry finish.

I don’t know about "Best beer in the world", but definitely a better than average dark beer. A little lighter for a stout, but still medium-heavy in appearance and mouthfeel. Has a good flavor....mainly of chocolate malts, little bit of caramel, and minor hops. Slightly bitter going down. Overall, a quality beer, recommended for anyone who hasn’t tried.

This so far worst stout I have had
alcohol, smoke, medium bitterness, medium sourness, flat, bitter,
Picked up a six-pack for the first time in years because it was on sale on St. Patty’s day. Very little aroma, taste is stale and rather harsh. Improved a bit as it warmed up

Bottle to shaker glass. Pours deep red/black, 2 finger off white head, nice lacing with some retention. Aroma of roasted malt, burnt sugar and coffee. Taste is malty sweet with a slight bitterness going on. Light bodied, moderate carbonation, slightly watery mouth feel. Finishes sweet with tasting notes of roast, salt, caramel, bitter nuts, coffee and dark chocolate. Guinness also seems to have a flavor that is hidden in the recipe that makes it taste like "Guinness". For St. Pat’s day............

Roast coffee and some stale funk aroma. Dark brown color with foamy tan head. Flavors of coffee, cherry, bitter chocolate, roasty and slightly bitter finish. Never can tell how long these bomber bottles have been sitting on the shelf or does INBev ferment in fiberboard drums? In my experience the version they sell in Ireland (and the British Isles) tastes better.

Poured from 12 oz bottle into pint glass. 3 finger tan head slow to go. Lots of lacing. Malty aromas of hay and toast. Taste is lightly sweet with light to medium bitterness.very mild roasty flavor, more grainy. Little bit of a rough finish.

The Beer was ok. Overall not what I expected. Was expecting a more flavorfull version of regular guiness stout. This is more like a less smooth version. Probaly won’t bother buying again.
Pours the part with a nice fluffy cream hued head that leaves a thick lacing coating as this is downed. Light roasted coffee, faint chocolate. Light to medium body.

Bottle from Pig in Lake Geneva. Pours black but without the wonderful swirl of a draft Guinness. Damn, I love that swirl. Nose has some of the usual expected mild stout; taste the same....good but not wonderful....need a draft!

Old rating. Poured into an English tulip pint. Beautiful deep black with ruby highlights and nice creamy beige head. Not much aroma to speak of...only a faint toasted maltiness. Well-balanced with roasted malts and slight hoppy bitterness on the finish.

Well I was pleasantly surprised by this brew; I actually might say I prefer this to the original Guinness draught. Although this doesn't pour with the famous nitrogen-induced cloudy head appearance, still has a solid ruby black hue with plenty of creamy head. Aroma is a little stale and bland, but has some roasty malty notes to it. The taste had a more pronounced earthy hoppiness than the standard Guinness, nice roasty malt balance as well. Smooth and drinkable, pleasant dark chocolate and bitter English hop finish. Not amazingly impressive, but I could drink this as a hearty dinner accompaniment.

Bottle. Black color with thin tan head and substantial lacing. Roasted malt aroma. Bitterness and chocolatey malt up front with some coffee notes. Sweet finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from the bottle into a Guinness Stout glass. Pours dark brown with a nice khaki head. Smells like creamy chocolate and smoke. Tastes like bananas, coffee, and chocolate. Palate creamy and smooth. Overall a really nice stout.

$3 for a bomber, can’t beat that. Like the draft with a bigger mouthfeel and more carbonation. Get the roasted malt and slight hints of chocolate. Very easy drinking, it won’t make you slow down like bigger stouts. Could session these but stouts not a style I session.
This is kind of similar like Draught, but dryer, may be too much. There is chocolate, caramel. Medium body and good carbonation. Not bad, but For me Draught is better.

Bottle.

A- Roasty, mocha, cocoa, malty.

A- Black color, black liquid, brown head.

T- Roasty, cocoa, malty, dry.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, roasty finish

O- Everything about Guinness Draught with extra. It’s not extra good but it’s still better than regular Guinness.

12 oz. bottle from BevMo. Nose of caramel and roasted malt. Taste of bittersweet cocoa, black coffee, roasted malt, toast, dark bread, molasses and earthiness. Fair amount of roasted bitterness on the finish. Good balance of complexity and richness of flavors. Not too heavy. Medium carbonation. Alcohol well hidden with only a slight warming after the finish. Could be smoother but generally a crisp easy drinking stout. Love the 5% ABV.

It's definitely a Guinness beer. I wish it had a widget in the bottle but does not. Still though, a decent dark beer for not a lot of money. I'd buy it again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500 ml can poured at home. Honestly don’t remember where I got it. It’s been in my beer fridge forever. Not my first, nor last time I’ve had a guinness. Pours tan in color and settles to a dark black. Thick creamy head that stays forever. Malty, molasses flavour, that is actually kind of watery (compared to what one would expect by looking at it). It has earned its reputation for a reason.
This beer is a classic. I had the North American one. Heard the original is different and has a better taste. Nice bourbon sweetness taste makes it worthwhile.

12oz bottle in snifter. Dark brown w/ tall foamy head. Aroma of German pumpernickel bread and rye. Not as dry and more bitter than I seem to remember this. Tastes nice and chocolate-y, and is quite quaffable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Look: pours a dark black. Light brown head. 
Smell: apples. Toasted malt. Sweet malt.
Taste: malt. Apples. Smoked malt.
Feel: slightly thin mouth feel for a stout. Very dry. 
Overall: ok beer. Not a lot of flavors jumping out at me. This bottle could be slightly old. 
First drank: home 12/2/14
Bottle, dark pour, tan head, nose is coffee, taste is coffee plus vanilla, plus bitter

Bottle to a pint glass. The beer pours a dark ruby brown with a thick tan head and nice lacing. Aroma is roasted barley, dark chocolate, and grassy hops. Taste is very roasty up front. Flavors of coffee and baking chocolate come in as well as a kind of earthy floral flavor in the background. Mouthfeel is pretty thin and it’s easy to drink. Not a bad session stoug.

A touch of coffee, alcohol, and prunes on the nose. Nice dark pour and a big fluffy brown head. A balanced body. Notes of toasty malt, deep fruit, bright carbonation, a little alcohol. It's really a pretty good beer for how widely produced it is.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz. bottle. It pours a dark brown color with a disappearing light tan head. Looks darker than the Draught. The aroma has some toast, cocoa and some dark fruitiness that I don’t remember getting from the Draught. The flavor is fuller and also more flavorful with bread, roasted malt, a little smoke and tobacco with a decent amount of earthy hop bitterness and cigarette ash in the finish. Hints of acidity and figgy dark fruit. Pretty good stuff actually.
Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is sweet caramel malts. Flavor is a touch of sweet caramel and a little bit of roast. A bit on the light side. Body is a tad light as well. Just okay.

Reviewed On: (5/22/14):


*Glassware: Nonic Pint


*Serving: 22 oz 


*Aroma: roasted malt, burnt bread, hint of dark chocolate, earthy smell


*Appearance: Dark brown with a rocky tan two finger head. The head receded very slowly to one finger. There was lots of lacing left on the glass, like all Guinness leave behind after they are consumed.


*Taste: Roasted malts, hints of dark chocolate, and coffee bitterness. 


*Palate: Medium bodied, creamy and thin mouthfeel, plenty of carbonation, Finishes with a nice dry bitterness.


*Overall: This is a fairly decent beer, that could be sessioned if one desired to. This is my go-to beer when options are very limited. It is more robust and flavorful than the Draught version, but is still thin to be a stout. Not much to complain about. Solid offering as a dry stout.

Bottle. Pours dark black with off-white head. Aroma of malts and corn. Tastes of dark chocolate, a little bit of roasted coffee and malts. Very light bodied for a stout. Easily drinkable. Not my favorite, but makes we wish I were in Ireland.

Poured from the bottle into a Guinness pint glass dark brown with a tan head foamy like a pillow top.
Aroma is weak but gather some roasted malts.
Flavor is dark chocolate coffee thin drinkable in mass amounts when nothing else is available. Bitter finish. Actually decent for me when the mood hits about once a year.

"smooth, but still thinner than i’d like. it’s already been said "and they all have a dry, tea-like taste" exactly! not bad, but way overrated. i just don’t get it. i’ll drink one but hundreds of stouts are better. maybe the foreign extra will convince me..."
Not bad for an commercial Inbev beer....... nice color. Palate is a little watery. Needs to be more bold!

I feel like most of the reviews below were drinking a different beer than I was....
Typical stout pour, although unlike below, the head had completely dissipated within a couple of minutes. Nose is very faint: toasted grain, treacle and (weirdly) sweet fruit. Taste is toasted grain, treacle, with a surprisingly dry finish (hints of bitter coffee). Mouthfeel is weird too. Low carbonation and pretty watery. Overall this tastes like something brewed by Labatt - and I’m not entirely convinced this isn’t their porter, poured into the wrong bottle.
This also somehow manages to be less interesting than the original Guinness in nitro cans, which is saying something.

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, bottled on 4/24/2014. Pours nearly pitch black color with a 2 finger dense and rocky khaki head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Dense soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of chocolate, cocoa, coffee, roasted malt, toast, dark bread, light dark fruit, light char, and roasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/roasted malt notes; with good strength. Taste of chocolate, cocoa, coffee, roasted malt, toast, dark bread, light dark fruit, light char, and roasted earthiness. Fair amount of roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of chocolate, cocoa, coffee, roast, toast, dark bread, light char, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice robustness and complexity of dark/roasted malt flavors; with a great roasted bitterness/sweetness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a smooth, crisp, and lightly creamy/chalky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is a very nice dry stout. All around good complexity and balance of dark/roasted malt flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A very enjoyable offering.
Drank with some birthday stout cupcakes. Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of light toast. Light coffee. Tastes slightly tangy. Medium light body, medium high carb.

What else can I say about Guinness that hasn’t been said. Aroma is faint, toasty beans and some coffee. Nice ebony with creamy head. Chocolate malt and toffee with a nice bitterness on the end. Prefer sweeter stouts... But good.

Transfer from BA review on 9-28-12-
 Poured from bottle into pint glass

 Appearance – Pours a deep-deep brown nearly black color. Upon pouring there is a huge tan head that has quite good persistence. The head fades slowly over time to give a great level of lacing on the sides of the glass.

 Smell – The aroma is heaviest of roasted coffee and some dark chocolate with notes of a lighter caramel and vanilla sweetness. Rather nice.

 Taste – The taste starts out of a good balance between a roasted malt and coffee flavor as well as a lighter caramel sweetness. Some light vanilla comes to the tongue, but overall the sweetness lessens as the taste goes on. Toward the end the roastier flavors begin coming more and more pronounced with the sweet fading more and more. In the end a slightly bitter roasted flavor is left on the tongue. While not bad, the aftertaste is a little too biting and the transitions a little too abrupt/harsh.

 Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is on the average side with the carbonation level quite average as well. For the roastier flavors a thicker and creamier body would have been better. Also while not unpleasant a lighter carbonation would have helped for the darker roastier flavors as well.

 Overall - The beer overall looks and smells great, and initially tastes fantastic. The very bitey aftertaste and the somewhat un-flattering mouthfeel however bring it down. Overall it is not bad, but not fantastic either. If looking for a Guinness I would go for their nitro driven draught as it flavor transitions and feels much better. But this is worth the try.

Reviewed from notes. 
This was poured into a pint glass and a snifter. The lacing just clings longer in the snifter. 
The rest of the appearance was a dark brown close to black color with a one finger white to off white foamy head that dissipated within about a minute. 
The smell was roasty coffee with a light chocolate underneath. 
The taste was roasty and sweet through the chocolate and coffee blend. 
On the palate, this one sat about a medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation was there but stayed slightly in the background. 
Overall, good foreign export stout worthy of having again.
Aroma of roasted malts and grains. A little more toasty than regular Guinness. Nice chocolate and malt flavors. Robust but can’t hold a candle to Russian stouts.

Good, sturdy, reliable beer with full flavors of dark, roasted malts. Long bitter finish and aftertaste.
According to label: "Brewed and bottled by Guinness Brewing Company, New Brunswick, Canada".
Not a big fan of stout. But really good looking bottle and beautiful colour.
Thick head with plenty of lacing. Dark and rich brown color. Smooth mouth feel that hangs at the back of your mouth. Rich molasses taste. This beer is a little too rich for my tastes.
Poured jet black with khaki to white head. Dark roasted coffee and chocolate aroma and taste. One of my favorite widely produced beers.
A mallty flavor with choclately coffee overtones. Small head and ok retention. Flavor is decent at best, a bit watery but redeems itself with dark malts and coffee.

It has a very dark brown color that appears black and very opaque. Its head is thick and foamy with a tan color that leaves behind light tan lace on the glass. The aroma has dark roasted malt grains with a light hint of some nice aromatic and grassy hops. There is a full robust roasted grain flavor with a hint of brunt sweetness that quickly turns dry with some grassy and floral hops at add a perfect balance of bitterness to stand up to the malty goodness. On the palate it is starts of smooth then turns very dry and crisp inside of a very drinkable medium body with a nice bitter fading finish. It’s much fuller in flavor and body than its nitro injected Cousin Guinness Draft.
Poured dark, bitter aroma. Taste bitter, licorice, and malt. Little complexity, small hint of chocolate.
Pour from a 22oz. Pitch black with tan head. Not a big aroma, bit of roasted malt. Taste is burnt malt and licorice with a dry, bitter finish.

Poured from a 6 pack bottle. Not really a stout. Not sure how they define it, however. Big thick, foamy light brown head. Smells breast and yeasty. Tastes of light caramel and a bit of nuts. Very light taste.

Mine was on nitro when rated. Pours a very dark brown/black with a super thick creamy head. Aroma is chocolate caramel malt with dark fruit notes and Vanilla with cocoa. Taste follows the Aroma perfect with a ultra smoothness to it. Awesome brew!!

Trying this again...man I loved this beer. Best on tap. Dry toasted malt . Zero complexity. If you like this I suggest homebrewing this ale. You will be amazed.

Rich chocolate, coffee and nutty aroma. Dark and thick appearance with foam lingering on the rim. Dark chocolate sweet taste that is thick and full bodied. Overall a good Irish beer to drink on more occasions than just St. Patrick’s Day.

Poured from a 12oz bottle. 
Aroma has a muted roast character with some light coffee and faint chocolate notes. Medium light dark fruit esters with faint banana and tropical fruit. 
Pours a clear, dark brown with some lighter brown highlights and a medium thick, moderately sized tan head that recedes to the edges where it lingers. 
Flavor has a faint sweetness with moderate roast and coffee notes and light chocolate character. Mid to late palate you pick up some fruit notes of berry, cherry and prune with faint hints of banana and tropical fruit. Finish has a lingering roast note. Medium light bitterness. 
Mouthfeel is medium light bodied with medium carbonation. Low, but present astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall a pretty unimpressive stout with a surprisingly large ester quality. Nice roast notes along with light chocolate, but not as Bright as they could be. Good mouthfeel with slight stickiness.
Pretty much a reliable standby when in the mood for a stout and your options are limited.

Bottle. Bought six pack for $5.99 for St. Patrick’s Day. Ten years ago when I first had this beer I thought it was great. Now, I feel that it is far below par as far as stouts are concerned. Brown hue, manila head. Beads of lace here and there. 



Smells oxidized and generically malty. Tastes of slightly aged hops, mild astringency, and zero roasted malt character delivered by a thin body. Wtf? 



Hard to be disappointed when coming in with low expectations, but here we are. This gives "dark beer" everywhere a bad name. Please stop producing it.

Nice black color with a thick creamy head. Smell is bitter/coffe/chocolate. Taste is coffe, but smooth in the mouth and bitter at the end.

Bottle. Light molasses, chocolate, and barley malt aroma. Black brown with a large tan head. Burnt barley malt, dark fruit, and a long roasty bitter finish. Light body, lively carbonation.

Bottle: Deep brown color, ruby highlights with a khaki head that isn’t nearly as impressive as Guinness on nitro. Very faint aroma; roasted barley & malts, grains, tin, a little bit of dark fruitiness, mostly red grape. Taste is a little more heavy... Roasted, charred malt & barley, toasted grains, positive alcohol presence with more red grape, almost in a wine-like manner. Finish with a hint of bitter coffee & mild ash. Booziness quite apparent for only 6% ABV. Not bad, but honestly I’d take the US Draught over this... Easier to drink & I like the dryness of it. I don’t love the vinous dark fruit I pull from this one.

This beer pours out thin and black but if held to the light you can see a dark brown hue. A fat loose head of tan foam that fell slowly to a film, then a small ring and left lace that was not permanent. Nose is malty and grassy. Sweet malt , light toast, light caramel and grassy hops. Then some dark fruits evolve. Prune and a bit of something grapey and quite sweet. Taste follows the nose all the way except the first thing to greet your palate is metallic. The malt is a bit awkward and husky but you begining to enjoy it as robust as you drink. The dark fruits are light and at first the prune is sour but that gives way to this grapey sweetness. Mouthfeel is light and has a nice dryness to the mid palate. Finishes a touch bitter and with that grass over top of a light caramel. 



For a stout this was crisp and mild. With a bit of hop presence this is an easy drinking stout that gives some light buttered toast and a touch of caramel to a bit of dark fruits and finishes a bit tame but altogether pleasant.

This is an intense stout, with strong hops and a medium body. The malt is understated while the hops are overstated. A nice head and a very dark color, this is better than the Guinness draught, but still not great.
Nice dark, almost black, appearance, big frothy head with terrific lacing. Subtle aroma, nice caramel taste with a slight bitterness.
Pours black with little head. Smells and tastes of malts, a little coffee, and a little bready. It's very smooth, light, and easy to drink. Good, solid stout.

Poured a big thick head which was a brown/white color, went away pretty quick but left a real nice lacing behind. Nice deep black color. Very malty smelling, with hints of toast, coffee and chocolate. has a roasted taste with a nice bitter bite. On the finish you get a little sweet chocolaty flavor. This is a very, very good beer. Definitely have a Guinness Extra Stout, this beer is up there with some of the craft beers I pay $6-$10 a pint for.

Toasty malty aroma, some coffee aroma in there. Taste of roasted malt, maybe slight coffe and a bit of an odd lager like finish (foot funk?). Enjoyable stout overall but prefer guinness draught.

A classic Irish Dry Stout. It’s smooth, dark, and, of course, pretty damn dry. Coffee flavor is prominent in this brew but there are also some rich, bittersweet barley notes. The creamy mouthfeel is excellent, too. It’s not so very different from other stouts but that distinctive strength and balanced sweetness is what makes it stand out. A classier alternative to Guinness Draught.

500ml large bottle into a Guinness glass; served cold.

Aroma: Really mild. I only pick up a bit of malt, and some corny adjunct.

Appearance: Completely opaque, black-brown body with a full, creamy, tan head.

Taste: Not as roasty as Guinness Draught. Pretty smooth, mildly sweet, but no big chocolate or coffee notes. It tastes like it tastes. Malty and dark, and kind of creamy.

Palate: Full bodied, creamy. Moderate finish and ends on a mildly sweet, caramel flavor.

Overall: Kind of strange. Good though. Nice stuff. I liked it. I wonder what the legit brew is like; I wonder if it really is better over there. Decent enough stout, nothing that will blow you away.

(3/18/13) Pour - Pours black brown with a rocky finger of khaki head. Not as creamy looking at Guinness Draught.

Nose - Surprisingly sweet. Sweet malts, dark fruit notes, and floral hops. Reminded a bit of a barleywine or a Belgian ale honestly. Quite shocked by the nose on this.

Taste - Earthly mild roastiness up front, along with a hint of those dark fruit notes. Earthly malt dryness and bitterness on the finish. Quite earthly all around.

Mouthfeel - Medium to full body and chewy. Good ole meal in a glass.

Overall - Picked this up for St. Pats. I first and last had this about 7 years ago when I started drinking Guinness and a friend bought me Extra Stout instead Draught. I couldn’t stomach the Extra Stout, but now I enjoyed it a lot. I don’t know why this doesn’t get more love (probably because people consider it a macro). Guinness has been brewing this for a long time and it’s a damn fine product. I definitely enjoy this more than Guinness Draught.

Not going to write too extensively. This is a decent beer. One of the first stouts I ever had. Now a lot of stouts and porters I drink are heavier, fuller bodied. This is still a pretty smooth, easy drinking stout, where you can enjoy multiple in a sitting.

Taste is big roast malt, slight earthy hop bitterness, toffee, and the slightest hint of dark chocolate and coffee. Roast malt dominates throughout. Medium body, low carbonation, dry finish. Overall good, wouldn?t seek it out, but worth drinking in the Ides of march.
Pours black with a creamy tan color head. Smell is malty with some chocolate. Chocolate malt taste with some bitterness. Full body with a dry bitter finish. Decent.
I feel like you can tell that this one goes through a weird brewing process with the wort being added to the other base in Canada - and you can tell.

Pours black with a tight khaki head. Aromas of coffee, toffee, nuts, touch of cocoa. A bitter chocolate maltiness on the tongue at first then some lager type adjuncts coming through followed by a coffee type flavor on the finish. Not bad , a heartier flavor than Draught, not as creamy but not as dry either.
A pour, bitter imitation of Guiness draught. Lacking all of the charm, character, and creaminess of usual Guinness, just to up the alcohol content.
Deep mahogany. Small creamy tan head, lots of lace. Aroma is roasty; roasted malt, carmel, a bit of chocolate. Medium body. Roasted malt, caramel, some hops and mild bitterness.
Pours black with a creamy tan head with good retention and lacing.  Aromas of roasted nuts, chocolate and a touch of spice.

Pitch black pour with creamy khaki head with decent lacing. Milk chocolate aroma. Nutty. Roasty. Coffee. Relatively light mouthfeel. Nutty, coffee, milk chocolate. Slightly dry finish.

From bottle. A lighter tasting Guinness than I’m used to. Paler in taste, but chocolate flavor is a little more forward.

Assez noire, avec reflets cola à la lumière. Opacité quasi-totale. Peu de mousse ou d’effervescence. Au nez, quelques céréales, mais certainement pas de malt grillé. Du sucre doucereux, du houblon, du bois et même du beurre. Au goût, du houblon, et au lointain, du café. Pétillante comme une blonde, avec une amertume pesante. Aqueuse. Good stout. A little sweeter than expected and not bad mouthfeel. However still dry and bitter

Solid dry Irish stout.  Not a huge fan of the style, but this is good. This is better than the draught, but the Extra Import blows this away.

Smell of a lager with a malty scent. Colour is darker than the former Penn St coaching staff. Had it a while ago and remembered it being a little better, More disappointed this time around. Slight coffee taste with a carbonated Guinness draught finish

It’s a funny beer, sometimes (from the tap) it seems like one of humanity’s greatest creations and other times (from the bottle) it comes off as wildly overrated, tasteless black water. Between the different breweries and different methods of delivery, you just never know. Ranges from a 3.0 to a 4.0 for me, roughly.

Noire foncée avec des reflets orangés. Ça sent l’eau! En bouche, c’est acide et amer en même temps. Sirop de café froid en finale. En arrière-goût, une amertume maladroite vient fermer la danse sans envergure. On cherche autre chose... mais rien. Arthur Guinness n’aurait jamais dû vendre son nom pour un produit qui n’est simplement pas à la hauteur de sa réputation.

I wish I could get the stout brewed in Ireland so that I could compare it to the Canadian brewed version. Anyway, one has to give thanks that it is available. A benchmark stout. Much better than the nitrogen infused version. (Am I the only one that thinks that the nitrogen infused version exists merely so that barkeeps can draw fancy shamrocks on the head?)
This is a nice product by Guinness that has an extra bite. Not creamy and smooth like draught, no, this one is harsh and strong. Very enjoyable.

We had this beer at the 2013 Tops of the Hops in Biloxi, MS. It was like a punch in the face. Take Guinness, one of the heaviest beers out there that needs a widget to stir up the sludge at the bottom of the bottle, and make it heavier. Rob made a face like a baby tasting sour milk. But I liked it, probably for the novelty more than anything.

Aromas of dark chocolate, caramel, coffee, vanilla beans, toffee, and hazelnut.  Appearance is almost black,  with khaki head foam of moderate retention.  Very light sweetness with a refreshing bitter balance right away.  Medium-full bodied, with good carbonation, and a roasty, quick finish.

No. Appearances are deceiving. Nice black pour witha mocha head. Faint aroma of chocolate and coffee which barely come through in the taste. The bitterness would not be bad if something else balanved this out. I wrote this in a blind tasting with 4 other stouts. This was the only one I so not intend to purchase again.
Bottle. Decent. Not sure I could tell the difference in a blind taste test but this seems to be a less watery version of the stout. Good roast and sweet caramel characteristics.

There are too many variations of this same damn beer...

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with very little head. Nose is dry and a little hoppy, but not overpowering. Taste isn’t all that strong, actually. Rather dry and a tad bitter. OK, but not great.

Pours a viscous black-dark brown.  When held to the light, traces of ruby red can be seen on the outline, but the beer is quite opaque.  A tall, beige pillowy head dissipates eventually, leaving a fair amount of lacing.  Aroma is rather musty, driven by wet grains.  Taste is much better, however, and far more complex. Flavors of coffee, toasted malts, and slight stone fruits give the beer a sour-sweet quality, which gives way to a slightly bitter finish.  As the beer warms, the malts assert themselves more and the other flavors give way.  Alcohol is faint, but noticeable.  Mouthfeel is thicker than water, but not by much.  In sum, this is the beer by which all Irish dry stouts should be judged.  That’s not to say it’s the best--a (select) few may be better--but this is the standard IMO, the exemplar of the style.  Plain (nitro) Guinness is too weak, too watery  for me, and Extra Foreign Stout too strong, too hoppy.  But this is just right.

Reviewed 11/04/2012. 22 oz bottle (brewed in Canuckistan by Moosehead) poured into a pint glass.

A: Pours a very dark brown color with great opacity. The head is a frothy three finger mocha color with decent texturing and excellent retention. There’s quite a bit of lacing left down the glass.

S: There isn’t much to write home about here. There’s some chocolate, unrefined roasted barley, sweet fruit esters, and even a little bit of adjunct grains. Meh.

T: Thankfully, the taste improves upon the aroma. Tart red fruit esters are the first flavor noted on the tongue, while it gradually gives way to roasted astringency. Slightly charred on the finish and less sweet than Guinness Draught. Only subtle hints of grainy adjuncts really detract from the general experience.

M: Light and bone dry. It doesn’t have the watery sensation the ’other’ Guinness has, but it does feature insane drinkability. Carbonation is moderate to slightly high.

O: It’s a great fallback beer, but it wouldn’t be my first choice in other situations. Good stuff regardless, though.

Dark brown pour, tan head. Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate. Very dry, no sweetness. 
I’ve always found Guinness unpleasant.

Got this with the company beer exchange.  

This was a great beer.  I am a seasoned Guinness drinker and did not expect much from this version.  Pours the same as a Guinness but the flavor is much more complex and has some great dark roasted malt and chocolate characteristics.  Full bodied but not too heavy, could easily drink a few in a session.  Would most definitely drink again!

The beer pours black with a frothy off-white, nearly tan head that sticks around throughout the entire beer. The smell of this beer is toasty and bready malts with a dough scented yeast emerging. The body of the beer is quite full with a flatish carbonation, but the finish is quite long and bitter. Despite the weight of the beer in your mouth and stomach, it is quite sippable.
Bomber.  Deep brown with thick head.  Aroma has roasted malt,hints of chocolate and dark fruit.  Tastes of coffee, chocolate, malt.  Slight metallic aftertaste.  Draught is much better.

Thin, watery and much like cold dilute instant coffee, I wa amazed to still find this being brewed in Ontario. Smae old atypical taste which actually makes the bottled Irish version seem pretty robust and dense. Imagine that.

Pint ay Doherty’s Irish Pub in Cary. Ok aroma, sweet. Roasty. Little chocolate, kind of has a tobacco scent and the bar is non smoking. Blackish brown good head, spotty lace. Sweet flavor. Light body, creamy smooth mouthfeel, dry finish. It’s Guinness. If you don’t know it, I don’t know why you’d read this, ha ha. Fine low abv beer, just had to get my Irish on, except it made in Canada, but I digress....had to edit, clumsy fingers on phone...

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle thanks to weihenheizen. Pours a rather dark ruby/brown with a large, dense, khaki colored foam. Nice looking, thick lacing.  This is a great looking beer. The aroma has notes of mocha, raisins, and coffee, all of which are pretty light nuances. The taste has some roasty bitterness, a touch of ginger, dry nutty notes, and a sweetness I can’t quite lay a finger on. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel. This beer isn’t as bad as I anticipated it would be, but it still isn’t something I would pursue having again.
Not particularly different from the "continental version" of this beer, but still really good.  Chocolate, coffee, and bread with a watery mouthfeel.

This is a solid beer and the first "real" beer many college kids venture into when they want to try something different.  Many of them consequently run back into the arms of a near-frozen Bud, but others branch out to try new things.  In college this was the pitch black grower of chest hair that only strongmen could stomach.  Now it seems fairly tame, with a simple dark coffee flavor that finishes fairly smooth.  This is a must-drink gateway beer before trying more complex dark beers.

Pours a nice dark brown with a creamy head. Semi-sweet, slightly roasted scent. Toasted malt flavor with some caramel and nut overtones. Nice hoppy finish as it goes down. Creamy in the mouth and very smooth.

This was the first stout I’ve ever had, and it’s been about a year since I’ve had one. Pours an opaque black with a one-finger khaki head. Aroma is toasted malts--subtle but distinctly Guinness. Taste is faint--but mostly bitter roasted malts and hops. Taste is most similar to a black coffee. This is the public face of the dry Irish stout, but honestly there isn’t much taste or character here to speak of. Still, this is an obligatory must-try stout.
Had this in Augusta at the holiday inn. Not a bad stout but definitely tastes a little main stream
Pours dark, very nice creamy head. Dark and malty as a stout should be, goes down extra smooth.  Simple, but this will always be a classic in the style.
Poured from a 12 oz bottle at a tasting. Pours dark with a tan head. Malty aroma. Fruity with a long lingering bitter finish.

I wish my last rating wasnt deleted. Delicious dark beer with vanilla & coffee flavors.

Poured into English pint glass. Poured a dark deep brown with a thick pillow top head. Nose of malts with just a hint of chocolate. A hearty beer that tastes of malts and chocolate. Always enjoy a Guinness.

This pours a dark brown/black color with a slight light brown head. The scent is of roasted malts, cocoa, and caramel malts. The taste is rich and bold. There is a heavy complex taste but has an awkward chalky finish. This is a decent stout that can be found and tried pretty much anywhere in the world. This one of my all time favorite beers! Just a classic, always well balance and damn smooth! The beer of big players:)!

This is one of my favorite stouts. It’s very roasty, but doesn’t have the burnt astringent flavor found in a lot of stouts. Its very full flavored and does not have that thin, watery mouth feel that I find in a lot of stouts. This is really well balanced.

Really good.. if you like strong and bitter stout this is the one for you... and not expensive

I had this in a 12 oz. bottle and blown away I never rated this version. Black in color with beige head, having spider web lacing. Chalky roasted malts, bland coffee, some light hops. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic and has a subtle bitterness to round off the roast. The only down fall is the thin body. But something you could offer somebody who has never drank any stout.

12oz bottle, great appearance, good color, lacing, head is an irregular frisbee loogie.  Light aroma, loses a few points there, but makes up for it in taste, complex, enjoyable.  Classic.

Great all-purpose stout. A good introduction to stouts. If you like this commercial stout try delving into some of the more exclusive stouts. Shipyard bluefin, belhaven Scottish stout, imperial stouts, murphys, etc.. great beer though, deffinately a classic and a daily go-to beer with dinner.
This is the beer that first stole me away from lagers. Bless you, Guinness, my thick, dark, frothy love.

Not as rich I would like it but well creamy. A lil toastedness to the bite like a pleasant burnt coffee taste. Nice head. surprisingly watery mouthfeel but thick when swirled. Nice chocolaty nuttiness.

Strong tempting aroma and black semi-thin pour but with a basic taste and simple mouthfeel.

Dark brown, chocolate/coffee color, aroma, & flavor.  One of my long-time favorites!  Medium head.  Good balance of sweet & bitter.  Chocolate, coffee, malty notes.  Slight bitter aftertaste.

Super fun beer. I hope to taste it all over the world someday. The nitrogen cascade is one of my favorite sights reminding me to just relax and enjoy the beer.

Excelente sabor maltoso, color oscuro y aroma inigualable. Su único punto en cotra es la baja concentración de alcohol
This is a slight improvement on an old standard at pubs everywhere. It is a bit more bitter than not but still very satisfying. Very rich taste. If you like dark, you can’t fail with this.

Bottle.Pours opaque black with a small head that dissipates fast with no lacing. Aroma is surprisingly lacking in body given color - mostly sweet grains like a pale lager. Taste is sweet grain/straw with a mildly bitter finish. Lacking in body and character. I with Guinness would withdraw the brewing license for this stuff.

I love the malty, chocolate goodness upfront.  It starts slightly creamy and smooth and leaves a hint of cocoa lingering on the tongue.  Immensely popular but for good reason.  A solid brew!

This is the second Guiness I’ve rated. The first is the Malaysian variety and this one is much better. It’s my sister’s favourite beer, in fact, and though she’s not into craft beer that much she does have standards. It’s nice to see a good quality macro on the Canadian market. So what if it’s brewed by InBev, Belgians know their beer, amirite? I’m in love with the mouthfeel of this beer, and I think it perfectly matches the level of the roast, which is not astringent to me. Smells of coffee and chocolate, but that’s to be expected.
pours thin and opaque. Smells timidly malty. Relatively light mouthfeel as expected of the style. A suggestion of smoky malt with fain hopes.  Oaked, roasted flavors.  Medium body, soft.
A gas station run...and this was the best bet. The familiar taste and aroma...roasty and bitter. I prefer the creaminess of the draught,  but this is fine in a pinch.
Brown black pour with tan head and lace. Aroma is flat roasted malt and a hinto coffee. Flavor is dry roasted malt with a hinto cough syrup, coffee, and a bitter malt finish. Medium bodied and fizzy.

Bottle from your Dekalb farmers market. pours thin and opaque. Smells timidly malty. Tastes... pretty much how I remember Guinness tasting, although its been a while. Relatively light mouthfeel as expected of the style. A suggestion of smoky malt, then some halfway respectable hop bitterness intermingled with more residual malt. Overall, seems like a slightly beefier   version of the original. I don’t often drink Irish dry stouts, but if I do, this one’s as good as any I guess.

Bottle. Extremely dark pour with a monster of a head - I actually spooned off about 3 inches of head just to get the rest of the bottle into the glass without waiting a half-hour. Nose is roasty with a hint of chocolate. Taste is roasty and decidedly dry with a touch of bitter. Palate is moderate at best.

The first stout I fell for as a kid. Now it barely stimulates my senses. This commercial stout saddens me as if my teenage taste buds were lying. As it warms the classic sweet and earthy Stout smell comes alive. Poured in a pint glass from a 1Pt 6Oz bottle. There was a 1.5 inch airy and quickly fading tan head with consistent lacing. The color was almost a completely opaque Dark Brown. Unfortunately as it warms the warm sugar/starchy taste fades and becomes more bitter. The palate fades from frothy and pleasant to watery with a light bitter bite. A seemingly well balanced commercial stout that with the exception of the aroma falls apart as it warms.
It pours a dark chocolate tone. head is thin a beige. It has a roasted coffee smell with a hint of hops. Not my favorite beer flavor. Too pricey for what I get. Definitely not my preference.

Pale copper brown pour with 1-2 fingers of head fighting to stick to the lip of the glass. Nose is estery with a light sweetness and banana gum quality and hints of soft bread.  Very nutty quality in the flavor with some isoamyl acetate and flat bready character.

341 ml bottle. Pours a reddish black with a thick, persistent, beige head. Smells like chocolate and hazelnut. Tastes like dark chocolate, coffee, sweet milk and hazelnut. Slight metallic aftertaste with coffee bitterness in the finish. Body is watery, with a creamy texture thanks to the huge head. Very good, comparable to canned draught (but not real draft).

Drunk..... Drinking crown earlier cant give a great rating due to drunk boooo good from what I notice.

Comparing American beer to European beer is like comparing European chocolate to American chocolate. America wins beer and Europe wins chocolate. In my book, anyway. At any rate, this Canadian version of "Guinness" is just an okay stout. Tastes a bit sour and weak to me. Too much yeast and bread and not enough nutty and bitter. Still a good choice for ending a hot day, but for a full bodied stout I expect more. Before I really got into craft beer I used to drink it and love it. Times change, and tastes change with it.
From the bottle. Dark malts and some dryness with a slight bitterness. Leaves some residual sweetness.
Pours black.  It’s sharper and a bit harsher than the real deal, but nice thick palate and drinkable.
Rating mostly on memory.  Very dark pour, not unlike regular Guinness - though without the nitro that I’m used to.  I found this one a bit more distinctive and complex than the original Guinness.
Reliable.  A good beer to have when you want something you can damn well taste, but don’t particularly want to think about it.

Dark brown, nearly black, with a tan head that forms with a waterfall of bubbles. The aroma is smokey, earthy with sweet tobacco, chocolate and coffee. The taste is medium sweet and medium/heavy bitter. The sweetness tastes a bit artificial which subtracts from the experience but the bitterness has a nice roasty and smokiness. On the palate it is medium bodied, feels a bit thin with average to soft carbonation.

Well I liked it better than the usual draft stout.  i liked the bit and carbonation and though there was a hint of smoke it did not dominate.  Not really hoppy, just bitter and clean finish.  My wife likes the traditional.
People keep buying this for me...why?  Aroma is all malt.  Taste is better than you think.  Give it a chance.  Its almost Guinness.  Palate is the best characteristic.
If I want a Canadian Beer, I’ll drink one and not a faux Irish beer made in New Brunswick.

had this at a party. Rated via mobile

S - Guinness smell but with extra bitterness, extra malt bites and extra maltiness all around



T - Intense for a stout. Not well balanced but very strong on the entire tongue



M - Dry and roasted malts really make this beer linger for a while almost against your wishes



O - Drinkable abut I wouldn’t recommend it.

341ml bottle. Pours black with a moderate tan head. Taste and aroma are mostly big roasty malts, but there is a slight tangy note to it that seems a little weird. Body is less creamy, but also less watery than a regular Guinness so it is a slight improvement. Overall, a decent macro stout.
Pours opaque pitch-black with dark, mahogany highlights. Aroma of dark roasted malt. Taste is robust malt with some bitter coffee and chocolate flavors.
Smell is coffee, malt, hops.  Taste follows odors, finishes dry and bitter with a lingering acidic malt dryness.   Interesting take on your typical guinness stout.

Poured from the bottle. Aroma is malty, and roasty. Flavour has light coffee and smokey flavours. This is quite bitter for a stout, but its nice. Palate is very dry and finishes sticky and oily not a as watery as the nitro version.

Black with a creamy head. Aroma is roated malt and coffee. Flavor is more bitter than most stouts I’m used to, and has an annoying medicinal aftertaste. Smooth finish. Overall, this is not a bad ale, and will do in a pinch.
Black pour with a nice head.  Smoky chocolate aroma.  Dry, bitter taste.  More hops than I would suspect.  When one thinks stout, you usually think of this.  This is the standard.
Bottle:  I am not a huge fan of dry stouts, but this is a very good one for that style.  Very easy to find also, which is good.

Coffee like aroma with slight toffee, chocolate and roasted nuts. Appearance is a very dark shade of brown with small foam. Taste is Roasted caramel, coffee and nuts. Not very thick as stouts tend to be. Pretty full flavor with a lot of roastiness and slightly smokey. Overall, a pretty tastey stout with good flavor. I’d give this a B rating
Bottle 12 oz, Florio’s Ristorante, Little Italy NYC. Black beer with a medium brown head. Aroma of toasted and lightly roasted malt with notes of smoke. The taste is sweet and slightly bitter malt.
Has a black color. Smell is of roasted malts. Taste is also malty, some coffee notes. Overall a pretty good beer.

12 oz bottle pours black with a tan head.  Aroma is of the roasted malt.  Taste is of coffee and the malts.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From notes.  First reviewed 1/25/2011.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pint glass. Part of a side by side with Guinness Draught and Foreign Extra Stout.

Extra Stout pours a mahogany color with a slightly transparent ruby tint and edges of walnut brown. A rocky tan head bubbles up considerably and takes a while to subside.

Roasted malt, raisins, chocolate sweetness, and molasses are all present in the nose. Maybe a hint of spice and light bitterness from a nuanced hop presence.

The flavor matches up with the aroma. The start is sweet molasses, heavily roasted or burnt malt, chocolate, and raisins. Light coffee leads to a lightly spiced hops. It finishes with some sweetness that ties the flavor together nicely.

This feel actually has some body to it. After drinking the Draught, though, maybe anything would feel thick and bold. The body is medium to full, with medium carbonation and a somewhat creamy feel, but with some carbonation that pops as well. Much different and more natural feeling than the Draught.

This is the Guinness I like and can really enjoy.
I am knew to dark beers but I thought this was an okay beer. I am a big fan of Guinness but the extra stout was a little more bitter than I had hoped. The color, aroma, and appearance is great.
12oz bottle: Appearance is pitch black with tan head. Aroma is of burnt malt. Taste is slightly sour along with some roasted malt. Pretty basic stout but not too shabby.

Poured into a snifter. I hate regular Guinness with a passion for its lifeless, black water taste. I’ve heard countless times how this is a real beer. We shall see.

3.5 A: Black color. Little over one finger of frothy tan head. Retention is about average and a decent amount of lacing is left.

2.0 S: Smells like a super old pot of coffee, like oxidized/acrid coffee. Chocolate underneath and a mild roast. While the regular smells like nothing, this smells strange and uninviting.

2.0 T: This has the same taste that a horrid brewpub in Baltimore had in all their beers. It’s like a soggy piece of bread or at least something of that nature. Mild roastiness. Even less chocolate. Old coffee.

2.0 M: Just lighter than a medium body. Carbonation is a bit too high. No creaminess.

2.0 D: This is a subpar beer for sure, but at least it has some taste (not necessary a good taste) unlike the regular.

Serving type: bottle
