Pours dark brown/black with a tan head.  Smells of bread or dough.  Taste is malty sweet, hint of coffee.  Much lighter than normal Guinness.

12oz bottle poured into an English Pint. Pours dark with about 2 fingers of dark tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and grass. Taste is about the same. Overall, not bad. I think I dig this more than regular Guinness Draught.
Good head and great lace, pretty fresh but not as pretty as the face of the girl who served it to me.  What can I say, it’s Guinness, but she’s so pretty I’m certainly going to have another!
Pours black with brown head... Has a coffe semi bitter chocolate type taste..very filling and satisfying

Pours a dark brown almost black with nice brownish head. Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate and some hops. Taste has alot of the burnt malts and chocolate with a small amount of bitterness. Very sticky on the tongue but nothing terrible. Not a bad brew at all, just not a brew separating itself from the style.

Not at all like its Draught cousin, but still very good.  Slightly pointed taste and finish, dark like a stout should be, but the head was weak.  Strong but very smooth aroma, floral mixed with a bit of malt; taste is more on malt.  Pleasant, woody aftertaste.

12oz bottle.  Surprised to see I had never rated this one.  Ruby black, some light shines through the corners.  Thinnish, patchy beige head.  Dry, bittersweet chocolate aroma, some mild dark fruit.  Roasty burnt chocolate tones.  Some sugary Caribbean style lactic oatmeal tones.  Faint pungency.  I suspect the bottle is a little old, or the recipe and process are different.  I remember really enjoying this beer 10 years ago, but I’m not so impressed with the current adaption

341ml bottle pours almost black on color with a finger of geige head that retains well and leaves some spotted lacing on the glass.  Aroma is roasted malts with hints of coffee.  Taste is roasted malt bitterness with some chocolate malt sweetness and hints of coffee, while any hops are quite subdued.  Body is a little thin for the style and carbonation is nice.  Overall, quite a nice ale.
Pours black with a great looking khaki head and tons lacing. Aroma was malt and a hint of coffee. Taste is bitter coffee, bread and malt. Lively on the palate but thin.
In my most objective opinion, this is the bench mark of all Stoudts, but then , you knew that. It looks great, taste great, smells great, yada-yada- yada. What cqn I say?
Pour from a 22 oz bottle. Dark brew iwth tan head. Aroma of raosted grain, grass. Taste is modest roasted grain with a nice dry finish. Average palate. Nice brew.
My favorite stout!  Readily available and more fun than Guinness Draught!  Just a great stout to kick  back and enjoy.  A Whoopie Goldberg in every bottle!  Yummy!

Rocky, fizzy, tan head of approx 2 fingers. Aroma was light malt which matched the palate. Overall, I was slightly disappointed with this beer. It is supposed to be an extra stout, but comes across as a normal stout. Nothing special or different here. Overall it was good, but forgettable.

Bottle. Pours black with lacing and a whitish head.  Smells of roasted malt and barley.  Some coffee notes.. but minimal.  Taste is peppy.. kind of dances on the tongue.. but the tastes is lightly bitter.. and lightly sweet.  This is solid..

12 oz. bottle.
Creamy, smooth
Medium to heavy slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, & vanilla. Flavor of roasted malt, hops, caramel, and some chocolate.
This is nicely done.

Bottle  Pours a gorgeous black with the classic Guinness "cascade" effect, producing a thick creamy head.  Aroma is smooth and roasty; really nice.  The taste is... not as good as I remember it.  Some smooth malts, roasted malts, but overall a bit watery.  Palate is very nice; one of the thickest creamiest beer I’ve had.  If only the taste were less watery...
I love guinness, but I actually don’t like the extra stout. Not sure why, but it has a very funky flavor to me. Tastes almost like... chicken liver.

Color is black and the head is short.  From a bottle so I did not know what to expect.  Caramel and roasted aroma.  Flavor is bitter with some sweetness at the end.  Finish is slick with a bitter aftertaste.  Nice overall.

Bottle. Pours black with medium tan head. Aroma of caramel, milk chocolate, marchmallow. Taste is mild sweet, finish is medium bitterness. Full body, long bitter finish. Probably the worst Guiness I’ve ever had.

On ne peut s’empêcher de comparer à la Guinness Draught.  une odeur de torréfaction qui se dissipe très vite.  Elle ne verse pas aussi bien que la Guinness Draught.  En bouche elle  n’est pas aussi soyeuse que la Draught (qui descend comme du lait!) et il y a plus de CO2.  Par contre le goût de torréfaction est un peu plus prononcé (on est loin d’une imperial, ceci dit).  Pas villain mais je préfère la Draught.
Aroma is a sweet chocolate malt. Taste is some toasty chocolate malts, but with some alcohol in the background. Overall not bad, but I hoped for better.

Una buena stout,olor suave a caramelo,al paladar un sabor a caramelo y malta tostada tipico de una stout y bastante suave al paladar, el contenido alchoolico es muy bajo para impresionarme pero me encanta para tomarme varias. Recomendada  si les gusta el aroma de una stout y no quieren alto grado de alchool.

341 ml bottle from The Beer Store.  Pours a dark reddish brown with decent-sized tan head.  Aroma is roasty, slightly stale grains and a little dark fruit.  Flavour is roasty malt, stale grains and some fruitiness with some metallic/chemically notes.  One of the thinner stouts I’ve ever had.  The cheap Labatt pale ale base comes through in spades and makes this a pretty underwhelming beer.
I love this beer.  It is smooth and available about everywhere.  It has a great head, good color, and nice aroma.

Tasted from bottle into standard pint glass. Poured a very dark brown, almost black color with chill haze and vigorous beige head, somewhat lasting with lace. Did a very slow "pub pour" because it was so foamy. Aromas of malt, bread, roasted grains, no late hops, some fruity phenols. Complex flavors of brown bread, toast, coffee and chocolate, caramelized brown sugar, raisins, plums and wild cherries. Medium body and well-rounded, "chewy" mouthfeel. Lasting, fruity aftertaste which finishes quite dry. A good roasty dry stout.

My rating will mostly reflect the differences between the Canadian Guinness vs. the Irish extra stout... first and foremost the flavor seemed not as bold... more watered down.  Also lacking in complexity... missing that sourness that the real stuff is well know for.  Just not the same beer... I almost boycotted Guinness because of this beer... the Canadian water must have really hurt it, because it is not the same beer.  Not bad, but not really Guinness.

341ml bottle from the Beer Store. Pours dark brown with a thin tan head. aroma of burnt malt and cheap macro-brew pale ale. decent lacing and moderately lasting head. hint of chocolate. slightly bitter flavour. low carbonation. Watery. cheap coffe tastes, roasted and unsatisfying finish. body is thin. Disappointing beer.

Pours dark black with a thick tan head. Very nice looking beer. Aroma is Roasted malts, chocolate. TTaste is Roastyness, slight chocolate, marshmallow, alcohol, bit of a piney hop bite. Fisnishes clean even with all the flavor. Very well balanced easy to drink stout. One of my old favorites before I tried alot of better stouts, still holds up great.
Pours black with little beige head.  Aroma is sweet malt.  Taste is dark roasted malts with some sweetness on the finish.  Mouth feel is very cola-like.
Guinness is perhaps my favorite beer. However, I definitely prefer the Extra Stout over the Draught, and regret having paid more money to try the Draught. Guinness is my choice beer!

Whoa!  What an amazing stout! This brew pours up a decadent black colored body with an amazing thick foamy tan head that has superb retention and leaves amazing lacing on the sides of the glass.  Wonderful scents of chocolate, roasted malts and some dark fruits (like plums or prunes).  And the flavors, oh my!  Roasted malts galore with the sharp bite of hops mingled in with coffee and chocolates.  The body is dry with just a slight amount of carbonation.

Draft in a pint glass - pours like motor oil with a cloud of milk and super rich tan foam. Aroma is coffee malts of a roasted nature along with a smoky quality. Finishes hoppy indeed and comes unannounced. Taste is bitter. Kinda wish I was drinking what was made in Europe. Lots of character and presence but light in body.

Dark, near black cola color with a light tan head that leaves rings of lace. The aroma has a sweet roasty character with some chocolate sauce and very mild dark fruit. Sweet malty start to the flavor with a very dry roasty break and a near burnt lingering finish where you can detect pale malts. Medium body with soft carbonation. All in all, better than expected but not exceptionally great.
Aroma of chocolate notes, roasted coffee and marshmallow.  Pours black with a medium white head.  Tastes of coffee notes and a subtle dark hop.  Mouthfeel is light but pleasant.  Not bad.
pours medium CO2 bubbles, decent head. Drinks quite sour, long sharp bitter finish, mixed with some notes of mildly roasted coffee. Lacks complexity and smoothness.
A solid easy drinking dry stout. It’s low ABV makes it a very nice beer to enjoy causally during the cooler month’s in the Midwest. This beer is not pretentious and is a great grocery store go to.
Bottle. Roasted malt aroma. Similar taste as well. Has some dark chocolate to the taste, too. Finishes with a nice aftertaste. Pretty good beer. 5.9% alcohol.
This is what I first thought Guinness was and it still does not disappoint. I do prefer on tap in Ireland but that is not quite Extra.

To be honest I was expecting something better from Guinness. Definitely an overhyped beer, although not bad by any means. Pours black with a tan head, has a roasty aroma. Relatively bitter without too much complexity. Also too thin for my taste. A decent stout, but nothing to go out of my way for.

Not a great beer. I find Guinness is far and away one of the most hyped beers. Guinness makes a dull concoction so that they can appeal to the general population while adding burnt malts. Extra Stout is much better than Guinness Draught
Yes, this is brewed by Labatt, but it’s a decent stout. Quite bitter, but still has that creamy texture you’d expect from Guinness.

The beer pours a dark brown to black color with a small tan head. The aroma is a mix of bitter, lightly roasted malt and a little bit of chocolate. The flavor is chocolate and chalky roasted malts with a little bit of bitterness. The beer is very dry and would be pretty easy to drink if it tasted better. Thin to medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

bottle.  Pours a very dark brown, but not black, with small light tan head.  Aroma of light roast, some milk.  Pretty smooth, creamy body.  Medium in feel, not very syrupy or thick.  Flavor of dry, slightly bitter roast, but interestingly with kind of a lactose aspect too.  Very light, subtle prune.  Ultimately, alot better than I would have expected.  Its a pretty good stout.
Meh. I remember really liking this years ago. Not sure who changed. Definitely drinkable but nothing special.

Bottle poured into imp pint.  Dark, nearly opaque black color with slight hints of ruby red on the edges.  Brown milky head goes from a finger thick and falls away pretty fast.  Very roasty aroma with little else.  Hints of leather, roasted nuts,barnyard, wood.  Quite carbonated and thin going down, taste features some sweet milkiness upfront, fizz, and then a slightly bitter dry finish.  Just not exciting at all and falls way short of Guinness’ flagship.

Pours a opaque coffee with a short and lumpy but persistent head.  Strong banana aroma with hint of chocolate.  Strong chocolate taste all the way throughout with a slight spice.  Heavy on the palate and decently carbonated.
A decent stout option, although in my opinion a bad recommend for people new to the style.  A bit of astringency or too-strong bitterness in the finish.  Light cocoa.

Good quality dry stout, better than Draught and the 250th Anniversary.  Roasted coffee, chocolate and malts come out in the nose and flavor.  Medium bodied, which really makes the case for this being better than Draught and saves the beer.  Smooth with only a mild bite at the end.

Rich black color; Medium to heavy slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, & some dark fruit; Flavor of roasted malt, hops, caramel, and some chocolate; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, pleasantly surprised - quite good.

Bottle. Pour is pitch black with a decent tan head. Aroma is coffee grounds, chocolate, roasty notes. Taste is about the same. Palate is bitter and a bit watery. This is a very sessionable stout, and definitely better than draught.
Brown black with a dense tan head.  Aroma is mildly toasty, bready with a tart treacle note.  Taste is the same, with a higher treacle acidity that lingers into the finish.

A damn sight better than Guinness Draught, Extra Stout was the beer I forced myself to like when I first started venturing outside of BMC.  (The very first time I drank Extra Stout I was tripping on acid and kept getting confused why my beverage didn’t taste like root beer until I convinced myself it did.)  There’s a nice, smoky richness to this beer, but it never develops past the initial imprint, leaving a bland, bitter finish to leave you frustrated.  I’m sure this bottle is getting a couple points out of nostalgia, but, hey, I’m only human.  Or a reasonable facsimile of.  (08/08)
Glass to chilled pint mug.  Had a bit of a skunky smell to it, and the flavor was on the bitter side.  Had a pretty decent bite due to the Co2 rather than nitro.  I’m not into this.

Pours nice and dark into a shaker glass, with a thick head and messy lacing. Aromas were sour and bitter, with a hint of coffee and chocolate. The initial taste is very dry, bitter and hoppy. Undertones of coffee and dark chocolate provide a good balance. You could say that and Extra Stout to Draught is like espresso to coffee - they taste almost exactly the same but one is stronger... much stronger.

Contrary to many of my friends both on this site and off, I have found this beer to be one of my particular favourites. The presentation is simply awe inspiring as it sits in the glass with a hue as dark as the night sky. However, I was a bit dissatisfied with the head of this beer as it seemed much flatter than its Draught counter-part. However, I personally enjoyed the burnt tastiness this beer provides and found its additional carbonation to be in fine company. This being said, I would definitely buy this beer again. Nothing like a good Guinness. Cheers!

Good, affordable dark beer but not necessarily something I’d go out of my way to find. Roasted notes and a decent body, but somewhat of an industrial feel to it, too. Somehow it is heavier to drink than the abv would suggest.

Excellent dark heavy stout.  The added roastiness of the malt is tasty; it’s a much closer to an Irish dry stout.  A strong stout for sure. Appearance and mouthful are certainly worth noting and excellent tastes of burnt.  I remember the first time I tried this beer, I did not like it.  But it definitely grew on me, now it is one of my favorites.

Bottle. Not as good as Guinness Draught or the Foreign Extra. Pours a deep, dark black with nice off-white head. Nose is roasted malt, hop, and raw accents, almost synthetic. Taste is similar to the nose but, to me, somewhat metallic like I was sipping it off of a spoon. Not bad but I would much rather indulge in a Foreign Extra Stout.

Bottle picked up at Total Wine in Alexandria. Served in a Hill Farmstead wine glass.

Pour brings a black-bodied brew with a good-sized light tan head. Head sticks around for a bit before fading into a nice cap with quite a bit of lacing on the edges of the glass. The nose is pretty off with some roast and chocolate plus a bit of cardboard. Slight metallic character there as well. The flavor is really bad. It’s metallic and oxidized with some dry roast. Feel is metallic. Just not a very good beer. I really wish they’d only make the Foreign Extra Stout.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-15-2011

Smells a little stronger than Guinness Draught, tastes nothing like it. Probably because Labatt brews it for Ontario... I really don’t like this beer so I am so sad because I love regular Guinness so much. So much. I love you Guinness...

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a high, fine-grained, light brown head. Nose is coffee, black tea, raisins. Very dark roast on the tongue, with savory and coffee elements. No sweetness, which is what I’d expect. Finishes clean but a touch weak -- texture is also thinner than I expect from a stout. It’s all right, but Foriegn Extra blows it away.
Not quite as good as Guinness Draught, but not bad either. Basically the same in appearance with a slightly different smell and taste.

This stout poured a deep black colour with a big, tan, creamy head. T the nose there are scents of chocolate, caramel,smoke, roasty malts and a little hay. First swig was alot more carbonated than I was expecting. Not quite as smooth as the regular Guinness stout but packs a huge flavour punch non the less. Flavours of roasted malt, smoke, caramel and molassass are most prodominant with slight flavours of coffee and cereal come in after. Finish is burnt with smoke flavour lingering.
I like brew much better than Guinness Draught.  To me it has a much deeper flavor.   I WILL have this brew many, many more times!

Bouteille 341 ml. 5%. La fausse Guinness de Labatt !! ;-) Couleur noire, mousse crémeuse brune. Arôme de houblon, malt torréfié et un peu de café. En bouche, douce et effervescente, houblon et malt torréfié. Surprenante. Finale avec un peu de café et une légère amertume.  Bonne

Nothing too bad here.  Does have a metallic roast and hop character, tinny, dry roast with light acidity, lightly fruity, bit of soy, kinda odd actually but not bad.  Body is smooth and creamy with larger sharp carbonation, but too much. Dark chocolate aftertaste with a metallic hop flavor.

From bottle. Head is about 1.5", true tan, creamy, indented top with big bubbles sitting below. Head lingers during drinking and leaves a cool, chunky indentation pattern. Liquid is expected black-dark brown, and somehow hazy looking. Aroma is less roasty than regular Guinness, more funky, more metal, more lager notes. Taste is dirt, burnt dark bread, very little chocolate/coffee (maybe none). I guess you could say this sits in between Draught and Foreign Extra, but I prefer the other two much more. Can’t complain about this beer though--drinks great.

Black in color. Caramel-colored head that is very frothy. Constallation lacing. Chocolate, coffee, raisin and black licorice all stand out in the aroma. Salty-sweet in the taste. Semi-sticky texture with a fizzy carbonation. Beer starts sweet and sort of salty. For a dark beer i was expecting a strong bitter flavor but did not get that. A smooth beer that i would definitely drink again.

Black with a clearish body, especially around the sides and bottom. Khaki head. Aroma was pretty barley malted, with notes of smoked chocolate and some peanuts. Smelled like what a regular Guinness was trying to achieve. Tastes that way too. Much more of a body than a Guinness, and the bright carbonation is a welcome change. Taste profile hits with some dry sourish chocolate tones, smoke, peanuts, and wet peat. Finished dry and unappealing. It tastes like a better version of a Guinness, but that’s not saying too much. Pretty ho hum.

Aroma is roasty chocolate, toffee and sour. Appearance is dark brown with medium small tan head. Taste is malt forward, followed closely by hops bitterness, roast coffee chocolate bitterness and hop aroma. Many strong flavors balancing and complementing. Sourness also present. Minerally, slight oxidation, butter. Palate is medium but crisp. Minerally-ness and bitterness help dry this somewhat thicker beer out. Overall a very nice beer. Unique and complex. Great drinker.

650ml bomber. I mistakenly bought this thinking it was the new foreign extra stout.

It actually has a decent appearance, if a bit inorganic. It is a thick,dark brown with a foamy off-white head that sticks for a good while.

It smells like circus peanuts.

The flavor is weak, with a hint of roastiness and a hint of fruitiness. There is also a hint of green bean.

It is pretty carbonated.

Overall another failure from Guinness, though as far as Irish Irish dry stouts go this might be the best example.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-20-2010 06:05:27

Poured from 22 oz bottle. Aroma is chocolate, smokey, roasted coffee.  Appearance is jet black with creamy tan head.  Taste is chocolate, barley, espresso, semi hoppy, creamy, and a little bitter.  Palate is full taste with a full mouth feel.  Overall, nothing like a guinness draught.  Extra stout is higher in alcohol, more bitter, sweeter.  I enjoyed this alone, but I believe it would go great with a steak or burger.  This is much better than a guinness draught.  I would love to try this on a nitro tap..

Not to be compared to guinness by much.  Pours the same color as the bottle, rich tan off-white head.  The nose is quite sweet, dark malt, very lightly roasty.  Taste is sweet molasses to put it frankly, light roasted barley, to me less mouth than a regular guinness, still creamy.  To rate separately, i liked the taste, it was enjoyable.

Poured from 12oz bottle, pours black with a nice off white head, aroma is sweet and the flavor is much of the same, it has some chocolate notes in the finish, decent carbonation and mouthfeel, decent.

This was dissapointing, I should have just got regular Guinness! It is ’thicker’ than normal, but not in a quality way. You can taste the cheapness of the malt and they must have had the wort in shipping for a while, it doesn’t taste like it kept too well. Ugh, I just had another sip. I was looking for a porter to please me but I’m gonna have to have some Vit P before another one of these, it has an almost unpleasant aftertaste.
12 fl oz bottle. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted dark malty. Thick, roasted and dark malty to liqourice. Lasting roasted and quite bitter flavoured. Ends dry roasted malty.

. Black with hint of brown. Aroma is roasted malt, caramel, and vanilla with booze. Flavor is also burnt and caramel with dark dark chocolates and long bitter finish. A weird fruit thing goes on also at the end but covered by the roast.
Not entirely sure why I get to rate this again. Plenty of delightful chocolate and raisins in the flavour.  Perfectly delicious and smooth in the mouth.
i was surprised with the drinkability of this beer. i wish they had this on tap everywhere instead of that watered down Guinness draft
Bottle. This beer was excellent. Pours dark black with small head that retains. Would love to have more.
A great macro stout. Always good on tap or in a bottle. Smokey malt and coffee with a raisin finish. Somewhat dry with a nice hop presence.
Like an amplified version of regular Guinness, better in almost every single way, especially without the widget.

This Guinness is better than the draught that is typically sold in the US. Slightly bigger body and slightly more robust in flavors of roast, cocoa, and coffee. But, I still find it lacking to be a solid stout.

12oz bottle. Pours black with a thick dark tan head. Nose is roasted malts and slight sweetness. Flavor is roasty, caramel, coffee and bit of bitterness as well. Dry finish with the roasty flavors lurking for a while. Not as creamy as the draught but still good.

Bottle pour into English pint.  Dark brown with roasted malts on the nose.  A bit of caramel, a bit of smoke.  Mild taste, very smooth yet not as watery of a feel as the draught.  Good finish, just lightly bitter - nice.  Very drinkable and not overbearing.
Bottle... black body with a light brown head.  Chocolate, barley, malt on the nose.  Smooth, silky palate with flavors of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, with a sort of chalky finish.

Bottle, as part of a Christmas gift.  Pours a mostly opaque dark brown with a tan head...normal head, not the nitro head that you’ll get from the Draught.  Smells roasty, some coffee.  Taste devolves into a little bit of chocolate as it warms, but it’s not overwhelming sweet.

Jet black with a huge brown head. Great head retention eventually leaving beautiful thick lacing. Aromas are of malt and dark chocolate. Taste is very slightly roasted malt, dark chocolate, vanilla, coffee, a hint of cola, and maybe some woody oakiness. Finish is  firm and bitter. Simple but very enjoyable.

Goddamn Guinness has a brewery in every country but here so they can call it an import.  This bottle says New Brunswick Canada but says nothing about Labatt so I assume they’ve changed to a different brewer/brewery to handle the Canadian end of things unless they just ditched it on the label which is what I expect happened. I just hate giving those motherfuckers at inbev any money.  Anyway, pours nice and dark and I like to give it a nice 2in head.  Foreign Extra is better but I won’t kick the stout outta bed.

Bomber brewed in Canada. Pours almost black with a big, rocky tan head that settles down to a creamy layer that leaves hefty lacing. A medium bodied brew that is soft and creamy in the mouth with a dry finish. The taste is well balanced between sweet and roasty with some juicy kind of grape notes and some underlying chocolate and vanilla. A nice simple stout.
smooth, filling, hint of coffee flavor, good foamy head, best experienced from a pint glass
Dark black pour from bottle.  Roasted coffee aroma, with a nice tan head. Bitter taste with notes of coffee and dark chocolate.   Decent.

Pours a dark brown-black .. . light tar and lots of roast, with an underlining lying sweetness .. . on the sideline cracking jokes .. . a nice beer but i like the draught regular much better .. . down goes frazier! down goes frazier!!

Appearance- Dark brown almost black with a nice two finger tan head.

Aroma- Some dark fruits come through as the beer warms as well as a bit of caramel.

Taste- Follows the nose closely with a slightly burnt taste on the finish.

Mouth-feel- Medium bodied bordering on full.

drink-ability- A session beer if you want it to be.
Pours black w cream head; smells of coffee and choc predominate; taste is quite dry and surprisingly bitter with nice clean finish

[3521-20101219] Bottle. Sweet roast malt aroma has a light metallic note. Slightly hazy, black brown body with a medium-lasting foamy light tan head. Sweet grainy roast malt flavour has a lingering sweet aftertaste. Medium body. Quite nice, a little sweet.

(w/ mebden)

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep brown with a creamy head and gentle lacing that lingers. Aroma is slightly sweet and tangy with a hint of raisin. Taste is tart with dried berries and raisin.  Slight bitter finish. Much better than Guinness Draught.

saw this at the nslc visiting while over xmas.  had the regular guinness draught but not the extra stout.   this pours black dark, not as big head as reg guinness draught, it has more bitter and not as smooth, but can get more coffee, oaky taste from it.   Not bad I would take this over a regular guinness.

12 oz. bottle. Black with a creamy tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty slight roast and a slight sour note. Taste is a little roasty that is dry with bitter finish. Full creamy mouthfeel though not too heavy. Overall a nice dry stout.
Bottle. Pours nearly black with tan head that isn’t big for long, but hangs on. Tastes, you know, like Guinness, but not as carbonated and with a drier finish.
12oz bottle.  Aroma of roasted malts and resin.  Flavor very bland for a stout.  Not worth drinking.
Not as good as foreign stout in jamaica very week and thin a little roasted malts tobstart nothing special

Pours from the bottle the expected dark brown, near black color. A small brown head emerges and quickly exits. This is disappointing as I am accustomed to a big creamy head of stout from Guinness Draught. The aroma is full of roasted malt, some milk chocolate, and even raspberry subtleties are noted. Actually a pretty intriguing smell. First thing to note upon tasting is a higher carbonation level and lesser body then the Draught. Extra Stout actually reminds me more of a porter. The body is leaning toward the lighter side and lacking the rich smooth texture created by the Draught or even the nitro cans. The flavor is pleasantly malty, revealing layers of bitter coffee, and some roasted malts. The finish is rather sweet, and ends dry, but not as dry as I expected. In a blind tasting I probably would have never guessed this as a Guinness because it is so different then the classic Guinness Draught I am used to.

This is one of the best macros out there, if not the best.  distinctive beer you can find pretty much anywhere  -AROMA-  the hops and malts tend to even themselves out here, neither realy surpasses the other.  bready, toasted malts and grassy hops both mixed together, earthy and notes and cellar aromas in the background  -APPEARANCE-  full marks on appearance, a very nice deep brown verging on black with a closer look revealing deep ruby reds.  pour gives rise to a 2 finger tan head that sticks around until the glass is empty  -TASTE-  a bit of a cereal taste to it, with roasty malts as well, a bit hopier than most stouts, but it doesnt take away from the flavor.  overall its somewhat earthy, and as with the aroma the hops and malts tend to balance themselves out.  finish is short, and tastes of roasted nuts  -PALATE-  has the usual thick stout body, and a creamy, thick texture to go with it, relatively soft carbonation  -BOTTOM LINE-  this is TheKing of the macros, an excellent beer that you can find pretty much anywhere.  obviously not the best stout, but leagues away from the worst

I would imagine similar to everyone else, this is the one stout that at this point in time have had the most of. 

Slight roasted smell. Pours black off opaque appearance. Taste medium full bodied, with slight watery crispness. Overall wasn’t my first and won’t be my last.
Watery taste and mouthfeel.  Some roasted character is present, but there is excessive bitterness from the hops.  Not terrible, but lacks the pleasantness and quality of Guinness Draught.

Silky black appearance with little to no head. Fairly mild aroma with light chocolate and licorice notes. Fairly creamed, smooth, not dry beer. I definitely prefer this over regular Guinness you find everywhere, that stuff tastes like watered down extra stout. Nothing mind blowing, but a solid beer. Paired perfectly with a bowl of chili on a cold day.

Pours black with a tannish head which leaves a network of lace along the way. His head lingers as a bubbly blob while mahogany and garnet highlights streak across my vision. No matter how low on the temperature scale I keep my fridge, it seems to me that my beers always come out far colder than I like and need them to be. So it was after a few moments of letting my Guinness Extra Stout settle and warm that I finally delved into his nose. Roasted grains and barley, dry and crunchy, while the back bites with hard root beer candy. Licorice root and licorice sticks meddle in his roasted barley affair, and a few snuffs later reveal nothing new. My first quaff is smooth with a good clean mouthfeel, albeit dry of course. Raw barley, cracked barley, and toasty whole grain crust settles atop the center of my tongue for the duration of our tasting session. Short in the front and short in the finish, the whole of his palate sits squarely in the middle. Chewy and earthy licorice root mingles with black earth while burnt cracked barley dries the top of my tongue. Burnt caramel is a feeble whisper. Eventually bitter and burnt root beer candy bite peeks through, but never enough to be a major player. The Guinness Extra Stout is not a heavy dark beer and as such, I am none too surprised to find my glass already empty.




Not bad and not great, for me at least having tasted so much more both within the style and outside the style, the American Guinness Extra Stout is a beer for the shelves. If offered I would drink it but don’t expect me to go out of my way to buy it.

Bottle. Black with beige head. Aromas of cocoa, toast, caramel, coffee. Flavors of toast, coffee, cocoa, caramel. Bigger hop bit in the back than Guinness Draught. Medium-full body with thick mouthfeel and moderate, bright carbonation.
From bottle. Nice and dark, like I like. Strong flavor for me and otherwise drinkable. I prefer Old Ras though.

The aroma kind of threw me off. Almost a raisin like smell. The color and texture was very rich. The taste had a burnt feel to it.  This was first time trying this stuff. I wasn’t sure at first whether I liked it or not but it grew on me as I drank it. It was OK but not something I’d go out of my way for.

Not as good as draught.  12oz bottle pours black with reddish tan head. Aroma is malty with notes of raisin.  Tastes of raisin and toasted biscuit with lots of bitterness.  Body is a bit thin for guinness which is a let down and flavor is a bit burnt. Plus I was disappointed that it was canadian and not from dublin

~Some grassy earthy hops in aroma. Pale malt aroma light roastiness.
~Pours jet black with lasting wispy brown head. 
~Spicy earthy hops in flavor. More roastiness in flavor than in aroma. Spicy  hops dominate.
~Med body med high CO2, lingering roasty burnt bitterness.
~ Hops?! Really?! Yeah not so much a fan in my stouts. Aroma doesn’t smell like a stout. If I was blindfolded I would actually guess some kind of Bohemian Pilsner. Hopefully more roast comes out as it warms. Not a bad beer just not what I was wanting or expecting. Very odd brew. I guess the hops make it "extra" 

Ok yeah. A bit more stout character comes out as warms. Still have that pils malt aroma, but also some roasted nuttiness. Up one point in aroma.

it’s been awhile since i’ve had the extra stout version of Guinness.  for some reason, i’d been buying the draught version with the darn widget to give that draft feel.  at some point i’d grown tired of the flavor and found it to be too light, and somewhat watered down.  bought a 22oz bottle yesterday to add to my chili.  poured 12oz in the chili and drank the rest.  fell back in love with guiness.  love that roasted malt taste.

BEAUTIFUL LOOKING DARK STOUT WITH A NICE TAN HEAD AND SWEET MALTED AROMA.TASTES OF BITTER ROASTED NUTTY COFFEE BEANS WITH A HINT OF UNSWEETENED CHOCOLATE FINISHED WITH A NICE AMOUNT OF CARBONATION, THIS BEER IS VERY NICE THE ONLY DRAW BACK IS THE LOW ALC. CONTENT.

Tasted from a 12 oz. bottle purchased in Fort Collins, Colorado.  Pours a thick creamy-black head with a deep brown-black body.  Sweet, dark malty head and like a Guinness but has a much stronger alcohol flavor but without a high alcohol content.
Dark, thick head.  Aroma is roasty, but with a slight sour hint.  Taste is very roasty with a sharp roasty finish.  Feel is thick - but not "buttery", and the finish lingers until the next sip.

Enjoyed on several occasions, this most recent one in a Guinness glass from a 12oz bottle.  The beer pours the iconic opaque black, with a smallish tan head.  The nose shows a nice low to medium English crystal malt character, and a nice bready undertone.  The palate shows far less roasted character than other examples, and instead favors residual crystal and perhaps toasted malt sweetness.  Malt loaf, caramel, and a sort-of muffin-esque notes come through.  A slightly ashy, vaguely roasted note does sneak in, as the beer warms.  The finish is semi-sweet and lingers nicely on the palate.  Overall, an enjoyable beer to sip on a brisk early autumn evening.  It suffers only from its ubiquity.

On tap @ Iona and many other places. Pours a clear, dark ruby-black with a stiff, tan head. Properly poured, there should be a lovely cascade and a trailing heavy lace. Medium body, creamy, some chocolate and coffee and a dry finish. Raters who experience a sour, watery or skunky pint should try a place serving a fresh keg at the correct pressure through clean lines. Eminently sessionable - maybe the most sessionable ale ever and certainly the most famous.

look, this shit ain’t half bad. well, it is half bad. it looks ok in the glass, fairly dark, bits of lace. smells like... nothing... tastes like... ehh.. a macrobrewed stout. it has that "piss" flavor going on and a bit of hops. it’s very drinkable. more roast and hops going on then guinness draught. i would certainly order this up if my only other choices were utter shit. it’s like a shit porter, really.

Guiness Stout has a thick, creamy, beige head and a very clear, almost black, red appearance.  Carbonation is fairly high and there is splotchy lacing down the glass.  Aroma is a syrupy, sickly-sweet smell, with a coffee background.  The taste is very dark chocolate and coffee, with a strong malt presence.  Bitterness is straight up and strong.  Mouth-feel is thick and syrupy.  Guinness finishes heavy and filling.  This is a fairly good beer, but I prefer the Guinness Draught.

RJT
Pours very dark, slightest ruby at edges with a big tan head. Nose is light coffee, general roastiness. Taste of dark chocolate, a slightly sour, lactic touch. Nice overall.

Bottle at Maria’s Taverna, pours black with a tan head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malt and some sourness. Flavour is very unpleasant acidity, some roasted malt and a stale character. This was quite vile.

Pours an extremely dark brown color with a small tan head that seems to linger for a while.  Nose of matly chocolate and coffee.  Acidic, almost a sour taste to it, really weird.  Some hints of coffee but the overwhelming acidic taste doesn’t leave room for much else.  More carbonation than the guinness draught, but still very minimal, also lighter bodied.  Some decent qualities, but I don’t plan on having this again.

Slightly sweet malt aroma. Hints of dark malt in the aroma. Big, thick, tan head that lasts forever. Deep black color. Nice mild chocolate malt flavor. Full bodied with lingering black malt flavor. Easy drinking and enjoyable. Not as big flavored as many craft examples, but this is a classic example of the style.

Appearance:  traditional Guinness draught color, but the head is different--more foamy/rocky head.  Aroma:  roasty dark malts and coffee, some bitter chocolate.  Taste:  smooth, rich lightly smoky and roasted barley, with dark chocolate notes and some slight dry bitterness.  Finish:  dry, smooth and clean; lingers just a bit.  Notes:  More intense flavor than the draught, but also intensely drinkable.  I will have this often.

This is one of the stranger beers that I’ve had lately, perhaps ever. The first one, was awful. It tasted like sour apples, almost exclusively. I thought that it was skunked and that I brought home a bad sixer. The second one is better. I notice a burnt flavor, like black coffee and still that weird bitter flavor that is not hops, but almost like rotten fruit. I find myself liking this fruit flavor more and more and it morphs into burnt malt and coffee flavors depending on the drink. Definitely a dry stout that feels older than todays microbrews.

Guinness Extra Stout. i quite enjoyed this brew. It pours out reminiscent of its Draught counterpart but has a nice head whereas Draught does not. The retention is very good in this beer and lingers for a long time. It had a nice roasted aroma to it that gave it a good zing. The flavor is much better than the aroma. It has a full flavor of molasses and caramel that shines through the innate bitterness. it has an unmistakable tartness that seems to come from dark fruits, but it’s fruits that I cannot place. Overall it is another beer that is more than worth trying. It is one of my regular brews.

Not a very interesting aroma, you get a light malt note and it smells like a macro lager. Pours dark brown with a lot of visible carbonation, but that dies down (with the head too). Taste is slightly nutty and candy and very uninteresting; quite watery.  I think my bottle may have been skunked or something. It just doesn’t have much going for it, very uninteresting, wouldn’t get it again. Didn’t expect much from this brewery, but I expected a little better. I’m thinking something may have been wrong with my batch or something. It tasted like someone put roasted nuts and green apple candy into tap water. This shouldn’t even be beer, worst I’ve had.

12 oz bottle in Baltimore. Pours a watery black - not as thick as I was expecting. Light brown head dissipated quickly. Nice mild chocolate and coffee flavors throughout the sip - nothing stands out above another. Smooth stout - but not special.
This beer has alot going on. It not all good, such as the finish, your finished with a bad taste that doesn’t leave your mouth for awhile

I can’t tell if I like this or dislike it.  It looks great: dark brown with a nice tan head.  It goes down thick, like syrup, with a slightly,roasted malty taste, but has a very noticeable wood smoke aftertaste, which gives me my dilemma.

Poured in Sam Adams Sensory Glass

Color is a dark molasses brown. Thick and fluffy tan brown head that leaves decent lacing.

Smell is of roasted carmel nuts and slight pine hops. Taste is very malty, almost smokey. Many roasted malts are present.

Mouthfeel is smooth, but it seems to be very cold on the throat.

Overall, this stout seemed to be a lot thinner than the ones I am used to drinking. There really wasn’t anything to special with this beer, but I think it could make a good session stout.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-02-2009 20:47:34

Draught at Rocket Bar.  Guinness does not seem to travel well, since this one is more bitter and acidic than its Ireland-borne uncle.  Still nice enough, but I would encourage fans (and even non-fans) familiar with the US version to try the Irish version.

Well I am rateing my favorite beers to start off my new membership,(ones I know from heart as if my first unopened one is in front of me)

 Aroma.......lol oo[ps i will admit now this stuff is strong,lkoij,mnlj>
as i listen to Korpiklanni folk rock ;)) !!!!!
coffie is the first word to come to mind and of course chocolate. an ...um
aged hoppyness, dark malty (roasted)  ,yet despite all the stoute’ness,
 a feeling that it was brewed with the watters of the snowmelt of snowdonia wales itself.

Malt.. roasted malt sweetish german choco

Yeast/Bac.. leather.. earthy..oak...ish?

I can tell my taste has changed with time because the first time I tried this I thought it tasted like burnt tree stump.  It still has a smoky flavor but in a good way.  Aroma is sweet coffee.  The flavor is smoke, coffee, chocolate.  I really like the look of this brew, black with a nice tan head.

Bottle in a Brooklyn backyard. Poured dark brown with the typical deep, thick beige head. Strong roasted malt aroma, with dark chocolate and light, bitter coffee. Flavor starts sweet with loads of cocoa. Some dry, roasty bitterness hangs around. Medium bodied with smooth, soft carbonation. Finishes semi-sweet and roasty with lingering cocoa. Really good bottle. Seemed much better than I remember.

I picked this up in 6 pack form when my band played dekalb Illinois. Enjoyed while sitting on a ratty chair with some weird bear skinned rug behind me.   It’s not bad, very creamy, kind of carbonated, hints of chocolate and roasted malt.

Dark brown in color with a foamy tan head. Roasty malt flavor with nutiness and hints of chocolate and coffee. Lacking in the smoothness and creaminess of Guinness draught. Not horrible, but not a stout I would take if given choices of others.

Pours black with a decent white head, looks like regular Guinness. Alas, it is inferior to the original in every which way. Very weak aromas of raisins and molasses. The mouth feel is thick. Taste of bland coffee, raisins/molasses, and licorice. Nothing here that really reminds me of the original. Still has enough character to make it average at best.
I have not had a pint of draft Guinness in Ireland close to the source.  But having only had Guinness on draft in the US, I have to say I prefer the bottled Extra Stout. Serving: Bottle

Bottle pour gives black color with persistent tan head.  Aroma very malty as is taste.  Flavor dark roast, malts.  Palate thick, smooth.  Finish long dry hoppy.  Alcohol not apparent.

Not bad.
Bought this at a publix in Miami. An OK cheap beer. Nothing too flavourful, but it’s not particularly bad. Great value for its price. Nowhere near as good as the guinness I’m used to, though.

chocolate,roasty and chicory aroma..brownish black color great head tan and dissipating visibly after pour..tatste of burnt malts cararmel chocolate with a certain dry tingliness..easy enough to drink as far as stouts go..excellent go to beer or night cap inexpensive as well..light bodied for a stout but flavorful

Guinness Extra Stout is brewed here under licence by Labatt Brewing. It pours a pitch black colour with very slight red highlights. The big tanned head is thick and creamy. It goes down very uneven, slowly. The lacing is all around and foamy. Sourness is in the taste and aroma mildly. Don’t know if this one was outdated. Found in a bad convenient store close to Montreal. Find this one less bitter then the Guinness Draught (can). Soft scent of roasted malt and nuts. Dry finish of hop. Thin mouthfeel but interesting. Not much, other then appearance.

Look, it’s just good beer.  Smells great, pours black as your soul, and tastes good all year around.  Pay attention tomorrow.  Wherever you’re at I bet you see somebody wearing a Guinness shirt.  That isn’t an accident.
Chocolate brown, very thick creamy tan head, foamy lacing.  Light notes of coffee and nuts.  Expresso flavor and bitterness with creamy mouthfeel.

Bottle.  Pours black with 1/4" caramel head.  Sweet nose of caramel, chocolate, and roast.  Flavor is watery sweet, caramel and chocolate, mildly hopped with a lingering sweetness and astringency.  Drinkable and decent.

Let’s skip to the chase: Should you drink this warm or cold? When it’s cold the flavors are: Dark chocolate, coffee, heavily roasted to burnt malt, and bitter hops. When it’s warm the flavors are more like: Sweet chocolate, maybe some sort of fruit, coffee, heavily roasted malt, and not so bitter hops. I perfer the sweeter chocolate, not burnt malt, and less bitter hops flavor when it’s warm.

Pours black with a large tan head. The aroma is roasty, sweet and slightly sour. The palate is simple, yet enjoyable. Coffee, banana, sour cherries and a dry finish. not bad, but I still like the smoothness of the original with the nitro.

The nose is a bit too fruity for me.  Also smells kinda earthy.  Taste is dry with some mild carbonation, kinda rough around the edges.  I am a huge Guinness fan so I think I’ll just stick to the original.
tastes of bread, chocolates with a roasty finish.  Stands well alone but with food needs strong flavors to cut through

Pours black with copper edges, thick creamy beige head. Aroma of dark fruits and roast malt with some mild hops. Taste has lots of toffe and fruity sweetness with some burnt/dark chocolate bitterness and a hint of butterscotch. Medium body, smooth carbonation. Not a huge fan of this overall, too fruity.

I used to love Guinness Extra Stout. Just had it last night for the first time in a couple years, and I was surprised at how sour it is. I remember it being thick, creamy, malty, and coffee tasting. Still thick, for sure, but strangely tangy tasting now. I’ve had stouts that are a lot more extra stout than Guinness since then, so I think I’ve moved past this old favorite. Oh well. Back to imperial stouts.
A little more punch than draft Guinness. Slightly more bitter, roasty, chocolatey and astringent. Very, very good beer. Very good stout and would drink this one again.

Pours black with inch-high off-white head. Leaves good lacing. Aromas of roasted and chocolate malt. The stout has a full body, yet very drinkable. The finish is dry and earthy. The flavor is lightly sweet with chocolate malt and the finish is dry and roasted. Overall, this is good stout. Very drinkable and enjoyable when fresh. Be wary of skunky brew that is past its freshness date (e.g., that great sale on Guinness at the local grocery store!).
Pours black with tan head. Nose and taste of roasted barley, sweet chocolates and coffees. Rated 1/3/2000

12 oz botle to shaker.  Pours black with thick beige head.  Aroma of bread with a hint of sour.  Has some mild bitterness that is balanced well by the sweet.  Palate is very heavy.  You could live off this stuff.
Still my favorite, extra stout is much better than its brother guinness, I taste toasted coffee and cocoa. The marriage of the two make for an excellent stout
Strong, smooth, dark beer.  Best served as a car bomb (pint of guinness and a shot of 1/2 Baileys irish Cream, and 1/2 Whisky dropped in.....chug)

Love this beer. Black as motor oil, strong taste and very smooth. Smoky, chocolaty flavor that accompanies heavy meaty foods. Best from the tap epically near the UK or Ireland since locally it’s stored in wooden barrels, but for export it’s stored in steel barrels. The wood helps to enhance the flavor.
Dark roasted barley nose. Dark brown, thin yellow head. Roasted barley flavor, a touch sour. Bark finish. A little filmy on the palate. Good for what it is.

A-Pours an opaque black with red hues. Big fluffy cream head dwindles down to very thin head. Leaves behing dome lacing in the glass. I was surprised at how light the head was on this.

S- Big smell of toasted malt and coffee. Some notes of chocolate too.

T- Initial taste is somewhat thin. Chocolate flavoring and malt come through the carbonation. Aftertaste is bitter and resembles burnt coffee. This taste lingers until the next taste.

P- Carbonation is very high and masks the soft taste at the meginning. Body is between medium and heavy weight.

O- Average drinkability. It was somewhat enjoyable and went down moderately easy-hence the average rating. It was nice to see the difference between Guiness and Guiness extra.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-22-2007 20:21:12
Very watery stout with a unpleasant bite on the finish.  Good for a mass produced beer but not much in comparison to moat microbrew stouts.
roasted aroma, pours a dark black with a good tan head. bitter taste with hints of coffee and dark chocolate.
Bottle: Poured a deep thick black with a beige head. Sweet grassy malts and roasted aroma. Taste is a gritty dark chocolate with coffee bean and yet some hops on the back side.

12oz bottle. Pours thin and completely black with plenty of head some of which was fairly long lasting. The aroma is very roasty up front with coffee and leather aspects. The taste is with slightly sweet and has a sour tanic aspect.that sticks around as if finishes with a fairly strong bitterness.

Aroma of chocolate malt and yeast, pours black with a nice tan foamy head. Medium sweetness with a roasted twang.  Low on the IBUs but smooth and finishes clean. Overall a decent stout more on the sweet side than dry.
I’m not getting a whole lot out of the aroma but the color is a nice deep dark brown color.  Flavor is nice and malty with a nice bitter touch.  Delicious!

Pours nearly black with a moderate white head. Nose is fairly weak but is typical stout roasty smelling. The flavor is stronger than I expected and has notes of coffee, roasted malt, dark chocolate and general earthiness. Finish is coffee-ish and slightly bitter. Solid beer and one of the best widely-distributed ones I’ve had.

This is NOT a standard stout, this is the original stout. As soon as you smell the deliciousness of this brew you know you are going to enjoy it thoroughly, I did. The appearance reaffirms this. The taste needs no description and the lacing is unbelievable. My palate is still dancing. A perfect brew.
Go-to Extra Stout.  Could be a dollar or two cheaper, whatever, it’s solid and can be found everywhere.  IMO it’s at  its best around 40 degrees.

Bottle. Pours a blackish color with a foamy and airy beigish head. Nose is light roast, kinda soy saucey. Palate is thin with a stingy carbonation. Flavor is light roast notes with some more soy sauce type notes.

What?  No one is rating this on St. Pat’s?  Bottle from Gomer’s Lee’s Summit.  Bought it because it was St. Pat’s and I wanted something relatively inexpensive and it was on sale.  On the way home I started regretting it a little, thinking of all the other great craft brews Gomer’s has for the same ballpark price.  When I poured it in the pint glass I was starting to get happier- plenty dark but with hints of color  and a creamy two finger head.  Aroma was roasty but a bit faint- I don’t drink many dry stouts so this is probably typical.  Kinda hard to follow the KBS I had this afternoon.  First drink and I was glad I made this choice.  Very full flavor for a dry stout with molasses and caramel added to the roastiness and even hints of dark fruits.  Very well-balanced with a great dry and bitter finish that was obviously a result of the hops but didn’t taste hoppy, if that makes sense.  What really stood out the most was the ultra-creamy and long-lasting head.  It stayed for the entire pint, adding new elements to its shape each time the glass was tipped.  You could make some impressive head art if you were so inclined, the shapes just held perfect, like a meringue or something.  All in all a great beer for just barely over $1.  Guiness is good.

Already rated Guinness draught tonight so figured I’d go ahead and rate this too.  Pour is dark brown/black.  Flavor is malty and smoky.  Some might consider this blasphemy but I’ve always felt that extra stout is as good or better than draught in its own way.

22 oz bottle.  Since it’s St. Patty’s day I had to have this with my Corned beef and potatoes(Not cabbage).   Pours dark brown with a medium tan head, good lacing. Aroma and flavor are mostly coffee and chocolate. Fine beer.  Seemed thicker and stronger 30 years ago when 1st had it.
Pours a deep brown/black color.  Aroma of toasted grain with hints of chocolate, molasses and iron.  Flavor is molasses with a hint of chocolate.  Finish is dry
Pours a very deep dark redish brown, almost black, with a thick, tan ,foamy head. Aroma has a hint of roasted malt. Taste is roasted,coffee, dark chocolate. Finish is a little bitter. A solid brew.

Bomber. Black with hint of brown. Aroma is roasted malt, caramel, and vanilla with booze. Flavor is also burnt and caramel with dark dark chocolates and long bitter finish. A weird fruit thing goes on also at the end but covered by the roast.

We all know Guinness Draught because it’s the beer that’s served whenever you order a “Guinness” at a bar or restaurant. But what about Guinness Extra Stout? Is it the same beer in a different bottle or is it truly a beer on its own? I decided to find out.

POUR, COLOR AND AROMA

The main difference between Guinness Extra Stout and Draught in the home version is this beer is missing the nitrogen widget which creates the lively body of sinking bubbles it would have on tap. Extra Stout pours and looks like a porter – extremely smooth and seemingly lightweight. It forms a soda-like, tan head which quickly fizzles out and leaves virtually no lacing on the glass (quite the opposite of the Draught). 

It’s actually quite easy to tell this beer is very dark maroon/brown in color, although at just an arm length’s away it appears to be opaque black. The aroma is surprisingly subdued as well, since the scent is very weak. It doesn’t have the obvious bitter aroma of the Draught; in fact, it has a mild, malty scent with just the slightest bit of hop to the nose.

TASTE

I’m not a fan of porters at all, but I do like black lagers or “schwarzbiers” as they’re traditionally referred to. I was curious if Guinness Extra Stout would taste like either of these beers since it has the visual qualities of both. I was relieved upon taking my first taste to discover it is very reminiscent of a black lager. 

The flavor was much like the aroma: very mild. Guinness on tap tends to have a bitter, chocolate and coffee-like taste, but Extra Stout drinks more like a traditional lager. It did have a sweet, buttery taste that wasn’t dry in the least and only slightly bitter. I probably would have preferred something stronger-tasting but it definitely satisfied me.

FINISH

Aside from the taste, the other noticeable characteristic that sets Extra Stout apart from Draught is the super smooth finish. Whereas the Draught has a heavier body and a stronger, bitterer taste it tends to have a bit of bite to its finish. Not so with this beer as it goes down like flat soda. 

BODY

If you just mention the name Guinness to Joe and Jane Six Pack they tend to scoff to the extent of how thick and heavy the beer is. While this is true of the Draught (and part of what makes it so good), the Extra Stout is surprisingly light.

At only 5% ABV and having a very thin, light body (probably under 140 calories), this drinks like any run-of-the-mill lager, only smoother. I drank two bottles without feeling full or buzzed in the least. It would make a great compliment to a meal or work well as an after-dinner reward.

FINAL THOUGHTS

Guinness Extra Stout was nothing like what I expected, so I was pleasantly surprised that it turned out to be such a tasty, smooth dark lager. I’m surprised Guinness doesn’t market this beer more aggressively, especially for the American mass-market lager drinker who wants something smooth and light. Whatever, I still like it. 

NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1yRmv2mDC94

Where traditional Guinness tastes like a candied smoothie, Guinness Extra Stout tastes like beer. I prefer the traditional Guinness, but if I ever want to feel dignified, I’ll take an Extra Stout.
Delicious beer. Big frothy head. Can drink it like a glass of skim milk. Bottle at who the hell cares.

Pours dark with quickly fading tan head, aroma is some chocolate and roasted malt.  Taste is roasted, thin and fizzy on the mouthfeel, but nice roasted character that finishes fairly bitter.  Not bad.

Bottle. Solid stout. Dry. It is very bold and makes a statement with every sip. Malty aroma, with hints of hopps. Heavy coffee flavor, with hints of toasty nuts and caramel. Bitter and crisp hoppy accent throughout and bitter finish. Solid long lasting head, pour was nice in appearance. Good beer.

12oz bottle in United Airlines Lounge @ JFK
Standard black pour, larger than expected tan head that quickly reduces to thin layer that seems to be fed by more lively and bigger bubbles than in their draft beers.  Roasted malt aroma with medium bitterness in the taste. Medium creamy body with average carbonation & long bitter finish.

Purchased at Food Lion, Winterville, NC

No real scent/smell.  Decent flavor.

This is not as good as the normal guinness and I miss the nitrogen.  An odd malt sweetness really comes out of this otherwise dry stout.  There is a cherry flavor in with the burnt malt, and you can actually taste the alcohol in this one (vs normal Guinness).  Not as good as normal guinness or 250.
Black pour with tan head. Roasted malt scent. The taste is overdrive burned malts or something. Kinda watery. Not what I expected. On second thought, this is not very good at all to me.
I was not a fan. It had a metallic taste. Kind of watery for a stout, not very tasty. Looked good, smelled good, but it honestly didn’t deliver on anything else
Dark beer near black.  Completely opaque.  Chocolate and coffee malt scent.  Bitter with a slight smokiness. A slightly oily mouthfeel.

Reviewed 12/24/2009 (Bottle):

Pours a very dark brown red color body, big frothy light tan head, very lasting, good lacing, creamy looking.  Roasty aroma. Some nuttiness, maybe almond or something. Sweet and a tiny bit dusty. Somewhat watery, somewhat creamy taste.  A little astringent. Thirst quenching.

The beer has an underwhelming roasted malt nose but better than the Draught. I taste chocolate notes, rather than the more widely reported coffee flavor. I usually don’t taste chocolate in stouts, so perhaps I just have some sort of taste problem where I confuse chocolate for coffee. Maybe, I should shut up and trust myself. It also tastes of black tea, english/irish breakfast, which I had a cup of before the beer. So, I have a little more grip on that flavor at least. I don’t really like the tea flavor. It’s sort of that drinking a cup of tea on an empty stomach with a big multivitamin experience. The dryness of the beer also contributes to a general mouth pucker. The aftertaste is somewhat bitter, which I don’t mind, but a bit too dry for me for a stout.  I have to try to separate feel from taste because the mouth pucker is really more of a taste issue than feel. The beer has a nice creamy carbonation, but it doesn’t really do a lot beyond that.
Dark Brown to black in appearance. Thick brownish head. Coffee and roasty flavours, some bitterness. Bottle.
While it did sort of look like  a Guinness it didn’t taste much like one.  Tasted more like your regular big brewer lager, not bad on a hot sunny day.

Smooth dry roasty malt with a tiny sharp hint of bitterness and hops. Really a great stout. Slight guiness twang, but that’s what we expect. The recipe is 200 years old and there’s a reason why it hasn’t been changed yet.

When I was pouring out in front of my head I could smell bitter drak chocolate taste as the head was foaming up. Not a hudge head but not small. Poured from 341ML(12oz)bottle. Taste alcoholicy(a tade)with some crisp clean water like taste that seem’s a little sour like(just a little or this water sour taste)but NOT in a way where it’s like ewww watery no thank’s. Head is creamy a little and taste is a little bitter burnt. It’s okay but I am not in love with it. Drinking it now. Made a review for youtube.

Bottle.  Can’t believe I haven’t reviewed this one yet.  It wasn’t terrible, but definitely didn’t do it for me.  Pours black with a small beige head, nowhere near as impressive as a nitro pour of Guinness Draught.  Aroma is roast, coffee, and chocolate.  Nothing special really.  Flavor is burnt/roasted malt, weak coffee, a little chocolate, and a strange, sour, almost vinegary note to it.  What is this supposed to be, some kind of wild ale?  Outside of that though, the flavor is decent.  Medium body with some acidity on the palate and average carbonation.  Overall, I consider this about average for the style.

Pours a nice amber brown color with a brown head.  Aroma is malty, caramel, roast, chocolate, brown sugar, and some spicy notes.  Flavor is roast, caramel, toast, chocolate, and a bitter spicy finish.
Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  Pours a very dark brown with tan head and watery body.  Taste is roasted barley, some dark chocolate, with a sour aftertaste.
Weird.  Thin and watery with tight carbonation - but with a faint chalky and roasty finish.  Dark Guinness color, but not much else in common.  None of the smooth creamy mouthfeel.

Appears like the common ’’Guinness" we all know, so we’ll skip visual aspects. Same aroma and taste  too, except maybe the hops flavors are more stronger in that ES. Also the great toffee-roasty flavor that made the draught so good is quite masked by ..something...hops I believe.

Pours cola black with a thick creamy head. 
Nose is of coffee, burnt sugar, and raisins. 
Taste is fairly sour and acrid, not like a lambic, but there is something sour about it. Thin coffee body, moderate carbonation, raisin puree, very light on roasted barley, strong acrid black malt, not good.

This may be the Guinness that started it all, but it definitely is not the Guinness that many casual beer drinkers worldwide have come to love. GES is too fizzy for my tastes. Without the nitrogenation, it does not have the smooth, creamy texture made popular by Guinness Draught (GD). There’s just far too much carbonation here. While GES tastes similar to Guinness Draught, that great stout chocolate-coffee-roasty flavor is overpowered by the bitterness of the additional hops. 

Another interesting aspect is that GES is not suitable for making half and halfs or black and tans. As a beer newbie, I wasn’t expecting this. My attempts ended up producing a blackish mass of an odd flavor that was only drinkable because I don’t believe in wasting beer.  

The worst part of this beer is the harsh metallic aftertaste. While I can overlook all of its other shortcomings, the aftertaste is what turns an otherwise good beer into something less favorable. After a few sips, the aftertaste becomes less noticeable, but it keeps GES from being a beer I could love.

Really pleasantly surprised by this beer. I love Guinness, but at same time i hate stout beers due to majority being very sweet. This beer is nothing like that. It has a bit of a pine flavor to it. Its quite bitter for stout. It has a nice dark brown colour. Foam is light brown and it disappears quickly. That is the only disappointing thing about this beer. It has a light aftertaste and its very smooth going down.

(br-btl bk/cm-lbl)

thin head, med co2, 

malty up front, slightly bitter on the swallow, slight charcoal aftertaste.  

much better than the regular american Guinness, but nothing great.

Bottle.  Pours black with brown highlights.  The frothy tan head quickly dissipated.  Burnt malt and vinegar aroma.  A tangy acidic flavor was overpowering.  Not much flavor beyond that, maybe a hint of burnt toast.  I like Guinness Draught, but this stuff was almost undrinkable.   Maybe I picked up a bad six-pack.

Smells bitter... tastes it, too. There’s a hint of pine... smokiness... could we just say, "Smells like a log cabin burning down?"
 Tastes... (very!) dark chocolate, old library book, burned coffee, or scorched black tea flavors... and bizarre in-betweens.
 Carbonation... bubbles hit the tip of the tongue hard. (Or I’ve bitten mine.) 
 Liquid rests in glass a deep brown, between root beer and chocolate... head is a light brown.

12 oz bottle. I can’t believe this stuff is brewed by Moosehead. I *hate* Moosehead. This is unbelievable. I figured when I bought this that it was authentic, meaning brewed in Ireland. WTF? Okay, I haven’t even ranked it yet. I will give it a chance. Aroma is excellent. It reminds me of Samuel Smiths’ dark beers. Smells like dough. Pours nearly completely black with a medium head which dissipates into a thin layer of foam. Nice lacing. Taste is somewhat sweet at first but it leaves a bitter aftertaste, then some sourness even. Full-bodied, fully carbonated. Obviously a very well-made stout. Good job Moosehead! Now if you can only apply this level of quality to your flagship skunky lager.

Slightly roasted malty, toffee syrup and nutmeg nose.  Deep black/brown with a subtle amber hue, massive frothy dark tan head.  Roasted coffee candy sweetness, tart bitter bite for balance.  Lively carbonation, medium body, finish is roasted malt with a lingering mouth of neutral smoke.  Tart bitterness holds up nice with the big roasted flavors, beer never feels overwhelming

(bottle) black with nice tan head. Roast malt aromas. Roast malt flavors with dry finish.
Earlier Rating: 3/24/2003 Total Score: 3.8
(bottle) Pitch black, roast coffee flavor. Not as creamy as the nitrogen charged stout on draught.

Bottle from Whole Foods Market, Charlottesville, VA. Pours an opaque black color with a large tan head that sneaks up on you. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of dry grainy notes and slight nuttiness with a tart dark fruit note in the finish. Taste is roasted malts and dark fruits with just a hint of smoke. Fairly hoppy. Medium bodied.

Bottle, Honolulu. Dark, opaque black. Nice head, hints of dark. Smells and tastes like the smell of a busy bar at closing time. Not sure what that is due to. Smoky and not that good to me. I like the can widget better.
Black appearance, Frothy head.  Taste is smokey and choclatey.  Short bitter finish.

12oz bottle.  Clear, very dark walnut body topped with a smallish creamy tan head, rings of lace coat the glass.  Musty, malty aroma with grains, yeast, and an old, damp concrete cellar.  Mouth is medium with foamy carbonation throughout the mouth and a bit watery on the finish.  Flavor is lightly malty--apple skin, nuts, sugar--with a definite roasted malt presence and moderately bitter finish with hops in the pine direction.  A little more exciting than the regular stout, if not so creamy and less traditional.

Poured from a large bottle into a pint glass for its first official rating.  The beer has a black color with a slight dark brown hue and a big creamy-foamy tan head that had long retention and a lot of cling and lacing.  The beer had a light aroma of grainy hops with some roasty caramel and chocolate malts too.  It tasted sweet with a slight caramel presence but was also largely bitter and grainy.  The beer had a watery characteristic and was somewhat thin with a light mouthfeel and average carbonation; modest dryness and a bubbly finish.

Very Sour, slightly ashy, very roasty, dry, some hoppiness, bitter. Smells much paler than it is. Interesting at first, then gross, then I started liking it more. Ultimately ok, but not something I’d want to drink again.
Very dark brown/black, little head retention. Not too much carbonation and a balanced mouthfeel. Light amount of bitterness but still dominate malt.

Picked up at the local corner store, and I have no idea as to why. Nice black body, but nothing special; poured rather thin. Fairly pungent beer with roast and molasses. Syrupy aroma as well; decent aroma. As expected...watered down stout with a surprisingly nice roast flavor. Slight bittering hop at the end, but other than that nothing really going for this beer in terms of depth.  I never have been a Guinness fan and I never will.
Black pour tan head lots of lacing roasted malt aroma... nutty chocolate roasted malt taste with a light bitter finish its ok stuff better on tap of course

19.2 oz. can from Total Wine (Triangle), Raleigh, NC.  Cola-like dark brown pour with a dense and frothy khaki head.  Aroma is mildly sweet with faint notes of coffee and chocolate.  Taste features mild coffee, sweet cocoa, and faint floral hops.  Mildly bitter finish.  There are certainly better stouts out there but one could do much worse.  (Replaces a review from October 30, 2009.  An improvement over that experience which was given a 2.4.  Perhaps the only time you could be pretty confident in obtaining a fresh representation of this would be around St. Patrick's Day so it seemed like a good time to give this another shot.)

12oz bottle. Pours dark with a light brown head, not much of a lace. Aroma has a nice hoppy floral smell. Taste has a bitter flavor with a nice amount of hops to balance the malt. Overall a very nice beer.

Pours the sheets of cascading beer falling downward for which the brand is famous. Once poured, has a dark brown, nearly black appearance; a slice of light brown head. Iconic.

Nutty and roasted smell, with a biscuity sweetness, like shortbread. Really unlike any other stout in the nose. Roasted and dry but a tad sweet as well. Amazing.

Smoky flavor across a roasted, nutty base. Flavor fades part of the way in, sweeter but still smoky. The smokyness really rules here. It’s a smoked porter more than a stout.

Feels creamy and foamy; thick as chocolate milk. A unique smoky, creamy porter. Not the best beer in the world as some claim, but a darn good one.

Bottle from Wegman’s.  Pours a very dark brown color with a giant tan head; very nice.  Malty aroma with some licorice notes.  Coffee, complete with coffee ground bitterness, and toffee are the major players in this medium bodied brew.  Breaking out the classics recently... good!

Bottle 341mL, 5%. Dark, black pour is always weird out of a bottle, always seem to get a wicked amount of foam. Aroma is very much roasted barley, and malt. Taste is a hint of coffee, and the roasted grain. Thick, frothy, and a little drier than Guinness draught, but still quite rich in flavour.

bottle from the LCBO singles bin:

Dark in the glass with a smallish cap. This Labatt version is a lot maltier and sweeter than the Irish version. It seems thin by comparison but this body isn’t bulked up with nitrogen. Decent stout for quaffing with mussels.
Very dark pour.  Dark malts, coffee, cacao, etc.  Very robust flavor and smooth mouthfeel.  Loved it.
A black beer with no head. The aroma is dark malty but not really much to speak of. The taste starts off watery that leads to a dry bitter ending. A boring beer that lacks any kind of flavor profile.
This is pretty much exactly like Guinness Draught but with a bit more of what i’d describe as an iron note.

I prefer this one over the Guinness Draught.  More aroma and flavor, and a slightly thicker palate.  Flavor contains a bit of coffee and some hop bitterness in the finish. Nothing too overboard, but drinkable and smooth.  An excellent session stout that is always easy to find.

2009 Bottle - Accidently drank this on Guinness day coincidently when using it to also make BBQ sauce...Pour is thin and black with a small tan head...aroma is roast and grain, burnt cocoa...flavour is similar, roasted malt, char, nice bitterness on the end...decent...
Guinness is one of my old favorites and a great stand-by. Dry and filling with a great taste.

This is the stout that I grew up with.  I had this one way before the draft Guinness, and in a way, I missed it.  It is shocking that it is brewed by Labatt, and it is brewed by wort from Guinness.  Nevertheless, it is a tad bigger in body than the draft Guinness, but overall, the slight roasted malt flavor and thin body just falls short of other stouts of today’s micro-brewed crazed country.
good coffee and chocolate taste with fair amount of hops and malts and a light head...

This is my second rating of Guinness Extra Stout (North America Edition).  I thought this one deserved a second look because it is my highest-rated massed-produced brew.  I’m not surprised to find it is Labatt’s highest-rated product in their portfolio.  There is no getting around this is a really nice dry stout that is actually affordable.  If this had a little more sweet malts for balance, I would even rate it higher!

tastes like quality black liquorice. dark color, almost black. you really have to drink it out of a glass with enough head to truely enjoy it. but even out of the bottle i’ve grown to like it very much.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The color is a dark brown and is almost black till held to the light, some nice light head and a little lacing.

The smell is of light roasted malt with an oat flavor in the background.

The taste is of roasted malts, some light herbal hop flavor. Has some slight chocolate feel as well with a bready feel.

The feel of this beer is not unlike the Guinness Drought. This is retty smooth with a nice creaminess to it. A light aftertaste but has light mouthfeel

Canadian Guinness ES... take off eh, Canadians know beer... love this stuff, not sure I’ve ever had the real thing from Ireland, but still probably one of the best stouts I’ve ever had... that I can remember... pitch black, tan head, dry, roasted toffee coffee flavor, makes you glad to be alive... one of the better beers!

[bottle]
Roasted barley vinous and dried fruit aroma with a coffee note. Nearly opaque, clear garnet-black with a thin, tan ring. Bitter dark malt flavour with some sour coffee and faint chocolate notes. There is also a spicy hops bitterness. A bit too much bitterness for my palate, but it is balanced by a big body--fairly big for a 5%-er. Medium to full body and almost chewy, medium carbonation, lasting bitter finish.

I can say that Guinness draught is likely the beer that got me inspired me to keep trying more. I finally come around to try this one. 

This is a very good looking beer, fluffy white head and good lace. 

Smell is earthy and hoppy. 

Taste is really nothing like Guinness draught. Reminds me of a dark lager. 

Mouth is relatively thick with high carbonation.
On draft. Pours black with super clean pure white head. Flavor is toasted grain, bitter hop. Nice creamy body. Been a while since I last had a Guinness.
This is very confusing - but I think this is what I had.  This is the better of the Guinness products but still not all that awesome.

Not a bad beer overall but there are way better Stouts out there and this is not as good as Guinness Draught. Poured dark with a tan colored brownish head that was small. The bitterness was there but it really lacked any complexity to get earn over what I rated it. Not bad but not the best. This is defiantly better than some of the beers out there.

This bottle was brewed in Canada, and I don’t think it is as good as the real, Irish-brewed Guinness.  Having said that, it wasn’t so bad.  The colour was right, very dark with traces of creamy foam swirling throughout, and the head was properly creamy.  Aroma was full of malt as was the taste, with a bit of sourness also.

[Bottle] Pours a very dark brown with a nice tan head. Seems to have a stronger flavor profile compared to most tap versions. Still has a dry and roasted character. The difference is it has a little more body (that could be because it isn’t force carbonated from the keg). Anyways, my conclusion is it’s slightly better than draft... but that doesn’t mean I’ll start buying it more.

Bottle.  Pours a black body with a tan creamy coffee head.  A nutty chewy malt aroma with hints of wood, almond,  and vanilla.  Chewy with a dry woody chocolate body and a light creamy finish.  Toffee caramel and a light mineral finish.  Nice, more abv would have made it superb.

Pours brown-black with a considerable amount of pale brown head. Aroma is a bit more present than Guinness Draught, but still a bit vague-a bit of roasted malt and yeast, perhaps. It begins very smooth and rather heavy with a quick followup of bitter coffee. Behind these main flavors, I can taste toffee, malts, and just the slightest hint of some light fruits (apricot and banana?), but I could just be making those last few up, they’re slight enough that it’s hard to tell. I have a good friend that loves Guinness Draught, but swears that this is the most filthy dishwater that he’s ever had the misfortune of pouring down his gullet. I don’t agree-it certainly isn’t the greatest beer out there, but I have had a lot worse.

This beer is by far the biggest difference between on tap and in bottles.  I thought I disliked Guinness until I had it on tap, and now I love it.  The mouthfeel is unbeatable. Take off a full 1.5 points if drinking from a can.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a very deep brown with small ruby highlights and a large, creamy, light brown head.  Roasted malt, toast, caramel, and light coffee notes in the nose.  Medium-low carbonation with a medium-rich mouthfeel.  Caramel, roasted malt, lactose, and a bitter coffee note on the palate.  Actually quite pleasant and a nice departure from Guinness Draught.
