Medium-short finish with a bit of mild bitterness lingering.  Great lacing all the way down the glass.  Overall a pretty decent stout!

Poured out a dark dark brown beer that is lighter than normal ’on tap everywhere’ Guinness and pours out a large bubbly tan crown that has no staying power. My beer is popping like Rice Krispies. The aroma is poor when on the cold side but does gain some credibility when warmer: light caramel and toasted malts, chocolate (if you leave it sit long enough) and maybe a touch of smoke (probably not). The taste is ruined by the carbonation. Seems too thin for a stout but really isn’t. Something tart, toasted and caramel malts, some hops that totally do not fit in. Over carbonated, medium bodied, finishes a bit tart and with no impressionable aftertaste except for a slight burnt bitterness. I really wanted some sweetness out of this bottle. This beer sucks. Labatt should be happy they have a stout in their line-up and Guinness should be totally embarased for this under license sub par product. This is a beer that I do not want to have to open and pour into a glass and wait an hour to drink to enjoy. With that said I had no problem drinking it. However, the bottom 1/4 of my glass smells like urine. Good times.
Poured a pitch black with a good-sized tan head. Aromas of coffee and roasted malts. Good flavors of chocolate, coffee and malt.

12oz bottle. Pours a black body with an inch thick, dense and creamy, tan head that dissipates quickly and leaves lots of sticky lacing. Aroma is malty with some toasted fruits, burnt roasts, and a bit of chocolate. Not a lot going on here. Flavor is a light amount of sweet malts and milky chocolate with a cheap, burnt taste that lingers in the aftertaste. Medium bodied, smooth, and somewhat dry. Overall, its drinkable, but cheap. The burnt roasts are way too astringent and don’t balance the sweet malts at all. I prefer the draught.
first illegal beer i ever had at 16 or 17, enjoy the draught version a little more, but a classic nonetheless.
Smooth and easy to drink. Medium bodied stout, my first introduction to good beers as well as many other’s.

Poured black with a solid, though not thick, head, excellent retention and lacing. Roasted malt aroma and flavors, with a slight bitterness. Some coffee and chocolate as well, if you look for it. Creamy mouthfeel, malts win out in the end. Much better than the Draught.

Although beers probably should be rated independently, I can’t help but dock this brew a few points with it being Labatt’s interpretation of Guinness. It’s a version not quite as thick, malty, or interesting.

12fl oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Pours deep dark brown with massive amounts of long-lasting creamy tan head.  Aroma is light and roasty.  Flavor is roasty, almost coffee-like with some sweet notes in there.  Long bitter finish.  Well crafted brew.
Tasty as always - its Guinness. Bitter finish, roasted malts, pretty standard.
It’s guinness, it’s great, drink it and you’ll get superpowers or something along those lines. Seriously tho, smooth greatness as always

Black color...opaque.  Pretty thick, fluffy head, with great lacing.  Slightly bitter malt aroma.  Very heavy roasted malt flavor up front...mouthfeel is only a tad crisp, with good body.  Bitter maltiness overwhelms the back.  Finish is long, and filled with the flavor of dry, roasted malt.  Much different than a typical dry stout...this brew consists of a uniquely strong bitterness, as well as an overly robust flavor of roasted malt.

Very confusing...multiple breweries brewing the same terrible beer. Again with the mouthfeel. Again with the flavor (blah). Aroma is weak. I realize this is a dry stout and as such will not have the profile of the more prevalent Imp stouts, but I’ve had better dry stouts.

When I think of a dark beer, Guinness Extra Stout is what comes to mind.  Dark color and a mystical but bitter taste.  However, those qualities are to be expected from a stout.  Will drink again and can only imagine drinking this in Ireland amongst the Irish.  A good, but not perfect, beer.
Dark red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, roasted, coffee, hop. Flavour is sweet, roasted, coffee, hop, malt. Medium body...it is what it is...

Bottle courtesy of Retorp. Pours a dark brown to black with creamy tan head. Aroma is roasted and malty with nots of caramel, bitter coffee, some hints of dark fruit. Flavor is mainly roasted malts with some lighter notes of caramel, honey, some dark fruits. Generally medium to full body with a roasted bitter finish.

Strong aroma of roasted malts, and slightly alcoholic on the nose.Black as the night, almost no head. Flavour is very strong and bitter. Roasted malts dominate the palate. Not as thick or as smooth as guinness. All in all I prefer the original.

Slightly sweet aroma of chocolate malts and a tiny bit of coffee.  Taste is very similar to Guinness Draught, but it is a little bit stronger and more bitter.  Tastes more like a stout.  Overall I prefer the Draught because it is smoother, and it is more unique.  This extra stout has to compete with all other stouts, so it doesn’t seem as good by comparison.

its like guinness draught but actually tastes like a stout. more malty flavor than the draught version but not enough flavor or alcohol to warrant the "extra". solid stout but there are many that are better.
Fine beer. Stout, but not exactly what I would expect from an "extra" stout. Good beer, but not excellent.
Pours dark with a tan head. Strong roasted barley and chocolate flavor. Thought I’d like this one more than I did.

pours a dark, dark brown with a tan head.  a rather weak aroma of sweet malts, coffee, dark chocolate, and hazelnuts.  flavours of  Dark chocolate, dark coffee, biscuits and nuts, with a basementy, almost leathery component, complimented by generously bitter hops.

For a king of the beers, this is nothing to write home about. Weak, a little bit of roast but nothing enduring, Dishwater and cheap malt base undergird this overrated swill. Some nuttiness and bitter. 
"But it’s so much better on tap in Ireland." Gimme a break.

Guinness created the category stout with this beer. By definition, one would expect it to score well if not the best. Honestly, I’ve always found Murphy’s to be a bit smoother, richer and creamier. This glass was well-poured by the bartender--two thirds high, rest, then finished. The head was two fingers thick, light beige and produced beautiful lace. The color was dark, dark brown, nearly black. 

The aroma was dark malt with strong coffee and biscuit notes. There was also a slight yeast smell. This was far subtler than I expected. This might be my only real disappointment. 

The taste features sweet, malty flavors up front followed by a hop balance. The aftertaste offers a lingering burnt, black patent malt. The liquor is viscous and rich. While not as creamy as some stouts, it is a very full bodied. Overall, an excellent beer that commands respect from beginning to end.
Bottle. Almost a black pour with a dark head. Aroma of coffee and malts. Taste was light coffee with a bit of caramel. Nothing remarkable.
(bottle). Pours a black color. Large head with tan color.  Heavy lacing.  Has a nutty aroma.  Flavor of nut and coffee. Creamy finish with slight bitterness. Soft carbonation.

Overall Impression: 
I know, this beer is the greatest...I get it...Just doesn’t do it for me...

Pours motor oil color with a tuft of head that stayed for the entirety of the evening.  Nose is roasted malt, dark chocolate, hops and creamy sweetness.  Flavor is watery malt and hops.  Finishes with a terrible waft of the rings of hell.  Very thin from what I remembered of Guinness.  Give me an Mbege any day!

Oh I love me some Guinness. With age I’ve come to appreciate the stout beers especially Guinness. I have yet to try the European, UK and Ireland versions but all in due time. 

Pours a deep, rich thick super dark brown with about a full inch and a half head. Head was light brown and slowly dissipated.  Flavor of roasty, maybe woody, slightly bitter brew. We’ll see if it’s true form is better.

The aroma is not quite to style. It’s only got a bitter hops element and alcohol as well as a toasted adjunct malt. The appearance is right, it’s dark brown with a large tan head. The flavor is awful. It’s astringently bitter with an over brewed coffee and corn finish. The palate is thin. This is actually bad.
Earlier Rating: 3/20/2005 Total Score: 3.1
I don’t know if it was just the lack of nitrogen and CO2 but this Guinness does taste different from its Draught brother. Smell is very rich with a toasted malt and caramel aroma. Color is dark brown and had a larger head than the draught version. Taste is much more acidic and bitter than the draught version. I feel like this one has a higher hops content as well. Same toasted maltiness that lasts through the finish. Sweet coffee and alcohol aftertaste.
Bottle.  Pours a nice black with decent cream head.  Good malt flavor but far too carbonated for its own good.  A little bitter overall.

Bottle.  Pours a deep brown, almost black color, with a thin, light and bubbly white head.  Aroma is mostly sweet but subtle.  Taste is similar to guinness draught in the watery base, but there is more to this.

Blah. this is just your typical run of the mill Guinness with carbonation. Not much of an aroma other than a little alcohol. Pour was a nice deep dark brown with a 2 finger tan head. Taste was very bland. Roasted dark malt is detectable with a bitter hoppy aftertaste. Nice carbonation which makes the beer better than the draught version. Very dry, hence the name. Not terrible but very average.
Earlier Rating: 11/28/2006 Total Score: 3.2
Old numbers- Aroma 7 Appearance 4 Flavor 8 Palate 4 Overall 18- Total 4.1
Rated this out of memory before I actually tried any craft beer. Woke up.
------------------------------------------------

Love the Guinness! The dark tan head with the milky taste makes it look almost like an ice cream float made with motor oil. Mcro light lager drinkers beware. This is the antithesis of all you adore! This beer begs to be drank in pints in Ireland with hobbits.

Poured dark brown/black, roasted malts, coffee, molasses, little bready, little chocolate, slight dark fruits.
Earlier Rating: 9/29/2008 Total Score: 3.5
Dark brown, roasted malts, little coffee, little hoppy, slight sour, dry finish.

I think this is the right one.  Draught at an Irish restaurant that says they fly their kegs in from Ireland.  Poured black with creamy tan head, built into a traditional pint.  Aroma of roast malt, fresh barley toast and molasses.  Creamy body, with more malt, molasses and a bit of coffee.  Malty finish, with the hop edge and touch of chocolate.  Light enough for a session beer.
Earlier Rating: 8/25/2007 Total Score: 3.9
Bottle. Poured black with thick tan head.  Aroma of malt and some bread.  Flavour, bittersweet chocolate, coffee, and malt.  Lasting finish with more coffee.  A very worthy stout

Bottle.  A very dark mahogany pour with a big and creamy dark khaki head that leaves lacing down the side of the glass.  Some roasty maltiness and slight hints of citrus in the predominantly sour aroma.  Goes down thin to medium-bodied with a good deal of carbonation.  Definitely leans more toward a porter than a stout.  Roasty malts and a toasty nuttiness start things off taste-wise.  Some definite semi-sweet chocolate and black coffee in there too.  Sour lemons and bitter grapefruits at the end.  Fairly drying finish.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown/black.  Aroma is roasted malt.  Mouthfeel is fizzy and prickly on the tongue.  Taste is roasty with some citrus/apricot tang, chocolate, seems to have some astringency from roasted malt.  Hops level is moderate-high.  Just ok.

#700 In honor of St Pattys Day.

Pours a deep brown almost black with a large soapy head that leaves a ton of sticky lacing down the side of my glass. Aroma is malts, chocolate, barley and some sourness. Flavor is sour, bitter malts, roast, cocoa, coffee, barley, grains. Quite dry, but easy to drink.  Bitter dry finish. Much better than nitro guinness, but not nearly as robust as the foriegn extra.

From bottle pours somewhat transluscent black with ruby halo and beige suds. Low aroma of malts and a tinge sour, with both characteristics more noticeable in flavor that is dominated by coffee and specialty malt notes. Thin body and somewhat watery finish.

On tap.  Pours almost black, with a hint of red, with nice thick capuccino coloured head, which leaves nice lacing.  Aroma and flavour of roasted malt.  Pretty good stuff, considering it’s a Labatt brewed product

Appearance: Pours a dark brown with a picture perfect foamy head.  As opposed to the "draught" offering, this head is more sudsy than creamy.
Aroma: Bready, twangy malts are coming out of the foamy cap.

Taste: Roasted bitter malts, a bit of bitter metallic hops. Almost comes across like a dark dutch lager??

Mouthfeel: Heavy, but not really thick.

Overall: This beer is nothing like it’s counter part. It is rather hoppy, has a almost skunky twang, and has a completely different mouthfeel.  Considering all the various lore I read online about who brews this beer, and in what country, God only knows how far this beer has traveled to get to my local Whole Foods, and what the bottle has been through.

Bottle.  Poured a black color with a tan, frothy head and great lacing.  Aroma of roasty and coffee malts.  The beer had a medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation, and a dry finish.  The flavor had a light sweetness and was very dry with almost a slight bitterness.  While I have started to really like more and more dark beers, this one is still a bit dry for me.
Had from a can. Eazy as hell to sink Less generic than their draught.Nothing much to elaborate.Roasted coffee ..creamy malt and burnt palates.

12 oz bottle.  Poured a dark brown color with a one finger tan head.  The aroma was roasted malt, coffee and a hint of baker’s chocolate.  The flavor was mainly roasted malt, but hints of coffee, nuts and dark fruits are present.  The finish is very sweet.  
Earlier Rating: 10/23/2008 Total Score: 3.3
Bottle.  Poured a dark black with a two finger brown head.  Aroma and flavor were roasty, and the flavor was caramel malt.

Pours a deep dark color with a decent tan head that laces the glass nicely.  Aroma is a little malty and coffeeish.  Flavor is mostly just bitter, though the roasted malts are somewhat noticeable.  Considering all of the better available stouts out there, I didn’t care much for this.

I’m not sure if this is the right one, this is brewed in New Brunswick, Canada.
Minimal roasted malt and a hint of molasses and caramel smell with a minimal aroma of coffee and maybe dark chocolate. Some citrus esters in the hop aroma.
Pours a black coffee color with a hint of an amber hue. The tannish and fizzy head dissipated within minutes, there was some sediment in the bottle.
Lightly sweet, acidic, and bitter roasted/burnt malt taste with flavors of dark chocolate and coffee. There are some esters in the hops flavor such as maybe orange.
Full bodied, almost creamy and slightly resinous texture, soft almost flat carbonation, and a metallic and slightly astringent finish.
This is drinkable, has a slight sour astringency.

[Look]: Dark brown to black with a nice tan color head. 
[Smell]: Roasted malts, coffee, hint of dark chocolate. 
[Taste]: Roasted malts and coffee, slight hint of chocolate and bitter nuts.  Dry fruity after taste.  Medium to heavy bodied. 
[Overall]: Pretty good stout.
Bottle. Not nearly as satisfying to me as a Gunness Draught from a widget can or on tap. It is an OK stout but there are so many better options.
Now this is a stout that I can get in to. Had everything in it that I was looking for in a stout.
not good.  Thin, watery, only real flavor is the astringent acidic aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours a jet black with a two finger creamy head. Leaves lacing on the side of the glass. Aroma is chocolate, caramel, deep brown sugar. Flavor is very robust, roasted malts. Very rich and creamy. Great aftertaste. Very good beer.

Pint draft. Poured a dark chocolate with a thick creamy head which lasted for the entire duration of the drink, with heavy lacing. Aroma of malt, chocolate, and brown sugar. Accents strongly of chocolate and coffee with a subtle alcohol finish. A little boring and lacking in complexity, but better than most widely distributed beers. I was not thinking about the beer while eating my accompanying meal of roast beef and Yorkshire pudding, which is unfortunate, and indicates its uninterestingness. I suppose I have been spoiled by the Belgian Trappists for too long. Still a tasty beer.

a beautiful pour with a nice light brown/tan head. taste is of smoky/lightly burnt coffee, the aroma though is its best feature. this was a dollar cheaper than regular guiness (i dont know why) a sixer but nothing more special than its brother. good beer.
Poured with a light brown head. Dark roasted coffee on the nose. Flavors of dark chocolate and roasted coffee with a pleasant bitterness on the finish. An absolute classic.
Poured a dark rich black with a creamy brown head. Slight coffee aromas rise through and each drink is greeted with coffee flavors and just a little hint of bitterness. absolutely delicious.

pours a very deep brown-black color with a thick mocha head.  nice retention and lacing.  very malty aroma with caramel,  and burnt toffee.  flavor is also malty and displays caramel sweetness followed by a light roastiness.  mouthfeel a little thin for my stout tastes but not watery.

Bottle.  Here we go, St. Patty’s day drinking special!  Pours a very dark black color that takes some time to settle.  Head is very dense, off white with solid foam.  Aromas of chocolate, roasted malts, and a hint of brown sugar.  Mouthfeel is creamy, then thick, then back to creamy.  Taste is actually very smooth with some roasted malts strong initially then followed by a nice light hop taste.  Great beer.

Deep brown with a decent sized beige head. Aroma is of roasted malt and coffee. Taste is of bitter chocolate, roasted malt and coffee.
Earlier Rating: 1/30/2009 Total Score: 3.4
Bottle. Dark with a medium head. Aroma is of grains and dark roasted coffee.  Flavor is of slightly burnt grains with some alcohol warmth.

Dark brown with a dark tan head that is creamy on top and foamy underneath.  Good lacing.  Earthy aroma with malt and some roasted coffee, and some doughy yeast aromas.  Taste has metallic characteristics, very malty, with a slight bitterness in the finish and a roasted coffee-like aftertaste.  Not nearly as smooth as the nitrogen infused Guinness, but still a great brew with a great history.

12oz bottle. Pours black with a thin beige head. What the hell? Aroma is like light beer...Didnt expect that. Flavor has a bit of woody/smokiness...but then fades to a nasty light beer flavor. Really light mouthfeel...Nasty aftertaste...not smooth. This stuff sucks. You get excited as it pours into the glass...After the first smell and sip...You realize its a wolf in sheeps clothing.

From a large bottle. Pours dirty black with a choco brown top. Smells of roasted malts, nuts, no choco common to other stouts. Tastes of roasted nuts, light smoke, light coffee conclusion. Light in texture. Not complex. Tolerable.

Bottle.  Smells roasty, almost smokey, and malty sweet.  Tastes like smoked coffee beans and a little chocolatey.  Slightly sweet with malt, and roasty.  Sweet long aftertaste.  Nice body and drinkability.

12 oz bottle... much better than that bullshit Draught can. Still, it is non-carbonated guinness garbage. drinks like water with a little carbonation. 

PS. don’t try to mix black and tans in a trappist glass

12 oz bottle. Pours a thick black color with a nice full, mocha head that has ok retention and very nice lacing. Aroma is mostly toasty malt and roast aromas. Flavor is mostly chocolate and roasted malt and a bit of a tobacco finish. A little thin for what I was expecting on the palate. Very drinkable

A Classic, I love Guinness Extra Stout, it does not have all the crazy new flavors of any of the micro brewed beers that have all come along.  But this is a true stick to its roots beer.  Great dark color, with a dark flavor, slight coffee flavor.  With a nice brown head. Bottle.

I wasn’t sure whether to rate this here as the bottle says "Brewed and bottled by Guinness Brewing Company New Brunswick, Canada. it’s the same "little brown bottle I’ve always seen in the US, but it doesn’t look like any of the pics here.Very dark, near black, rich tan head, light aroma of roasted malt with slight vinegar and peat, flavor of sour medium body malt with strong bitter finish. I’ve been drinking this all my life and think of it as the first craft brew - where do you think DFH will be in 200 years. This beer is definately different than draft from a tap!  Only very well used and maintained taps taste better and I won’t even rate the swill that they label as "draft" in those black bottles and cans! But the little brown bottle is the elixer of life. I can quickly rattle off ten stouts I like better than G. Extra, but all of them taste somewhat similar to one another and none of them taste any thing like the original dry stout from Eire!
Nice stout, lite bodied, no hops, lite aroma.  After so many monster american micro ales and beligum ales this one feels less than...

Like OD40oz, I’ve not rated this yet, and am surprised as I’ve been drinking this one for what seems to be forever.  Maybe that’s why!  Typical lasting, albeit thinner head compared to its draught counterpart.  All the same flavors, coffee/roasted grain, caramel, and freshlyt crushed grain aromas, biscuity, malts with a hint of diacetyl. Typical Guinness "tang" , but in both flavor and aroma, there is a greater hop presence whereas it is pretty well absent (IMHO) in the draught version.  Always solid, and one of my first loves!

WOW I love Guinness draught so tried this. Not at all what i expected. The aroma really reminded me of Labatt Blue with a hint and i mean a hint of guinness. That kinda ruined it for me being from NY i had my fill of Blue and Blue light in college.

I was surprised to see that I hadn’t rated this beer as I thought that Guinness Draught was the same as this.  Poured a nice black with a decent sized foamy, beige head.  Malty, coffee smell.  This didn’t seem as chocolatey or as dry as the draught which I like better.
Bottle pours a near black body with a healthy tan head. Roasted coffee is the dominant characteristic, maybe some raisin and hop bitterness as well.

Jan 1, 2009  
Dark colour, nice head. Standard Guinness with distinctive wheat and coffee notes. Lovely, as usual, although on tap is still much better.

Looks is very black and a pretty good beige colored head.  Smell is malts, coffee, very roasty, and maybe some chocolate.  Taste is dry, little bitter, malts, and coffee.  A fall back drink when you can find nothing else, but quickly losing it appeal to me.  Watery. 
Earlier Rating: 3/13/2008 Total Score: 3.3
Bottle. Dark with a medium head. Aroma is of grains and dark roasted coffee.  Flavor is of slightly burnt grains with some alcohol warmth.
Dark colour, nice head. Standard Guinness with distinctive wheat and coffee notes. Lovely, as usual, although on tap is still much better.

12oz bottle.  Poured a nice thick, creamy 2 finger foam that lasted about halfway down the glass. It had a light, roasty smell. The taste was very good. It starts out smooth and creamy before it becomes slightly acidic and finishes with a refreshing hoppiness. This beer has a lighter mouthfeel than most stouts and porters, but it is very creamy and satisfying. A very drinkable stout with a refreshing finish that is dry and hoppy, with a slightly sour edge. .
pretty much black in color, mostly just found it to be thin, very bitter and strong.  sucks drainpour.  Guinness must make more money off of their branded junk then they do the beer.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a thin beige head and moderate lacing.   Nose is bread, toasted malt and some dark fruits.  Taste is burnt toast, cocoa and light bitter coffee in the finish.  Lighter mouth feel than the regular, but this does not have the nitro boost.  Decent stuff.

22oz bottle. Quite surprised to see I hadn*t already rated this one. Pours pitch black with a fully receding tan head. Aroma of mild roast, pale malt, toffee. Taste is actually fairly mild, light chocolate, nuts, and roast malt. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, slightly chalky [basic] with soft carbonation. Enjoyable, but this is weak sauce compared to the Kalamazoo Stout. 
Earlier Rating: 10/22/2005 Total Score: 3.1
Bought this thinking I was buying my first foreign stout. Pours black with a foamy tan head.  Aroma of roast, burnt chocolate, nutty malts, and molasses.  Taste is miild, with slight roast and chocolate.  Heavy bodied with a creamy mouthfeel.  Pretty uneventful, and quite dissapointing.  I need to find Lion Stout again...

12 oz bottle.  Pours a thick black color with a nice full, mocha head that has ok retention and very nice lacing.  Aroma is mostly toasty malt and roast aromas.  Flavor is mostly chocolate and roasted malt and a bit of a tobacco finish.  A little thin for what I was expecting on the palate.  Very drinkable.  I like it but it pales compared to the Draught.

Pours mahogany with reds coming through the corners when held to the light. 3-4 finger chunky tan head with good retention nice thick persitent lacing.. Aroma is roast, raisins, molasses, dates, and spiced ginger cookies. Flavor has a nice char roast malt, flame toasted french bread, on top of a sweet slice of carmely date nut bread. After a little bit the bitter hop notes come in with a earthy hebal slide to them, finish is slightly bitter hops, with the various roast flavors dissipating from a sort of tannic charred wood taste. Honestly I really like this beer but it really tastes kind of watered down, I would love to sample some of the versions the rest of the world gets.

The Extra Stout gives a thick, creamy head that is only the slightest bit spongy. The head is straw-colored and the beer itself a caramel-tinted deep black. The nose is delicate, with major malt character. A strong biscuit and toast brown malt aroma hearkens back to the porter roots of the style. Light caramel and roast add complexity.

The flavor has a similar detached bitter astringency as in the tap version, but there is also a significant contribution of flavor from brown and roast malt. While the roast still seems underbalanced for the bitterness, it is certainly much closer to ideal. In addition, there is a meaty yeast character that was entirely lacking on tap. The palate is thick and creamy without being cloying or undrinkable.

uprating from 9/5/8/4/17 = 4.3.

i’m dumbfounded as to how this isn’t the Reference Stout the world over.  i’m liking this too much right now to find any fault with it.  way preferable to the nitro’d draught version everyone knows about.   malt profile has sweetness (cereal? chocolate?) and roastiness, along with fruitiness (raisin?).  it’s there in the flavor and aroma.  the aroma also brings to mind the best of the german doppels (asam-bock, celebrator).
Blah. Not even as good as regular overrated guinness, but at least with more of a dry stout feel to it and less watery. Stil not tasty though.

Pours dark black into a creamy head which never really dissipates, but fades into lingering heavy lacings on the side of the glass. Aroma of creamy yeasty hops and roasted malts and barley. This is the very beer I first had on tap that lead me to check into microbrews. After trying it, I KNEW that my ’style’ was porters and stouts. If it is on tap when I belly up to the bar, you can bet I’m having a Guinness!

Bottle.  Pours a near black with ample brown head.  Light aromas of roast, near sweet caramel, and a twinge of lactic acidity.  Flavor has a tartness to it.  Velvety medium full chewy body.  Lingering chocolate bitterness in a long aftertaste.

i am admittedly trying a bottle that has been in a garage without temperature control for several years... but it smells like a stout, but not like guinness draught usually does. the taste is sour at first, then turns sweeter than most guinness i am used to, it tastes a lot less burnt and more rich and sugary. i think it has gone off a tiny bit however, it is almost completely uncarbonated and had a microscopic head that disappeared completely. never was the biggest fan of guinness, but was hoping the great age of it would help it do something more interesting.

lol re:rate after not even checking in a decade - it's a good solid beer.

12oz bottle from the LCBO
I have some more of these at home will do a full rating SOON

12 oz bo9ttle into shaker.  This beer and Sierra Nevada pale ale turned me onto flavorful beer.  Until last night, I hadn’t had one of these in a couple of years.  It was very one dimensional, all roasted malt on flavor and aroma. and the aroma was pretty soft.  Not very special - one was fine, but I went for the SN pale for my second.
Black pour dark amber head.  Nose was smokey as well as the taste.  Great stout when at close to room tempature.  Roasty.  good.

Pours dark brown with a brown head. Aroma is of malts and some coffee. Taste is far more bitter than the draught version. The bitterness in each sip is followed by the taste of lightly roasted malts and bread. Not very drinkable and somewhat dissapointing.

Pours black with a tan head that disapates.  Tastes of malt, however not a strong taste.  Extremely drinkable due to the lack of depth.

1Pint 6oz. bottle

Pours a dark brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma is very malty and nutty.  Taste is of roasted malts and coffee up front with slight bitterness towards the back.  The carbonation is alright, but nowhere near the mouthfeel of regular Guinness on a nitrogen tab.  Still a good and decently drinkable beer.
I’ve enjoyed this beer many, many times! It’s the best of all "Guinness" products available in N. America, regardless of whether it’s brewed in Dublin or eh? Canada?

Bottled.  Pours a very dark brown color with a large thick tan head.  Lighter aroma of roasted malt and dark chocolate.  The flavor is lighter biscuity malt, some roast, dark chocolate.  This is lighter in body and has a dry slightly bitter finish.

Pours a motor oil black with a beige frothy head. Aroma is roasted malts, and light coffee notes, pretty mild and uninteresting. Flavour is mild to begin with, but as the beer washes to the back of the mouth the flavour opens up with roasted malts, barley, and coffee. Finishes on a unsweetened chocolate note.  
Earlier Rating: 7/15/2007 Total Score: 3.4
Pitch black with a thin froathy head. Aroma is weak smoked malt. The flavour is mainly roasted malts, with notes of dark chocolate with a semi sweet finish. The palat has the right amount of carbonation, with a velvety smooth mouth feel. Not a bad beer in any way, just nothing fantastic. Nothing like the nitro can version. They both have there ups and downs but this version is better overall.
Comes in a can with those little carbonation balls, great for Car Bombs, but not much else. A TransAtlantic journey kills the magic of European ales.
Pours dark brown/black with tan head. Roasted malt aroma. Sweet roated malt flavor with lots of bitterness. Mediun to full body with minimal carbonation.
Getting notebook online. Bottle. Very malty sour bitterness. Not much fruitiness. Really hits the roof of the mouth hard.
Bottle pours opaque black with thin tan head. Aroma is malt and some hops. First taste is sweet malt then hops. The finish is dry with little hops bitterness. Average.
I liked the import extra stout better than this one. dark pour. Nice head. Smooth guinnes taste

I have had this beer on several occations, but have not rated it until now.  I had it on tap at Riverbend.  The pour was a dark brown, almost black.  The aroma was roasted malts and chocolate.  The flavor was watered down and it went down way smoother than I remembered.  The finish is a tad bitter leaving a aftertaste slightly comparable to coffee.
Not much that has not been said, obviously.  Dry and more sour that what I expected, also very alkaline.  Very mild malt component,  very burnt and earthy.
Malt, roast, lots of water. Burnt aroma and flavor. Thin, not very interesting or enjoyable. It is what it is.

Despite it’s commonality, still a note worth stout. Deep coffee and chocolate malt, a smooth, milky texture. It’s a full bodied stout that’s still light enough to be a session beer. Legendary head when poured from a nitro tap. Yeah, it’s good.

On tap:  Finally rating this one.  The pour and cascade are well documented...as are the flavors really.  Mild and refreshing yet with "darker" flavors.  This is an easy choice for me at most places without an interesting selection of beers.
Dark and robust, bitter with a thick brown head. Has a wonderful roasted flavor. A nice brew.
Almost black, thin tan head and lace. Nose of mild coffee and chocolate. Fairly smooth, kind of a thinnish body and palate. Some decent coffee flavors and bitterness, moderately dry

deep black pour, aroma of roasted malt, and a touch of coffee, and some cheap grain. Nice thick mouth feel, some roasted malt in the flavour, and more cheap grain, meh. Decent stout. I prefer the draught out of the can. 
Earlier Rating: 3/12/2007 Total Score: 3.3
a decent stout. i’ve had it before, but couldnt remember it. Bought a 6 pack today. looks nice, aroma is quite bready. flavour is a your basic stout, nothing spectaculay, but its solid. nice bittnerness.
Pours nearly black with a tan head and smells like malts and alcohol. Tastes like malt and some slight coffee. Finishes light and dry. Not a bad brew.
Good overall, but not as good as the draught. Pours dark with a brown head that dissipates fairly quickly. The body is pretty much black.  Some coffee-ish flavors with roasted malts.

(Bottle).  Malt and coffee aroma.  Black with brown head.  Mouthfeel is pleasingly full.  However, the flavor balance, at least to me, leaves something to be desired.  There is roastiness and a touch of coffee and malt....but nothing seems to work together.  Then, there’s a rather weird bitterish finish that jars instead of satisfies.

Opaque black pour with a tan head - nice and thick fluffy.  Malty aroma with some chocolate and caramel.  Nice bitter malty flavor with molasses and a creamy coffee flavor.  A bit watery, but overall a good beer.  A classic!

12 oz bottle poured into pint glass.  Couldnt pin point any unique aroma that differed from the Guinness Draught, which was malt and coffee in scent.  The appearance is darker and the head was more tannish in color, but it did not stick around as long as with the nitro-can.  Flavor was better than the draught, very nice roasted malt flavor.  Overall it is a very good beer, just still surprised its only 5%!   I think I need to try this on tap to re-evaluate and get a better impression.

I cant believe I havent rated this previously.  Pours a very dark almost black color with fluffy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts.  Flavor seems to me to be a bit more bitter than the Draught.  Also thinner mouthfeel due to the lack of nitrogen.  Decent beer.
Earlier Rating: 10/20/2006 Total Score: 3.4
Personally, what this gains in alcohol content over the Draught it loses in taste.  Still a good beer, but not quite as good as the Draught.  Much thinner also, with a more bitter taste.
Pours dark dark brown with a light tan head.  Taste is of roasted grain and light hop bitterness.  Not as sweet as the others.
Black with fluffy tan head which sticks around for most of the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts and coffee.  Flavor is of bitter coffee with hops and roasted malt at the finish

Very dark with light brown head.  Pleasant, slightly sweet aroma.  Less smooth and more dry than Guinness Draught with more carbonation and a less creamy aftertaste.  One of those beers where I enjoy the second more than the first.
Magnificient, dark brown/black with a nice fluffy light brown head.  Lightly roasted and moderately hoped.  Nice dry finish.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown/black, with a red hue when held to the light. The head is thin, clingy, pillow and tan in color.  Taste is of roasted malt, smoke, hops and is bitter in the finish.  Has more body than the regular Guinness Draught.  Aroma matches the taste.  Overall, this is a pretty enjoyable and fulfilling beer that isn’t bad to have occasionally.
Pours a very dark brown with medium, light brown head and very little lacing. Dry tasting with hints of chocolate and light hops. Not my favorite stout but a good choice.
dry flaky aroma of chalk, chocolate, coffee, wood. much clearer than the draught. Delicious dry thin finish with nice hop aftertaste. Prefer maybe a little more smoother for my stouts.

Not so different from normal Guinness draught but the initial head is not as creamy or as long lasting. Lacing is almost absent as well. A little richer on the cocoa and chocolate notes and the alcohol content is still completely masked. Overall much lighter than Foreign Extra and slightly bolder than normal Guinness. If I had a choice though I would stick to normal Guinness on tap.
Guinness was my first beer a couple of years ago. It was rough at first. But after you get used to it you can appreciate the fullness and richness of this beer.

People can knock this workhorse all they want, but it’s often the best chocie on tap in 90% of the place you find it.  Much lighter in taste than its reputation, you find yourself loving it again every time you have to "settle" for it.

Best from the tap. Much better aroma that way. Pours dark, like motor oil, which is great. The flavor is of medium bitterness, but also has a bit of sweetness at times, especially when the head is still present. A good dark beer, but maybe too familiar to be appreciated anymore.

I do prefer this over the regular, but not by much.  Certainly more malt and more punch in the nose and on the tongue.  Heavier and more coffee and chocolate flavors are certainly there.  Cheers!
Earlier Rating: 6/24/2008 Total Score: 4.1
I forgot to rate one of the beer kings?  Yikes.  Anyway there isn’t much to add except when given a choice of your typical 20 beers on tap I ALWAYS go for this one.  Old faithful it is.

pours black, frothy tan head.  didn’t sniff much, but a hint of malty sweetness.  very creamy, roasty, sweetish flavor.  i didn’t catch any hoppiness.  a pretty disappointing drink, and way too expensive at my burbank, ca. hotel.

I liked this better than guinness draft. The nitrogen in the draft kills most of the interesting flavors that exist in the extra stout. It pours a dark black with a tan head that leaves decent lacing. Hints of coffee in the flavor with malt dominating.

Bottle. I’m not sure if it’s this version though. I bought it in San Diego, US. But it’s imported by DIAGEO from Canada. And another ’but’: on label it’ writen that it’s produced by Guinness Brewing Company in New Brunswick, Canada - not London. I’m confused with all those versions, can someone help?

Pretty good dry stout. Lots of roasted malts on the palate with some coffee. Roasted, not too intensely bitter and a dry finish. Pretty good brew, wouldnt pick it over the draught, but if selection was limited id go with this one and not be unhappy about it.
Earlier Rating: 12/6/2007 Total Score: 4
Pours very nicely with a rich creamy head. Best served very very cold. i have found that the warmer this brew gets the more intense the stoutness becomes. Excellent roasted flavor and bitter finish.

Decent dry stout and pretty reliable.  I don’t have a whole lot to add beyond what has been noted here - roasty, slightly bitter, not very sweet.  Not a top choice by any stretch but is a decent alternative when selection is limited.

Bottle:  Pours a deep brown with a large, frothy tan head.  Nose is rather hoppy with light cocoa and some roastiness.  Tastes more roasty and dark chocolate based.  Some light bitters with plenty of roastiness and a little molasses.  Thinner on the body, but a decent brew.
Earlier Rating: 4/4/2006 Total Score: 3.9
Definite flavor present here.  Coffee and chocolate tones, malts, roastiness, and a nice balanced amount of hops.  Color is dark brown/blackish and thick.  Finished with a nice bitterness, but overall is very smooth.
Dry is right. They took the parts of Guinness Draught that I liked and subdued them here.

Poured from 12oz bottle a dark brown black with a large frothy tan head that left blotchy legs as the foam receded.  Nose of a tart roast grain rises through the foam.  The flavor goes much the same with a mild tartness leading to a roasted smooth grain with a touch of ash or smokiness, coffee, and a very light caramel without any sweetness.  The palate is dry, tart, and mildly bitter.  A sipping beer to be sure but easy to drink.

Pours black with one finger tan head. Aromas of roasted malt and a dash of hops. not too complex, but it goes down easy. Roasty and relatively flavorful. Good if its the only thing available, but otherwise I shy away. 
Earlier Rating: 10/2/2007 Total Score: 3.5
Black with thick creamy lasting tan head. Quite similar to Guinness Draught, but without a widget and slightly more bitter. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Flavour was a little on the bitter side, with roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate. Definitely going to stick to draught.

6/24/08 From the bottle. Aroma is creamy roast, with much more chocolate than Guinness Pub draught and a slight black malt sourness that becomes morenoticeable once you taste it. Appearance is very dark brown with a well maintained fluffy off-white head.  Flavor is a strong, somewhat roast/sour/bitter black malt forward followed by some dark fruit sweetness and near zero hop bittering, but some noticeable light flora. Mouthfeel is full bodied, with strong but not overpowering astringency, low carb texture, and a dry finish. Overall, there’s interesting complexity, but the black malt makes more than one of these questionable and refreshment unlikely.

Bottle, shared by Maria. It poured a clear, reddish brown body, topped by a dense beige head. Slightly cellarish nose with cooked vegetables, roasted malt and some chocolate. Roasted, chocolatey, coffeeish flavor with a touch of vegetables. Chocolate finish. Dry, quite effervescent. It disappointed a bit, I sure didn’t expect the vegetables, but else it’s a decent brew. (080412)
Bottle @ Maria tasting. Dark red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, roasted, coffee, hop. Flavour is sweet, roasted, coffee, hop, malt. Medium body. OK beer.

Presentation: It was poured from a short brown 12oz bottle into a pint glass. It has a very dark brown color that appears black and very opaque. Its head is thick and foamy with a tan color that leaves behind light tan lace on the glass. The aroma has dark roasted malt grains with a light hint of some nice aromatic and grassy hops. There is a full robust roasted grain flavor with a hint of brunt sweetness that quickly turns dry with some grassy and floral hops at add a perfect balance of bitterness to stand up to the malty goodness. On the palate it is starts of smooth then turns very dry and crisp inside of a very drinkable medium body with a nice bitter fading finish. It’s much fuller in flavor and body than its nitro injected Cousin Guinness Draft.

I have to say, I cannot complain too much. For a mass produced Stout, you can`t go wrong. I found the carbonation to be a bit on the heavy side, otherwise a very good palate. The rich coffee and chocolate roast flavor leaves a pleasant aftertaste, however, the initial aroma left a bit to be desired. My overall impression is in the `not bad at all` category. I would try it again, but I wont rush out to the store to get it again right away. I am a bigger fan of Guinness Draft cans I must admit.

bottled.  Aroma of roast caramel malt and very slight chocolate/coffee.  Very dark brown/black with average off-white head that mostly diminished and left good lace.  Flavor is roast caramel malt and a little coffee/chocolate.  Palate is light and smooth with soft carbonation.  Below average but at least you can buy it most anywhere.

Guinness Extra Stout tastes like a Sharpie marker smells with late hints of chocolate and caramel.  Its fail proof.  If you can’t decide on which beer to try next and you haven’t done your research you know that Guinness Extra Stout is there for you.  Something you don’t have to think about; just drink.

I’m not a very big fan of the original Guinness, but I really liked this one. Much thicker, creamier palate than standard Guinness draft. Tastes fuller as well. Again, there are better stouts out there, but this one was pretty damn good.

A one-finger head topped a pitch-black body that smelled of molasses, cocoa and a somewhat unpleasant sour yeasty aroma. Solid molasses and roasted malt flavour that yields to a grainy dry finish. It sounds curmudgeonly, but I remember this beer being better even a few years ago.
Am I the only one who finds the aroma of this beer offensive?  It tastes good enough though.  If I had my choice, I would go for the regular Guinness.  Its a good beer.

Bottle from Matt7215. Pours a black color, small head.  Not much aroma but some roasted malt.  Taste is roasted malt, with a thin texture overall a solid beer that reminded me of my days in England drinking guinness..... A gateway beer for young stouties!

12 oz bottle. Clear, very dark mahogony. Large fluffy tan head.  Mild aroma of roast and chocolate malts . Dry roast and chocolate malt flavor with good hop bitterness. Some sour notes and a bit of astringency in the finish.

Pours black with brown creamy head. Wonderful, roasty aroma of coffee. Chocolate and coffee in the taste. Medium-bodied, slightly creamy mouth feel. Very mild carbonation. Finishes with a strong bitter bite. Basically, the more you drink it, the more you’ll love it. A godly beer, one of the best macros around.

Pours a opaque ebony. The head was more cream colored unlike guinness draught’s white head. The smell is espresso like with a strong malty aroma. The taste is slightly chocolatly with a vanilla/french roast bite. The finish was dry and harsh with a bitter hop aftertaste. Carbonation was a bit heavy.All in alltruely a fine mass produced stout.
A strong, very dark, full bodied beer with the classic Guinness cream colored, frothy head. A nice note of coffee flavor, and it has a noticeable bitterness to it.

Dark black pour but the light comes through at the edges.  Puffy tan head.  Nice dark roasted malt nose but not much else.  Cool and light on the tongue but with a nice body to it.  Again solid roasted malts in the taste but not much else.  Good and solid beer with a nice lingering finish but not much depth.

Bottle @ Thisted Tasting by Maria.. Clear dark red brown color with a aveage to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, chocolate. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is light to medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. (120408)
Bottle.  Pours black with foam head.  Smell of coffee with a hint of chocolate.  Taste of the same.  A quality beer.

One of the greatest beers ever, but can only be appreciated by a true beer drinker.  I remember the first time I tasted this; it tasted like motor oil.  Since then, I have learned to love it, and it is a well-earned treat!

A classic beer all around. Pours a deep black colour. The head is tan and offers a  soft sweet mouthfeel. its sweet, thick, creamy rich, fruity with soft nutty and caramel flavors. 
Earlier Rating: 5/15/2008 Total Score: 3.7
A masterpiece stout all around really, if you haven’t tried it- wake up and try it! Dark black colour, full tan head, heavy, moderately carbonated mouthfeel. Lots of flavor, smoke, soft vanilla, tofee and cream. great brew.

3/22/08 notes:  bottle.  Heavy roasted malts in the aroma, along with bread.  Pours jet black. Body is medium to thick with a creamy roasted flavor and fairly prominent bitterness.  Finishes similarly, with lingering bitterness.  This is a solid brew.
After pouring a tan head formed, which lasted a minute or so.  It tastes like chocolate, coffee, and slightly like dirt, but not in a bad way.
A decent stout. Not even close to the top of my list of favorite stouts though. Weak in depth and flavor for a stout. There are notes of coffee and a light smokiness with a slight bitter end.

Great rich malt aroma, a little earthy.  This is how a beer should look.  Good foam, could last a bit longer.  No sweetness is the strength of this beer.  Good coffee bite.  Full and rich on the palate, but not a creamy as Draught.  This is a classic, to which I compare all other bottled beers, often
 unfavorably.

Pours a dark black with a small tight brown head that lasts for awhile. Heavy malt aroma with hints of roasted grain. Light to medium body. Tastes of sweet malt with a heavy sting of carbonation. Fades to a delicate roasted coffe flavor with hints of toffe and licorice , a lingering astringency of roasted grain on the sides of the tounge and a little on the roof of the mouth. Overall a very good mass produced stout.

This beer brings back many memeories of college, ha. This tastes dark, dark and many of my friends have called it "liquid bread". The flavor is very acidic but not awfully bitter, but it really is bitter BE WARNED! Very drinkable if you ask me.
This is a classic stout, the one and only Guinness.  Got to love this wonderful smooth flavor of a Guiness Extra Stout.

I had rated this when I first joined but somehow it disappeared! Bottle from Country Club Liquors; Says brewed and bottled by Guinness Brewing, New Brunswick, Canada; Nose of roastiness, coffee, with light notes of licorice and vanilla; Hazy black with yellow brown edges and a medium beige head; flavor has roasty coffee, hop bitterness, and a molasses note; finish is a reallly hoppy bitterness.

Courtesy of After4ever, thank you Tom! It’s dark brown with a red hue, and it’s lighter in color than the European variety. The head is huge and creamy. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, light coffee and licorice. The flavour is slightly burnt, with a nice, dry bitterness and a light sweetness and notes of licorice.

I used to hate beer. Then I tried Guinness Extra Stout. 
Many great beers later, I love hops, I love roasted barley malt. Many brews beat the pants off this brew, but she’s still my first love.

Pours a lovely dark black with a tan head. When consumed at the proper temperature I enjoy the roasty flavours and aroma. I can’t wait for a trip to Europe to try the real deal.

A lovely velvety mouth feel with just a hint of a bitter kick at the end to keep it grounded. A nice light snack.
Nice, thick head, bitter, not near as smooth as the draught, but undoubtedly high quality.
the aroma was great, the appearance was lovely, the flavor of the beer almost made me vomit, yet I continued to drink because I thought it would get better pitty me.

22oz Bottle, Toronto: Pours dark brown w/ a large tan head. Nice lacing. Caramel in the aroma & that’s about it. Okay, here’s where things get weird. How one can make Guinness taste like a cheap lager is beyond me, but somehow it has been done. My mind is blown, how the hell can this happen? Simply put, this is the suck. Christ...I can’t believe the rating didn’t come out lower...
Deep brown of color with a creamy beige head. An aroma with coffee and roasted notes. A flavor with roasted notes, coffee and dry notes.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color, with a fluffy creamy head, and good lacing on the glass. Caramel aroma, as well as molasses, slight vanilla, and licorice. Flavors of roasted malts, some milk chocolate and dark candy. Very subdued overall, though. Smooth-bodied, dry, and easy to put back.
It smells a little skunky. DARK reddish-brown in color. I still like the regular Guinness a lot more than this, maybe the one brewed in Jamaica is better than the North American version.

From a 1 pint bottle: pours with a decent, grey-brown head, but it’s not as creamy smooth as the typical pint poured in a pub. Nice, bready aroma. Taste is as expected. The basic standard...smooth, easy drinking and not very bitter or harsh.

4/2/08: Bottle.
  Rich brown body with a creamy, frothy, tan head.  Nice malt aroma.  Roasted malt and coffee flavor with a bitter finish.

Wow, I didn’t know that there were so many versions of this beer. I believe mine is this one, as I got it at my corner AliBaba’s which is in no way a specialty shop, however this one has Guinness Brewing Company in Toronto, not London, Canada. Oh well, my guess is that it’s the same shit, but maybe the editor’s note should be updated, if necessary. In any event, this is a beer that’s hard to dislike. Robust flavor and rich appearance and drinking experience. Pours viscously with a 1/32 inch film. I taste coffee and musk. Very smooth and widely available, I’m glad I tried this for the first time in a while, as this may become a "go to" in places with limited selection in the future. So the best part of this beer is that it’s good, affordable, and relatively speaking, widely available.

aroma of roasted chocolate malt. black with beige head which  doesn’t last long in my snifter. Flavor of bitter burnt strong coffee, roasted malt, hops.  Thin mouthfeel, with carbonation.  I think I prefer Guinness Draught based soley on the mouthfeel.

Pours near-black with a thick, foamy head which never completely goes away.

Smells almost of coffee.

Feels surprisingly bubbly despite its thickness.

Taste is slightly roasted yet bitter.

Guinness is a must for stout-lovers! Highly recommend! Even great out of an 80-oz glass boot! Whoo!

(cleaning out my beer bottle collection as pictured in my profile and utilizing ratebeer.com)
As I recall, the classic dry stout.  Pours black as night with bittery but malty flavors.
Extremely heavy. Very dark in color with a strong coffee cola aroma. Creamy yet bitter coffee/nutty flavor. Solid stout.

bottle. black pour with the famous thick, creamy head that seems to last forever. Roasty aroma with the slightest hint of dark chocolate. Somewhere between watery and not-so-heavy on palate with limited carbonation. Nutty, malty, roasty flavor.  A descent beer, but not as flavorful as many of the ones I really like. However, this one will always be special to me as it led me from the crap beer to the craft beer world. Almost, but not quite as good as the stuff on tap.
Bottle.  Black pour.  White head.  Nutty aroma.  Longer lasting head than the canned version of Guiness that is available.

Bottle. Opaque, dark brown pour with 2-inch creamy light brown head. Aroma slight at refrigerator temperature; some yeast and caramel. Taste is medium sweet, slightly sour, slightly bitter. Starts sweet; sourness appears at back of tongue. Smokey, burnt aftertaste with caramel and brown sugar notes. Mouthfeel is full and lively. Good drink at good price.

Guinness Extra Stout
ABV: 5%
Calories: estimated at 300 C
Volume: 22oz
Glass: pilsner
Purchased at: Sherwood Liquors
Price per fl oz: $4.50 / 22 fl oz = $.20 per fl oz
Consumed at: home

sensory first impression: Rich, deep, roasted malty aroma - different from regular Guinness stout in this way. Head and pour are absolutely beautiful. Color is an inpenetrable black except for a ruby hint around the edge. Wow - taste is deep, malty, syrupy, cloying, and dessertish. Heavy on the tongue and surprising flavor for a 5% abv. Has overarching oak and wine flavor. This has all of what regular Guinness is missing - depth, bite, hops, flavor, and character.

Aroma/Olfactory:
Malt flavor is: caramel, syrupy, coffee, roasted
Hop flavor is: resinous, hay, grapefruit, pepper
Yeast flavor is: crumbs, leather, very dry.
Other flavors include: alcohol, tomato paste, medicine, raisin, sulfur, soy sauce, walnut, oak

Visuals/Appearance:
Color is: black, ruby highlights
Liquid is: darkest night.
Head and lace are: bumpy, frothy, tan, brown, with classic lacing.

Taste/Flavor:
Maltiness or Sweetness level is: medium to heavy
Hoppiness or Bitterness level is: medium to heavy
Sour level is: light to medium

Palate/Tactile:
Body or Mouthfeel is: full, raging
Texture is: creamy, sticky, thick, gritty, large particles, paper towel, cardboard
Carbonation is: lively
Finish is: astringent, long, syrupy, very nice.

Overall experience: An absolutely stunning beer for its distribution. I liked to punch, the bitterness, the depth, the warmth, the color, and the flavor. I did not like a slight metallic tinge, the price, or the idea that the regular stout is so deeply different than this.
Great stout. Easy to find. Nice jet black color. Firm thick head. Goes down smooth. Slight aftertaste.

Surprisingly, this is probably my favorite Guinness, outside of a true draught in a true pub.  The draught cans/bottles don’t hold up, so I prefer to drink the Extra Stout here in the US.    Lost of oak, lots of roasted grain flavor.  Very complex and leaves a very satisfying mouth feel in the end.  I will admit, that I enjoy this beer more when it is colder than most people say to chill it, but that’s just me.  Maybe that kills some flavor, but I like it better that way.  I enjoy the carbonation in this Guinness a lot.
Pours a near black color with a thin tan head.  Bitter chocolate and burnt coffee aroma.  Bitter flavor, yet surprisingly thin.  Reminds me of a condensed, flat Guinness draught.

I had this listed under the wrong beer. extremly bitter taste. Not much flavor and has coffee notes. Large dark brown head. Decent taste. but a bitter aftertaste. Better as it warms. 
Earlier Rating: 6/20/2006 Total Score: 3
extremly bitter taste. Not much flavor and has coffee tones. Large dark brown head. Decent taste.

Bottled. Compared with all the other versions I’ve had today, this one definitely has better mouthfeel, but is still a bit bland. A bit more bitterness/ a touch of lactic sourness make this a little more interesting.

I’m so familiar with the draught style Nitro cans, but have from time to time picked this up and really enjoy it.  Less mellow, more of a tartness or bite to it.  I like the flavor, but it seems to be a little more watery than the draught.  Still good stuff.

12oz bottle.   Dark brown with a beige head.   Dough, burnt toast, and metal in the aroma.   The flavor is a little roast, some tartness, surprisingly sweet, and a little wine bitterness.   Fuller and more lively body than the draught version, but still pretty thin.   Definitely not as good as the continental europe extra stout, but still better than the watery nitro stuff.  (2.7)  Rerate.   Ya, its a bit livelier than the dead palate of draught, but there are some weird metallic flavors going on in the bottle I*m having right now, plus its still thin and the carbonation is too loose.   Tastes more like an industrial lager with some food coloring.   I guess that*s what happens when you brew with hopped malt extract in a giant factory setting.   Just tried this side by side with my dad*s home-brewed dry stout because I told him that this was the original.   Well, his blew this away and it was his first batch brewed on his own.   I wish that they would import the extra stout that they brew in Ireland for Continental Europe.   That stuff is leaps and bounds above this.

black pour with a khaki head.  moslty roasted malts and the thickness was pretty good.  not a bad beer to have around for a back up.  
Earlier Rating: 1/27/2008 Total Score: 3.5
black pour with a tiny bit of lacings.  lots of roasted malts on the nose but that’s about it.  the thickness is very good and it’s tastes mainly of roasted malts.  i’d take this over the draught honestly.

Aroma of malt, grains, chocolate.  Black color with a tan head.  Smokey flavor with chocolate and coffee.  Palate not nearly as smooth as the draught.  All in all not bad but doesn’t compare to Guinness draught.

Bottle. Consumed yesterday (St. Pattys Day), seemed appropriate. Pours a dark brown that shows some red when held up to the light. Small off white head & spotty lacing. Aroma is faintly molasses & roasted malt. Mouthfeel is clean & dry. Flavors are molasses, roasted malt & a hint of chocolate. All flavors are mild. This is not a "big beer" by any means. Still, it was nice visiting an old friend.
Not bad, better than the widget stout in my opinion.  Somewhat bitter with English hops.  Warm is better.

12oz bottle in celebration of St. Patrick’s Day, even though this is brewed far away from Ireland. Very dark brown or black pour with a massive tan head. At least 3 fingers thick with incredible retention and some very nice lacing. Nose of dry malts, chocolate, coffee, roasted grains and some molasses. Also get some tangy fruit esters at the very end of a big whiff. Fore is astringent roasted malts, bitter chocolate, coffee grounds and molasses. Tangy fruit notes build up in the back of the throat and throughout the finish. Light to medium bodied, perfect for the style. Astringency builds and dries out the palate as more of the beer is consumed. Roasted malts and chocolate dominate the finish. A nice bitterness becomes apparent as well. Good stuff.

Can. Pours black, creamy white head. Smooth velvety texture. Subdued for a stout, but overall a good drink. Slightly malty, with a bit of coffee. Decent, but not the best stout, also not near the worst.

I’ve been skeptical about the guinness-labatt’s connection, but I think it’s worked out really well. This is still a classic beer, pours almost black with a thick, rocky tan head.  A nice roasted aroma and a very dense, chewy, roasted malt flavor with a delightful sourness to it.  The dry finish goes on and on with layers of roasted bitterness and sourness.  Much preferable to the draught cans which don’t have that sour quality to it and lose some of the depth.

Canadian Guinness?!!?!? Well, at least its nots being bottled by Miller or Bud! (Enough with the editorializing). Pours a very thick head. Leaves lots of foam on the glass as its starting to fall. Typical dark brown color with little light passing through it. Nice lightly malty head. Tastes a heck of a lot better than what I remember the last few years. Good bitterness in the mouth, probably from some roasted malts. I think one of the reasons why I’m enjoying this more than the others is that I usually buy the draught cans. That softens the flavors a bit.

Bottle. Poured a nice black body with thin head. Aroma was tought to grab as I wasn’t getting much of a scent from it - light roast. Flavor is bitter chocolate with a creamy mouthfeel. Not bad at all...

Faith and Begore, what better day to rate Guinness Extra Stout then on St Patty’s day. When Iireland created this brew it was a great day for the Irish. Very good aroma, appearance is nice and dark, the flavor is terrific with a good aftertaste on the palate, I have to rate this very high. This goes o so good with Corned beef sandwiches, Rebuens, Hamburgers and fish of all kinds.
Earlier Rating: 3/17/2008 Total Score: 4.2
Faith and Begor what a better day to rate Guinness Extra Stout then on St Pattys day. This  is a great beer when your in the mood for a full bodied tasting beer. Goes super good with cornedbeef sandwiches, Rebuens, hamburgers etc. The day Guinness came out with this brew was a great day for the Irish!
Very dark pour, with a deep red tint if held to the light. The head is thick, tan, and lumpy with lacing.  Smell of malt and a hint of apple. The taste of bitter coffee, a little dry for my taste.
Pours dark, w/moderate head. Aroma is cafe, it’s not bad but needs more complexity IMO.

This pours a dark, almost black color with a tan, frothy head. There’s not much aroma, just a very mild roasted malt scent. The taste isn’t bad, an earthy, coffee, and malt flavor. Not much hopping. Fairly average stout.
dark with very bitter flavor.  a very heavy beer overall but a very flavorful one. one of my favorites

A pretty decent copy from Canada. You can find this product almost anywhere.
Very dark almost black. Semi-sweet flavors of chocolate, coffee, dark roasted malt. A long, dry, bitter finish.
I would like to try the real deal sometime in Ireland.

Pours black with a nice tan head. Nose is malt with some chocolate and coffee notes. Dry, roasty flavor with some hops and a touch of alcohol in the nice dry finish. Bottle says it’s brewed in Canada, not as good as the authentic stuff in Ireland. However, it’s a suitable substitute.

Great beer.....pours a rich black color ith great thick tan head with excellent retention......aroma of dark roast and hops, with fruity notes.....flavor is much the same with a nice bitterness to finish it off......good stuff!
Pours a dark black color from a bottle with a full lacing head. Dry sour aroma. Also a dry almost tart flavor, not a bad beer but not my favorite stout by far.

Haven’t had the extra stout in a few years, mostly drink the regular draught when I drink Guinness. Aroma is pleasant, mostly roastyness, hints of chocolate. The flavor is similar, the roasted malts are the main flavor, other flavors are present in the background. Nothing special, I don’t like it as much as the draught, but not bad for a stout that you can get pretty much anywhere.

I LOVE GUINNESS - I don’t like this one.  I heard its the same as the draft but with CO2 instead of Nitrogen.  Not really sure if that is true - The beer pours DARK red like all guinnesses - large cream head.  The palate is sort of bubbly and the flavor is just strong for sake of being strong.  Not a favorite.
Earlier Rating: 2/6/2007 Total Score: 3.3
Looks Good, feels good but this beer has hardly any aroma to it and doesn’t have much more in flavor.  It better then most at most American pubs, but thats not saying much.  

Not bad, but certainly not good.
Black with coffe colored head.  Bubbly.  Roasted malt and hops flavor.  I’ll stick with the original.
Not the fullest flavored stout. Not bad, but not great either. Flavors of toffee and chocolate, but very light on those...

Pours completely black with a fluffy whiteish head that disappears quickly.  Some decent lacing.  Aroma is almost a sour note, not much malt at all.  Taste is much of the same, a bit sour, yet nicely dry on the finish.  Some notes of burnt malt come through.  Also a little thin.  Decent beer, but I like most other stouts much better.

OK, I first had this brew about 30 years ago, and it’s still my go-to for stout.  I really like the dark color, with thin tan head and fine carbonation.  The caramel and roasted barley aroma and flavor place this brew above many other competitors.  There is a silky mouthfeel, and a nice, warm aftertaste.  I really like to pair this beer with pepperoni pizza (my wife likes it with anchovy pizza).
This beer is pretty well covered the one thing no one sems to have noted is the bitter metallic aftertaste.

Aroma is of toasted malts with some molasses, very light hops hops with vanilla and something slightly sour. Pours with a largish, creamy, light brown head with some lacing. Full retention. Extra dark brown body. Taste is watery up front with burnt coffee out back with a bit of breadyness. Very dry. Too fizzy.
truly an irish beer, TO NOT DRINK OUT OF THE BOTTLE! bubbles will be enjoyable to watch, black in color, tan head.
Great stout that has withstood the tests of time. Burnt flavor with chocolate and coffee notes. Very creamy texture. I like it much better than the draught version.

I will say one thing. I am a Guinness man. This brew has a more hoppier taste to it and has a slight after taste on the palate. Serve ice cold and be sure to pour in to a chilled pilsner glass. Has a wonderful taste.
Has a slight burnt taste along with hidden hop tastes and a good amount of grain.  Goes down smooth and is pretty wonderful.  Real creamy.  Would buy again.

22. Pours black, but not inkily so, with a thin sudsy tan head. Sharp fusel and aluminum notes cut through an otherwise pleasant roasty and herbally hoppy nose. Medium body, a bit creamy. Harshly ashy with some roast on the mid-palate. Not much of a beer, especially not compared to the motherland version of the Extra Stout. Meh.
Earlier Rating: 12/13/2006 Total Score: 3.1
12-oz. Thanks, whoever left this in the work fridge for over a week! Pours deep black with a thick, rocky light tan head. Smells roasty and, believe it or not, a tiny bit c-hoppy. This actually ends up being so thoroughly like beer in every way that you can’t believe the name you see on the label. Moderately aggressive attack; decently full body and a bit of carb, plus some rather assertive flavors. Roast, chocolate, a bit of coffee, some sour chalk. Noble/c-hop there at the finish. All subdued, not all positive, but not unlike many rather better stouts in several ways. It’s really a pleasant surprise how much better this beer is than the "Draught."

Bouteille 341 ml. Couleur noire avec des reflet violets. Mousse présente qui reste. Au nez des effluves de crème sûre, de toast rôties et de caramel brulé. En bouche le corps est assez mince. Le goût est semblable au nez, c’est-à-dire trempette aix légumes et crème sûre, orge rôti et pour terminer un peu de caramel et de café. À noter, je l’ai bue froide et je me demande si cette bière n’était pas passer date, car elle a une bien meilleure note que je lui accorde.
not a good as the original.  the bottle says brewed in Canada.  some coffee flavors, but mostly bland
slightly burnt taste gives it more body and flavor than most Guinness.  I really like the aftertaste and the lingering flavor.  Unlike most Guinness, this is less textured and more taste.

341ml bottle.

Pours a deep black colour with a medium sized tan head that fades mostly. Roasted malt aroma with hints of caramel and chocolate. Similar flavour with a sour, bitter and somewhat dry finish.

Bottle. 12 oz. This dark beer has great aroma toasted,dry,just like its flavor which i think its  nice a little bit syrupy and well toasted , but typical guinness taste, the palate was creamy and sour at the same time. WORTH TO TRY

Pours dark brown with a bubbly tan head. Aroma of light roast with a little sweetness. Mild roast with a touch of metallic sweetness. A light lingering roast. A rather dull flavored stout. A mild lingering dry roast. Light body. Medium carbonation.

Bottle (12oz).  Irish beer, brewed in Canada, purchased in Buffalo.  Deep ruby-brown pour, clear yet almost opaque, with a huge fluffy tan lasting head.  The aroma’s quite light, and I had this at high cellar tempurature - mild roast coffee and root beer syrup, vaguely herbal.  It’s a nice balance between dry grassy bitterness and dry over-roast coffee/molasses sweet malt - seems a tad watery, and there’s only minimal carbonation, but the sticky malt body is somewhat balanced in the finish by dry bitterness - not all that bad, really - pretty light yet roasty.

I bought a sixer of this for $8.99+tax last night because I was at a St. Cloud liquor store that barely had anything decent and I was very disappointed, even though I had low expectations. What’s the deal with people’s respect for Guinness? Is it because it’s an old brand and people are suckers for brand loyalty and identifying with certain brands, particularly ones that claim a tradition steeped in excellence with a long history? It certainly seems so given that you can buy Guinness clocks, glasses, shirts, etc., but this beer just ain’t special.

Deep brown with a large, rocky, tan head.  Roasted malts, caramel, chocolate, earth.  Medium body with a carbonation bite.  Roasted malts, cocoa, molasses, and earthy notes.  A solid, easily accessible stout.

One my first favorites from way back. 
Pours with a big beige head (like the one in the picture) The doesn’t stick around too long there is however a small lasting head that leaves a nice lace.  Deep black color. Smells strongly of coffee, a little molasses, and roasty malt. Taste is similar, but in reverse a lot of roasty malt, a little molasses and some coffee. Taste has some nice balance sweet at the front with good bitter hoppy notes.

I know what you are all thinking (PERFECT!)... I’m sorry but it’s my all time favorite beer. To me Guinness is perfect, what all other stouts strive to be. That wonderful malty coffee aroma, the dark brown almost black color, and that smooth taste that you almost have to smoke after... to me it’s perfect. A pint of Guinness and a glass of Jameson’s 18 year and to me life doesn’t get any better.
chocolate brown color with tan head,  bitter flavor with lots of toasted malt, good stout
Always a good choice when just having a beer or two.  Thick and flavorful...coffee like flavor.  A classic beer that is enjoyable
Thick tan head, poured very dark smelled like coffee and malt! Taste great goes down smooth. Must drink ice cold!

For my 150th rating, I wanted to do a special one.  So I chose this old favorite, which I drank regularly and proudly for years.  I will always have some respect for this beer, the first stout I ever had.  They probably invented the stuff, or at least popularized it.  The label is a classic, I hope they never change that.  The aroma is disappointing - a little metallic and cheesy.  The taste is robust (stout?), well-bittered with leathery notes.  Not sweet, and with a clean, hoppy finish.  Certainly not bad, but not the best either.  Will Guinness start doing a little more to maintain its hold on stout drinkers?  The answer is yes.  i upgraded it a bit in 2014.  It looks like they changed the recipe a bit, made it smoother and maltier, and this improved it a little.  It continues to be one of the best macros on the market.
The aroma is coffee and malt. The appearance is  dark black with a tan head. The taste is like a bitter coffee. Feels too watery on the palate.

Good sessionable beer!  Very easily accessible as well.

Pours almost black with a good head.

Smells really dark and chocolatey.  Very nice.

Wow, this really tastes good for a very accessible beer.  Nice and dark and full of roasted malts with a nice bitter dark chocolate aftertaste that I like a lot.

Liked this one a lot.

12 oz. bottle made in Moosehead brewery in New Brunswick, Canada. Pours a deep black that hints at some redness when held up to a light with a powerful awe inspiring beige head. The aroma is mostly roasted malts with some hints of sweet coffee. The taste is more bitter than draught Guinness; uncooked coffee beans, roasted malts, old car oil, some light hops and a tiny dark fruit aspect. A bit too weak for my desire, but I will always love Guinness. It’s the champ in many ways.

Lacking the complexity of the Draught it tends to be on the bitter side. Its still better than most commonly found beer but doesn’t measure up to Bass, Newcastle, Draught, Yuengling or Killians in my book.

I have had this brew countless times and forgot to rate it. Pours a murky ruby red color almost black. Nice frothy tan head that fades unlike the draught. Taste is much fruitier than the draught with the same bitter coffee aftertaste. Overall a pretty averge beer but has more flavor than the draught which to me is not a good thing. Prefer the draught....
a wonderfully attractive stout with a lasting, frothy head and a pleasant mouthfeel. the only drawback is the taste, it just doesnt live up to some of the stronger stouts that i have sampled

12 oz. bottle pours black with a thin tan head, decent lacing. Pleasant buttered toast smell. Thick, chewy mouthfeel. Taste is of toasted grains and black coffee. Has a bitter black coffee after taste. Not bad for a mass produced stout, and better tasting than it’s canned draught sibling.

Bottled.  Poured medium-deep brown with a tall, fluffy cap of tan head.  The aroma picked up dry-roasted chocolates, sweetened iced tea, and sweet caramel.. herbal notes accent.. really sweet, but I rather enjoyed it.  The flavor had supa-sweetened dry semi-sweet chocolates, chalky herbs, and molasses.. leaving an ugly lingering coffee and herbal bitterness on the finish.. this was tasty until right there in the end.  Light-medium bodied with too much sweetness for its own good on the palate.. the finish was a bit painful, and had some sourness to it.  Not bad overall.
On tap.  Black beer with light tan head.  Chocolaty aromas.  Dry on the palate.  full body, but not ’heavy’.  Finishes with a touch of sourness.

Pours with a light tan head, dark brown color in the glass. Smells off lightly roasted chocolate and coffee with a slight metallic tinge. Flavor is pillowy on the tongue, starts off thick and hoppy with overtones of malt, ending slightly watery. A metallic bitterness is left at the end which dissipates quickly. Taste is left lingering on the top of the throat at back and moves down until it is no longer noticed.
Bottle, pours dark, wonderful frothy head that lasts.  Very dry, slightly bitter or acidic, burnt roasted flavor, malty.  Very smooth, good for cold weather.
Big bottle.  Poures black.  Taste of caramel and coffe.  expected much more from this beer.  Very nice though
Extra Stout Is not As EXTRA as i expected. Slight bitter after taste. Still good when ice cold.
Nice dark brown with light tan head.  This beer, eventhough much more mainstream that some, stil holds it’s own.  I thoroughly enjoy this beer’s roasty flavor.
Guinness Extra Stout is a great beer to drink anytime, although I prefer the Draught.  One of the most common dark beers sold in the US.  Good stuff.

12oz bottle. Liquorice, dry malt, light coffee and lactose on the nose. Pours dark brown with a thin khaki head. Quite dry and bitter on the tongue. Lots of bitter and roasted malt. Some vanilla, dry oak. Lots of "roasty" notes. Medium bodied with good carbonation.
Pours black.  With a thick brown head.  Aroma is malty with coffee and caramel notes.  Tastes roasted with strong coffee flavor and a little hop bite at the end.

Smell is rather non-descript - a bit lagery with a touch of malt. Smells more hoppy as it warms.  Damn fine head on this one - very thick and velvety, with a dark complexion.  Initially a bit thin in the body, but the carbonation takes hold upon entry and thickens the brew considerably.  Flavor starts a good bit tart, then finishes both roasty and hoppy.  Quite dry.  Sort of reminds me of midwestern dark ales.  This brew is nothing special but decent nonetheless.  I do, however, prefer the Draught.

Super roasted though not too much else in terms of complexity. Coffee and a nice full body. Very bitter hops balance out the stout. I hope I’m rating the correct stout, there’s so many Guinness Extra Stouts.
I just had this with a steak dinner and it really tasted well.  A great taste to go with a full body, a good beer.

Bottle. Appearance: Dark brown/black, thick tan head. Aroma: Very mild roasted coffee malt. Palate: Fairly thick, coats mouth. Flavor: Bittersweet roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Very slight metallic taste on the back of the tongue. Overall: This beer just isn’t the same from a bottle.
This is great stuff, dark, chewy, thick, liquid bread, amazing head, delicious, great aroma and a bitter finish
