Better than the canned draught version with nitrogen, almost as good as the draught pulled from a tap.  Nice aroma lacks any hop aroma.  Looks great, black with a nice rocky head.  Flavor is straight forward with a very dry finish on the dry side.  Nothing complex about Guinness, just good ole dark roasted goodness.  The mouthfeel of the Extra Stout is far superior to canned draught, though it’s a bit too bitter like it has just a tad too much black patent malt.  A bottle of this never disappoints.

pours a dark brownish black ith a light brown head.  aroma is coffee, roast malt, some vanilla, milk.  taste is pretty much the same.  starts off wet & heavy giving way to a nice roasty malt flavor that finishes smooth and bitter.  for an uber-massproduced brew, this one’s pretty good.  i like this one better than the draught.

Pours thick black into the pint glass with a huge tan head.  Scents of chocolate, cream, vanilla and coffee.  Dry, thick body with tastes of roasted malt and coffee.  More robust than the can and on tap.

24 oz. bottle.  After a vigorous pour, very dark brown color with a dark head of modest size.  NO cascade : (  Aroma was very faint and smelled like dried apricot, coffee, and molasses--more complex than I remember Guinness.  Taste is burnt chocolate malts--flat and dry.   Tastes like prunes.  It goes w/o saying that the draft is better.
Pours black with a thick white head. Slight dry roasted barley aroma. Roasted barley, malt and a hint of chocolate in the taste. Finishes clean. Solid.
Bottle poured into pint glass.  Moosehead production line.  Simply resembles the other products but a little less liveliness compared to the nitro taps.  Still a solid, classic stout.
12 ounce bottle purchased at World Market Pembroke Pines, FL for $1.69 Good

12oz - For years I never knew there was a difference between this and Draught.  Roasted chocolate head, deeper flavor than the nitro.  I’ll stick with other stouts over this, but it is a good, solid, ubiquitous beer.
It’s as if it’s alive sometimes.  I love Guinness it’s a favorite of mine.  Dark beer, tan head, and constant movement.
Good beer one of the best readily available beers in East Texas. I don’t jerk off to it as do some of my Irish buddies but will never turn one down.

Pours black with a thick, foamy tan head. Aroma is light and woody, not very strong. Mouth-feel is very much like that of Guinness draught. Thick and smooth. Taste is bittersweet with hints of coffee and deep roasted malts.
Pours a blackish brown with a thick, light brown head.  Mildly skunky aroma.  Medium texture.  Good amount of carbonation.  Tastes like Newcastle Brown Ale with a more coffee and caramel finish.

22 oz. bottle pours dark brown, certainly not black, but mostly opaque.  Head is abundant and attractive with a slight deepening in hue where beer was poured.  Head lasts and lasts.  Aroma is chocolate, burnt candy and coffee, mild.  Flavor is much the same, but not very sweet.  Bitterness comes out and shines, with a deep, dark, satisfying taste I was surprised to find in a north american guinness.  Palate was pretty blah, the only real disappointment here, watery and unrefined.  I’ve heard ’guinness is the beer you eat with a fork’  yeah...right,  so I better get a steak knife for my expedition then!
Very dark brew with a two finger thick head. Smells is sweet and chocolatey. Taste is smooth and malty, with a mild hop aftertaste. A good all around brew.

Ho-hum.  Pours dark brown with a short tan head.  Sour aroma of malt, smoke, and cocoa.  Bitter taste of roasted malt, earthy malt, metal, sour coffee, and a dry finish.  If this is a representation of Guiness that one would find in Ireland, it is pathetically average.
Earlier Rating: 9/28/2005 Total Score: 3.4
Dark as night with no head.  Taste is very bitter in comparison to its weaker sibling.  Minimal hops, but lots of smoke and malt.  A decent beer that’s easy to come by.

1pt, 6 oz bottle, imported...from Canada.  sigh.  Pours a deep near opaque black w/ ruby undertones, not much for a head, slightly off white.  Nose is nice, peaty and smoky, fruitier than draft guinness, faint hint of earthy hops.  Palate is definitely somewhat lacking, a little thin, more smokiness, nothing too overwhelming in the bitterness, finishes slightly dry.
Porus a dark black with a medium sized head. Smells of chocolate and cofee. Lots of hops and a bitter aftertaste.
Ooof, this is a beer that will make you wonder what hit you when you taste it.  Stronger tasting and more carbonated than standard Guinness
Smells of dark roasted malts, slightly bitter. Pours black with a small creamy dark tan head. Taste is rich and bitter. Tasty. So much better than Guinness Draught
Dark, formidable appearance with a small tan head. Smell is gentle, and the overall taste is smooth and hoppy. Definitely enjoyable.
Deep, dark brown, nearly black color with a loose tan head.  Smell is light, with a hint of coffee and chocolate.  Taste is smooth and memorable.
Bottle. Pours dark dark brown with medium bubbly head. Malty aroma. Taste has a hoppy finish. More carbonation that I like in my stouts.

12 oz bottle- poured non transparent black, nice frothy tan head, aroma of coffee and roasted malts.  Hits the mouth with a medium body, consisting of malt and a coffee note that carries to the finish, a touch of sourness on the finish.  And I thought that the draught was great, this beats it.
Dark brown with a medium light tan head. Aroma is light roast malt, coffee, metallic. Flavor was sourish malts, nutty, mild smoke. Pretty average.

Bottle. Pours out a very dark brown with a medium head light tan head. Very light malt and coffee aroma.  Dry coffee and malt flavor that finishes watery. Leaves nice lacing. This is an OK beer but there are much better stouts out there to spend your money on.

Poured a clear deep brown color with a small beige head.  roasted coffee and light doughy aroma.  The flavor is fairly roasted with a hop and bitter middle to finish.  Dry and highly bitter finish.  Medium body.

Bottle. Poured a very dark brown with a tan head. The aroma is sweet raisin malt and licorice. Thin mouthfeel with a sweet chocolate malt woth light bitter finish. Very easy to drink, a very good Dry stout from Guinness.
Something about it that is different somehow than the Draught. Not that it is bad by any means, just different. Still a good stout on anyday.

Bottle. Very dark brown to almost black in color with nice off-white fluffy head that lasts and makes a wonderful lacing on glass. Aroma of dark roasted malt with hints of coffee. Earthy flavor of dark malt and coffee. Very good mouthfeel. Not too thin ot thick. Pretty decent beer. Easy to drink.
I love the Guinness Extra Stout with anything. It has strong flavor and creamy finish.

Deep, brown color with a thick head that dissipates faster than I’d like. Tastes of coffee with hints of molasses. I prefer not to drink it right after taking it from the fridge, warmer temperature brings out better flavors. My favorite of beers so far.
bitter, very dark with tan head, dry finish, taste of coffee, chocolate, very bitter but pretty good beer
I like this one a bit better than the draught - a bit more of a true stout.  Black, coffee colored, and nice complexity to the malt flavors.

Bottle.  Pours black with a medium tan colored head.  Faint scent of malt and maybe dark roasted malt.  A little bitter and the coffee comes a little through.  The finish is definitely dry.  I prefer Guinness sans nitrogen.

re-rated: old rating 6/5/6/4/16-3.7



Imported by Diageo.
pour is black with a medium size tan head, okay lacing.

smell of ash, coffee, cocoa, sour malt, touch of licorice.

taste is dry, sour, dark unsweetened chocolate, ends somewhat bitter.
A beautiful beer, with a pleasant bread like aroma and just the right amount of bittering hops. This is a great stout perfect for drinking in big creamy gulps.
This is the best, most-common dark beer sold in the US.  That being said, there are many other dark beer makers that make a superior product.
Pours an opaque mahogany with a dense tan head.  Nice roasty nose with a hint of coffee.  Rich full body with a pleasant bitter twang and a nice dry finish.

its a staple, the window to good beer, it is considered great until you get deeper into beer, I like, but compared to better stouts it gets sour, but usually you can find this everywhere, and when all else fails, at least you can get a Guinness.
I thought this was a bit better than the draught actually but still not very good, guinness has just become a symbol for dark beer, but isnt a good dark beer.

favourite beer - used to like draught and avoided this since I tasted it as a kid from a bottle my dad forgot in his fish boat - ugh at the time! Tried again a few weeks ago and was amazed  - like it way better than the draught bottles.

12 oz bottle...black -dark brown body with a tan head...rich aroma of coffee...medium refreshing body ...flavor is good...coffee beans and bitter molasses....finish has a bit of bitter to it, and a very slight metallic quality...very slight...nice sippin’ stout...leaves a nice froth on the glass as well...perfect with a chocolate chip cookie!

Bottle pours dark with a sustained head.  The aroma is of roasted malt.  The flavor is malty, better than the draft, and sweet.  The palate is more rich than the nitro, but not anything of note.  Overall, I was looking for a single bottle to bring home with dinner, and I picked this one.  I’m sort of indifferent to it.  It suits me.
Earlier Rating: 10/2/2003 Total Score: 3.8
Sampled 1 pint 6 oz bottle at 63 degrees F.  Pours a dark opaque color that appears to have deep amber to it as seen with very bright light behind.  The head was quite significant, but was only an average looking head of bubbles, vs. the draught with the creamy looking head.  The head diminished to minimal after several minutes with decent lacing.  The aroma was chocolaty and coffee like.  The flavor was better than the draught version, bit more character to it as is a bit more toasty (almost a touch smoky) and more bitter.  The palate is more carbonated a just a little more thick.  As with the draught version, I still find this beer to lack in flavor compared to the rich mouth feel.  It tastes out of balance in this respect.
esta es probablemente la mejor cerveza que ha hecho una cerveceria local, porque me ha gustado  bastante

341 ml bottle. pours black with red edges and a medium tan head. aromas of esspresso but subdued. flavours are a bit thin. its weird that they increased the alchohol and decreased the flavour. some bitterness in the finish. not a bad stout but not even close to the best.

More than your average guinness.  Smooth like the original, but has a massive aftertaste that will linger in your mouth long after you’ve finished.  Personally, I enjoy this one at room temperature, which lessens the bitter aftertaste, which can overwhelm at times.

Bottle. Pours black with nice big tan head. Aroma is very faint but comes through a little malty and roasty. Flavor equally light but has a more pronounced maltiness and roastiness. Lightly bitter overall with a dry finish. I suppose one could drink many of these with no ill effects.

This beer pours a nice thick chocolate color head which happens to be very creamy. It has a dark color to it and a smell of cream. As you drink it the beer is very smooth and creamy. It leaves a nice sweet flavor in your mouth.

Bottle from neighbors crappy collection. They know I like dark beers so I guess they thought they were doing me a favor. I will keep it simple. It’s ok. Thick body a mild roast coffee flavor.  Not one of my favorite stouts(see Three Floyds, Bells, Ale Smith or Goose Island)
a good go to stout that is recognized all over the world, pours thick with a creamy head and beautiful lacing but there are far superior stout out there.

Pours a dark coffee brown from bottle, making an impressive, lingering head even without nitro widget.  Nose is simple: roasted coffee with the tiniest hint of sourness.  Smooth mouthfeel with sharp but not unpleasing sourness on tongue.  Big roasty flavor dominates clean finish (sourness still lurking in the background).  Seems to have a tad more alcohol character than the 5% rating indicates.  I prefer this to all other versions of Guinness in bottles or cans I have tried in USA, although hand-pulled is still the way to go.
classic guinness extra stout. poured deep dark brown, almost black. nice head but faded quickly. i prefer this over the regular guineess. the flavor seems to me a little more complex.

For creamy stouts, this is the only one. Like chocolate milk. But you can only get it in can or on draft. Nothing is worse than Guinness in a bottle. What a shame to pop open that bottle and see nothing but flat beer.

Bouteille 12 oz (brassée au Nouveau-Brunswick). De couleur noire et opaque. Nez de grains de malt assez rôtis, moyen de chocolat noir, léger de houblon herbeux, de café noir et de pain grillé avec des petites notes fruitées (notes de cerises). Moyenne-mince en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture crémeuse. Très léger goût fruité aux petites notes sûres (cerises) ainsi que des notes métalliques lors de l’entrée en bouche suivi très rapidement d’un goût moyennement amer de malt très rôti, de pain grillé-brûlé et léger de chocolat noir puis en finale l’on retrouve un léger goût de houblon herbeux asséchant ainsi que des notes de café noir. Post-goût long et assez sec, moyennement amer de rôti, léger de houblon herbeux et de chocolat noir, léger de café et avec des petites notes de métal.

Good ol’ Guinness.  Better than the regular.  Nice frothy head, dark brown opaque head with a little red on the fringes.  Flavor is malty roasted chocolate, smooth mouthfeel, a little fizzy.  LIked it.

Been a few years since I’ve had one of these, so I figured I’d give it another go. Pours almost black with mahogany hints when held to light. Nose is more complex than basic Guinness, with a little more roasted chocolate and fruit sneaking through. Taste is not quite as bitter, but the finishing sourness is prevalent. Better than I remember.

12 oz bottle.  Not too much difference than the canned Guinness with the widget.  Still a great drinking beer, but if I have to make a choice I will stick with the canned version with the widget.
Earlier Rating: 1/18/2006 Total Score: 3.9
Pours a dark brown with a coffe like head.  Very easy drinking, smooth and silky.  A must for St. Patrick’s Day, or any day for that matter.
A muted version of the draught, with slightly stronger coffee flavors and more bitterness. Tastes better with the right food.

Black with good head. Drier and less complex than I had remembered, but still fairly well balanced by roasted malts. Good chocolate roasting with a drying souring finish.  Not bad but I still prefer a nice Guinness on tap.
from a 1 pint bottle after work .. was very disappointed almost skunky aroma ..bitter after taste compared to the smoother draught.. stick with it from the tap not the bottle!
Not as dry as a regular Guinness.  Tastes like a slightly stouter, hoppier version of an Irish ale.
Ahhh much better than a standard Guinness. Good flavor and a deeper and richer taste.
bottle.  pours a deep black with a solid tan head.  aromas of sweet malt.  bitter and sour on the finish.  thin body and a bit watery.  not that special.

Labatt version. Aroma is strong, malty and dry. Tastes good, the strength is in the simplicity. Prominent hop bitterness with a touch of plum and cherry flavor, and the malt only for texture. A good, dark sessioner. Goes really well with honey-roasted peanuts.

Pours a deep reddish brown with a dense, pillowy, tan head. On the nose are dark roasted malts, light coffee and chocolate notes as well as a bit of sour milk (and initially, metal). Light-to-medium bodied and slick with a sour/astringent finish. The flavor follows the nose with a distinctly sour/bitter finish that transitions to a dry, bitter, metallic aftertaste. While this is certainly a bolder beer than its ubiquitous cousin, I actually prefer that softer and arguably blander beer to this one.

Deep dark poor with a medium light brown foamy head showing a little lacing.  Aromas of dark chocolate, roasted malts, burnt toast and thats about it.  A slightly pungent flavor or sensation in mouth that i have probs describing ... sour?... Nicely bitter and has a medium body but maybe a little to much carbonation.  Nothing realy more to add... better than the Guiness draught...

12oz bottle. thanks carmen!
solid black color is left with a little less than an inch of sandy head. tart sourish nose is backed by some robust aromas. sour cherries come to mind when i drink this. the back end tastes less robust and more burnt. the body is thin and watery and fades to more of the sour fruit. this is way worse than i remember.

This is generally nice and smooth, with a good, rich, thick head and almost no fizziness.  The flavours are good and and it has a pretty full palate.  This was my first stout type after Watney’s, but now I find it a little bland and less complex by comparison with others.  It’s a little one-sided with a little too much strength on the chocalate’coffee element and too little in other departments.  However, it’s still good and quite drinkable.  It is much better than the Guinness Draught.
This was an excellent beer. The appearance is almost sensual but the dark color and firm taste holds a very masculine appeal.

341 mL bottle.  Deep opaque brown with a decent, but not huge, brown head.  Aroma dominated by roast malt - not much else there.  Flavour is not much different, although you can add to it some burnt toast, and a touch of both sweet chocolate and sour apple cider.  Medium body, and perhaps a little heavily carbonated for the style.  Much better than Guinness Draught.
Pours black with lasting head. not much carbonation (which isn’t a bad thing). Alittle dry with a note of bitterness at the end but not overwhelming.
Bottle. Similar to Guinness Draught, but stronger and thicker in the mouth. Burnt toast flavor and aroma. Opaque and black. Delicious.

Re-organized rating (rated a while ago for the old 6.8abv version of this): Nigh chocolately falvor, with a bunch of bitterness and body to back it up. Drank it out of the bottle, but color was really apparent by looking into the dark bottle. Definately a well crafted beer. Don’t know whether I prefer this or Guinness Draught. Both are good, but this one probably has a richer flavour.
coffee, roasted (maybe burnt) chocolate. nice consistancy thin flavor feel but thicker on the palate. touch winey which is nice. bitter and sweet over the head of this brewery. congratulations!

You either love Guinness Extra Stout or don’t. It’s the benchmark by which all other stouts, particularly dry/Irish stouts, are judged.

Similar qualities to a dry port. Roasted malt comes through in the nose and palate. Very mild hops aroma. 

Most Guinness drinkers overlook Extra Stout for Draught. Two totally different brews. Draught drinkers are missing out, IMHO.

Love Guinness? You’ll love my website... www.gigfy.com!
nice dark black,tan head,roast coffe nose,roasty coffee,chocolate,slight bitter finih.very tasty.I like this better than the draft.

this is the only Guinness stout that we have been able to get in the US before the nitro widget stuff arrived. I had my first one of these in the 70s. My tastes have matured greatly since then and this beer is too crude for my palate now. My advice is to get a Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout bomber for a real great, easily located import stout.

The name is synonomous with Stout. Good opaque black color, creamy tan head. Smells "roasty". Mouthfeel and flavor for a stout, well, seems to be average. Nothing powerful. Roasted malts imparts both sweetness and bitterness; coffee, chocolate are normal flavors, but not up front. They blend in with the hops, with some bitterness. Still, a good stout. Nice and dry, not too sticky
Earlier Rating: 8/8/2007 Total Score: 3.7
like guinness. i do. the only drawback to this stout is that the flavors and characteristics do not stand out WHEN COMPARED TO a top tier micro. it’s still damn good as everything blends well. roasted coffee bitterness and sweetness mingles with a chocolate body. again, mouthfeel isn’t too big to me. it’s good, just not too heavy when compared to some other micro stouts i had. nice dry finish
Slightly better than the original, but I can go either way. I love them both. This one is a little more bitter -- and that is exactly the way I like it.

This is the perfect beer in my opinion, and the beer against which all dark beers are measured in my world.  Coal-black color with good lace.  Strong taste of cocoa and coffee, without the burnt taste of so many inferior stouts.  Good mouth feel, no lingering bitterness.  From a bottle.

This is one that grew one me as I moved through my six pack. A big fan of the original Guinness, I thought I’d check this one out. It’s dark (almost black) and full of flavor, but isn’t particulaly smooth. Had a really nice head for a stout, and left a nice lacing on the glass. Has a rather "burnt" taste, but nice complexity with sweet tones underneath. A winner for me.

Pours black with 1 inch of off-white head and loose lacing. Smells richer and smokier than regular Guiness with the typical chocolate malt and coffee notes. Tastes like it smells. A little heavier and possibly more enjoyable than the Draught. Definitely not as watery. Alcohol is noticeable, but not unpleasant.

1 pt. 6 fl oz (US) bottle with label  "Product of Canada."  Mostly black pour with tan-brown head.  Unexpected medium mouthfeel.  I’m used the Guinness with a heavier mouth feel.  Just kiind of bland and watery compared to the widget cans.  I just didn’t get into this bottle.

When the commercial description says ’Similar to the Draught version’ they aren’t kidding. I really couldn’t tell the difference until I compaired the two side by side before a Dropkick Murphy’s show (excellent setting for any St. James Gate beer, especially the iconic Guinness). The extra stout is more active visually right after pouring and has a slightly creamier mouthfeel with the same relatively mild taste in comparison to how it looks. (Am I the only one who expects Guinness to be much thicker from just looking at it?)
A much more substantial beer than straight Guinnees. Nice thick body, plenty of roastinesss, actually tastes like a quality stout!

Definitely not as good as Guinness Draught...bottles and cans.  This stout seems to lose some hop notes, and even a little complexity with the reduced carbonation.  The full body does shine through on this style, however.  Solid

This is an excellent brew, full flavored, malty, deep, and a nice hoppy finish.
This beer, while not the best available, will not disappoint.
Rerate, my taste has changed this is a lovely and tasty beer.  No probelms with the taste or palate anymore.  Good overall.

Bottle. Deep dark black in color with a nice fluffy off white head.  Chocolatety malty caramel aroma. Nutty notes Malty caramel flavor.  Roasty flavor. Chocolatety bready smokey flavor. Full bodied. . Nice beer.
Ahhh...black gold.  Pours cascading dark black with  abundant creamy light brown head.  Malty, caramel flavours.  With a bit of a bitter finish.  Always a pleasure to have.
A very deep black color with a dark tan head. Hints of coffee, chocolate and a smokey malt. The taste has a strong hop, but not too hoppy. The finish is smoth  and enjoyable.
Dark brown almost black pour with foamy off-white head.  Weak aroma with roasted malt but a much better flavor than the canned version.

Had two 12 ounce bottles with dinner.  Not a bad beer, but this is my least favorite style of stout or porter.  Slight coffee taste and a bitter finish.  Not much going on here really.  None of the nice strong roasted flavors that you taste in a Samual Smith’s Oatmeal Stout, for example.

Black pour with lasting thick foamy light tan head.  Smell is a nice subtly roasty smell with a hint of sweetness and some caramel as it opens up and warms and becomes cloying smelling and artificial after a bit.  Taste is nice and full bodied as opposed to Guinness draught which is pretty thin and watery.  Much fuller taste, roasty malts, a touch too much caramel flavor, but with the right amount of bitterness.  This is so much better than regular Guinness I think.  Mouthfeel is thick, creamy and nice, but with a good amount of carbonation that keeps it from being too heavy.  Finishes with a medium to long lengthed slightly bitter roasted malt aftertaste.  A solid stout for sure.

Pours an opaque black with a tan head that lingers.  Aromas of espresso and dark chocolate malt.  Taste of espresso and strong roasted malts.  Leaves a bitter, stout aftertaste with the throat feeling parched.  Not too bad, not very adventerous or complex, but o.k.

This beer poured nicely, but the head disappeared rather quickly.  The taste was slighlty different from the draught Guinness, it had more of a bite.  I enjoyed it, but I would like to try it out of a tap rather than a bottle.
black with a small light tan creamy head. nice roasted malty aroma. creamy medium  thick body. tastes of molasses, roasted coffee and light cocoa and a lasting bitterness

This is the beer that convinced me that Ales are not for me.  I think the aroma is alright, and as for appearance, there is something about beer that looks like coffee that turns me off.  Even the flavour wasn’t that appealing to me.  I found this to be a slightly bitter beverage.  Even the mouthfeel felt very thick and strong with little in the way of carbonation.  I’m the only person I know who doesn’t really like Guinness so it’s not you people...it’s me.
Pours black, little head. Minor aroma of coffee and chocolate. Very bitter flavor that sticks with you. Very characteristic roasted malts that hit you in the face.

Pours an opaque black with a pillowy tan head that retains fantastically. The flavour is sweet toffee, coffee and roated malts which aren’t very intense, but still pleasant. The palate is a bit watered down for a stout, or compared to other craft stouts brewed here in the states. Either way, this is a great beer considering its accessability and popularity.

Bottle; New Brunswick, CA; Could be Labatt, could be Moosehead. Roasted malt aroma. Nearly opaque black color with ruby tints at the edges. Frothy tan head that laces. Medium bodied; lots of carbonation. Starts a bit sour, with roasted malt. The finish is dry, light touch of coffee, and mostly the remnants of the roasted malt. The sour got lost along the way. Doesn’t have the burnt toast I seem to remember from years ago. Ok, but many American stouts are as good or better. Guess I’ll have to get my hands on one from Dublin. Imported Guinness from Canada almost seems misleading.

Very similar to the draught in flavor and style, but lacks the unique creamy smoothness that its cousin has.  Rich roasted malt, oatmeal, and coffee.  Non-dememo  aroma.  Somewhat bland.  Decent enough brew, just not as complex as some of the other stout offerrings out there.

Bottle.  I am guessing this is the version we see here in the states.  There seem to be a ton of different brewers.  Opaque pour with just a bit of light creeping through at the edges, huge tan head.  Rich dark stout with a roasty, toffee bitterness.  Excellent body.  With all of the other stouts I’ve tried lately, it’s always good to come back to the first.  And the amazing thing to me is that for a mass-marketed beer, it still holds its own against the great premium craft stouts out there.
Huge foam and roasty aroma; black ale with a nice hop and smooth feel, but there is a slight metallic taste; slightly bitter finish
Dark brown with a creamy off white head.  Faint roasty aroma and equally faint taste.  Watery palate.  Not a very satisfying stout.
DArk pour with a medium size head.  Fairly weak roasted malt aroma and taste.  Thin body.  A little expensive for what it is.
This appears to be a great beer, it smells and pours excellent, like regular guinness. However the palate ends abruptly and is lacking in a full finish.
caramel, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, Still one of my favorites...
Draft. Guinness is overrated, but it has grown on me a bit since the first few times I’ve had it. It actually has a really watery palate with notes of roast and coffee.

I drank this after having the Guinness Draught and the initial flavor is similar but the extra stout has a very obvious bite to it.  It’s really good though.  I am a stout fan (or as big of a fan that a 21 year old can be) but this isn’t the best I’ve had. I would place this behind the Guinness draught and the Rogue Shakespear but ahead of the Bare Knuckle Stout.  I am drinking this while I am writing this so it’s fairly accurate. LOL  I drank this out of a shaker
I’ve always enjoyed thi one when I’m in the mood for dark. The fact that you can get it almost anywhere makes it almost a comfort beer.
Bottle 12oz.  Have also had this on draft in Ireland, Amsterdam, England, and Us. Prob best enjoyed on draft abroad.

Bottle. Large head that lasts and leaves some crusty lacing. Aroma is chocolate, malt, graham cracker, and metallic hops. Taste is chocolate malt on the front, but slides slowly into coffee. The finish is  mostly dry, with a come-from-behind victory of grassy hops over a dark fruit and malt body. Palate is light-medium and dry. Pretty nice industrial brew.

Rated 8/18/06:  This is a wonderful beer to look at, with a dark soft color and fluffy head this beer is beautiful. Not much aroma is given off, my nose can’t pick up much of anything. Mouthfeel is real good with a texture that is silky soft and smooth. Finishes with ease. The flavor is where I am most disappointed. Overall the taste is good, but I want more flavors in a stout. I don’t want to say Guinness is bland, but in a sense it really is.
Earlier Rating: 5/23/2007 Total Score: 3.8
Rated 8/18/06:  I like the extra over the regular, there is a much stronger flavor which I enjoy in a hearty stout. Aroma is good slightly malty and a touch of sweetness. Pours great from the bottle into a pint glass, dark and creamy with a nice head, not as good as the draught can or from the tap since there is no cascade effect. Mouthfeel has more fullness than the regular also which is nice. Flavor is heavy with dark roasted malts, sweet and also bitter, very drinkable and always enjoyable.

12 oz. bottle. Roasted malt aroma features chocolate, a hint of lemon, a touch of coffee, tobacco, and soap scents. Pours a dark brown with an amber hue and a moderate to large amount of smooth, even, tan head. The liquid is clear, but the beer is dark enough that it appears opaque at first. Produces fairly extensive lacing. Sharp, dry, somewhat hoppy, coffee bitter taste. A not particularly appetizing sweet and sour character develops after multiple sips. Long, bitter finish. This is not a complicated beer, but I suppose it serves its purpose adequately. Long, dirt-like, bitter aftertaste. Light to medium body. A bit oily and course. This is a drinkable beer, but, frankly, it’s not very good. I will say that it blows away the more famous Guinness Draught, for whatever that’s worth.
i prefer this over the draught but an all time favorite for me. great from the bottle or in a pint glass.

Bottle; Pours a very dark brown with small tannish head.  Aroma of roasted malt and coffee.  Flavor of roasted malt and coffee; very mellow.  Some nuttiness as well.  Body was a little on the light side.  Prefer regular Guinness

Bottle.  Pours a deep black with a small  darkish tan head that quickly disappears.  Aromas of light toasted malt with hints of coffee.  Very thin mouthfeel.  Seems overly carbonated.  Very subdued, lifeless flavor of toasted malt and light hops.  Weak bitter finish with lingering coffee tastes. Just an OK beer.  Greatly prefer the Draught version over this.
Pours dark with a creamy tan head.  More flavor than guiness, particularly that of guinness.  The only downside is a metallic after taste.

The aroma is of dark roasted grains. The flavour is very bitter and metallic. In fact, it has a very overpowering metallic taste both while drinking and afterwards. The texture is pretty thin. This beer is entirely overrated, and I can honestly say that it’s one of my least favourite beers of all time.

Pours as dark as CocaCola.  I have to say I love love love the flavor of this beer, but cant stand the aftertaste.  It is at times unbearably burnt bitter tastng, but then again I’ve drank a few that went down perfectly smooth.  The ones I’ve drank that had a smooth aftertaste I would rate a perfect 5.

Can’t believe I’ve never gotten around to drinking this before. Bomber or so sized bottle.  Pours dark brown/light black with a light brown head.  Aroma is that Guinness smell - roasty, bitter, chocolate with the chocolate being more pronounced.  Taste is dry, creamy, watery, roasty, with a bitter chocolate finish.  More flavorful and better than regular Guinness.  Still, there are plenty of other stouts/dry stouts I would get over this.

Very decent beer for those who want something thick but not sweet, and dont want to pay an arm and a leg for it. Compares with beers twice its price. You cannot see through the glass that this is in. Bright white foamy head.

Aroma and flavor have hints of molasses with a little nuttiness underlying.  Definitely has more oomph than the draft, taste-wise.  It’s Guinness, what the hell more can you say?  You’ve tasted it!  We’ve all tasted it!  Now to find some export versions...
a well brewed stout with plenty of dark roasted flavor with nothing wrong with it s flavor.
This 12oz. bottle had the tan head that lasted a long time.  Musty yeast, a little roast, and a moderate amount of sugary chocolate.  Very decent and would make a regular drinker.
A deep, dark beer with a thick strong taste to match.  It really is stout.  Roasted flavors with a cream head.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark black/brown with a frothy tan head that retains fairly well and laces the glass.



The aroma is musty yeast, metallic grains and some chocolate.



The flavor is grainy chocolate,coffee and a little slightly sour fruit with a burnt roasted bitter finish that lingers in the aftertaste.  The mouthfeel is medium with some sharp carbonation.



Overall, a decent dry stout.  It’s much better than the nitro draught, but I’ve had much better stouts.

if you like your beer to hit your mouth like a strong pot of coffee and wake your ass right up, drink this shitty mess. tastes like a garbage man stopped at my house and gave me the coffee in his thermos. why people drink this expensive shit is beyond me. tastes like ASS
Finding this on tap with a bartender that really knows how to pull it is a blessing.
not bad especially when you get used to the bitterness  but i would much rather have the draught.
I enjoyed it but I also like dark beers, its a pretty common beer, nice smooth feeling with an earthy aroma and taste.   Pretty good for the price

Most of my experience with Guinness has been the draft - which is probably why I have always had such a low opinion of their products. Finally I managed to get around to trying this one.  Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a medium sized fluffy brown head. The head lingered nicely. The aroma was light toasted malt. The flavor was a bit gritty and had a nice presence of roasted/toasted malt. The finish was a bit bitter. Not bad at all. This one redeems the brewer in my eyes.

12oz bottle - I’m actually quite surprised I’ve never rated this one.  Pours black with a fair tan head that stays well and leaves lace.  Aromas of slight roasted malts, and a touch of coffee.  Flavor is roasted malts, slight chocolate, and a little coffe.  Dry throughout with medium body and a very dry finish.  Slight bitterness at the finish.  This is a solid brew and tends to be my standby...
Earlier Rating: 8/7/2005 Total Score: 3.3
12oz bottle - Pours black with a nice tan head.  Aroma of light roasted malt and coffee.  Flavor is much the same with a dry finish.  Palate is full bodied creamy and smooth.  Quite drinkable when you want to have more than one stout but not as robust as other stouts I’ve tried. Basically what can you say about this one that hasn’t already been said.
Extreemly dark pour. A solid and smooth feel  with respectable taste. A pleasant lingering aftertaste/
smell is ok, light hop amd coffee smell.  taste is thin and every flavor in this is subdued.  its alright i guess

Pretty good, not for the average macro drinker (obviously). I’ve heard this is more like the original Guinness, as opposed to the modern Guinness Draught. Very nice head with pleasant hoppy aroma. Generally good taste but with a very strong, and long bitter finish.

12oz bottle. poured dark brown with off-white head. nose is very faint, some stale roasted and hop notes. flavor is again pretty stale, some roasted chocolate notes but those are very faint. mild sweetness. finishes dry. a pretty boring beer.

Pours a dark brown with a creamy beige head. Faint roasted malt and bready aroma with hints of sweet smoke, black coffee and something burnt. Some bitterness in aftertaste.  I enjoy it more than the draught.   Rate: 3.1
02/28/2010
not bitter or burnt this time, giving this a 3.5

341mL bottle. Pours very dark brown, motor oil like colour. Aroma is similar to generic Canadian pale ales but a little sharper. Flavour is  relatively weak and watery but has the distinctive toasted/burnt Guinness flavour and bitterness. Much lighter mouthfeel than expected for a beer this dark. Dissapointing compared to Guinness Draught.

From a 12 oz. distinctive shaped Guinness bottle with no freshness date, short blurb on the back label, brewed in Canada, sampled at cellar temperature in a pint glass. 

Poured a reddish hued blackish brown with a frothy, foamy, bubbly tan head, decent retention, minimal amount of ringed sticking.

Aromas of roasted malts, earthy coffee and charcoal, sweet estery and floral.

Good, even medium carbonation and a malty crisp, dry, slightly slick, smooth airy medium bodied mouthfeel.

An old familiar taste, malty flavors, burnt grains and molasses, charcoal and earthy coffee, a sweet dark fruitiness, a subtle hop presence, mild bitterness towards the end, and a dry burnt grainy, earthy malty bitter finish.

You either love this or hate it, this has been an old bar stand-by with me, great with the beef and barley soup I had for lunch today.

Oh guinness! where to begin? First off did you know doctors subscribe this to woman to drink during pregnancy in europe. It’s true. I drink it because I like the taste (that you have to grow up with) And the solid black poo that comes out the next day. Black as night it’self.
Pours black with thick creamy head.  I much prefer the Dublin draught version.  Burnt chocolate and a long dryness.  An astringent bitterness.
again no more neeeds to be said of a guinness product grab one today they great beers
Bottle. 12 OZ. Very dark with thick, long-lasting off white head. Nice lacing.  Average malty aroma.  Decent palate.  Flavor is a little watered down, but smooth.  Pretty mediocre.

Bland.  One dimmensional.  Over-rated.  Yeah, I’d rather have one of these than a bud light, but... so what?  Guinness is a relatively new "invention"... Most people don’t realize that it is really two seperate beers (a dark ale and a bacteria-infected pale ale) that are blended just before bottling/kegging... and It’s got just about the same calories and alcohol level as bud light.  If you want a really good, true to style Irish stout, do yourself a favor and try a Beamish...  It easily beats Guinness.  And as a side note: Actually, Guiness was not the stout that was suggested for pregnant women... That would be Milk Stout... milk stout is brewed with lactose ( a non-fermentable sugar) and it was believed that this milk sugar aided in the mothers ability to nurse.

I love dark beer.   My motto is " the darker the better".  Well, Guinness is about as dark as you can get...it is black.  If you follow my theory, it would be the best beer out there,  Well, it isn’t.  It isn’t bad, mind you, but just a little f""flat" tasting.  You expect, looking at the color, this great big taste,  but it just  doesn’t happen.  It’s disappointing..sort of blah.  The best thing to do with Guinness Stout is to mix it into a "black and tan".  By itself it is OK, but nothing special.

Pours a motor oil black with a small tan head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, and a hint of chocolate. Flavor is mainly roasted malts and coffee. Medium body with a little bit of bitterness in the finish.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Completely black and opaque with a good, lacing, beige head. Toasted and lightly burned malt aroma. Medium body with some lightly sweet, burned malt and a bitter, burned finish deriving from the same malt. 230307
THis is an ok stout. Nothing spectacular, I prefer the draught beer, but after tasting many a microbrew, I realize this just cant compare. However, I still enjoy it.

I don’t like the extra stout as well as the Draught. To me Guinness needs to be foamy, thick, and heavy. The extra stout while full bodied in taste does not deliver the same experience as the Draught or overseas kegged version.
It should be drunk warmer than normal beer to deliver the full flavor.

Pours very dark - nearly back (dark brown and red shine through in the light) with a tan head. The aroma has a decent bit of hops, burnt grain, and yeast. The flavor starts off with an interesting earthy hoppiness and yeastiness combined with strong roasted flavors. The middle of the tongue picks up slight sweetness from the malts, more hops, and hints of burnt toast. The finish is full-bodied and roasty, with a strong hop flavor, too. The hop bitterness is noticable but not too strong - but lots of black grain. A very decent stout.

Dark brown with a light tan head.  Sweet, smoky roasted malt aroma.  Dry, coffee flavor that gives way to a sour bitterness and a finish that reminds me of charcoal.  Quite a disappointment after the draft version.

Pour was ultra dark brown with a thick, nearly rocky off-white head.  Offered up decent lacing.  The aroma was slightly smoky with a bit of sweetness coming through.  The flavor was initially sweet and dry but soon overtaken by a sour flavor that bordered on wretched.  Blech.  Like opening one of those little plastic packets of soy sauce at the mall and drinking it.  Mouthfeel was borderline watery.  Didn’t really enjoy this.

Pours a nice dark brown/black with a decent brown head.  Nice bubblegum like dark fruit malty sweetness on the nose with a hint of smoke.  Medium carbonation with great coffee like chocolate bitterness.  the finish is brutally bitter with a smokey oakiness to it, but nicely balanced.  A solid beer to say the least.
I would normally rate it closer to the draught, but what a terrible aftertaste.  Although I like this one better for Carbombs!

kind of salty hops, not particularly good, i guess after enough on st pattys day they are good. light tan head
 not to great after taste

Pours black with a medium creamy light tan head.  Aroma is not what I was expecting, almost reminds me of Mexican lagers.  Taste is more of the same, this is really disappointing.  Sweet and metallic, some bitterness.Some roasted coffee comes thru in the end, but overall....Blah.
Very light aroma.  Dark color, thin tan head.  Lingering bitterness.  Strong aftertaste.  Sweetness in finish.
Pours black with a big light brown head.  Aroma is of coffee and burned flavors.  Flavor is nice and roasty but there is too much carbonation and the mouthfeel is a little watery.
Bottle. Color of night. Smells bready, like toast--and 7-11 coffee. Bitter and dry. Prefer it to Guinness Draught, but not by much.

22 oz. bottle, poured black with tan bubbles, roasted and dark roasted malt fragrances, faint dark chocolate and caramel, little sweetness, faint molasses and cold coffee fragrances, dark malt taste, some bitterness on the tongue, dry on the palate, faint coffee flavor, creamy in the mouth, hint of soy sauce flavor in after taste here and there, smooth drink.

I’m going to assume readers of this web site don’t need and explanation or description of this classic so I’ll move on to my other opinions.  Still better than many of its imitators, but poured from the bottle there is a noticeable decline in quality and taste.  Thinner, weaker head and less creamy, the bottled version should be your last resort to drinking Guinness after 1) On Tap, and  2) Can with that little carbonation ball.  Despite my criticism, for a mass produced stout, it remains the standard by which all others will be judged.  Now go pick up a 4 pack of this stuff and get to work!

A classic international staple.  Tried this again today after not having one in years and noticed the sour beer that guinness adds to their beer.  Its more pronounced than the roast and adds a dimension that you dont get even with most craft stouts.  The flavor is robust and satisfying but vanishes almost immediately in between sips.  Overall excellent beer full of character and body.

Bottle.  Poured out opaque dark brown with a tan head that clings to the edge of the glass and left a good amount of lacing.  A sweet malty aroma with hints of acidic fruits and grapes (weird).  Slightly sweet flavor with a noticeable roast character that lingers a bit.  An out of place but small degree of sourness pervades the brew.  Thin, light bodied with a little bit of a lingering bitterness.
What can I say?  It’s my comfort beer.  A highly-drinkable classic that has little else going for it.  I’ve had better, but I’ll not turn down a Guinness.

I prefer Guinness Draught, this isn’t a bad beer in its own right. It pours dark, but not quite as dark as the draft. This beer doesn’t have the same thick head that the draght has and it vanishes pretty quickly. This beer has a little bit of a sweet smell compared to the strong coffee smeel of the draught. This beer has a crisp bitter taste, but the most recent time I tried this beer out of a bottle it had a hint of sknuky flavor. The one place where this beer really stands out is that it feels great in my mouth. It has the perfect combination of body and drinkability. Overall, this is a good beer, but I wouldn’t choose this over some other stouts and wouldn’t choose it over Guinness Draught.

very pleasant aroma and so black it’s opaque. looks very thick. smooth flavor, but can’t taste any alcohol whatsoever. flavor resembles roasted wine, and has a deliciously bitter afterthought. the flavor is very pleasant. although, the flavor at the very end and afterward tastes like it is fortified with blood. are the guinness brewers vampires and we don’t know it yet?

Nice creamy  head, hearty roast aroma, roasted bitter smooth on the tounge with a medium mouth feel, sour lactic finish. Not teh best stot out but definatly the most popular and good enough to drink everyday.

almost opaque... when light gets thru it is almost deep brown.. with thin tan head
Nose: Clean, roast, (slight coffee espresso??) and some corn
Taste: Very slight coffee, chocolate peeks thru before the DMS (corn) and astringency take over... 
Finish is dry lingering roasty and clean hop bite
Overall: Darn it... I dont know if this is a bad bottle... but the corn like flavors are very distracting.. the clean dry-stout like flavors are there but drowned out. I wonder if this is a quality control issue...

Ratin’ this shit at work. Only remotely decent free beer available. This, unfortunately, is like an amplified normal Guinness (surprise, surprise), but what it’s amplified is not very good. Normal Guinness succeeds (somewhat) in its very gentle, smooth flavor. This one, OTOH, is over-roasted to a point is gross burnt bitterness. This bottle is also a bit skunky, and corny in the nose. If people are in love with normal Guinness, I wouldn’t necessarily push them towards real stouts... if they are in love with this, though, they have an exciting road ahead of them.

Pours a opaque ebony. The head was more cream colored unlike guinness draught’s white head. The smell is espresso like with a strong malty aroma. The taste is slightly chocolatly with a vanilla/french roast bite. The finish was dry and harsh with a bitter hop aftertaste. Carbonation was a bit heavy. A nice stout, not as good as the draught though. 
Earlier Rating: 1/24/2005 Total Score: 3.5
Pours a opaque ebony. The head was more cream colored unlike guinness draught’s white head. The smell is espresso like with a strong malty aroma. The taste is slightly chocolatly with a vanilla/french roast bite. The finish was dry and harsh with a bitter hop aftertaste. Carbonation was a bit heavy. A nice stout, not as good as the draught though.
Pours jet black with a sweet molasses aroma with chocolate and coffee.  Taste is bitter with the coffee notes coming through.  Tasty beer with some chocolates
Seems to be a smokier, darker chocolate, and more carbonated version of regular Guinness. Not much more to say about that.

341 ml bottle - pours much lighter than I was expecting - still dark, but certainly not stout dark, more like dark brown ale dark.  Foamy off white head dissipates pretty quickly, but a small surface layer remains.  Aroma very much like a dunkel, or even a pale lager - not a stout.  Taste - yup, it’s a Labatt product.  Not a bad thing necessarily, but it has that distinct macro-taste and mouthfeel.  Sort of metallic and sour with some adjunct and a faint roastiness in the finish, just so they can call it a stout.  But it isn’t - it’s basically a 50 with some Guinness wort extract in there to darken things up a bit.  Not bad, but not a stout.  As per comparisons to the actual Guinness, like, the one from Ireland......I honestly think I might choose the Labatt version, which lacks the wateriness of the Irish one.....it’s a close call though.  I’ll have to do a side by side tasting and possibly rerate.

The best bottled version of guinness sold in North America is brewed in Canada under license. This is the closest to guinness stout as served on tap in pubs in the US.
A benchmark stout  that never disappoints.
dark black.  dry malt flavor.  bitter finish with a hint of dark chocolate.
Nice dark color, thick foam that lasts too long.  Flavor is medium bitterness to me, but I am not much of a beer critic.  It was just okay, did not live up to the hype.
A good ordinary beer. Bitter taste. Color is extremely dark. head is cream colored and  takes a while to get rid of.
Great head retention, but with no smell, so it is basically useless except to give you a foam mustache.  Beer itself is bland, watery, and very much like a macrobrew.  Quite a disappointment.

THOUGHTS: I think I’m rating this in the right spot. It was a Guinness Extra stout brewed in Canada, but my bottle said it was brewed by Buiness Brewing Co., New Brunswick, Canada not Labatt Breweries, London, Canada. I always would tell people that I liked this more than Guinness Draught but this was the first time I tried them one after the other and now I know for sure that I do. Not much better in aroma than the draught, but way better in the flavor and palate. Much fuller flavor and less one-sided in flavor. A pretty good dry stout.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark brown. It was a little lighter than the draught. Ther was a huge off-white head that mostly diminished and left fair lacing. The aroma was light to moderate dark bread, raste, chocolate and coffee malts. Also none of the witch hazel aroma I noticed in the draught. The initial flavor was lightly sweet and bitter, and the finish was lightly sweet and acidic, heavily bitter, and a little sour and salty with an average duration. The body was meium to full and dry, but not as much as the draught, with fizzy carbonation and a slightly metallic finish.
A nice beer that is much smoother after the first sip. Goes very good with pub food. The benchmark for other stout beers.
This is the original Guinness. This is the beer that made the company’s name. The beer’s roasted malts give a distinctive dry, oaky, slightly coffee flavor. No nitro in this brew.

Poured from a bottle and the bofdy was dark almost opaque.  Head was a dark tan.  Very plain and flavor and overall just an average beer.  I agree with other raters that say they remember when this beer was considered strong.  For the price I would take samual smith over this anyday, heck I would take samuel adams over this.

Bottle: pours 3/4 inch head;  body is solid dark mahogany color.  Nice malty aroma.  Excellent head throughout. The malts are right up front but nicely balanced with strong roasting.  Finish imparts a mild roast bite and is dry.

I beleive I had this on my 21st birthday some years back, and i thought i was going to die. More flavor then the draught with real nice head and good color. Back then i used to know only mich golden and this was to much for me, i can put them back now but dont ever buy this with better micros in my area...to many brews to little time
This dark brown ale poured with a beautiful tan head. The flavor is roasted malt with a hint of coffee. The flavor improves significantly as the beer warms, and leaves a smoky taste on ones tongue.
You can never go wrong with a nice stiff guinness stout.  Very dark. Very dry. Very bitter. Very good.  A delicious stout that should be a staple in every stout lovers beer list.

Pours an apparently black color, until you hold it to the light and see that it is really a deep dark brown. A good inch of frothy tan foam tops it, leaving behind some nice thick rings. Mild aroma of raosted dark malt,

Nice roasted bitter grains witha bit of burnt oily coffee. A roasted-tangy flavor kicks in after the initial sip, and sticks around into the aftertaste. Just a hair ashy in the finish. Pleasant smooth carbontation, just short of medium bodied.
Pours black with a tan head. Roasty malt aroma and flavor with some coffee notes. Is full yet watery at the same time. Drink in small quantities and do not use for drinking games.

Aroma of a watery cheap macro? I would have to agree, not much flavor here, watery, burnt taste. Not terrible, somewhat bitter bakers chocolate aftertaste. I’m on the fence with this one. Probably won’t buy again.
Very good stout. with its nice black color and malty taste. It also has a very dark head. This kind of stout should be enjoyed in small quantities. Very good winter beer
More of a bitter taste than that of the draught.  Big head and no settling action.  Still a nice option and tasty.

Bottle. "Guinness Traditional Extra Stout". Bought in Mendoza, Argentina, on a hot summer day in January. Straight from the cooler! Black colour. Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate, little bitter. Flavour: smooth, bit waterish compared to the normal draught version, chocolate, some hops. Watery aftertaste actually but still darn good. Though the draught one is better.

Pours nearly opaque with a thick tan head.  Aroma is pretty faint but of both dark malts and slight hop smell.  Mouthfeel is a little thinner than regular Guinness, I can remember when this beer tasted strong to me.  Still very good but makes me yearn for the real Extra Stout.

what is this in my fridge? sweet! guinness extra stout someone left at my house after a holiday party! thanks someone! hmm im just gonna sit this here while i drink this delicious goose island IIPA. *hour or so passes* okay that was tasty. what about this guinness? let me just pour this into my trusty stone ris glass. what the hell?!?!!!? watery thin dark brown? hmm. lets smell this stuff. Colt 45? Old E? King Cobra? no wait...its guinness?!!?!!?! I am afraid to taste. okay......lets take a little sip..........BLAH!!!!!!*spit spit spit* what the hell!?!?!?! weak watery fizzy with a hint of that chocolate easter bunny you forgot about ?years ago....you find it under your bed......chocolate kinda sounds good right now....ill just take one bite...oh god that was a bad idea.... oh wait here comes the finish.......oh its horrible.  the finish is so horrible like chewing on four day old fogers coffee grounds. i need to pour this out and get a strohs to wash the taste out of my mouth. its giving me a headache. blah. never again. Literally the only beer that I have ever poured out!

Guiness, Guinnes, why do I keep trying?  It must be the mystique of the first ‘craft’ beer I sampled, years ago, along with Heinie dark.  But I sample this one as I rate.  I have been mostly disappointed with the few other guinnes styles I have drank.  I’m hoping this has some carbonation left over from 1759.  Brown 12 oz bottle, must be from the UK, 12 oz, not 11  point something.  Shorter and stubbier than most bottles. With a small head it pours nearly opaque in my stein.  Not overwhelming but the slight aroma of a porter or stout, you know, typical dark beer smell. The flavor is pleasing with the available carbonation.  Smooth fine bubbles grace the back of my throat. After the sip a nice short burst of foam arises to the top of the brew.  Has a nice roastyness about it without being overbearing.  Finish is not an onslaught but it does gently fade into a grapefruit peel bitterness that you won’t soon forget. Carbonation is much better than the other guins. Best guinny I’ver recently had. Could not drink too many of these at a time. Taste is somewhat like La Rossa but not as oppressing. Better than draught guin and mendico black hawk dry stouts.

Not big on aroma. Opaque with good head retention. Tan head. Malty sweetness with dark chocolate notes and very long bitter finish. Coffee and even raisin-like sweetness is detectable. Very good. It goes down very easy. My kind of beer.
This is a great beer.  I have to say I prefer this over the draught.  It’s not all that common in this area but it can be found if you know where to look.

I had no fuckin idea there were so many varieties of this stout. I live in the Northeast, so I am assuming that I am drinking the Labatt’s version. It was palatable, decently hopped, with a nice mouth feel. However, I swigged it right from the bottle, which gaves it a little extra bite. This is an ok session beer, I prefer the Sierra Nevada Stout though. 

PS You can taste
 the swilly Labatt’s underneath it all...which blows.

From Canadian bottle. Light toasty grain aroma. Mild chocolate in sour milk. Carbonic gassiness. Bit of sweet malt and light metallic tang. Dark brown black clear with light tan lacing head. Light watery body with medium carbonation. Starts with quick bit of carbonic sourness. Bitter coffee sourness. Watery bitter after and finish. No complexity at all. Tangy watery after and a bit chalky.

A 22 oz bottle with no made or freshness date on it. The beer poured a dark brown body with a brown head. The smell is of toasted malt and a little bit metallic. The taste is a nice malt that finished with a Carmel taste. Good carbonation and flavor all the way through.

Sampled on 11/29/2006 at the November meeting of the Junedale Beer Klub.  Brought by Tods...  

Tasting notes:  

Very, very dark brown (almost black) in color and clear.  Large, dense, and creamy tan head.  Flavors of dark chocolate and biscuits.  Dry bitter finish.
POurs black with a nice pillowy tan head.Lots of roastiness aroma and flavor.Hints of caramel and toasted malts.Had some bitterness at the end.
Easier to find than Guinness Draught. I do drink it on occasion, even though I prefer Draught. Still, it’s a good smelling dark beer with a bitter taste. It’s my number 2 choice.

Cold 22oz bottle:  Pours a dark chocolate brown color with a decent sized tan head that mostly dissolves.  Aroma is of roasted malts and earth.  Taste is mainly of roasted malts.  Medium bodied, crisp and well carbonated.  Ending is bitter with sour notes.
Smells roasty and pours a nice head.  Nice strong hop bitter that overpowers almost all alcohol flavor. Good balance.

Always reliable and even throughout. Distinctive crisp bitter ending than makes you salivate and bring out the blaclk patent malt and wish for more. I encourage people to write poems about its mystery.

I really don’t care for this beer. It certainly looks nice but the flavor is too bitter and there is a real lack of carbonation. The aroma I find to be too malty. I have tasted better stouts even though this is supposed to be one of the best,
Always smooth, no alcohol flavor.  If you’re not sure what to order, order this.  Slight hints of choclate.

Malty aroma suppressed by thick cream head, dark brown appearance, rich dry flavor with no hint of water, smooth on the palate. This is a great beer, will defnitely buy again and recommend to all to try at least once.

smooth mouth feel, leaves a dry resin on the tongue ( but its mild and good).  Sweet molasses and sweet coffee aroma.  no alcohol taste.  great lacing and character.  Best Guinness i’ve had.  good for a mass produced brew.  Don’t be intimidated by the color or style, its tame.  Try it.

poured dark, medium/light viscosity. 1/4 big bubbled brown head. up to the light not as dark as a lot of porters/impys.  first sniff gives hoppy chocolate.  almost a rancid smell, but the kind i’ve found in lots of beers and not the kind that is bad or says the beer’s infected.  not strong enough; i’m tired of dipping my nose in these damned underpowered-aroma beers.  horribly light-bodied.  pretty empty taste with lots of back-ended bitterness.  bad bitterness.  maybe a bit oxidized.  worse than guinness, this beer fucking sucks ass.

Bottle.  Sweet malty aroma.  Malty sweet flavor with light bitter earthy finish.  Slightly nutty. Frothy head, with tan color. Good flavor, very drinkable, fairly simple and straight forward, nothing outstanding or complex.  I agree that it’s not as good as the draught.
Not as good as the Draught, but still pretty good. Dark brown with little hints of chocolate.
Pours dark black brown with off white head. Aroma is malt, coffee, molasses. Flavor is coffee, grass, caramel, molasses.
In my opinion, this is better than Guinness Draught. Richer in flavor than its kin, and just as attractive. Both are pretty good examples of the style.

Came to my table with its famous milky carbonation billowing up from the bottom.  Odor of coffee and malts.  Once it settled I took the taste, wow, was I disappointed.  Yeah, malt, some hops and coffee.  Sour and rather boring on the back side.  Could have been better, many better stouts here in USA.
Thick frothy head.  A bit more hoppiness than normal guinness.  Not very good though.  Flavor of weak chocolate malts and sourdough.  Can’t say that I’m impressed.

The beer to be seen with when you need to be seen with beer.  Smell-Great.  Appearance--Bloody fine.  But here we falter.  It writes checks it can’t cash.  It makes me root for ulster.  Hints of cardboard and grass roots.  Perhaps defined best by its Lacanian lack.
You can taste hints of chocolate in this beer.  It’s quite malty and dark like you would expect.  Good stuff.
Malty aroma with hints of chocolate.Pours dark black with tan head.Slight chocolate taste.Very thin in mouthfeel.

22oz bomber. Very dark amber color with thick creamy tan head. The head doesn’t match the unsinkable quarter inch foam wedge of the draft version. There are roasted, molasses and licorice notes in the aroma. Tasty rich malt flavor of chocolate malts, black patent type burnt malts and sweet molasses.

first impression is bitterness.  As I drink it, I notice other flavors such as roaster malt and acidity.  Lacing is very interesting with this beer too .  some notes of coffe hidden in the aftertaste.
Bottle 42F Pint. Mild malt aroma, nice head, dark color, tastes watery with a bit of roasted malt and some chocolate, not a great stout but well known.

Poured from bottle into a shaker glass, it formed a thick, foamy head with the color of light brown sugar.  The head quickly collapsed into a crater-pitted wasteland.  The body was dark brown (almost black) but had some ruby hints show through when held to the light.  I’m going on and on about the appearance because there’s not much else going for this beer.  The aroma was a weak mix of roasted malts and sourdough bread.  The flavor was dry with a little tangy sourness in the finish.  Body was medium-to- thin.

12oz. bottle.  Black with creamy tan head.  Heavenly aroma of caramel, roasted barley and chocolate.  Big body, big flavor, with  bitterness in perfect harmony.  Too rich for a session beer, but one of my all time faves.   THIS IS STOUT. RE-RATE:  This has become very different of late.  May be the Canadian version we are getting now.  Watery, far less flavor, will not be buying this again.
Poured black with a creamy head. Taste was a bit disappointing. Flavor was thin and minimal. Maybe I got a bad bottle...
Pours a dark brown/black.  Decent smokey/chocolate aroma.  Flavors is same as aroma.  Very easy to drink and a little thin.  Better than the draught.

bitter, soft carbonation, creamy, full body, and a black beer. Loving my past experience with stouts, I was expecting somewhat of a joy since the university students seemed to love it (which i thought was probably the best considering that they love macros). Quite disappointed. My friend and I could not stop criticizing it. Nice bitter finish, and it has the overall feel of a stout. However, the within the flavour is a signature labatt taste, and a somewhat minimal chocolate flavour. A well rounded beer ruined by the skunky smell and taste. Nice appearance, but not on my future list of beers to drink. 

EDIT: I had another bottle recently, so i’m raising the score a bit. It’s actually not too bad. I was mildy surprised by how much better it tastes in a glass (yes, i should have done that first).  Tastes a bit nutty. I don’t know why everyone seems to hate guinness, perhaps it is the draught that’s miserable. Is it a connoisseur beer? I wouldn’t think so, but it’s damn good for a macro. For $37 a 24, it’s definitely worth the buy. Cheers to Labatt for the one decent beer that they have managed to brew.
a very thick and dark beer. has a 2 finger head. Alsdo it is chocolate taste.
Bottle.  Pitch black pour, tan head that disappeared quick.  Pour from bottle only had some of the signature layer of a draft pour.

Dark beer with a tan foamy head. hints of coffee and chocolate in the flavor. 
Aroma was that of a standard issue guinness.  I prefer guinness draught
A very, very dark, almost black colored stout.  It has a unique taste that can be appreciated if you like a heavy beer, otherwise, avoid it if you are primarily a lager, light beer drinker
now this is the best beer ever created, you really have to be in a guinness mood but once you are there you can go on all night with its rich taste and and how smooth it is going down

Pours opaque dark brown w/ a shallow puddle of semi creamy froth. Aroma malty w/ some faint roasted notes. Full nectar w/ mellow residual effers. Flavors are fully dry w/ moderately malted coffee bean and leather. The malt recedes quickly then a hoppy bitterness kicks you in the mouth thru to the finish leaving an asprin tingle and a parched palate. A simple brew w/ a strong bittering.

Tasted 04/10/2006. "Tallie" bottle from the cellar at the Currimundi shopping centre. Black with a dark tan disappearing head. Caramel and roast barley dominate the nose, with a slighly musty sourness.  Inthe mouth it is the same, with an extremely long dry astringency in the extended finish. Lightly carbonated but the roastiness makes it seem quite zippy. Good drinking.

Nice aroma and of course that thick frothy Guinness head.  Very strong and even sometimes hard to tolerate if you’re not up to it.  Damn good stout though, puts hair on your chest and makes you feel like a man. Muahaha.

Bitter sweet aroma with a thick frothy head of three fringers that remains throughout.  Dark brown complexion with no apparent carbonation.  Strikingly bitter tasting with a flat palate.  Very delicious with any seafood.
tasty beer. not too bubbly sort of heavy good overall taste in mouth and afterwords. settles well in my tummy. i would drink 3 or 7 if i had the bucks. but i don’t so now i’m drinking a labatts

Dark black pour.  Slight roasted, malty, coffee aromas.  Flavor seemed a bit too bitter and didn’t mesh particularly well for me.  Decent, but I’ll stick with the original stuff from now on if I want a Guinness.

This beer is much better to me than the draught version.  A nice beer for the half & half.  Great, and great history.  You’ll feel a wee bit more Irish when you drink this.  And you might get ahold of the Crak!  (I’m Irish....)
nothing like the original....not a huge fan.  sorry for my poor rating.  i wouldnt get it again.

First taste was strangely cherry and strawberry.  After this passed, it was just a nice roasted flavor.  No hops really.  Fuller mouthfeel and flavor than the draught version with nitro.  Basically just tastes like roasted malt.  This is a pretty tasty dry stout.  Very dry roasted malt flavor.  Quite acidic, actually.  Very similar to a cup of black coffee.  Not bad at all.

Guiness Extra Stout
Bomber
Recent bottling, imbibed 09/06
Medium hard pour in an English pint glass

Poured black with deep brown mahogony outer edges with a huge mocha fully lasting rocky head with excellent lacing.

Smelt of moderate molasses, with faint deep roast, and coffee.

Taste was upfront moderate lactic sourness and light sweet molasses followed by a strong bitter burnt aftertaste with accompanying moderate acidity that dies with faint fruity esters and light semi dark chocolatey sweetness that all blend nicely in a long finish.  Mouthfeel was medium body, slightly dry, lively carbonation, with moderate astringency.

Overall, it still bites strongly like a classic beer that one can always fall back on.

Side note: The pale ale base does seem to give it a more watery feel than it used to.   The flavor remains mostly unaffected though.

Wow.  I passed this beer up many times because I thought it would be just like the draught.  Pleasantly surprised, this beer looks great, aroma of roasted hops, and has more depth than the draught.  Tastes like espresso, notes of oak, and as others have mentioned "burnt toast".  Not bad.

pour is midnight black with small tannish head. Taste is burnt malt, roasted coffee, and slight chocolate flavor. Mouthfeel is initially creamy but transitions to very bitter towards the end. Ok, but just not my style for a stout. This definitely has more going on than the draught (widget) version, but I cant say I love it. Guinness is at its best when  mixed with a shot of baileys and a shot of jameson in the form of an irish car bomb in this rater’s opinion.
Pours pitch black with with thick off-white head out of a snifter. Strong taste of espresso with hints of burnt toast. This definitely upsets the bottled Guinness Draught(bottle).

Pours black and thick, with a frothy light brown head.  Aroma is complex, heavly toasted or burnt malt, chocolate malt, mild coffee, oranges and lightly earthy.  Flavor is lightly sweet and moderatly bitter, with a more bitter finish.  Medium to full bodied, creamy, toasted chocolate malts.

12 oz. bottle.  neck label says "Imported Guinness Extra Stout"  a very nice everyday type of stout.  roasted malt aroma and flavor made even better without the nitro.  
Earlier Rating: 10/2/2005 Total Score: 3.4
can’t believe I hadn’t yet tried this one.  jet black with a good looking tan head.  ahhhh smell those bitter hops!  flavor is of dark roast malt, bitter chocolate and hints of coffee on the end.  as you would expect, that dry bitter finish on the tail end.  as the weather starts to cool, I’m looking forward to drinking more stouts!

From the bottle it pours black with a thick light brown head. Malty aroma. Roasted malt and chocolate flavor with more carbonation that its brother. Good brew, but I prefer the regular draught.
Earlier Rating: 7/15/2006 Total Score: 3.6
From the bottle it poured dark brown/black with thick lasting head. Aroma of malt, chocolate and coffee. More carbonated than the original and with more bite (a bit of hops ?) making it more beer-like than a stout. Enjoyable brew.

Soapbox: Why isn’t it easier to find this beer than the crappy, watery Guinness Draft with the gimicky nitro widget that is the bane of beer drinkers who favor taste over appearance?  Rating: Pours an almost opaque blackish brown with a large, fuffy, lacy tan head. The aroma is Coffee and toffee. Creamy medium body with light carbonation. The taste starts lightly sweet with coffee, burnt toast, and a bit of chocolate. Espresso-bitter finish with a touch of smoke and pepper. Re-Rate 05/2007: Pours an almost completely opaque black with a large, fluffy tan head. Aroma of yeast and chocolate. A touch of coffee in the taste, along with roasty malt and a bit of molasses. Medium body and light carbonation. A bit of ash in the otherwise nondescript finish. The mouthfeel is significantly different than the nitro widget version which somehow feels silky and watery at the same time. The nitro version also lacks the yeasty nose, but the nitro doesn’t have as much of a nose in general, and the nitro taste is comparatively vacant. I’m not sure why the brewer claims it is "Similar to the Draught version, but without the extra nitrogen." Color perhaps?

Pours a black color with brown highlights and a thick rocky tan head. Aroma and flavor of coacoa with some roastyness and a mild bitter finish. The body is light to medium and the texture is creamy, the carbonation is soft. I definitely prefer this version of Guinness than the bland, watery Guinness Draft that comes in cans.
Dryer than many stouts, which makes it more drinkable than sweet stouts for me. Attractive black color. Roasted malt flavor.
Guinness Extra Stout is, I think, one of the greatest beers ever crafted by man.

Pours jet black into a snifter.  Slight caramel notes.  Off-white head with excellent retention leaves pancake bubbles on the surface. Thin, crisp and dry with roasted caramel and a lasting bitter hop finish.  Much better than draft...

Bottle. I guess this stout is not for me, i found the flavor overwhelming and the after taste made me not want to drink it. I bought a 6 pack but because i didnt want to waste alcohol i drank  4 1/2 of them before i couldn’t take it anymore. Like i said, i guess extra stouts are not my thing.

Tap:  What can I say that hasn’t already been said.  Pours jet black with a tan creamy head.  Taste of bitter chocolate and burnt coffee with no carbination.  In my state people think this is the beer of all beers, thats because we can’t get anything above 6%. But I just have never been a guinness fan, even when I didn’t know anything about craft beer.  I’m not taking anything away from Guinness it’s just not one of my favorites when there are much better stouts out there IMO.
can with nitrogen pack - hard to describe flavor due to the sour beer that is added during production but it is a nice sour chocolate/coffee mix with a somewhat sweet aftertaste

Black with big tan head. From Toronto Canada.  Rich mouthfeel. Nose of Malt. Taste of malt. Good tasting.  Not sure who actually brewed this 22 oz bottle.  I wonder if the serial number on the back - L11M551W L5315 MT1 gives a clue.  
Earlier Rating: 8/22/2006 Total Score: 3.7
Black. Huge head.  Big maltly nose. Thick mouthfeel.    Favor of dark malts.  Finish of chocolate.
Fantastic head, an excellent stout like drinking fizzy coffee yum toatsed chocolate malt not bad for commercial beer

Consistent.  Flavorful.  Kicks US/EU corporate beers right in the arse.  Say what you will, this is often times better than drinking  most commercial alternatives.  Don’t fool yourself, this tastes the same in any UK pub.

I really like the unique look of this beer and the initial taste is great,  but the mouthfeel and ending is too watery.  And I used to think this was a thick beer!! My how my pallete has changed.  Its still good though.

Bottle obtained locally. Deep brown/black color. Massive dense head. Disspipates quickly. Average amount of lace. Not much aroma. Also not much flavor. Perhaps some bitter chocolate,raisen,  and coffee. Hard to detect under the bitterness. Bittersweet dry finish. Don’t think I will purchase this one again, not when I can get the awesome Obsidian Stout so easily.

Opaque pour with that fantastic creamy head that lasts the whole pint.  This stout needs an appropriate pour to fully enjoy the taste and look.  I prefer the Extra Stout version hands down but it is a decent commercialized stout beer.  Burnt chocolaty and malt aroma. Good full bodied beer I enjoy on a rainy day!

Pours out a dark black colour with a tall creamy head. Scent is of chocolate and roasted malt and hints of caramel. Taste is very unique for a stout- it has a strong malt body but its hop bitterness is balanced by its smooth and creamy character. There are strong caramel notes interspersed with a sharp bitter flavour. Has layers of character that interplay well and balance out to make a well rounded stout
pours large creamy head.  somewhat on the bitter side.  I find nothing great about this beer.
From New Brunswick, so likely from Moosehead. Dark black color with a thin light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt. Flavor of roasted malt and some light chocolate.

Pours a darker brown with some red coming through.  Poured with a large foamy tan head that sustained and left some lacing.  Aroma of dark fruits, light chocolate, sweet malts and some hops in there.  Flavor of chocolate, toasted malts, dark fruits, light coffee, sweet malts and a touch of hop bitterness.
Nice when you can’t get a draught, but not the same.  Seems to go bad much faster bottles/cans of guinness with the cool high-tachnology widgets, balls, and cool-guy features.
A lot like Guinness Draught, with a similar aroma. The head isn’t as pretty and the taste is more bitter. Still, not a bad stout.

Dark brown in colour, with a thick dissipating light moka head. Sweaty malt aroma, with notes of raisins, fruity, with sulfuric notes. In mouth, acidic, with chocolate and boiled vegetables, light hops, dry and short in mouth. In a blind tasting, i thought this was a schwarzbier. June 2006.

Opaque dark brown with a thick glasscoating light brown head.  This is the real deal, not nitrogen injected like the can.  This is natural CO2 carbonation.  Aroma is roasted malt and coffee.  Delicious coffee, molasses, and bitter chocolate flavor.  Some pleasant bitterness in the aftertaste that is from the roasted (nearly burnt) malt, not hops.  This is a classic.
Much like the Draught except it uses CO2 instead of Nitrogen.  And it has more of a ’chocolate / coffee’ taste.  My favorite.  Also has hint of fruit (apple) and citrus (orange) taste.

The stout I compare all others to. I’m not pretentiously glorifying it... It’s a great beer (and reliable). I guess it’s a middle of the road stout. Not too bitter nor sweet. Thick, like a meal, but not too heavy.

God himself drinks this Emperor of  beers. The Irish make it. It is not for newbs,nor the faint of heart; it is for men and women who love the brown (or the black).
