It pours like a mystery, and while we wait, we are able to ponder its majestic slow settlement the way we’d watch a lover undress. The nose is of morning coffee and open country air. The look is of deep northern water with the sun filtering through. The head is milk and sea foam. The first taste is caramel and a whiff of the mast in the brewery. The second drink is cool, involving, and refreshing, as are those that follow. A friendly beer that bids you return, and take your time when you do.

From Friday’s scribbled notes. Pours a dark mahogany with a medium tan head.  Aromaa had a little skunk, caramel and roasty dark malts, coffee.  Taste had a lot of toffee with a roasty coffee finish.  The skunk is gone!  Light to medium bodied, sharp carbonation.  Better than the draught.  May have to rerate this one when I’ve had a couple few less beers in me.

Pours dark brown with a thin tan head.  Not nearly as much head as the nitrogenated version.  Dry, malty aroma with some hazelnut, dark fruits, brown sugar, and caramel.  Guinness has a very distinctive dry stout flavor - I like this original version more than the nitrogen one.  The extra stout is not as creamy, but there are more complex flavors and it doesn’t taste fake like the nitrogen drought bottles.  It has a pretty good mouthfeel too - at 4.3%, it’s not as thin as you would expect.  It has a dry, slightly bitter nutty finish.  Overall, I’d much prefer an imperial stout over a Guinness, but it’s a good, easy-going beer that is a good choice when there’s nothing better at a bar.

Black like the draught, but the head isn’t as creamy. Many of the same flavors as the original, but with CO2 it’s just not the same.

Earlier Rating: 6/21/2006 Total Score: 3.4
Theres miles of difference between draught (or canned) and this, so don’t expect it to taste like it did on tap. Bottled Guinness has the worst aftertaste though

One of the earliest "real" beers I had. I remember grabbing it thinking it was the draught version. Much more bitter, and slightly astringent. Not bad though. 
Earlier Rating: 2/20/2004 Total Score: 2.5
Roasted malty flavor with a very bitter aftertaste. this one had to be pretty cold to hide the bitterness, as it became too much for me as it warmed.
Just had a marmite sandwich with lettuce sprinkled with crushed pepper and washed down with a perfect pint -- of Guinness.Good combo

.5 liter bottle.  Pours a medium black and a fizzy short lived off white head.  Aroma is yeasty, and somewhat dirty, with some chocolate and nutty hints and light roast.  Light caramel sweetness, but dominated by nuts, yeast, and roast.  Dry and overcarbonated mouthfeel and the finish is a bit difficult to take, even when drunk.
Ok stout. not what i expected. i’d like to try it tapped. cans suck. but there are better cheaper stouts.
Not bad for mass produced.  Guinness has seemed to lose a bit in translation to the NA liscence.
to stale of taste for me. i love my stouts and should of stuck to original.this is hard for me to rate this bad but i did not like aftertaste or taste.
This eber is aight.  Good for a mass-produced beer.  Stouts are usually delicious.

A: Good dark tall head that grows like one of those cheap novelty snakes that kids light on July Fourth. Beer is pretty much pitch black. Heavy lacing as the head recedes minutes later and during the duration of the pint.

S:Hearty malt smell; hints of floral hoppiness

T: Heavily toasted malt flavor. Strong coffee and earthy flavors explode on the tongue. Good hop balance especially on the way down.

M: Nice sized beer with good presence. Palate is nice and dry.

Notes: Great classic beer. Not a bad option... especially if on a tight budget or if you’re living in rural SC. *winks*
This had a nice thick lasting head.Aroma was a pleasant malt.somewhat bitter.biting taste.quite good.I liked this alot.will buy again!!

Why mess around when you’ve got a good thing already? I didn’t think this was nearly as good as the Guinness Draught, although some of the difference may be bottle (never seen this one on tap) vs. draft. Too thin for a stout.

Not a very good stout at all, this stuff is so popular for one reason and that’s marketing.  Tastes like someone poured beer on some roast beef and threw it in a blender.  Pours nice, but it’s deceiving.

Guinness extra stout has nice, peaty flavors to it, and I like the occasional random availability of 22 oz. bottles in convenience stores, bodegas, etc., but it’s rarely a first pick for me outside of those situations.  Outside of a 22 oz. at night when nothing’s open, I’m not really headed for it.  Good beer, but I’d tend to go for something less common in most cases.

Made the mistake of buying this one thinking it was from another country.  Pours a watery dark brown with a soft tan head.  Aroma is kind of bad...way heavy on low quality sweet malts...smells a bit like feet.  Flavor isn’t so bad...a bit of rich malt flavor and a bit of bitterness.  Mouthfeel is not kind of light...but appropriate for a beer that doesn’t taste very good (I wouldn’t want a rich, thick, and creamy beer that tastes like this).

This is the Guinness I like.  Very dark, noticeable but not overpowering carbonation...malty but has a good heavy viscosity, and goes down very smooth.  If the choice arises between draught and this, it’s all about the stout.

Pours very dark walnut brown, bnice lomg-lasting foamy tan head.  Aromas of malt, peat, grapefruit, ripe dark fruits, cherries, and earth/peat.  Flavor intensely malty and bitter, with notes of strong coffee, dark chocolate, herbs, grapefruit, and yeast.  Thick and succulent mouthfeel.

This beer pours a dark black color with a large tan head.  It has a very roasty smell as well as flavor.  Lots of smokey peat in the flavor.  This is a classic stout but, there are much better stouts out ther if you ask me.

Aroma is suprisingly poor with little but a light grassy tobacco smell.  Opaque with a huge tan head and generous lacing all the way down.  A bitter pipe tobacco flavor along with dark roast malt and char.  I found this very flavorful and impressively strong. Better than the Draught in my opinion.

words can’t describe but I will try anyway.  being a light beer drinker i had my worries when drinking this and i was right. drinking this alone was horrible but when i ate food with it the taste became amazing....weirdest thing to ever happen, but my advice is buy it and try for yourself.
Pours an almost black color with that famous Guinness cream colored head. Nice deeply roasted grain flavor in the palate and an awkward dry finish.
Robe noire aux reflets bruns surmontée d’une mince mousse beige qui persiste. Arômes légers de café. Saveurs légères de café, de caramel. Légèrement acidulée.
Excellent stout beer.  I like the beers I can pave my driveway with!  Thick carmel/chocolate... Excellent head esp. on tap.  A Fav.

Bottled, naturally.  What else can be said about this guy?  I would love a horizontal tasting of G’s from each brewing division...
Earlier Rating: 3/1/2006 Total Score: 2.5
Essentially the same as the well-known draught.  Black as pitch, dry, ashy, etc. etc. etc..

It has a much more bitter ale flavor than the draught, but that also makes it taste a little less unique.  Overall, though, a Bass Ale and Guinness Draught mix tastes much better (i.e. Black & Tan), but it’s still pretty good.

A classic solid stout.  Not too big and not to small.  Probably the first stout I ever had.  Malty, chocolate and roast/smoke aroma along with a bit of sweetness.  Creamy and thick mouthfeel.  Dry roast astringency sticks to the mouth.

Aroma is all Labatts - husky and corny - no roast whatsover.  Fairly flat pour.  Deep crimson in color.  This tastes like a decent pale ale - lots of creaminess, with faint hints of roasted malts.  Unusual - but not a great stout.
dark brown to black, bottle, big head for bottle verion detected caramel roasted malts in a big way, slight tang and citrus peel great bitter roast finish

Guinness is the standard by which all other stouts are judged. This bottled stout made in Canada under license from the famous Irish brewer pours a very dark brown-black with a creamy tan head that’s long lasting. Its aroma does not overpower and is slightly hoppy. Very creamy on the palate and full bodied. Hints of coffee and a slightly burnt taste greet the taste buds. It finishes with a dry, slightly bitter aftertaste. A very good choice especially in an Irish pub. Many of its American craft brewed cousins stand up very well to this respected original.

My first rating here.  Here’s the deal.  I was riding my bike home from class one day, and swallowed a bug.  This bug died in my throat, and seemed to be stuck.  I needed something thick and cheap to get this bug out of my throat, so went to the first grocery store, and bought the first stout I saw.  Look, it’s a fine tasting beer, but go for a micro-brewed stout.  Negatives: weak body, harsh carbonation; head reflects this in its large bubbles.  Decent aroma and flavor, but weak finish, probably owing to the weak body.  Good bitterness, though.  Bottom line: go for a micro-brewed stout, but this will dislodge half-swallowed insects just fine.

Good aroma, pours to a rich dark brown color. Had the bottled version recently, draft version a couple years ago. Both are strong with a good finish. These are better when just sipping one or two early in the evening. Too heavy for late night or mass consumption. Overlall, a  good stout beer.
The co2 instead of nitrogen gives this more dry bite and lets, I think, a more roasted character come through. Of course the beer looks different, a darker, foamy, instead of creamy, head.

Bottle: I love this beer. A superior stout with a nice taste with balanced bitterness. Has a slight roasted coffee after-taste. Great if you’re looking for a beer with a little more punch than draft Guinness.

Not as good as the draught... we only bought it becaue we wanted to drink some guinness on St. Patty’s and it was the only stuff left at the distributer.  Taste is lacking compared to draught, less body.
Alot better than the draught.  Has a bitter nutty chocolate coffee flavor.  Not bad.
Just like the draught, but with a harsher taste and a pretty rough carbonation.  some will love this beer for these features, while others will prefer draught, either way a good choice.
Poured a dark brown with minimal head.  Aroma was roasted malts with a hint of coffee.  Unfortunately, the flavor was dominated by the bitter.   I’ll stick with the draught.
very good flavor.  tastes best at room temperature.  nice thick beer. can’t really go wrong with a guinness

This one is more bitter and flavorful than the draught.  Smells like bitter coffee and tastes like a dry stout.   Someone left it in my kitchen and I tried it, but I  there are much more interesting stouts to spend my money on.

bottle.  blackish body, chestnut colored edges.  frothy tall craggy dark tan head.  aroma is roasted malt and a bit sourish.  some chocolate malt aroma too.  flavor is dry roasted malt, like coffee grinds.  mouthfeel is slick, carbonation is lively to low.  a bit of chocolate malt flavor in the middle, and dry bitter finish.
very dark beer.  Has a good flavor but somewhat of an after tase.  Would not buy this berr

Rich dark brown (as always), generous tan head. Mostly raosted grainy maly aroma, a hint of coffee maybe. Muted coffee and chocolate palate, mostly blackened toast malt flavour. Lacks the creamy heavy mouthfeel I get from the "foreign" versions. Of all the versions of Guinness, this would be my least preferred I think. But it is still a good beer.
Faint chocolate scent. It had a heavy bitter and chocolate taste to it. Had a dark and mellow taste. Gorgeous.

I have to admit that I enjoyed this beer and would drink it again. The roasted malts — both in aroma and flavor — were present but not overwhelming. There was a touch of molasses in the flavor and a touch of bitterness in the finish. Slightly acidic and dry as expected. Low carbonation and thin body.

Ahhh... sweet prunes and toffee to the nose. Head provides a thin, sudsy tan cover with spiderweb lacing to the glass.  Bitterness present in this one, with notes of tart fruit, coffee and trace dark chocolates.  Provides a round mouthfeel with a long bitter finish.  Not bad at all.  I agree with others, it’s not same as the draught, but then again, it’s not touted as such.
Definitely an above-average beer, but I don’t like it as much as the Draught because the flavor is dominated by the bitterness.
I really enjoy this beer. A very nice dark color with a creamy head. Slightly more bitter than your average guinness, which is why I like it a bit more. Lots of coffee taste and chocolate.

an amazing taste thats unlike any other beer out there. doesnt have much more alcohol than the normal guinness, yet it does seem to take away from some of the creaminess, I wish you could have it with the widget too.

(Draft.  03/2006).  What can you say about Guiness?  Mild aromas of roasted barley and chocolate.  Deep, deep amber-approaching-black.  Mild flavor and, frankly, a bit watery, with hints of coffee and chocolate.  Thinly-bodied, in the end, the palate is greatly enhanced by its soft presentation on beer gas.

Mine must have been bad, cause i was very disapointed with this stout. 22oz Bottle. the aroma and taste reminded me of a regular guinness draught mixed with a miller. i got some of the traditional, malt, coffee,etc. but that was minimal. The flavors that seemed to dominate reminded me of a macro lager. no good. didn’t even want to finnish this one.
Bottle.  Alright, nothing really overly special.  Heavy flavor, but a very nice aroma.  Coffee and bitter tastes.

Nice black body.  Redish brown foamy head.  Not as pretty as the on-tap version of Guinness but not a bad looking beer.   The Nice malty aroma also has hints of coffee.  The flavor is malty sweet with a bitter finish.  There are hints of chocolate and coffee in there.  This is one of my favorite beers.

Pours black, like a guinness should, with light tan head.  Bold coffee, chocolate and malt aromas with a flavor that follows.  Medium bodied with a slightly bitter finish.
Earlier Rating: 1/2/2006 Total Score: 3.5
Pours a thick black with dark tan head that fades over time.  Heavy roasted aroma of malt and coffee.  Flavor follows aroma with a slight bitterness at the finish.
Thick rich dark tan head that lingered.  Coffee chocolate aromas.  Medium body, slightly sweet with a dry bitter finish.  Bitter aftertaste.

Pours a dark cola color.  Thick mocha colored head that lasts for quite awhile.  Decent web lacing on glass.  Smells much like nuts and chocolate with a slight honey aroma.  The taste is very dry and slightly bitter throughout, with only the beginning carrying any sweetness.  Somewhat of a lazy mouthfeel, smooth and creamy.  A little dry for my taste but a decent and complex beer none the less.

Nose of cereal, perfume, flowers, musk, coffee, nuts, toffee, and fruit.  Pours from the
bottle black with the most wonderful cascade that I could never get tired of watching. 
The tall rocky tan head has excellent lacing, and is not going anywhere, gimmie a straw. 
The flavor has more hops presence than the standard issue.  Very caramelized, and kinda
smoky at the finish.  The full body is lively and dry at the finish.

Bottle.  Pours dark black, with a nice tan head that lingers and leaves lacing.  Aroma and taste are best described by the name, really: like Guinness, but extra stout.  Since Guinness is so ubiquitous, it’s hard to describe this in isolation, but in comparison to the standard draught variety, it’s more bitter, less creamy, and a bit roastier.  On the whole, I prefer the draught, but this is a respectable dry stout, if a bit more bitter than warranted.
I like stouts and  I know that guinness is in most parts the most popular, but for me it is a bit to bitter so I prefer  Murphy’s or St-Ambroise black.
Pours black with a big creamy head.  Falvor is weak for  a stout, but the creamy mouthfeel makes up for it.  Nothing offensive, and very easy to drink.  Much much better on -tap than in a bottle.

Bottle pours a deep, ruby/brown with a frothy, tan head that holds and laces. Nose is musty with burnt grain while the flavor carries the roasted malt bitterness as coffee with a touch of plum and berries. Mid-bodied with a bitter linger. I personally prefer the creaminess of the draught version.


I must say that the great thing about Guinness is its versatility... you can drink it warm, cellar-temp or cold; you can mix it with other beers that you like (or dislike); it pairs with most foods but is fine by itself; you can find it just about everywhere and it’s always on sale in early March! 


6-pack from Cub Foods, Tinley Park, IL 60477

Not bad.  Far from what I was expecting and different from the draught sold in North America.  Actually a little sour, and there is considerable roasted grain in the flavor.  Medium body.  Some coffee and choclate.
Guinness is alway my beer of choice.  Incredibly drinkable and a great constant.  There are few things as enjoyable as watching a pint of guinness settle and then taking that first frothy sip!!

This would undoubtedly be my base for comparison of all stouts.  This is the first beer that I ever became addicted to and is the only beer I drink regularily.  I love the bitter raosted taste.  My only problem is that it leaves a bit more of a numbing aftertaste than other stouts I’ve had.  Wonderful creamy head, but it doesn’t last, at least the bottled ones don’t.  I can’t and won’t decide if I prefer the Xtra Stout or the Draft.  Both are divine.

Overall a good beer. The standard by which most stouts are judged. Pours with a nice head, has a good aroma and moderately bitter aftertaste. Does well with food. The tap is much better than the bottle and would rate a tad higher in my opinion. If you can’t get your favorite stout...get a guiness.
Much prefer this over their draught.  Chocolate/oatey much taste throughout.  Can’t complain about this one.
Pours almost black with a creamy head. medium bitterness. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, roasty, smoke which is reflected in the taste. My baseline dry stout for comparison.

Guinness got me thinking beer could be better than Old English Malt Liquor.  It made me love looking at a dark beer with a long lasting head.  Those deep tones of a bitter cocoa that makes your mouth feel alive.  That remniscent clinking inside the bottle.  The feeling that you are providing your body with something more than metallic filth.  BUT this is no way near a true Guinness.  If you want the real experience you MUST have a draft in IRELAND where the beer is unpasturized.  There you can carve your intials into the head and they will stay throughout the entire glass.  Make no mistake we are being ripped off in the US on this beer.

Bottle.  I love the way this beer pours. Brown but settles to a nice pitch color.  BIG, lasting head.  Head is more foamy, less creamy than draught version.  I taste roasted coffee and some chocolate notes.  Smooth finish with a considerable amount of bitterness.  Can’t go wrong with this one.

Pours dark mahogany with a "mocha" head. Decent body. Tastes like coffee and some poor licorice. Perhaps too much of an astringent taste. If it didn’t remind me of bad tea in the finish, this rating would have been above 3 for sure.

I don’t get all the hype behind this beer? I undertand that they have a dollar or two and have some funny commercials but the product they are schilling isn’t all that tasty. Weak aroma, thin mouthfeel and flavor. I just don’t get it. Perhaps when people drink this stuff they think they’d better like it or people will think they’d are either clueless about beer or that they are wussified. It’s okay not to like this. It’s not very good!
Malty aroma, fizzy, long taste duration, but nthing that terribly stands out. Decent beer but overrated.

This beer is pure heaven in a glass. Maybe it’s just the Irish in me, but there are few things I would rather have in my mouth than this beer. The color is a very dark..almost black with a creamy head. the flavor has a sort of coffee tast to it and goes down smooth.
Yes Guinness. Pours a Great Back with a very nice head. This is the Beer for me. The Blacker the better.

Very good.  Low carbonation, thin head, sweet at first, but bitter in the end.  tinny metalic after taste that fades.    this is my baseline stout to which I compare all others.  Is it as good or better than an Extra Stout?

What can one say about this work of art that hasn’t already been said. Thick and creamy with a great bitter finish, a true meal replacement in a glass. I love it as a black and tan or as a half & half. I tried to duplicate the stout in a home brew and came close but nothing will top guinness on tap.

Ah, this is a beer for real men. Unfortunately, I wasn’t man enough to handle this. I loved the taste of Guinness Draught in a can, so I figured I should try its brother, the Extra Stout. It was beautiful pouring it out, with a nice thick tan head. The aroma was powerful, with heavy roastiness and coffee. I took a swig. It was thicker than the Draught, and had a more intense flavor. There was also a stronger taste of alcohol, and heavy carbonation. The finish was very bitter and sour. If you like this, more power to you, but it was a bit hash for me. It lacked the creamy smoothness of the Draught.
Bottle 341ml. Appearance:  dark brown with a tan head. Aroma: roasted malt and coffee. Flavor: coffee, chocolate.

Aroma is kind of molasses and lagery with sweet malts and something corny, but it actually smells ok taken as a whole. Black body holds a firm and creamy thumb thick head that is mostly lasting. Flavor is sweet and malty. Hints of raisin and chocolate. Tastes a lot like a Schwarzbier to my palate, but I like it. Extremely different flavor palate from the draft. And extremely better.
Earlier Rating: 8/18/2004 Total Score: 3.7
Guinness was always my old standby. especially once Irish pubs got popular. i could always convince people to hang out there so i could at least drink an ok beer. Guiinness runs the gambit nowadays. Most places can’t pour it right and some places even put it in mugs....still it’s Guinness my first beer I ever really had a passion for and I still have a soft spot for it.
A bit richer in mouthfeel than the regular stuff.  Chocolate and coffee flavors and molasses as well.   Some astringent bitterness in the finish.  Very average.

Bottled.  Pours very dark brown, almost black with a soft, tan colored head.  Aroma of fruit, malt and chocolate.  Good mouth feel with flavors of chocolate and coffee, slight bitterness.  Astringent aftertaste.
Dark dark dark pour with thick thick brown head and little lacing.  Aroma is very coffee-like with nutty overtones. Tastes very full, very thick like dark roasted coffee and cream.  Excellent import!

Such a cool looking beer to pour!  Very dark body with a thick, rich dark brown foamy head that will not quit.  The aroma is of over ripe fruit such as raisens.  In the mouth the beer is dry and bitter but that is not overpowering.  It was actually quite nice.  Flavor was somewhat roasty coffee and chocolate with a hint of sweet malts.  Enjoyable.

Aroma a light salty roast. Pour of dark clear brown, with ruby glint and a thin head of tan. Flavor is a soilid, slightly sour and dry roast, with salt and a good dose of coffee. Thicker and much more substantial than standard Guinness.

Bottled. It says "Canada" on the bottle, and there’s no widget, so I think this is what I’ve had. My sampler taster is foamy. Standard Guinness black body, probably not a big enough sample to catch the Guiness "cascade." The flavor is nicely soured but offset by driness. Thin coffee notes and a nicely warming roast. Very favorable.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a tan coloured head which quickly disipitates. There is a flavour and aroma of chocolate.  I do not like this as much as the regular guinness draft.

Bottle: Dark dark brown, with light tan head that faded on me. Rich smells, and chocolatey taste.  Doesn’t seem as watery as I felt regular Guinness did.  Very much enjoyed.  Clean finish.  Tastes of dark chocolate lingered.  Will have again.  and again.  Possible again after that.  I enjoy the flavor of this more than Guinness Draught, though the Draught goes with food better I believe.

I can’t believe I haven’t gotten around to rating this one yet. Pours a deep black with a thick mocha head that lasted through the entire pint. Heavy roasted aroma of malt and coffee. Flavor follows the aroma along with a slightly dry, bitterfinish.  Combine this with Bass Ale for a Black and Tan and its a 4.0
C’est une reproduction, donc elle n’est pas aussi bonne que celui à l’azote (vendu par Sleeman). Par contre, elle a une assé bon goût avec un légé saveur de café.

looks great smell great is great 
really dark brown head
no carbonation to speak of
but it fits just fine

A Canadian Irish beer? :P  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Smells doughy with some chocolate and coffee notes.  Taste is bittersweet with some cocoa and chocolate.  Not as thin as it’s lower abv cousin.
Guinness is nice thick and smoothe. It has a nice foamy head. Do not drink guinness out of a bottle or a can because it will ruin your guinness experience, take the time to pour it into a cup.

"Not sure why the decided to come out with an extra stout, when the first one was very good. I think i will stick with the normal stout this one had a thing mouthfeel to it and was more bitter then the regular."

More rich and not as tart as draught, with deeper roasted malt flavor, a thicker mouthfeel, bitter finish, a noticable alcohol.
Earlier Rating: 2/6/2004 Total Score: 3
Big tan head that the bottom fell out of fairly quickly, leaving some splotchey laceing behind. Dry grainy nose. Black in color, opaque. Full bodied, friggin bone dry. A noticeable sourness,(not a bad thing). Roasty, grainy almost puckering dry finish. A somewhat complex brew, has a certain tang.
Bottle.  This is pretty much like an amped up version of the draught.  More roasted malts and coffee, but not too much to make it too dry.  All in all, it’s not bad.
All the goodness of Guinness Stout but darker, creamier, and more ot the famous Guinness bitterness we all love

bottle - To me this beer is very much like the draught, so I won’t repeat too much.  I just taste a little heavier roasted malt and a little more bitterness.  The widget in the draught does give a bit better appearance and palate.  Both are good beers, especially impressive for a megabrewery.

Bottle.  Sour malt and molasses aroma.  Dark brown opaque with moderate head that collapses quickly.  A sweet and sour molasses malt flavor with moderate carbonation.  Moderate body.  I decided to taste this along side the draught version (can with a widget).  This version has  more aroma and flavor;  however the main difference is the level of carbonation - the draught version is completely flat whereas this one is fairly high - if you like it with a higher carbonation, buy this version but if you like it more like when it’s pulled, get the draught.  Personally I like this version better.

(22 oz. bottle) Rocky light brown head atop very dark brown body. Aroma of bread, coffee and some chocolatiness. Lacing foamy, sloppy. Mouthfeel smooth, robust. Flavor of dark coffee, hint of chocolate, finishes pretty strongly bitter. Lingering bitter coffee/chocolate aftertaste. A different animal than the Draught, a bit more complex and less roasty. Exceptional. UPDATE: 1/10/11  Meh, alot less impressed with this after a few recent bottles. Mass-produced feel, watery texture, bland vague coffee-chocolate flavor. Just unimpresive really. Current rating is an average of the two.
has a sweet taste that gets a slight bitter but always goes down smooth to the very last drop

This is the best beer out righ now in my book. First, it is the type of taste I like th most in beer. I am a bock person. Ya, I know this is not a bock but it is lot like like one. The color, the aroma and taste. It goes good with all types of food as well as being able to take a sixer with you with no ice it cant be beat. This really isnt a rating more of a hey go try some if you havent all ready. I think you will love this beer I do and always will.
                                       your friend ME
A darker version of the regular. I actually got this one on accident and was suprised at the bitterness. I can’t handle more than one in a day, actually. Nevertheless a fantastic beer.

Drank this straight from the bottle on a hot day, may be why the score is affected. Wasn’t what I expected from a guinness, didn’t stand up like I expected, really didn’t have much of a roasted dry flavor.
A dark almost black beer with a thick head. Has a srong hoppy aroma. Has a smooth,but abitter hop taste. One of my favorite beers.

Pours a dark brown with a medium creamy tan head. Aroma is dark roast coffee and chocolate. Some grassy hop aroma as well.
Sharp carbonation and bitterness come on strong from  the first sip strong coffee flavour. Bitter kick in the finish but still fairly clean.
Flavour is perhaps a bit thin. But still enjoyable. I actually prefer this to the draught stout.

Dark black, couldn’t see any other colors, thick thick tan head.  Aroma of bread, flowers and coffee.  Nice smooth creamy palate, hoppy strong tastes ensue and stay with you.  Some grain in there.  I am a big fan of this stuff, underrated.

The lack of nitrogen affects the appearance and palate a little, but doesn’t seem to affect the taste or aroma in the least.
Earlier Rating: 12/12/2005 Total Score: 3.6
Classic deep obsidian appearance with cascade.  Malt aroma with some dark grainy elements.  Smooth mouthfeel, albeit a tad light, with a roast malt flavor.  Refreshing.

Bottle.  Black body, very creamy, tan head.  Aroma is very dry, with coffee and perhaps some chocolate.  Flavor is very roasty and dry, a lot of coffee flavor.  Finish is very bitter, perhaps due to roasted malts.  
Earlier Rating: 2/9/2005 Total Score: 3.3
Bottle.  Light tan head, medium size, with 
a very dark body that is just barely see through
with reddish color.  Aroma is mocha and 
roasty, although the aroma is not too strong.  I can 
taste the roasty flavor and a decent amount of sweetness
with the coffee flavors.  Has a slight lactose/sugar finish.
Much  better than the draft version, and a lot less bitterness
combined with a lot more flavor.
Darker head than the draught....Better tasting in my opinion. A bit more malty with a more intricated taste to it. definitely enjoyed it more than the draught(which tastes like pee)

Quite a different mix than the draught. Certainly more malty and more complex; just as smooth as draught, but much more bitter. Good looking pour, but not quite as nice as draught, with a darker head and less lacing.

Earthy plum aroma., Dark brown almost black appearance. Medium/Full body. Flavor has a hint of dark roasted coffee, and moderately bitter. Light to moderate carbonation. Not bad for a mass produced stout. Very filling. Good for those who find the draught too light.
Nice dark body with a small tan head.  Great aromas of chocolate and burnt malts.  Flavor had a nice bitter bite to it.
Not too different from the Draught version, same premise, just less silky in the mouth. Same minimal coffee and roast notes, finishes more bitter. I likey a bit better than draught.
Oatmeal smell. Slightly bitter on palate. Slightly bitter finish. This is nice for a mass-produced stout. But it can’t touch smaller breweries.

Has a smooth creamy head. A black appearance with a brisk sharp flavor tamed by notes of dark malt and chocolate, finishing clean.  A classic porter stout by which all others are measured. Alcohol content 5.6 percent by volume.
Rich and flavorful, but I prefer Guinness Draught a little bit more.  I have only had it in bottle, perhaps it is better on tap.  But a good tasting, rich, stout beer.

Bottle poured a translucent dark reddish brown with a large, creamy, long lasting head. Aromas of roasted malt, dark chocolate,and a hint of coffee. Palate was light bodied and creamy. Flavors of roasted malt, dark chocolate, and a hint of smoke with a creamy, slightly bitter finish.

I agree that newer microbrew have improved on the dry stout, but Guinness is the standard by which others are measured.  The Extra Stout is less creamy and more bitter than the Draught version, but retains the classic Guinness flavourings.  One of my favourites.

Bubbly head.  Fair amount of carbonation.  Feels more like a porter- it’s palate is fairly thin.  Flavors remind me of some imperial stouts.  flavors like prunes, raisins, maybe figs.  I remember when this USED to taste strong to me!  Wow how things have changed.

Smell of Peat on the Nasal. 

Rich Dark,

Rating too high here. 

This beer is getting its ass beat by recent microbrewries, but I will not turn down a Guinness either. 

Mass Producto.

The standard for good stout.  Fairly high bitter,  somewhat yeasty, extra-fortified fizziness (why they do that I can’t imagine), but it is good for what ails ya.  I, for one, am glad it’s now available without a prescription.
Good overall, but not as good as the draught.  Pours dark with a brown head that dissipates fairly quickly.  Some coffee-ish flavors.

The dark stallion gallops on.  The hints of coffee are not quite as overwhelming as some of the other stouts I’ve tried, which I consider to be a welcome change every now and again.  Honestly....if you have not tried this beer yet, and you consider yourself a connoisseur of beer, you should rethink your status.

Very nice black color. Head is thick and rich. Taste is also rich, with bittersweet chocolate notes. Nice bitterness, but not over-powering. A very nice stout.
Earlier Rating: 5/2/2005 Total Score: 3.8
Nice thick head which dissipates slowly. Leaves nice lacing. Smells really good with chocolate malt and roasted coffee aroma. Color is black. But when held up to bright light a very deep ruby can be seen. Flavor is delicious with not so much bitterness on the tongue as there is in the finish, which lingers a while. Drinkability is very good. My first Guinness Extra Stout, and certainly not my last.

This dark beer is good, but I don’t like it as much as Guinness Draught. It’s nice and thick, just like it’s brother Draught, but the creamy head is missing, as is the flavor I long for. This one’s a bit on the bitter side, not overly, but enough. It’s a drinkable beer, but not something to drink on a regular basis.
Earlier Rating: 2/2/2004 Total Score: 3.5
This dark beer is good, but I don't like it as much as Guinness Draught. It's nice and thick, just like it's brother Draught, but the creamy head is missing, as is the flavor I long for. This one's a bit on the bitter side, not overly, but enough. It's a drinkable beer, but not something to drink on a regular basis.

Roasty aroma is mineralic in quality with underlying fruity esters.  Darkest mahogany brown body with a decent, fine bubbled, fizzy, tan head that recedes rapidly to partial cover and ring with some lace.  Flavour is also quite mineralic with cakey and fruity esters and quite a strong roasted barley bitterness in the finish.  Flavours, though not unpleasant, never seem to marry.  Medium body with moderate carbonation and a texture that seems syrupy without being thick.  Half pint glass.  Allowed to warm from fridge temperature.  Bottle (purchased Sep-05).

Dark brown body with a tan head that laces well.  Roasty aroma but with an anemic watery, mineral orange candy thing lightening it up.   Light, airy flavor and mouthfeel yet it still packs a decent amount of roast flavor.  Lots of fruity ale yeast notes too: orange-flavored vitamins along with minerals.  Dry, limey finish.  I’ve never been a big dry stout fan, I’m not just giving ths a mediocre score because of its bigness.

In my infancy I viewed Guinness as the "Dark, Heavy" beer.  Since I’ve had a few Stouts I’ve realized that this one was lacking a bit of "Oooph".  

Poured dark brown with a nice tan head.    As soon as I drunk it I felt something was missing.  I was missing the malted goodness that a stout requires.  

OK, but if there’s a choice I’d probably choose another.
Not bad, but defiantly the weaker version of its’ draught cousin. Just too bitter by comparison.
is it just me or has this brew started to get thinner and more watery. it’s still a great beer but it seems different from years past. full body, coffee/molasses flavor, bitter.
A good representation of the Stout style. It’s thick and dark, perfect for a cold winter night.
Dark brown in color, almost black but not quite. It’s a watered down stout to me. roasty, malty aroma. what else can I say.

Pours a dark black color with a nice amount of foamy tan head.  Aroma is corny, malts, and roasted nuts.  Mouthfeel is thicker than guiness draught, bitter chocolate flavor, and sweet malty finish.  Overall, a decent brew.

22oz Bottle: A true classic. Probably everyones first stout. I always enjoy this one with its creamy, earthy qualities. Pours very dark, almost black. Can’t see through it. Rich creamy head quickly forms and lasts until the end of the glass. Has a rich earthy aroma with coffee notes. Very bold earthy taste. Goes down very smooth, no alcoholic notes. Little to no aftertaste. Probably one of my favorite easily accessible brews. Never disappoints.

To me - a heavier, smokier taste than the bottle/can draught, creeping up to a porter.  I like that the draught can with the widget gives a somewhat creamier head than this bottle.  Most would agree that none compare to Guinness straight from the nitrogen tap.

Bottle. Poured a black color with an average rocky light brown head that was mostly lasting. Average roasted coffee aroma. Medium to full body with a creamy texture. Light sweet dry flavor with an average duration finish.

I can’t give this anything more than a one in every category except appearance.  The Salvadorian version of Guiness tastes like bug spray.  It should not be purchased.  Stick with Gallo, Presidente or look for my favorite rum Flor de Cana (from Nicaragua).
A great stout. It has a bit more punch then it’s relative, but that’s a good thing! Great with a meal, or chillin’ out with your buddies. Great beer!!!

regular bottle - dark color, with dense rocky tan head. Aroma is slighlty sour, malty, full of roasted barley, hints of cherry, vanilla. Flavor has roasted malts, a hint of sourness, roasted barley bitterness, and a hint of metallic-ness.

when I first started drinking beer - this was grreat.  Now - not so much.  It’s a liitle watery compared to the most stouts.  But it’s a classic and I’ll drink it again and again
Earlier Rating: 3/18/2005 Total Score: 3.6
I used to think that this was a premium stout, until I tried brooklyn’s black chocolate stout.  But guiness is decent, not to thick brew
what a great full flavored strong thick taste its a must have beer at least once in your life
This is a great beer. A huge THANKYOU to the Irish. The beautiful dark color just draws you in. The flavor is esquiset.

very very good.    Much like your standard guiness.  The lack of nitrogen took away from the cool effects.  I also found the beer to be much heavier then expected.  Also not quite as smooth and a touch hoppier.  This , however, added to the flavor nicely.
Earlier Rating: 7/25/2002 Total Score: 3.3
This is a little too stouty for me.  But hey, it's still Guinness  :)
Thicker and richer than the standard Guinness you buy in a bar.  Fuller in flavor with a pleasant semisweet chocolate taste.
NOT as good as I expected. IT was almost flavorless, but the aroma and the taste were really good as far as I could get them.
good staple. I like black and tans, but I’m not huge on drinking this alone. it feels a bit too heavy for me.

I found this version slightly more drinkable than the pseudo-draft bottle version.  Again, it’s still Guinness.  However, I’d still rather relegate this to homemade black and tans and wait to drink straight Guinness when it’s on tap.

a subtle, clean aroma. nice thick tan head from a bottle isn’t as nice as draught. thick roasted taste that fades away smoothly with a hint of smoke. a little too bubbly in the mouth makes for a tingly drink. oldy but a goody.

Bottle. Very dark with fluffy tan head, but the head doesn’t cascade up as attractively as regular Guinness. Aroma of dark malts, coffee, milk chocolate, and even a trace of alcohol. The flavor is robust and ultra-malty, containing elements of bitter chcolate, espresso, and a little bit of salinity, with a somewhat hoppy, warm finish. This is a very tasty fallback beer.

Bottle, can and draught bottle. It is a treat to watch the cascading effects, with the widget can. The unwidgeted bottle is dissappointing. 
Not a ton of aroma. Roasted malt flavor, some chocolate hints. Dry and silky. Slight tartness. You can drink this all night, not real strong. Good as an Irish Car Bomb (shot of Jameson and Bailey’s dropped in glass) or Black and Tan.
Not bad, but not very good either. The taste is that of any stout except it is missing that extra punch in taste that would make it more enjoyable. An average beer.
Deffinatly one of my favorite beers, takes a little getting used to however most deffinatley one of the most fulfilling

pitch plack. does not allow any light to pass through. It just dares you to drink it. Quickly diminishing tan head that leaves an average amount of lacing. Only the color was impressive, every other aspect was average. a vinous, fruity, and roasted smell. Molasses. No hops present. Almost smells like a muted version of a belgian ale, similar in that it is fruity and vinous, but different in that it is much more roasty. Burnt coffee. Start is moderately roasted with a faint dark fruit sweetness that carries the roastiness through smoothly to a bitter, moderately dry finish. Leaves a bitter aftertaste that isn’t unpleasant. Tastes similar to an American Stout, but only a little sweeter and weaker. Medium body with moderate carbonation. With all of the hype surrounding Guinness’ thick mouthfeel, I was disappointed to find it too carbonated and thin for my taste. It wasn’t significantly thin or carbonated, but it just wasn’t what I expected. Very easyto consume. I had it on two different occasions. I consumed three of the twelve ounce bottles with drinking room to spare on the first night. The second night I had a pint and six ounce bottle that was sufficient for me. Not a heavy beer.  Well, my first encounter with Guinness is over and I must say that this beer does not live up to the hype surrounding it. It is a good beer to be sure, but it is not incredibly thick, heavy, or bitter. Is it a great beer? Not in my book it isn’t. Is it a bad beer? Certainly not. This is definately a fallback beer for me. I need something with more flavor and more body. A respectable beer nonetheless. It is certainly better than Beamish, but it is nowhere near as good as Shakespeare Stout.

bottle. Revisited this since my beer options are particularly low in my home town. This is a great reminder of how far along my beer palate has come and yet how far it still has to go. The pour on this is definitely dark ruby with a pretty nice, rocky tan head. The aroma has a bit of that creaminess going on with the addition of caramel, creamed corn, and just a hint of coffee. Fairly sweet in the mouth with a dose of toffee, some breadiness, a bit of chocolate, and a slightly tannic finish. I suppose the sparkling, carbonated mouthfeel, acidic notes, and the 1% higher abv might make this "extra stout," but doesn’t cut it for me. It seems like too many off flavors come into play in this version and in the end, I’d rather stick to regular old Guinness even if it is less full bodied. This definitely doesn’t hold a candle to the foreign extra stout.
Widget in a can is a neat idea. The more stouts I drink the thinner and weaker I find the old standard.

It’s kinda hard to belive, but I found this in a shity corner store in a realy getto region of montreal. There are 2 kinds of guinness extra stout made in canada, no not the draught, just the extra stout. Guinness Ireland sends the original unfermented but hopped Guinness wort extract to 2 places in canada. Labat makes the fermilar Local Guinness E.S.  by adding said wort  to a plae ale, and Guinness Canada {a small brewier in nova scotia} adds yeast and water to properly brew the stout. The guinness canada one is normaly exported exclusivley to the US, but for some {prpbably illegal} reason, I found a store with it here. This is probably the best dry stout I have ever had. Pours a jet black with a heavy dose of small carbonation bubbles, thin whispy coffie with cream head, quickly disapating, minimal lacenings. Aroma is coffie, sugar cane, and noble bitter hops. Palat is smooth and silky with a light dry finish. Taste is what it’s all about, cryin of irelen. Full flavour like there isn’t room to disove any more. Sweet dark chocolate malt, red ruby pumb malt, and roasted barley dancing with a very noble blend of earthy bitter hops. undertones of grapfruit, acidic tones, a slight sour bite, yellow plumb, green apple and a sweet burnt sugar finish. Robust after taste, nutty and sweet with a finaly of deep full mild bitterness. Gaz returns {burps} taste of roasted nut and dark chocolate. This is amasing. I must tell people about this discovery. Cheers. 
Earlier Rating: 2/1/2005 Total Score: 3.9
Stop confusing this with the very diffrent Guinness Draught. Even though people only seem to sing the praises of draught, this is a little bit closser to the orignal 1759 version mentioned on both labels, the draught only came into exzistance in the early 1960’s, {although the original guinness was actualy a black porter that disapered some time in the 50’s, but I digress}. Ok, Pours black with whispy large bubbled head, quickly fades. Light carbonation,  Malty nose, some nuttyness. Thick mouthfeel {somtimes slimy if it’s not fresh} Black Malt flavour, roasted barley, smoke, mild sweet caramel, and just the right amount of bitter hop to smoth it all out. Aftertaste is sweet, folowed by a {unfourtently}  skunky finish. All in all a very nice beer from labat, very tasty and feels good in the blood. It makes me VERY qurious what the  pale ale base that labat add’s the wort extract to would be like on it’s own. Cheers
Not as smooth as Draught, but still an in-your-face punch in the mouth when you drink it.  Less carbonated than Draught which suits me fine because the taste is excellent.

Where the hell did my rating of this go, this is the 2nd of my ratings to mysteriosly vanish, what the hell? Very dark black with a brownish thick head. Had some more chocolates and body than the regular guiness. I liked it more. I feel the regular guiness has a bit of water to it, where as this does not, it is full.

ya, so like i though i had this, but i didnt. much respect to my girl for inspiring me to score this brew. its pretty damn dark and has a solid coffee colored head.  the aroma is way too green for me. i expected more choco, coffee, but i got green. smooth, nice subtle bitter bite to it, aight, yea,   peace

ok beer... it’s weird how from can to can or bottle to bottle taste can change from drinkable to very sour.. so I figured that is I will not take my chances on getting a beer which I don’t know if I’m gonna be able to drink cuz its after taste
In my opinion, Guinness Extra Stout is the King of Beers. It is great warm or cold and goes especially well with dark chocolate. Hail, Guiness!
I prefer Guinness Draught to this but this is also an acceptable alternative.  More bitter than Draught and less carbonation too.

i always like the way a good stout looks so i like it in that respect. not a great stout but it wasnt bad. i had to drink it in a hurry so i discovered how hard it is to take big drinks of a beer like this.

Not as creamy and rich as regular old Guinness.  This one is definitely dry compared to it.  Would one say that this one’s over-roasted?  Definitely robust.  But, does that make this good?  The jury’s still out on that one.
A roast chocolate aroma with a creamy light brown head.  Black in color. Starts off with a roasted taste and finishes with a nice malty sweetness.
All in all a very different very flavorful beer that I think is drank best after a meal... just one or two.. then a lighter beer after if your having more.

I need to go back and rerate Guinness Draught, because this is a lot better.  It has some kind of sour bite to it.  Overall, just screams to be consumed at a party with your friends.  Sorry the review isn’t more indepth.
well i’d have to say not too bad.  Had a great body and a very nice taste that left a sweet aftertaste.  It’s like a stout  but with twice the punch and taste.

I like a dark, crisp, flavorful stout, and Guinness Extra Stout doesn’t fail to impress (unlike the Guinness draught in bottle or can which is watery and disappointing.)  
Earlier Rating: 7/21/2005 Total Score: 3.5
This is the Canadian Guinness Extra Stout, brewed by Labatt.  The Labatt base is evident, making this taste like a cheaper mainstream beer and inferior to the American Extra Stout.  Still, Guinness Extra Stout is typically a very nice dark stout, especially for those who like something less sweet.

Really can’t go wrong, though it’s not quite the same without the nitro or the tap. Still, has a nice roasted flavor, with a big tan head. Some chocolate overtones, but mostly just malt. Nice, and the alcohol is so low you hardly feel it.
Earlier Rating: 5/1/2002 Total Score: 3.6
I actually like this better than the draught. A bit smoother, with a pleasant aroma.
I had forgotten how good Guinness actually is after being away drinking good and bad micro brews for so long.  I do have to agree that this bottle is better than the one with the nitro ball in it.

pours very dark, with a large tan head, aroma roasted malts(weak although)tastes of roasted malts also very light alcohol taste, kinda smooth for a stout beer, im not that impressed with this beer, yet it is drinkable.
Earlier Rating: 5/24/2005 Total Score: 2.5
good stout, im not a big fan of stouts though, alcohol a little weak for its sour like taste. thick beer.
This real Guinness, (as opposed to the ’draught’ crap that is watery in those cans with the nitrogen thingie), is arguably the only import beverage worth considering for any long-term consumption.

Pours a dark brown color.  Smells of mild malt and roast.  Tastes very much like a Guinness Draught with some more roast flavor added to it.  Has some sherry aspects in this brew.  Not as great as other stouts.  But nor horrible either.
As many know Guiness has a head that sticks around a while. Black, stong chocolate like with some bitterness but a classic and instantly recogizable as far as the taste.

roasted aroma.  black and opaque.  stout that bites your tongue.  bitter.  not as thick as it looks.  i noticed a stronger hop flavor than the draught.  but i enoy the draught’s milky and oily texture.
Strong, full-flavored, thick, smooth, Fully lasting, Bread - dark, Creamy, Bitter - moderate
Question? How do you make Guinness worse? Give it a macro Lager yeast strain.

Nice dark pour - rocky tan head.  Light aroma - would have preferred a littl emore in that department.  Looks great - very dark, nice roasted taste, but without a really strong aftertaste.  Maybe a little mellow for a stout, but very good for off the shelf at the grocery store.
This is THE stout! Tastes much stronger than it actually is, due to the roastiness. An excellent beer.
Toasty, dark chocolate aroma. Thick brown head, lasts forever.  Black body.  Dry and fizzy, would prefer more alcohol flavor.  I like this much better than the "draught" for some reason.
This beer hit my in the face like a soccer cleat. Its super, super bold and full tasting. It was almost too much for a beer lightweight like myself to handle...But I enjoyed it nonetheless.

Bottle, LCBO singles bin.  Black pour, small white head.  Sour aroma, uh oh, bad singles bin purchase?  Taste is all sour unfortunately.  I was really looking forward to seeing how this stacked up against the draught and the extra stout British versions I’ve had.  Guess I’ll have to wait until next time, as this beer is off.  It pisses me off the lcbo would throws these out for purchase - if someone returns a bad 6 pack, don’t sell of the other bad bottles you inconsiderate idiots.  But what am I going to do, buy somewhere else?
1 pint 6 oz bottle.  Black with a carmel colored head.Chocolate, camel, roasted malt, with a dry finish.  Smooth and enjoyable stout. I like this just a little bit better then their Draught.

Pours a deep ebony black with an abundant head of fine tan bubbles that leave a beautiful ring of scummy foam around the glass, like the settling foam from a glass of whole milk. Aromas of coffee, brown sugar, and a clean sweet yeastiness. Understated, yet very rich. Flavors of burnt toast, coffee. A pleasant dry bitterness that lingers in the finish. Some sourness that gets more noticible in the last third or so of the glass. Smooth and substantial on the palate. 

I would vote for Guinness Extra Stout as the of the best widely available imported beer in the United States. What a shame that when people think Guinness, they think about the even more widely availble, but insipid and boring Guinness Draught! Extra Stout is beautiful (without the artless "widget" for a crutch), flavorful, and worthy of the grand Guinness stout tradition. But....brewed in Canada...a Frankenstein blend of Irish wort and Canadian pale ale. What a strange world we live in! In case anyone asks, I disapprove of all that nonsense. But in the meantime, Extra Stout is pretty tasty.
Sourish/Bitter taste but enjoyable after about the 3rd. Good coversational session beer. Thick like dark chocolate. Yum

Aroma of malt, some floral hops, molasses, and some herbs.  Fairly decent head and completely dark black body.  Nice roasty flavor, bit of coffee, something sour, and bitter chocolate.  Nice bitter kick in the end.  Feels lively on the tongue.  Very dry as well.  Not bad, but there are many other stouts id choose before this.

Very passable.  Very passable.  Dark black color.  Enormous, frothy, tan head.  Flavor is mostly of roasted malts.  Dry, bitter finish.  Not my favorite stout, but certainly one of the best, easiest to find stouts.

Not the best stout ever, but one of the only dark beers that you can find almost anywhere.  A decent roast malt flavor throughout, that gets a little bitter in the after-taste. The beer I drank the most, so it generally is one of my favorites.
I like Guinness.  It is just a bit sour for my tastes though.  I prefer sweeter stouts.  For the style (since guinness set the style, it’s obvious) it hits the spot just right.  ;-p
Took me a long time to finally down a Guinness.  Always thought it was overrated but I was wrong.  A very nice dry stout with a nice bitter taste to it.  Leaves you wanting another sip.

Very bitter and some real taste (as opposed to its creamy nitro cousin. Sour from start to finsish. I wish the draught could take some of the roastiness of extra. However, little too much on the thin and sour side. I realise this review is sub par...I just don’t have the energy after a day like today. (As if you care)

Pours pitch black with a medium sized tan head. Quickly dissipates leaving lots of lace. Smells like Guinness! Nutty, roasted malt and a bit smoky. Lightly bitter.

Taste: Bitter and smoky. Burnt malt fades to a round nutty flavor. Quite bitter up front but fades and creamy flavors replace it a bit. Way down there in the flavor is a bit of fruitiness as well. Full bodied and lingers nicely on the back of the throat. Nice aftertaste.

I have tasted alot of good, strong stouts since my first bottled Guinness but I am still in the bag for this brew. The best widely available stout in the world.

One of those beers I’ve had many times in the past, but had never gotten around to giving a rating to.  I swear they’ve messed with the recipe.  I remember an almost acrid bitterness, that Guinness tang, something that reminded me of a regular lager that had been filtered through an ashtray.  I liked that beer.  This offering was a pale shadow of that previously tasty concoction.  Dark brown, ruby showing through (I swear it has gotten lighter), OK head.  Aroma was faint and a bit bready.  Sweetness (what??) dominated the flavor, mostly of bread and molasses.  The bitterness of roasted malts was gone, the tang is gone, and I was left with an underwhelming sweet stout.  Grrrrr.
Very black with a little red hint.  Tan head that is pretty large.  Aroma is of roasted malts and is very rich.  Slightly bitter with a lingering palate.  Great brew

Pours black with a thick, dense beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, some hops and a hint of caramel. Burnt and bitter taste. Flavor has notes of roasted/burnt malt (a healthy dose of black patent malt perhaps?), chocolate, coffee and a solid presence of hops. A slight hint of sourness, lasting burnt/bitter aftertaste. Medium body, very aggressive carbonation at first. Lacing hangs on the glass in thick rings, great head retention. I like this more than the draught version.
Bottle. Dry, carbonated mouthfeel. Medum boided. Roasted malt and dark chocolate flavors with a bitter and heavily metallic finish.
definitely better than the guiness draught.  has flavor at least.  roastyness and bitterness are apparent and make for a pleasnt drink.

Must I describe Guinness to you.  I hope you’ve had it already.  A wonderful, creamy, dark experience.  However, I think it’s best, poured out of a can.  Refer to my other Guinness Original rating for similar statements.
Earlier Rating: 10/30/2004 Total Score: 3.1
This Guinness is stout.  Extra stout.  What more is there to say?  It’s just like Guinness, except a bit muddled by a coffeeish bent.  Not a bad beer, but I like regular ol’ Guinness better.
Bottle. Blackish beer with a big beige head. Roasty aroma along with caramel and coffee. Slightly acrid. Roasty flavor, lots of malt. Some sourness.

12 oz. bottle into tulip glass.  Pours a copper brown transluscent, more opaque when in the glass.  Large tan head is rocky and mostly lasting with very uneven lacing and reticent, quick racing.  Bready, herbal aroma, slight skunk, with some brown sugar spice.  More acidic than the "Draught," but less creamy, this has prickly acid and roast malt at first and expansive carbonation delivering unidentifiable malt flavors.  Quickly transitions into dry hoppy finish that made it famous.  Finish almost becomes metallic after about 15 seconds, slightly cheesy.  Cocoa powder comes on late in the finish and is a nice touch.  More malt backbone would make this a great dry stout, but it feels a bit wimpy up front and doesn’t balance it’s dry bitter finish well enough.  As it warms, it’s watery mouthfeel begins to annoy.  Also, this reminds me of Anchor Steam for some reason, maybe in the metallic nature of the finish.  Stouts shouldn’t remind me of steam beer.  Downgrade.

Draft. Well, it looks nice. Dark black w/ light tan gluey head. I smell almost nothing. Mouthfeel just slightly thicker than water. Almost no taste whatsoever. This has got to be one of the world’s most overrated beers. I just don’t get it. Vague malt presence. All I taste really is the faintest sign of some sort of roast. Their Pub Draught is so much better than this.

12 oz bottle. Pours out inky blak with ruby tinges. Thick tan head that recedes slowly.

lots of sticky lace left behind.

aroma of grain and roasted coffee, a little chocolatey sweetness.

flavor is roasty coffee, with an underlying sweetness.
 I still like this once in a while.

Pours black, thin tan head. This is bitter as hell and very dry, it’s an amped up guinness but not in a good way. The hoppy bitterness overides anything else and leaves an irony taste in your mouth, taste like they used too much crystal malts also, this sucks.

Bottle.  It was offered to me at a cookout..by the host---didn’t want to insult him by turning it down, besides it was this or Dud Light.  Nose is tinged with a toasted malty aroma. Color is dark brown and had a larger head than the draught version. Taste is as expected...malty (maybe a chocolate hint or two) with some light hop bitterness.  Mouthfeel is ok, although is mostly thin.   In the end it finishes as bland as every other rendition of this overrated ale.

You can really taste the roasted nuts in this one. Pours dark as it should, with a tan 1 to 1and a half inch head. Not a bad after taste that hangs for just the right amount of time. I’ll reach for it again!

When I first drank this beer a year ago, I thought it was too strong for my taste. 
But after a few more tries, I really began to aprreciate this beer.
A dark bitter stout with a strong roasted presence. Savor every gulp, dont swig it down.
I’ll make sure to drink this more often now
More carbonation than the draught.  Not as good, but will do if you don’t like cans and can’t get to a tap.

If I’m gonna have a Guinness, original draught is the way to go. Also no cascading effect... *sigh*. I do like the darker head, though, and the well-balanced roasty nutty chocolately flavors make this a drinkable drink.

I really enjoy this stuff it is so easy to drink but it is still has flavor and ends with a biter note.. poured black great loooking beer
Earlier Rating: 12/10/2004 Total Score: 3.2
I have drank this for years and it is still a treat. Sure it is not the best but a Guinness is a Guinness. it is a really thick beer and has a strong after taste. I don’t drink on weekends because it is kinda hard to drink a lot of...... hi mom college is so much fun
A staple stout.  Goes down smooth.  It has a smooth bitterness.  A perfect beer for relaxing with friends at an authentic Irish pub.

Bottle.  Slightly grainy aroma to start with some faint DMS notes.  These notes disappear into a more roasty, sweet aroma.  Coffees are also noted.  Mostly transparent dark dark mahogany with mild garnet touches.  Nice frothy tan head and nice lacing.  Nice chocolate bittered roastiness to finish.  Quite toasted finish.  Start is mildly sweet without much going on.  This could use a touch more body, but as far as beer goes, this isn’t bad.  I don’t care that it’s macro, it’s still good stuff.

Similar to draught Guinness, but the head is not creamy, more fizzy. Aromas and flavors of bitter coffee and toastiness. Rich, potent mouthfeel, leaving the drinker realizing they’ve had a real beer. One hell of a pint.
Earlier Rating: 1/25/2001 Total Score: 3.9
A little more chewy than Guinness Draught. This makes a very rewarding pint, and tastes great right out of the bottle too. Bitter roasted coffee flavor. Sturdy mouthfeel. I used this to make beer batter for prawns once, and served a glass of it on the side. Very exotic.

Nice head, not creamy but it lasts. The body wasn’t as hearty as I expect from a stout.  The flavor was a little harsh, nowhere near as smooth as a traditional Guinness. It had a lingering hop taste. A novelist has written that the closer you get to Dublin the better the Guinness tastes.  I thought at first that this was nostalgia or ancestral pride.  Alas it’s true.  This one was brewed in New Brunswick, Canada.  It couldn’t touch the draft I had at the St. James Gate Brewery almost 9 years ago.  You can get a much better stout at a brew pub in New Brunswick, New Jersey.

Black with large tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt and hops.  Flavor is more roasted malt and coffee.  Dry, bitter finish.  Medium bodied.  Very nice, but not as impressed with this as I was 25 years ago.
Black with a lasting tan head.  Aroma is coffee and hops.  Nice roasted flavor with coffee and dark chocolate notes.  Dry, hoppy finish.

Unfortunate beer. I remember drinking Guinness when I was younger, it was so flavorful I gagged. This is a weak representation of the real thing. Everyone knows what this is like so rating can be nothing but redundant. But, here goes.
Pours opaque black/brown. The head is like the commercial, very lively, lasting and lacing. Aroma is weak at best, what little I can smell is hoppy and bread type yeast. Flavor is good, there just isn’t enough.
I think the next stage for Guinness is a tablet or powder that you can pour in water or Old Milwaukee, so you can mix your own!(I hope they read this website!)

a very hoppy aroma comes off of the black body that one comes to expect from guinness.  of course without the nitro, the head is only thin and tan, and fades down to some wisps.  the flavor is a decent balance of roasted malt and very strong bittering hops. the tail has some coffee hints, but an unbelievable amount of bitterness, which lingers around for awhile.  mouthfeel is nice and chewy, reflective of the full body of the pour. if this were side by side with a draught, i would never think they are the same beer, as this brings a totally different flavor.

Black with a tan rocky head. Spotty lace. Bitter and sour aromas with some roast malt back. Bitter hops and roasted malts with some caramel in the flavor. There is a hint of smokiness to it as well. The palate is medium to thin, and it has a strong roasty finish.

This was the original way to drink Guinness at home before there was the widget. Often considered to taste flatter than a true tap pour, this beer does in fact offer a completely different flavor. This is one beer that may not be for everyone.
Pours black with brown head.  Thin body but the roasted flavor jumpis out at you.  Found this beer rough on the palate.
Not as foamy or lacey as the draught (can), but better tasting. Nicely roasted to the palate. Enjoyable
There is nothing like the sight of a well poured Guinness.  This beer should be rated higher, in my opinion.  This, to me, is the King of Beers

Black in color. Brown head. Aroma is a bit roasty. Flavor is fairly roasted. Tastes a bit different the Guinness Draft.
Not as dry. Not all of the bubbles and head either. Good quality stout.

A very dark tasting beer, with lots of head.  A little bitter, but overall a good beer.  
Earlier Rating: 4/18/2004 Total Score: 4.6
Very dark and very good.  This beer is one of the best out there.  Its a bit pricy but definately worth the try.
Good stong hardy brew.  Much like regular guiness but stoutier (if that’s a word).

This is the real Guinness dammit.  As opposed to the draught, this actually has a thickness and character to it besides bitter water.  Not the best stout I’ve had, but definitely a good choice if you’re out and about and it’s the best available.

Dark ebony body with a gorgeous cardboard colored, light brown head. Reverse waterfall effect is worth watching. Smell is roasty and chocolate. Taste is more watery than other stouts, but this is Guinness, almost a style of its own. Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, a tinge of coffee and water. Thats it. Feels like liquid silk going down.

Beer is burnt-black with a roasted marshmallow head. Smell is malt, coffee and bitter hops. Very heavy/big in the mouth. Taste is burnt hops and coffee resulting in an unpleasant charred bitterness and weird sourness. Aftertaste is more bitter hops followed by wateriness. Flavor isn't nearly as enjoyable, nor as refined as the Draught variety (read my rating for it). Had this from the 1 Pint, 6 oz. bottle from the local grocery store.

Bottle. Extremely dark with a tiny ring of lace. Roasted, smoky aroma and flavors. Flavors are much stronger than the aroma. Pretty bitter, but no hop flavors detected. Not nearly as dry as the Draft version. Not bad, and by no means undrinkable, just doesn’t get me excited. I had my coffee this morning, I don’t need it again tonight.

I like this more than the draught or their other bottle and can products.
Pours an opaque body, black in colour, with a thin and very shot lived mocha head. Aromas are hops, very subtle coffee and malt. Taste is bitter, mildly malted, and some coffee. Very bitter finish. I imagine this is what the beer is supposed to taste like, as opposed to what I normally find on draught.

pours black with a tall fluffy head. aroma is a bit smokey roast  and something sugary.  taste is a little sweet with some chocolate and coffee. dry mouthfeel. finish is  a bit more roast coffee and chocolate.

Dark opaque blackish brown appearamce, thick foamy head formation. Roasted dark chocolate and licorice nose. Sweet treacley palate, slightly burnt cookie flavor, decent bitterness in the finish. Not very thick compared to US stouts but flavor stands up well.

To me Guinness is highly over rated.  This is by far one of my least favorite stouts.  I always said I hated stouts because this is all I had ever had.  I then tried some good stouts and found I love stouts, just not this one.
Better than guinness draft.  Darker, more bitter, nice tan head.  Flavorful and enjoyable.  A good standard that’s easy to find when you’re somewhere that doesn’t sell a lot of craft beer.

This beer tastes extremely burnt, in a bad way.  There is no discernable grain flavour, just the burnt taste, which gives way to a sort of unpleasant sourness reminiscent of many American macrobreweries.  While you certainly can’t say it’s bland, and while I tend to like stronger and more bitter beers,  this beer is just foul tasting to me.
very difficult beer to drink. could only drink one or two of these. I’m not a fan of stout beers but i would have to say this is still a decent one. guinness draught is still much better

Well...I think this is almost exactly what you get with the nitro widget can, except of course the carbonation level is much more appealing.  for this reason alone (and maybe a smidgen because I hate cans), this rates higher...well done.

341ml brown bottle. Poured extreme dark brown, almost opaque. Very creamy, sticky head topped it, light tan. Coffee and chocolate nose. Starts with a bitter bite of roasted malts and black coffee flavours. Slight sourness combined with bitterness in the finish.

12 oz bottle:  Brown-black color wtih a small fading cocoa colored head. Light toast and coffee scent. Flavor starts lightly sweet followed by a sharp bitter coffee taste and finishes with a lingering dry bitterness. Creamy palate. Much better than Guinness draught.
my first stout, and i am sure that i am not alone.  a yardstick for all stouts.  i still make guinness clones every now and then.

Pour is black with a medium tan head...smell is all roasty and coffee...taste is bitter and burnt coffee...there’s a shock...
Earlier Rating: 9/27/2004 Total Score: 2.8
Poured black with rocky tan head...smelled very roasty, almost burnt...body was a thin and watery...aftertaste was burnt...as was the finish...

Still a little thin, but a far cry from the abomination that is Guinness Draught.  The lack of nitrogen makes it amazingly more palatable, even though it doesn’t give it quite the head.  The aroma is sharp and acidic from the sour mash.  Color is almost black, but still brown.  The sourmash dominates the flavor, but there is still a strong roasted malt note behind it.  Other notes of coffee and milk sugars are there.  Overall good, just slightly overpowered by the sourness.
A great stout for starters but I enjoy a little more body.  Great color and velvet head with a touch of coffee.
Guiness extra stout has more sweetness to it than a normal guiness. It s not as bitter and has good sugary flavors balanced with a thick dose of cofee
Not as good as draught, but still a quality stout.  Tan head, black beer.  Medium-full bodied.   Bitter finish
Brown-black with a tan head, coffee and dry, maybe I just like a smoother stout but I’m guessing this tasted a lot better when it was coming from Ireland.

I know it’s lame to rate long after you’ve had a beer, but I forgot about this one.  After all, I think I’ve had it enough that I remember.  It’s good.  Pretty good.  It blew me away the first times I had it, before I was introduced to good beer.  It’s still a good stout.  That said, why buy this when there’s so many better ones?
Earlier Rating: 1/28/2004 Total Score: 3.9
I miss the nitrogen!  This is great stuff and you don't have to worry about people wanting to share your beer with you.  Wish it was a little stouter in the alcohol dept.

Pours a thick jet black with a medium-sized tan creamy to foamy head.  A fair lined lacing ensues as you drink.  The aroma is toasted malt to fresh dark roasted coffee with a faint hoppy nose.  The initial draw is slightly dry dark roasted coffee with roasted malt notes.  It finishes with a dry hoppiness.  The palate is dark and dry yet a creaminess tries to push through.
great tasting beer.  average duration on the finish. good lookin beer when poured correctly into glass. damn good brew!!
Unlike an Imperial Stout, Guinness Extra Stout is something I could drink every day and not grow tired of. Great with shellfish.
Out of all the beers that I have had in my life no other beer or stout compares to the taste and flavor of a guinness in a can, bottle, or draught.

[12 oz. bottle] Dark black color with a thick tan head. Mellow and mild aroma of roasted and toasted malts and some coffee. Smooth roasty taste with a nice coffee finish and a slightly sweet chocolaty finish. For my money, it’s better than the nitro Guinness, especially out of a bottle. Draft on the other hand, is a different story.

Bottle 341ml 

Aroma: sweet malty front with dark notes as backing. Lacking depth. 

Look: murky brown with lighter tanned creamy top. Ring of lace but cap was short lived.3+ 

Taste: medium bodied. Good frontal bitterness with creamy mellow backing. Grassy, green hops on top end. Rather thin finish but with decent dryness.

Dark mahogany colour with a lasting light brown head.  Light aroma of toast, cheap coffee and macro ale - adjuncts, quick & dirty esters (think Alexander Keith’s).  Reasonably full body, slight creaminess.  Light roast flavour, with hints of milk chocolate.  Too much carbonation - not only detracts from the presentation but amplifies the astringent roast finish to unpleasant effect.

Dark brown beer with a thick dark tan head.  Faint fruity aroma with a strangely intense pale malt aroma.  Some nuttiness in the nose as well.  No obvious roasty character.  Flavour is also a poor combination of pale malt, a touch of nuttiness and molasses.  Where is the roastiness in this bottle.  Long bitter finish.  Poorly done and completely underwhelming.
nice light chocolate head wonderful looking in the pint and the smokey-coffee flavor is right up my alley only downside-a little sweet i can get it most anywhere and will continue to do so

Pours a big tan head with a good amount remaining for quite a while, then the lace completing it all. The brew itself is the real dark brown-red that would pass for black. Yep, it’s a stout.

Smell a bit of the celery and grass, some coffee, nice and roasted.

The mouthfeel is heavy-ish and smooth, but not thick like the nitro-can or the tap variations. Not overly carbonated, just as much as expected for a stout. It coats the tongue.

Taste is at first a nice sweetness, with the roasted malt topped off with a bitter, hopped metallic finish. I find a trace of alcohol even in this 5% version. My big complaint is that the finish becomes strangely unusual after the beer warms, much more harsh and off-putting. It shouldn’t, obviously.

As far as Guinness goes, I enjoy this bottled Guinness better than the nitro-can (I agree that it has better depth of character and flavour). I haven’t had it on tap in ages, so it’s not fair to compare in that area. I like it, but I don’t think this is the best stout.
This is much nicer than regular guiness with a lot more character and depth. The overiding characteristic is the coffee nose and roasted flavours.
Over carbonated; mild cookie dough and coffee nose; sweet, burnt-roasty flavor, some licorice, a note of cola; moderate body; significantly better than the regular stout.

Bottle. Thick black color...ok, I love Guinness Draught, but this is just not my bag...baby. I think that Guinness xtra stout tastes too much like Worchestershire sauce. Good though don’t get me wrong! I used to drink this alot in high school...but give me a regular draught please.
pours black with a medium tan head... Very roasty/coffee taste with a malty sweetness and a bitter aftertaste..  One of my favorite stouts!

Wow - I haven’t had this one for awile, I forgot just how roasty it tastes.  Looks mosly like the regular Guinness - black with a medium light brown head and good lacing - looks like it’s got larger bubbles though.  Taste had a nice robustly roasted flavor and some sweetness (at times the sweetness seemed to take over) with a lingering bitter finish

Bottled. Better than the nitro stuff, I think. Dark brown to near black body. Brown head with mild roasted notes and light coffee. Taste is much the same. Pleasant roasted notes. Light bitterness. Bittersweet chocolate as well. Mouthfeel as some light creaminess and mild bitterness. Finishes with more roasty malt and cocoa. A favorite!
Earlier Rating: 7/22/2002 Total Score: 3.4
Always a classic! Blackish brown in color. Foamy tan head. Not as thick tasting as you would think. Tastes of coffee, roasted malts and maybe a slight tobaccoey hint. Slightly bitter finish. Really not that great of a beer, based on newer experiences, but brings back great memories and is an easy drink.

Aroma is sweet malt with light roastiness.  Beer pours black with a nice thick well retained tan colored head.  Aroma is remarkably light and sweet for such a dark beer.  Seems like it should be much roastier.  Anyway, flavor is also sweet almost like sugar water.  The most redeeming quality of this beer is a bit of roastiness in the finish.  The commercial description seems right on.  It does indeed seem to be a pale ale with Guiness wort extract dumped in.  A very biforcated beer.

Pours with a nice foamy head.  Very dark rich amber color.  Not much aroma after pouring.
Flavor gets better with each sip.  I feel it’s to be enjoyed slowly with a good pretzel. I’ve had other Guinness but this is my first Extra Stout.

Pours with a two-finger light brown head that is thick and frothy leaving a ton of lace.  Totally black color.  Light-medium carbonation and heavy bodied.  Nose is barely there can’t get anything distinguishable.  Starts with a strong roasted, almost burnt coffee flavor and finishes slightly bitter with a lingering aftertaste, goes good with dry peanuts.

I’ve drank a lot of Guinness here in the States, and in Europe.  What comes in bottles here is not as good as what comes in the tall thin cans, and what comes from a good tap with clean lines is even better.  Guiinness is always good, anways tasty and always mellow.

When your with an Scottsman who is brillent, who can remember to rate?  I have drank this beer so many times, yet this time is was somehow sweeter.  I even gave lessons in the qualities of lace and head.  Great head, excellent aroma, smooth taste.
Very very nice.  I could "drink" this everynight...

Jet black in color with a tan head. Slightly tart, roast grain and toffee aroma. Good body with a bit of a slick finish. Distinct Guinness flavor that I would describe as black current with some acrid burnt flavors and a bit of chalkiness. Bitter bite. Fairly good stout.
