Bottle. Deep brown, thick off white head. Nice aroma, a hint of coffee. Not a very diverse flavor, I taste some coffee notes but not a lot of malt, quite dry. Finish is pretty empty. I like cooking with this beer, it’s great in chili and a good bath for some brats, but that’s about it.

Darker than black, light doesn’t seem to escape this beer.  Smooth almost non-existant palate, just seems to glide right in the mouth and down the throat.  Taste is a little like the palate, non-descript.  Not too bad with some good food.  Don’t have it with Italian food.
Earlier Rating: 10/14/2004 Total Score: 3.5
Darker than black, light doesn’t seem to escape this beer.  Smooth almost non-existant palate, just seems to glide right in the mouth and down the throat.  Taste is a little like the palate, non-descript.  Not too bad with some good food.  Don’t have it with Italian food.

12oz bottle.  Black body with a tan head that  subsides fairly quickly.  Tasted at 50 degrees in a tulip. Roasted malty head with soapy? notes. Super-roasted (burnt?) malt flavor.  Bitter coffe flavors.  These two flavors are almost all of the taste.  The finish is dry and bitter with only the burnt flavor. Not a good mouthfeel, makes me wish for the dreaded nitro packet. It’s not real great as a sipper, as yayforbeer noted, and it does go down easier when slugged down, of course, that is not what I am looking for in beer. Sorry Guiness, I have had some great times with you, but this beer is subpar.

(Bottle)  Pours a black body with a thick, creamy beige head.  Aroma of toasted malt.  Flavor of rich malt and coffee.  
Earlier Rating: 4/24/2004 Total Score: 3.7
Pours a dark chocolate colro with a thick tan head.  Smooth, creamy, coffee, and chocolate taste.  Good, but prefer the draught version.

Roasted toasted malt aroma. Dark pour, nice head, tam, fluffy and airy. Sour taste followed by a bit of a bite. I even feel the alcohol finish. Good. I agree mr. YAYFORBEER> much better when drank with gusto!
Draft is the only way to experience Guinness. This is a decent substitute, but has a very strong arabian coffee aroma and taste.

Burned-grain aroma after a very dark pour.  Excellent tight, tan head that really lasts.  A friend of mine brought a six-pack over and I waited until he left to break into it!  Slight sour after taste buta bit too carbonated for me.  It’s true what they say, Guiness is much better when you get it in Ireland.  Luckily for me, I get to travel there on business often!

I suppose most stout drinkers started here, as I did, and its good to come home occasionally even if you dont plan on staying long.  Found it on sale for $4.99 a six today and loaded up.  I can always drink a Guinness.  Dark brown pour with a decent tan head.  Roasted grains in the flavor with a little bitterness and a slight sourishness.  A touch of sweetness with medium body.  Just like I remember, this one is not for sipping, tastes much better when you drink it with some gusto.

An attractive beer, pouring pitch black with a brown head of tiny bubbles. Smells of burnt grains and a bit of a sour smell too. Taste is bitter and a bit sour, typical guinness though just more powerful. It’s a good beer. The finish isn’t bad at all. It doesn’t linger. A little too sour for my tastes. I’ll have to compare it to a regular guinness side-by-side sometime.
not crazzy for the taste of this beer think its over priced very bitter think reg guinness is better than this
this stuff is bitter than fuck. regular guinness is better, but this ain’t too bad
dry, a little bitter at times. toasty malt aroma and flavor. creamy. not as good as regular guinness.

Motor oil black with a frothy tanned head that lingers around.  Aroma is light and not very appealing for a "extra stout".  Rather bland flavored and dry but some burnt malts do add to the taste throughout the drink.  Sticking to the regular Guinness.
Pours out deep black color with tan color head.  Nice roasted flavor, coffee, nutty, and touch of molasses.  Very nice stout.

Thanks to my futrue sister-in-law for this bottle from Ireland. NIce drinkable stout. Had a good roasty flavor. Not as smooth as regular Guinness.
Earlier Rating: 4/2/2004 Total Score: 3.8
Had a bottle at a Guinness Believer event in Philly. This was a good stout. Had a nice bitter bite to it. I liked this better than the regular Guinness.

Well, I think that this is what I am drinking.  So many damn varieties.  Wow, I am really surprised at the very large head on this brew.  I actually expected it to be kind of flat.  Light brown head.  Creamy and rocky on top and settles slowly.  Creamy milk aroma, with a bit of roasted grains.  Color is black with a hint of dark brown around the edges.  Dry flavor.  Bit of bitterness with dry roasted peanut skins and bitter hops.  Finish is dry and parching.  A decent stout.  Hey wait, I though Guiness was brewed in Ireland not in Canada.  I am calling my lawyer.

Seriously, what is there *TO* say? It is the famous Guinness, only not as good as on top or in a can. Mmm but less mmm.
Earlier Rating: 7/22/2004 Total Score: 3.8
The Guinness in a bottle is not as good as in the can. This is strange, but stranger things have been true. I like Guinness, and it can hold its own on most any other beer out there - but, go with the cans or get it on tap, please. They’re better that way. And in the cans you get more ounces...

Better than the nitrogen infused draught botttles and cans.  If you have to drink Guinness prepackaged this is the way to go.
Earlier Rating: 10/27/2004 Total Score: 3.3
Dark color with the tan head.  I love pale ale, and I love Guinness draught, so I thought this would be perfect.  Perhaps my expectations were too high.  Has the roasty choco-coffee flavor with a bitter finish.  Would probably really enjoy this had I never had the original.

Pours a deep dark brown with a nice tan head. Big roasty carmel aroma. Notes of chocolate and coffee. Flavor is rich with carmel roastiness. Nice hoppy bitterness and dry finish. Have had many microbrewed stouts since I last had this, and this is the standard that all stouts should meet.

Pretty much what you’d expect, though not even close to what it tastes like on tap in Ireland.  Some decent bitter notes, dark roasted malt and mild aroma of dark malts.  Easy to drink, but it still tastes terrible after having it where it’s the best.
a good dark beer...a mildly bitter aroma...a roasted burnt taste; surprisingly hard to determine what i am tasting...a lasting aftertaste...a decent beer
Not as good as the original guiness that I usually get on tap but this beer is likely  the best from Labatts.  A nice Canadian copy.

Color as black as pitch, big, creamy, rocky tan head. Aroma is filled with sweet and roasty flavor, hints of coffee and spice. More flavors come through on the palate, dark cherries, berries, chocolate. Some bitterness, huge and flavorful malt. Long lasting and tasty finish. Bold and substantial, this classic is best consumed cool, not cold. 
Another devotee of "draught" once told me on the subject of stouts, "There’s only one!", referring to Guinness. I’m glad that that’s not true, but I never turn down Extra Stout.

Great aroma of sweetness and notes of something bitter. Moving on with the taste, the let down arrives. I really cant place the taste but it was kind of like burnt candy and coffee. Finished watery and bitter.

Bottle:  Aroma is rather weak.  Kind of like a  pale lager mixed with a very faint coffee smell.  Pours  a very dark brown, virtually black, with a nice tan head with good retention. Virtually no lacing.   Flavor is mostly in the finish.  Coffee, roastiness,  bitterness, and slight dark chocolate.  Slight salt taste in the finish as well. Light malty and coffee aftertaste.  Just an okay beer, nothing special.  Overall score is going to take a hit based on weak aroma.
I really like this one. winter or summer it is a treat. The suprise find  is that it goes better with a meal of Jerk Chicken, Buttered Navy Beans, and Corn pudding than even Red Stripe does.

To begin with, I really like the aroma. It is literally a pleasant mix of pale ale and stout - never would have thought such an odd combo could go so well together. The color is like Pepsi syrup and the head dissipates surprisingly fast - but what can be expected from a pale ale mix. Guinness Extra’s palate is thin as mentioned in other reviews, but in this case it serves to hide the 6% alcohol quite well, so I don’t spite it for this. However, the aftertaste is tinny and somewhat acrid so I still give it a low Palate rating. Stout seems to have developed as a winter beverage - though I prefer thicker, traditional stouts I’d actually recommend this type more for after work on a hot summer day.

Ah ha!  So it’s "imported" but from Canada.  Those crazies.  I think I actually enjoyed this beer.   Vague aroma, what is it...  Meaty taste, like having a good ham sandwich, with the ham 3/4" thick sliced.  What is that aroma....?  Ah, I’ve got it now, this beer smells like... a freshman dorm!  No, seriously, the smell is like walking down the hallways of a freshman dorm.  I don’t know why, but I tell it, it’s true.  Maybe its beacuse they rinse the walls of Warren Towers dorm in Boston with Guinness Extra Stout?  No, no...  maybe Guiness Extra Stout smells like mindless, will-regret-it-tomorrow sex?  No, no...  why?  Who knows, but it smells like the hallway of a freshman dorm.  A weird scent, but gets points for being different.  A alcoholy stream cuts through this beer, slightly offensive but handle-able.  Nice color, beams itself nicely in a glass.

This brew really doesn’t live up the the Guinness name. Pours nice, black with a tan head, but from there goes down hill. Very thin on the palate, overwhelming bitterness in the end, leaving an unbalanced feeling to it. Lack of carbonation makes this brew feel dead. Some roastiness and coffee flavors, but the thin mouthfeel just ruins this stout.
This reminded me of a flatter, stronger Guinness.  It ends up being halfway between the smoothness of the original and a standard Imperial.  Not the best of both worlds, however.
A nice alternative to the Draft.  The head is nice to start but loses its texture.  Has a nice coffee-ish aroma.  Popular whereever you may go.

This might be marginally better than the draught (the bottle and can versions extra nitrogen ones).  
These days, having had some amazing  imperial stouts, Guinness is really only useful to me for carbombs but lots of other people seem to hold it up as the holiest of the holy

This pours a dark, almost black color with a tan, frothy head.  There’s not much aroma, just a very mild roasted malt scent.  The taste isn’t bad, an earthy, coffee, and malt flavor.  Not much hopping.  Fairly average stout.
Pours black with a nice off white creamy head. Nose of coffee dark malt. The flavour has some coffee notes and a medium bitterness to the finish. An average stout.

Once you acquire a taste for Guinness, you will drink it, whenever possible, and drink it properly. Americans, totally brainwashed by the phrase "Ice cold" seldom get to appreciate the real taste of Guinness, which does not taste all that great "ice cold", and should be drunk at celler temperature. Contrary to a popular American misconception nobody drinks Guinness "warm", but "cool".
Looks like Guinness. Tastes like Guinness. A bit more bitterness throughout. Nothing special.

Certainly a great beer, with a solid amount of history behind it to secure its place in the upper echelon of beers.  Granted, following historical leads isn’t always the best plan, there certainly is a reason this beer has obtained the reknown reputation that it has.  Observing a solid pint of it is truly looking at a masterpiece of beer, with the beautiful contrast of the thick, creamy head, and the rich succulent liquid that lies beneath.  The only real issue I’ve taken with it, is that if it either starts out too warm, or somehow manages to work it’s way up to it, it becomes a little rougher, and sometimes smokier than something I’d like to drink.  Oh well, keep it cold, keep ’em coming, and sit down with some good pals to share some laughs and a good beer.

I used to like this beer,but now I don’t.
Looks good,smells good,and tastes bad.
Has heavey coffee flavors,and burnt smokey flavors wich also sounds good,but this beer is entirely too harsh,and needs better balance.
Very hoppy,and malt is not sweet enough to save the beer.

bottle 22 oz. Made in Canada. Dk brown almost black w no light through it. Good tan head that could have lasted longer w lots of large bubble carbonation, some lace. Aroma is mild dk roasted malt w a touch of coffee & some hops. Flavor is dry & a bit sour dk roasted malt & bitter unsweet dark chocolate w a rather pronounced hop bitterness. A bit harsh and watery at the same time. Not enough malt flavor. There is a definate hop bitterness on the palate and in the finish with the malt and hop flavor somewhere in the background. Hop bitterness lingers long on the finish w a dusty aftertaste. The commercial description of Labatt's ale with an extract added explains it for me. My 2.6 rate is frickin generous. I thought about dumping it down the drain
A bit of an improvement on the regular stout in that it ups the coffee ante and tones down the licorice to make way for a sweeter stout.  A filling drink that remains satisfying.

This beer is black like motor oil and slick.  Great stuff.  Bitter and satisfying.  Great classic stout.
Earlier Rating: 6/8/2004 Total Score: 3.3
Darker and thinner in consistancy than the original.  Dark tan head.  Aroma is of raosted coffee, almost burnt.  Taste is equally "raosted" with malts and coffee. I have only had this in bottle form and would be anxious to taste it from keg at a bar.  Regular Guinness is far superior and more consitant in this form, so I would be anxious to see if the extra stout work the same way.

Deep ruby black with fluffy tan head.  Faint coffee aroma with roasted malt.  Malty sweetness with strong hops bite up front, burnt coffee and some licorice.  Palatable but not very tasty.  Thin body with long, bitter finish.  Worth one or two but not many more.
overall, my classic favorite. i love the creamy head (haha) and the smooth taste. nice and mellow.
Didnt like this one a whole lo. Bit to strong. Maybe be better off the tap but i dont know. think ill stick to guinness draught.

Bottled.   More bitter than the draught, or maybe the lack of nitrogen lets you taste something. . . I find this much less thin, more flavorful and just overall, better of a beer.  This is the Guinness I remember, not the watered down, crap that you buy in bars on draught today.  I’ll take this every time.  I wish I had tried the unpasteurised bottle in Ireland, I bet that is tremendously good.
Earlier Rating: 7/9/2002 Total Score: 3.5
very bitter, like coffee at the end of the pot. hmmm, not bad though, still a bit watery and syrupy.  It'll do if it has to

Pours dark brown black with light brown head.  Smells like chocolate and coffee.  Nicely carbonated and flavored.  Seemed to be more roasted coffee flavor than the Stout.  Has nice long finish to it.  I liked the flavor in this better than the stout and therefore liked it better overall.
Even though I normally like stronger stouts, I find this less pleasing than Guinness Draft.  Seems to be less rich and less flavorful than the Draft version.

Not a very tell tale nose here.  Just kind of bland for a stout.  Appearance is the normal for a stout, but maybe a tad heavy on the head.  Flavor is not terribly dry, but has a good malt feel thats rather smooth.  An yes, as the past few ratings have said, its not really extra compared to anything notable.

Wow, I did not know that Guinness Extra Stout has the highest alcohol content of all Guinness, weighing in at a whopping 5%. Ya live, ya learn I guess. The last time I bought a Guinness packaged product was for Irish Car Bombs and the cans ended up in my fridge for at least a year. This is the bottled stuff which I haven’t had in a few years. Pours with a puffy head but a tinny aroma. The taste is bolder than both the draft and canned product I’ve had in the recent past. Decent bitterness as well. Frankly, not bad at all. I like it. Woo hoo.

Rating based on the Canadian version brewed by Labatt. Dark ruby-black colour with a small tan head. Very nice aroma of dark fruit and roasted coffee. Body is thin, but the flavour is decent, very roasty with licorice and coffee notes that are balanced by a slightly sour and dry finish. It pales in comparison to the Caribbean version I tried a couple of months ago, but it’s still not a bad beer, aside from the weak body.

Dark ruby tinged black body, with a smallish head. Sweet raisiny fruit in the aroma along with some mild roastiness, which pretty accurately describes the flavour as well. Thin body is its downfall, but it is not unpleasant and a different experience from what you find on tap. This may have benefited a bit from its pairing with some spicy food which enhanced its appeal somewhat.

bottle from local bodega, 
jet black with tan head,not much carbonation. mostly malty taste . not super flavorful  but very drinkable when only lighter big name crap are at hand.
I was already a huge dfan of original guinness, but this freakin rocks, the flavor is so full with a hint of black licorice, it was simply amazing.
Very dark, almost black beer with a tan head. Tastes like coffee and has a coffee and malt aroma, not bad at all.
pours dark brown almost black like the draught, but better, has more taste to it, brunt coffee like as well.  rich aroma, bitter ending.  needs an acquired taste...
This is the king of Stouts. Great coffee flavor.  pours well with a great head.  my favorite beer by far

Traditional bottled Guinness pours with medium body, soft carbonation, and medium hop lace.  Excellent head retention, with black malt and sour mash aromas.  Malts dominate the palate, with bitter, oaky, sweet, and more sour mash notes.  Medium hop flavor, more prominent in the aftertaste.  The flavors mesh better in the early 2010 version than they did in 2004; perhaps Moosehead makes a better ale base than Labatt’s?

Somewhat coffeelike aroma, a little sour, a little chocolate.  Flavor is dominated by nearly burnt malt with an underlying layer of butterscotch.  Finish is extremely bitter.  So much better than nitro guinness

Oh... how I love Ireland... the Magical Emerald Isle!  The current Guinness brews in the west and USA... including this version... are no longer the brew brewed and bottled in Ireland. This was a horrid  change. The strong  enchanting  Aura of Ireland and its magical/faery lore and lush ancient lore and feel used to be tasted and brewed right into all of the Guinness variations, and the quality from Ireland was superb!  You could also feel  the Heart of the Irish people and warmth  of the ancient gaelic Ireland in all Guinness brews. .. all  the Irish subtleties and richness was then in their Guinness brews.  The fatal mistake is now the Guinness brews, including this Guinness Extra Stout are now brewed and bottled in Canada of all places! Canada is not known for its ability to recognize any subtleties and is very simple and plain in its tastes. Canada is not into the Guinness Ireland ancient feel and lore and true traditional tastes. The place where a brew is crafted, brewed and bottled is brewed right into the beverage.  Irelands Aura and enchanted taste and influence is now missing from the Guinness brews brewed and bottled in the west and Canada!  Still, this is still a Guinness Extra Stout to be enjoyed and savoured, even though the travesty of its being created in Canada now.... and this is not the True Guinness from Ireland. {Best to import Guinness from Ireland!.} This is still a very enjoyable brew.  Dark velvety black with a thick  caramel head. Very dark malty roasted flavours brimming with coffee, and toffee or butterscotch hints, and some chocolate hues. The hoppiness in the Extra Stout is a little bitter for my taste. And, under No Circumstances should any Guinness be served too cold... this absolutely mutes all flavour... and it only tastes bitter, too watery and nothing else!  Let it warm up a bit. Serve nice and cool but not overly cold... then the full dark roastiness and all its other enjoyable flavours come out. Looks beautiful and rich in mug. Good full~mouth feel {usually.}  A bit too bitter finish. Still Very Good!  Still A Brew To Savour!

Haven’t seen this on Tap, maybe it doesn’t come that way? But from the bottle it just doesn’t have the taste/feel/something that good old draft Guinness does. And because of that it takes a distant second seat to Guinness on Tap (IMO).

Maaan!!!  Absolutely delicious!!  One of MY FAVORITES!!  Yummy in my tummy!!  Phenomenal stout.  Beautiful georgous ravishing spectacular long lasting head!!  Possess a nice deep chocolate caramel color; aroma has hints of burnt coffee, VERY MALTY too! Little bit bitter which i luv.  Very mouth-furfilling.   Makes me dRoOoOoL just thinking about it!!  AWESOME to use for carbombs!!  This a mosdef a meal in a bottle.  Excellent energy pick me upper!!  Kinda like a gateorade.

Pours black with a thick tan head. Smells like coffee.  Has a coffee flavor with woody overtones. A pleasantly suprising body given my past experience with guinness beers. Not as watery as the draught, with a good aftertaste. Harsher than most beers, but worth saying "Brilliant" too.

This just proves that Gunness is Gunness is NOT Guinness.  I had this in a rickety bar in Superior and wasn’t too impressed... Alot more bitter. Wasn’t able to put my finger on it, but prefer the draught version MUCH more.
Earlier Rating: 6/21/2004 Total Score: 3.8
This may have been one of the first non-swill beers I’ve had.  I cannot remember the first time I tried it but it’s definitly my favorite any-time beer.  Dark, with thick head...malt, small roasts....a.k.a. The Shit.

Guinness®. ARRR! Well Let’s see what Labatt can do with her. I don’t know why they needed to be chilled for 3 hours. ’Cause stouts real tastey when it’s froze. Enough of the sarcasm. Pours cola brown with a frothy tan head. For something as roasty as this there is very little to speak of on aroma. Maybe slight cereal and toast.  Lemony, chocolate, coffee are in the forefront. Fruit tart and sweetness raspberry/strawberry.  Burnt sugar.  Very dry finish. This beer is one step toward redeeming itself.

Dark black.  Dense, brown head.  Is almost overwhelming with coffee, chocolate, all flavors to the front including alcohol.  Quite a lot of roasted malt character, quite bitter at the end.  I may never drink it again as there are many more interesting stouts out there, but for Americans it is the standard.

This was the first "real" beer I ever tasted (prior to this, I was mostly Coors and Coors Lite), so I have fond memories of this one.  Maybe it’s for sentimental  reasons that I rate this so high, but it IS a very nice sipping drink, particularly on cold nights.  Highly recommended, especially for those of you making the transition from "trough water beers" to the "real thing."  Bits of chalky chocolate swirl amongst fresh coffee beans covered in cocoa.  Watery mouthfeel, but the flavor is so intense that this aspect is forgotten.

Eh. About the same to me as Guinness original, although a tad bit hoppier and more bitter. Strong aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Flavor is roasted coffee and malt with hints of oak and hops. Not bad, but nowhere near as good as Guinness draught.
Earlier Rating: 6/2/2004 Total Score: 3.8
For some reason, I’m not as big a fan of bottled Guinness, except for the new widget bottles, which closely approach the flavor and texture of Guinness on tap. The bottled original pours an opaque dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is as rich as usual, but the flavor is very bitter compared to the draught version. Much more of the roasted coffee flavor, but it’s not necessarily a good thing to me. Oh, well. Still an excellent stout.
Bottle - Very dark with a thick, long lasting tan head.  Fairly thick and quite creamy.  Bitter with an intense coffee and roasted malt flavor with a long dry, bitter hop finish.

Rating a bottled version from Canada which is brewed by Labatts (Interbrew). Bit of a sour aroma, flavour is malty and cheap. No lingering flavours which is a good thing in this case. This beer is terrible, maybe we need a specific catagory for the version brewed by Labatts in Canada. At first I suspected a really old or bad bottle but I’ve had this on two separate occasions and it was just as bad both times.
Very dark and very thick beer with a lasting head.  Chocolate aroma with a bitter after taste.
mmmmmm... guinness...  and the original is at least as good as any other.  there’s nothing that looks more appetizing than a freshly poured guinness.
Smooth, basic in style whose formula is basically unchanged for the longest time. A mid-sip chocolate sweet roast and spicey malt. Bitter aftertaste but not a smuch as their draft.
It’s black, but there is too much carbonation for me.  It is not as creamy as draught.  Very bitter aftertaste.

Bottle.  JZ and I argue over this one and the draught from Guiness.  I like this beer.  It is strong, nice bodied, black as night and has a little hop flavor hiding inside.  I do not like this as much as the draught however.  JZ does.  He is not wrong, simply doesn’t know what he is talking about.  Not as creamy or thick, but still a fine brew.  I think the Guinness family is royalty.

There is nothing to say abou Guinness except for you either love it or hate it. I still can’t decide whether i like Stout or Draught better, I always find myself gettin a sixer of each to help me figure that out.
damn, tastes like chocolate...and coffee, i got pretty f*cked up on this last easter
super bitter flavor--i’m surprised how intense it is.  very dry bitter finish, and pretty good overall.
A good stout.  Classic Guinness taste with a little sour in the mix. Very creamy texture.
A stout, it is bitter, coffee taste and carmel. it has to be served at its proper tempature. Real heavy, i could only drink two, filled me up. Good though, would not expect less from Guinness.

A good all around stout.  A bit more flavour than the original and slightly more alcohol at 5%, which is pretty low in itself for a stout anyway.  
Earlier Rating: 4/19/2004 Total Score: 3.3
Not quite as good as on tap or the extra stout and foreign versions, but a decent stout none the less.  Its smooth and creamy with a strong head.  Not the most flavourfull.
I like this one better than the draught. More carbonated and hoppy. Comes out pure black like a usual stout. I am not a big fan of the draught, but this one aint bad.
The druken irish boys have stuck gold with this fine stout. It has a nice head. After my first beer i wanted to get up and do a little irish jigg

Its Guinness and thats good. But its not nitro drawn and doesnt have the guinness head. Taste is a bit more complex than draught, but still, I like the draught experience.
Earlier Rating: 4/5/2004 Total Score: 3.3
The more I drink this, the more I wish I had bought a draught pack. This stuff is too bitter and acidic.

Phenomenal stout. Opaque, deep chocolatly color; aroma has hints of burnt coffee. The head on a pint of Guinness is simply spectacular...long-lasting, slightly bitter cocoa qualities. Heavy mouth-feel...best served very cold. Bitterness increases exponentially as beer approaches room temperature. Quite satisfying. Guinness: a meal in a bottle.

Faint whiff of roastiness in the aroma.  Tandem coffee/roasted barley blast hits you.  Quite dry in the finish.  Its refreshing to actually taste roastiness in a guiness, something you can't do in a pint of the nitro stuff.

This brew is for me more robust more bitter and more flavorful then the Draught version; the latter being flatter and less flavorful. The appearance is pleasing with a rocky head. Although it is high in Carbs approximately 17g per 12oz bottle its also high in Flavour. If you are seeking a good wallop then reach for the Black.

a bit too dry for my palate. all the expected burnt malt flavor. i like it somewhat more than the draught. but when i drink this beer it teases me with the burnt malt flavor and nothing else behind it to follow up.

Pours a dark, dark coffee brown that appears ebony without light.  The head is light tan and pretty consistent.  Smells almost like a wheat beer, and the taste reminded me a lot of a wheat too.  However, I hate wheat beers, but I enjoyed this one.  Medium-bodied and smooth, but doesn't go down as easily as the draught.  In all, it was good, but I'd definitely pick the draught over this.

Pours inpenerable ebony color. Nice tan head, with a sticky lace on down the glass. Smell of grain, sugars, hints of chocolate and wood. Taste is semi-sweet and a generous hop flavor to finish. Very light-bodied IMO, and a signature stickiness that almost saves it for me. Pretty drinkable for it's style and just found I got bored after a few. A brew I think I've out-grown a bit. A beer that seemed better a few years back. It's a great "once in a while" beer

Very dark brown, small tan head, a littl bit of lacing. Aroma is mostly of roasted barley back by some faint hoppiness. The flavour lacks strength and character, but is overall quite quaffable. Medium body. A good stout. Bottle.
This is a failry strong brew but probably not as good as its brother the stout.
I was rather suprised by this one... The Draught was pretty bad, and watered down, this isn't as much.  It isn't anything great, but it is solid.  Nice mocha head, coffee aroma, smooth.
Nice strong aroma. Great appearance. Doesn't do much for me in the way of taste due to I'm not that keen on thick beers. Definetly a feeling beer. Great breakfast for someone on the go.

Poured the same thick, blackish-brown as the "draught," but with a more rocky, darker head than the smooth white nitro head found in the can.  Flavor was substantially stronger; it was smooth and malty, with smoky, roasted, chocolatey notes and a strong, bitter finish.  I prefer this flavor to the draught, but I must confess that I enjoy the ultra-smooth, milky mouthfeel of the "floating draught system."  I definitely have a love for Guinness, and this is an excellent stout that serves as an alternative to the usual.

Whats the big deal about this beer. Huge foamy head. Very little sweetness, with almost no stout aroma. oh, did I say it was also very dry. Aftertaste is much too thin. Might enjoy beer if im watching a movie and would rather not think about what Im drinking.

Pours black.  Close inspection reveals small amount of light penetration and dark ruby highlights on the edge of the glass.  Light brown head.  Aroma is decent, smells of wine.  Yeah, it smells like this was made from grapes.  Flavor is a bit thin for a stout, but richer (using this word lightly here) than the Draught version.  I can’t believe this is actually rated lower overall.  This isn’t great by any means, but it sure beats that watery crap they try to pass off as a stout.

Pours like a Guinness. Not the best head, I must say. Especially when you're expecting the draught version. Good mouthfeel from a bottle.  The carbonation seems off as well. Not bad in a pinch, but give me the nitrogen!

What a ditz I am, I knocked back 5 of the 6'er before I realized I wasn't drinking the regular Guinness. It's been a year since I rated the regular version and somehow, this just doesn't quite measure up. Feels a bit thinner than I remember.

This is, IMHO opinion, a far superior product than Guinness' regular draught and canned offering.  It has everything I find pleasant about the other GS, i.e. nice dry, somewhat in-your-face roasted malt aroma and flavor, without the unpleasant sourness they add to the regular stout on purpose.  I don't even buy the other one anymore, but this version can occasionally be found in my fridge.
Dark color, sharp bitterness, good mouthfeel.  Burnt-smoky start finishes smooth and creamy.  Enjoy it good and cold.

Poured black but when held up to the light, some light easily gets through.

Aroma is of roasted malt and slightly tart flavors. 

The taste was quite sweet with candy sugar, but it was nicely balanced.

The mouthfeel is slightly creamy but a tad thin.

The drinkability is good because while this is not a really interesting stout it is quite quaffable.
best stout I know of, but serve cold, unless you can take a very bitter aftertaste.

Picture Guinness Nitro bottles with the plastic wrap and the nitro widget inside. Now think of the exact opposit. That's about what you have here. They should dump the crap and focus on this. But then again I'm marketing to myself and not the masses.

Pours a solid black with a nice tan head that left some nice lacing down the glass.

Smells of roasted malt sweetness.

Tastes primarily of roasted malts with some fruitiness in there as well. It's not overly complex and doesn't hold a candle to most other stouts, but it's a far cry from their normal offering.

Mouthfeel has the benefit of a decent mineral mouthfeel to add to the fullness. Not as nice as Sheaf Stout, but not bad at all.

Drinkability is pretty good as well. If I were to find this in a bar next to the crappy Guinness, I'd grab this as fast as I could.

Too much malt. I find this too dry. Not very easy with food as it overpowers most other food. Too much roasted taste. 
Earlier Rating: 11/10/2003 Total Score: 3.2
Re-rate. Has a grassy and malty aroma. Also hints of brown sugar and molasses. The color is a beautiful black with a small, but everpresent tan head. The taste is coffee and some chocolate. Actually, pretty good.
slightly sweet aroma of malt; very dark with a medium tan head; the flavor is dominated by hops, especially in the aftertaste

Pours black with a small brown head.  Nice roasted malt aroma and flavor.  A little sweetness and good bitterness balances a nice flavor.  More carbonation, not as thick or creamy as the draught.  Flavor is stronger and maybe better.  Nice beer.
This stout is the standard by which all others are judged.  Some can be better, but this will always be the standard.  Beautiful dark color, sharp bitterness and easy carbonation.

Near black color with a tall foamy tan head. I catch a lot of caramel, some roasted malts and a hint of hops. It has been at least 7 years since I last had this one. Almost wish it was longer. This is nowhere close to the memories of this one. Dry and acidic malt with only a touch of hops bitterness. Decent malt linger, miss the old Guinness.
Earlier Rating: 7/23/2003 Total Score: 2.9
Dark brown to black with a fluffy tan head. Light toasty grain aroma. Light start with some mild sweetness. Middle has a slight  hops bitterness and touch of molassas. finish is just a bitter roasted barley flavor that leaves a caffine type acidity residue on the palate. Are we to chill it three hours to kill the flavor?

Poured a dark colour, with burgundy showing through a light. A very sharp and bitter start, but it certainly improved as it warmed.  It had a bit of metallic taste, though it was from a bottle...could have been the fact it was lying on its side in the fridge for a week.  Had much substance though, a nice palate, although I found it too carbonated.  All in all ok, but not what I expected.
Opaque black color with a medium tan head. Sour bitter aroma. Roasty, tangy, almost burnt malt flavor, with a dry hoppy finish. Not bad.
Not all that bad, dark with a long lasting tan head. The nose was sweet and malty. The taste was bitter with some malts nd a long lasting aftertaste. Medium body and overall pretty good.

.Nice, pitch-black with decent head and lacing.Aroma is of hops,coffee, and malt.Hops hit you on the first taste, but then dies out afterwards. Carbonation kind of ruins this one. But overall, not bad  but not as good as regular draught.
Good smell, awesome appearance and loved the flavor. Classic guinness taste only stronger. The extra hops are very good, would've liked a better head.

Pours very dark brown with a light brown, foamy head.  Thick, fluffy gobs of brown cotton candy adhere to the mug.  

Nose is extra roasted grains, and day old coffee sitting on the stove.

Grassy, grainy burnt roast.  Touch astringent.  Not too pleasant on the palate, first thing to note.  Starts burnt, a bit of sweetness helps, and a very  dry finish.  Not all that drinkable.
Same traditional beautiful color, with slightly less head. Guinness is great already, but the extra hops in this make it even more special.
I prefer this one over the draught version.  Much more carbonated, robust aroma.  Nice coffee taste.

bottle-I picked this one up in a mix a six pack deal and i was pretty suprised how good it was.  Its all about to coffee on this one-aroma, palate and flavor all have coffee on them.  pretty straight forward and solid.

Pours dark thick color with only the lightest ruby color showing through.  Has a thick tan head, without the nitrogen, which is nice.  Sweet candy-like almost foreign stout aroma with some smoky peat malt character.  Body is sugary sweet and lightly complex with hints of dark fruits.  Finishes bittersweet, dry and lightly roasted.  A nice dry stout.

Rated lower than regular Guinness but this is a better beer.  Pours very dark brown with a creamy tan head.  The body is nicely carbonated which provides a different mouthfeel than regular Guinness.  Bitter roasted malt aroma with surprising hops notes.  Body is smooth and silky with bitter roasted barley balanced by slightly sweet caramely malt flavors.  Hops are present although subdued.  Surprisingly good and much better than their standard offering.


Hmmm...after having a couple of these the other night, I’m not sure where my original 3.7 rating came from.  Bitter and rather unbalanced.

Black indeed, medium head is unremarkable.  Aroma is roasty and pungent with good sweetness, but oddly metallic.  Metallic bitterness middle way through followed by decent bitter finish.  Roasted, woody malt front.  Nod bad, but this is not my favorite style.

Black, brown head. Spicy, clean aroma, earthy, dry, with the familiar dry finish. Seems much more substantial than the draught can. Better than I remebered, but no longer the benchmark stout for me that it used to be.

Canned, at Slea Head, Kerry, Ireland. Black with a large frothy brown head. Tastes OK for a canned beer but with all the quality draught Guinness about the place, this was just a romantic surrounded by absolutely stunning scenery on the westerly most part of Europe. Breath taking this place was.

Fermented mud puddle!  TONS of flavor, tons of aroma, lots of stuff.   My straw stood straight up in it.  Real eye opener for what beer can be, and one is plenty for me.  Everyone should try this beer.
More bitter and more dry than the regular Guinness. The taste comes through more in this as well (due to non-nitro?). Roasted flavor, not much hop flavor in the taste.
Guinness is a smooth stout with a nice coffee taste. I would never complain about drinking this beer.

This is a slightly stronger Guinness.  It pours black with a hint of ruby once the glass is nearly empty.  The large tan head is lasting, but it doesn’t lace like a Nitrogen can of Guinness.  The palate is not subtle, and this is ok in the beginning as the coffee, toffee, and woody flavors come through.  The bitter aftertaste of the hops is a bit unpleasant, however.  This beer is still pretty complex and delicious, but the original is better.
a great beer to look at with the black fluid and creamy head.  i love the creamy, hoppy rich flavor and the dry aftertaste.  a good beer!

(Brewed in Canada) I poured at a medium pace and generated a three-inch head. The nose is fairly strong and dominated, by coffee and dark chocolate. The palate is a bit on the light side and is noticeably pasteurized. The main flavor is bitterness derived from malts as opposed to hops. The Canadian version extra stout is not as rustic as the Irish version that I had sampled in the past. Overall, GES is an average beer, but is much better than the draft version. The beer really isn’t very complex.

This stout proves it’s worth.  With a nice head and rich aroma, my mouth waters before it hits my lips.  The bitter coffe taste is very nice, though a tad too bitter.  My only draw back with this beer is the bloat factor.  After drinking a 12oz bottle, I feel like I just ate Thanksgiving dinner.

A black color, pours with a thick creamy brown head that is quite persistent, the head gets quite rocky over time as well.  There is a slightly roasted aroma with a bit of sweet grain character.  It has a lightly bitter astringent finish.  Fairly thin in its consistency.  Some roast character is here and it has a bit of a sour twang to it in the finish.  Overall this beer is quite disappointing, and much worse than I remember.  It is missing the character that I was expecting it to have.  Not too bad, but certainly not great either.
As near to perfection as one can come with as mass produced stout.The dark black color and head are are great with that wonderful bitter finish. A step above the Draught
Looks terrific, thick tan head with large bubbles. Roasted dry hops, nice balance of bitter/sweet. Many times more interesting than the Draught.
Wonderfull hops and dark flavor. Similar to the draught but alittle stronger. Good pallet and excellent aroma.

Bottle... Picked up six bottles of this at the local grocery store. Lived off of this stuff in college. Not the best out there, but it’s been around for a long while and there’s a damn good reason. Great, malty, roasted aroma and flavor. Very well-balanced. Not sweet for even a moment. Strong, blackstrap molasses notes. Small, creamy, off-white head with excellent lacework. Mildly carbonated and lightly creamy on the palate.

Poured black as night with a tan bubbly head.  Smoky aroma.  The flavor of this is actually more fulfilling than the regular stout/draught beer.  It doesn’t have that milkiness but rather the regular active texture of beers, and the flavor is more subdued, relaxingly smoky and coffee-like.  Beautiful.

One of the finest things to watch is a Guiness as it settles, lovely, of course I am reffering to draft.  Flavors are of some roasted malts with coffee and slight hops...Body is abit watery....This is the first stout that I had many years ago and will always have a special place in my heart!!!

Deep, dark body with a tan, creamy thick head.  Good, rich flavor.  Long my favorite beer, it has been dethroned by some of my recent finds but still rates as a keeper for me.  I’m told that no Guinness is a real Guinness unless it is had in Dublin.




Can’t believe this rating.  Well, I was still new to craft beer at the time.
Thin body and watery taste taint an otherwise wonderful stout.  Stick with the draught.
Still a very decent bottled stout.  Dryer than some of the more hipper new ones, but still has a full body and plenty of roasted malt flavor.

Dark dark pour, massive tan head, scents of roasted malts and coffee.  When in a chilled glass, has a very smooth flow over the palate and is very drinkable.  The smokiness really comes out when it warms up.  A very good brew.
Dear guinness.....i love you..waht  great beer its sick its tasty and it hase heart i just cant get enough ot this tasty black stuff

Dark beer, with brown, dry thich head.  This fabulous foam lasted 3/4 of the beer.  I have a new favorite.  Enjoyed much more that the draught.  Very distinct flavors, I'm still stuck on a few of the flavors. I'll update the next time I buy this beer (tomorrow maybe, and the next day).

Better than the original, because of the bitterness. Dark, dark and darker it pours. I love to watch the bubbles cut through the beer
Earlier Rating: 11/14/2003 Total Score: 3.8
Good beer, a classic. Dark, Dark, Dark, in color obviously the reason for the little widget to cut through. Tan huge frothy head. Roadted malty flavor, hoopy. Good stout. It does taste a little better on draught.

Grabbed a bottle for old times sake... Very dark with a decent haed, nice retention.  Super roasty with hints of coffee, not as chocolatey as I remember it, but that was before I had sampled over 100 other stouts. This is still a fine example of the style and is greatly enjoyable.  A bit thin and weak.
Earlier Rating: 3/3/2002 Total Score: 3.5
People still get this dry stout confused with the draught, but there is always a time and place for this stuff. It's been my New Years Eve beer of choice for a couple of years.

Had this one in a 12oz bottle.  Love Guinness, should love Guinness Extra Stout.  Poured the expected very dark color with an inch tall head that hung around.  The aroma was mostly just roasted malts - slightly stronger aroma than my beloved Guinness draught.  The taste is somewhat burned with some bitterness to back it up surrounded by a creaminess.  This is a good beer, but it doesn't hold its ground when placed against Guinness draught.

Got this one in the 22 oz bottle , brewed in Canada.
Appearance, well the beer pours a deep deep black with a lovely tan head which dissapated to leave a ring around the glass.
The aroma was very malty..roasted malts..some espresso 
Now the taste was a big let down for me..it was surprisingly weak and "thin" compared to how the beer looks..odd..bitter black coffee taste some hops at the end..but somehow metallic.
A little too much carbonation for my tatses..thin feel in the mouth for a stout..this is almost like a porter.
Its drinkable but thats all.
I was quite dissapointed with this stout, maybe its better if it is made i Dublin or even London. Wonder if they tried to "dumb it down" for the percieved American market?
I will stick with Obsidian or Sheath stout for now.
This was a re-review I wanted to make sure that i was correct about this beer being "just average"..unfortunatly i was first time round ..dissapointed..regular Guinness daught from Ireland/England is better.
Bottle: Heavy, strong body, alcohol comes through. Nice aroma with chocolate tones, still not the real thing. Now retired.

I approached this with an open mind, having been disappointed by other variants on Guinness.  I let it warm a bit before opening.  The pour was not entirely satisfying--no cascade effect, alas--but the head clung admirably for a long time, like the residue of a vanilla ice cream float.  96% opaque black with dark caramel edges.  The aroma indeed reveals hops among the roasted coffee beans and mild smokiness.  Early on in my bottle, the rich coffee flavors seemed to dominate, although from the start there was a distinctive metallic twang snapping against my tongue.  Some nuttiness came out in the aroma about halfway through, and there were some subtle things going on there that raised the standing of this beer.  Yet, the flavor lacked a certain depth, only exacerbated by a mouthfeel that bordered on cola-like carbonation with quick burn-off finish and a limp feeling.  Not a bad beer in a pinch, but the kind of stout better suited as a cooking ingredient than for sipping and savoring. 
Earlier Rating: 8/3/2003 Total Score: 3.3
Interesting.  I think I preferred this to draught Guinness because it replaces the excessive smoothness of nitro-driven Guinness with a tangy bit of carbonation.  No trademark cascade...too bad...just a big but mostly dissipating head.  The aromas I got were strange--frying bacon, plum preserves--but still plenty of room for the classic roastiness.  The dry, chocolate flavors were decent, although a slightly metallic, chalky mouthfeel underminds the good vibes a bit.  Still, there is plenty to like here.
Great aftertaste that lingers after you've it.  makes you want another.
Just an all-around fuller aroma and flavor than the regular. More hops. Coffee, roasted malt, dryness, bitterness, some cocoa. Defintely not bad at all.
Much better than regular Guinness in my opinion.  Cocoa, coffee, woodiness, dry....blah blah, you've had it.
gross i hate coffee tasing beer. this one leaves a verry bitter and nasty after taste

I like stouts but, not this one.  It's not the worst thing I've had but there are far superior examples for less money.  Just to bitter, there are other flavors but they are muddy and way in the background.  Mix it with some Bass Ale and enjoy.
gross i hate coffe tasing beer. this one leaves a verry bitter and nasty after taste
a bad malty aroma, taste of rotten hops. bitter and not deep enough. overall I was rather dissapointed with this beer. I dont have much to say as i cannot decipher my handwriting.....

I can tell that I've been spoiled. If I didn't know that this was a stout, I would have thought that it was a porter. The beer is definitely dark, but light comes through more than the edges and has a good reddish-brown color. The aroma is faint. The flavor has an interesting bit of wood ash to it and a surprising bit of hop bitterness, at least for a dry Irish stout. Still, it's fairly thin and not complex at all. It did mix well with Dogwood IPA and created a nice hoppy porter-like thing that was pretty damn tasty.
black with a rocky tan head. tastes more black coffee, than chocolate like the draught. definitely more bitter than the other varieties.

Aroma is very one-dimensional and is characterized by rancid-smelling hops. Apperance is good - a deep dark brown with a tan head. Flavor is also one-dimensional - not much besides a strangy hoppy flavor. Try Bell's!!!

"Brewed by Guinness Brewing Company, New Brunswick, Canada" - Chalky, pastey aroma.  Bitter, with a bite: very sharp, good FES profile all around.  Some musty charcoal, cream, licorice, and hickory smoke flavor.  Very musty, quite delicious.

Either the beer has changed or my palate has, I remember this being tastier smoother and stronger. I bet like everyone else, this is one of your favorites until you really get into the wonderful of stouts
Decent but boring.  The only good beer at a resonable price at the grocery store.  They were out of Arogant Bastard so I got this.
I sampled this here and overseas in croatia, and I have to say I was more impressed with the one I had here.  It didn't excite me too much but did have a nice bitterness and chocolatey flavor.
Dark almost black colour,aroma of malt and coffee, medium body and taste of rich dark chocolate and mild coffee, not a long finish.

pours black with a tan head. aroma is bitter with notes of chocolate and coffee. medium body flavor is bitter, with a decent hop flavor, but lacks the oomph (rich chocolate and coffe flavors) that i have come to enjoy from stouts. all in all i prefer this over the draught version, but i really don't think that i will seek this beer out, but i will settle for it if nothing better is available.

From bottle.  Deep opaque brown in traditional Guinness form.  Thick beautiful brown foamy head.  Definite lacing. Aroma is chocolate and coffee with various malt tones. I don’t smell the hops others refer to.  Flavor is roasted, burnt, with a nice strong finish.  More carbonation than regular Guinness and a little more "in your face".  I like it.  Maybe a little more sour than regular Guinness too.  If you want smooth, get Guinness draught. The exra stout seems to  have a little more attitude.  And a little more alcohol content.

Guinness is one of the greatest stouts ever made. This is probably the best thing to come out of Ireland besides U2. Mix it with Champagne or Framboise.
Earlier Rating: 9/17/2003 Total Score: 4.1
This is heavy. One of the first beers that I ever drank. The stout is a little sour and very strong. The taste is a little hoppy and not as smooth as regular Guinness. This really is a treat. The head is a little bit darker red brown.
It poured with a large tan head that left nice lacing.  It was almost opaque, old roasty coffee aroma. Taste was rather watery with a coffee character in the aftertaste.

Lumpy, large tan head similar to dirty sea foam and a black body with a maroon sheen. Toasty aroma of chocolate, hop spice, and warm bread. Hops are also evident in the flavor along with an additional roasted bitterness. A hint of chlorine taste brings this one down a bit. Palate is less full-bodied than expected.

I was very disapointed in this beer.  Its appearance was great but the rest of the Guinness experience was not good.  The beer had a tan lasting head with geat appearance.  The taste however was weak and finished with an obeverly bitter aftertaste.  Very unimpressive.
Earlier Rating: 10/5/2002 Total Score: 3.6
Drinkable stout.

Light chocolate roast aroma, detectable hops and caramel malt. Flavor is slightly watered down but flavorful, not too bad, it's a guinness without the nitro, a little more up front and not as smooth (if you can call it that).

Ah Guinness. Dark as can be and beautiful to look at. Aroma has an aluminum bite to it, but the flavor is unforgetable and unique: Cold Espresso. Would rather have the real deal but you can get this import version at many sporting events in my area now.

Beer pours (in Chimay glass) a black liquid light can not penetrate with froathy, bubbly caramel colored head that lingers and as it sits, becomes very creamy.  Very nice.  Aroma is of light chocolate, faint hops and light skunk spray.  Flavor is of medium to strong (closer to strong) hops with a very dry ending.  The hop flavor is almost painful to the tastebuds.  Lacing is complete and does not fall away.  This beer is drinkable, but has no characteristics that make it enjoyable.  Sampled at 71 degrees Fahrenheit.
this is a wonderful very hearty beer great on a cold night but not for the rice water bud drinker

Nice dark color with a head that left a decent lacing.  The extra stoudt is more bitter/dry than the normal stoudt.  Initially, I was mad at having bought the wrong beer, but as I progressed through the case, it grew on me.  Definitely one to try.

Pours a dark black...not as creamy as in the cans.  Get a much more bitter taste from this.  Malty flavor with a hint of chocolate and coffee aftertaste.   Not bad but i prefer in the cans
Earlier Rating: 6/15/2003 Total Score: 3.2
Pours out nice and dark and creamy.  Wonderful roasted coffee aroma.  Very smooth and rich.

I had the 'regular' Guinness many times in Ireland, in pubs on tap, and in nitro cans.  I bought this one for the first time for the tasting.  I like regular Guinness but I like this stuff just as much.  I miss the creamy head from the nitrogen you find in regular Guinness but this stuff has more flavor and a lot more hops.  A nice change of pace if you like regular Guinness.
Ive had the draught for years before trying yhe extra stout. Was pleasantly suprised, nice hop, deep malty flavor almost chocolatey or like coffee. Been around for so long for a reason.

Very dark in color with a large lasting frothy beige head. Aroma is toasted malt and grain, some coffee notes. Flavor is rich, malty, creamy, & coffee. Lightly bitter finish. Excellent.
Earlier Rating: 1/24/2003 Total Score: 3.4
Did not like it as much as the draught. Still an enjoyable brew I would recommend.

What can I say--it's popular, but its popularity doesn't detract from its taste. I prefer the pint bottles, since I believe--perhaps falsely, since such things are so difficult to detect--they're more carbonated than the standard bottles. I can tire of Guinness easily, but just when I think I won't drink it anymore, it tastes fresh and exciting. All around, I think it's one of the most consistently good stouts I've encountered.
Not to be confused with the draught version, this is a very different brew. The "dirty" head is, to newcomers, offputting. But this beer tastes the same now as it ever did. Like it? Love it.

This one just tastes bad period.  Burnt, over-roasted malty bland coffee that has been sitting in the pot for a couple of days.  Thick, the beer that eats like a meal.
Earlier Rating: 1/21/2003 Total Score: 3.4
A nice peppery smokey aroma that follows you right into the first taste.  It is entertaining to watch this one being poured just for all the acrobatics going on in the glass as it settles.  This is really quite an amazing thing to drink.

Very dark brown hue with solid medium tan head and good lacing. Aroma is that of espresso, burnt malt, pecans, oak and earthy. The taste start very malty but then a nice hoppy bitter balanced it out nicely. The finish is long with lingering bitterness. The mouthfeel is oily and soft, full-bodied, with a moderate alcohol feel. While similar to the draught, the Extra is bigger in aroma and taste. My only knock against this beer always as been the burnt/smokey aroma. Still a all-time favorite of mine.

Thick dark brown color, fair head and lacing. Decent malt/hop aroma. Starts moderately sweet but gets more bitter as you go along. Finish was dry, with peculiar aftertaste. Perhaps not as fresh as it could be. So so. Big bottle.
Black with  a brown and goodlooking head. Tastes of coffee and cocoa, but there is an artificial touch in the middle of it all. Surprisingly mild but a bitter finish.
I'm developing an appreciation for this one. Dark and bitter it's perfect if Stouts are you cup of tea.

Better than the draft or canned version. You can actually control the temp. it is served at and as a bonus no nitrogen to ruin it. Very black. Nutty aroma, very full mouth-feel. Dry and clean on the finish. Overall OK but there are much better stouts to be had.
Malty sweet aroma.  Tasty thick, black toasted coffee notes. It is rich and flavorful, still not too heavy. Nice beer, it goes the "extra" mile to satisfy my need for a stout.

What can I say about this classic that hasn't already been said.  Just looks yummy out of the tap. The new druaght bottles taste a lot better than the older bottled style.  I love watching a persons reaction when trying a Guinness for the first time, they usually look like they're going to barf.  I love this stout!!!
Tan creamy head over black body.  The hoppiness is more notable than the other Guinness.  I prefer this one almost, also goes well with a shot of half Jameson half Bailey's

The worst beer I have ever tried to drink period.  I was drinking at my local water hole, and decided to try it because all the "great" comments I read about it on here.  I paid $3 for a bottle.  Opened it and took a swig.  After about puking I gave it back to the bar tender and told him to get rid of it.  He threw it in the trash can.  I then ordered the King of Beers in a can (which is my favorite and to me the best beer ever) a Budweiser.  Guinness reminds me of a cough syrup I have had before.

The "heavy" Guinness in my opinion.  I drank this long before I every managed to try one on draft.  Now that they've even come out with the draft in bottles, this one just isn't quite the same.  Still notable in it's own right though.
This doesn't have the wonderful apperance that the draught does, but it is still a quality beer, that is very accesible.

Bottle.  Pours almost black with a thick brown head.  Roasted malt aroma, chocolate and molasses.  Smooth toasted malt and coffee flavors, with dry hoppy finish.  Medium to full body with minimal carbonation.  Not bad for a mass produced, but doesn't stand up to many of our American microbrew stouts.
I like this beer because it is accessible, relatively cheap, and it doesn't have that stupid nitro head.

One of the classics. Simply looks amazing. Flavor is of dark roasted coffee. Has a distinct bitterness to it that is kind of astringent and takes away from an otherwise very drinkable brew. Superior to the bottled Draught.
i think i like this better than regular Guinness.  it's a wee bit more creamier and seems to have more character and flavor.  not quite as smooth, but better in a different kinda way.
Compared to Guiness stout I found  texture and appeareance to be the main differences. The stout seemed more creamy.
Better than Guinness Stout. Decent head, nice lacing, good but slightly thin mouthfeel.  Makes a great black and tan; lingering bitter aftertaste.
Starts with a nice dark pour and a mediocre head. Flavour starts with a teasing caramel and roasty malt. Finish is the achilles. Thumbs down.

Thought I might have given this world famous brew a bum rap, so here's the rerate. This beer is an intense deep black color. The head  is medium brown. The nose is mostly black coffee, though there are definite dark fruit overtones. The taste is bitter espresso with some bitter chocolate traces, plus a touch of prune and liqorice. The burned , undrinkable aspect I noticed before is nearly absent, though there is a slight smokiness to the beer, which is not at all undrinkable. The nasty taste of the first Guinness I rated can maybe atributed to  the fact that,  1. The bottle I had was old, or 2, I drank it at too warm a temperature.( According to the website Guinness is one stout that should be drunk cold.) Anyway the second bottle was much better. Still very bitter, but drinkable.
As close to heaven as I'll ever get. Very heady and all around good stuff . Not as good as Guinness from a beer engine but as good as can be expected.

Dark brown to black in colour.  Clean and bitter with a decent roast character and finsih.  Not all that imposing and maybe a little thin.
Earlier Rating: 9/12/2002 Total Score: 1.9
The beer that kept me away from really discovering Guinness.  Bottles found in Canada have often been abused.  I have never had a good one yet.  The beer is lighter in colour, thinner, and the head is not nearly as resilient as it's draft twin.

Doesn't have that strong alcohol taste of the other "intense stouts". Head will calm after a few minutes and looks almost like regular Guinness.  Bitter, burnt taste that sticks to the tongue.  Mmmmm... burnt...
A black pour with a foamy carbonated head. Didn't like this too much as it's not a nitro like the original. A definite acquired taste.

Probably not something for everyone, but some of us love it. Great appearance and the quintessential stout flavor. Perhaps the bitter finish is an acquired taste, like coffee, but I find it hard to beat.

Pours black as night, with a tan head that can be described as nothing other than sexy. A bit much carbonation, and a not so mild aftertaste, but a great drink none the less.  Definitely an acquired taste, but instantly became one of my favorites!
This with the widget would be near perfect. Very tasty ,toasty flavors. A meal in its self.
I like this WAY more than draught. More flavor, more body. If only ALL Guinness was as good as this I would have a better opinion of it.

Big tan head that the bottom fell out of fairly quickly, leaving some splotchey laceing behind. Dry grainy nose. Black in color, opaque. Full bodied, friggin bone dry. A noticeable sourness,(not a bad thing). Roasty, grainy almost puckering dry finish. A somewhat complex brew, has a certain tang. Gotta giv,em credit, Guinness that is.

Good beer -- very black with a moderate tan head; after only detecting a faint aroma, I was suprised by the flavor burst of coffee and chocolate this stout provides. The hops stick to the tongue long after the drink is gone. Good price, too.

This is one of the first "real" beers that I ever tried.  I fell in love with it then, and I am still in love with it to this very day. A Very solid and satisfying stout.  Has a beautiful dark brown/black color with a thick, creamy, tan head.  Thick and robust in flavor. Contians a plesant bitter, roasted, chocolate flavor followed by a slight sourness. Not watery at all. The flavor lingers in your mouth for quite a while. Although it is not as complex as other stouts, I still find it just as enjoyable.  I am very pleased that this is available in most supermakets today.
Chocolate, coffee, and nutty aroma. Molasses, coffee, and chocolate flavours, without the burnt character of Guinness Stout. Also doesn't have the watery finish the regular stout has.

I first had a Guinness in an Irish pub in Hong Kong of all places. I fell in love immediately.
Strong yet not over bearing flavor. Let it settle a bit before you drink it and you could slam a pitcher full. Add a shot of Bushmills to a pint, and enjoy a "Belfast Car bomb"!
I really enjoy this one.  Good hops, nice strong flavor.  Thin, creamy head that lasts.  I usually prefer my souts a bit sweeter, though.

too bitter and too thick for me to enjoy.  this is one of those beers i would drink a 24 of after having a 12 pack of something else.  the appearance and aroma however are most excellent

*rerate- bought a 22 of this the other night since i have a new aquired taste for darks more than i used to.. a much better brew than i remembered it once was.

I sometimes wonder how the world would have come together if this beer were never concocted? I will always be a big fan of Guinness Extra; it is not overly complex but always enjoyable. Sometimes simple is better.
Basic roasted coffee grounds aroma, dark brown/black color with a thin tan head, good flavor, nothing too complex, mild coffee/chocolate. This one gets points for being so consistant and available.

This version is less watery then the can version but not as good as the one on tap. It is mentionned to drink from bottle but I still suggest using a regular stout glass.Usual bitter aftertaste but not much coffee taste as with other great stout. This is legend but I think that other brewery are now doing better stout.

drank this from one of those large bottles. I do not like this version of guiness.  Its bitter taste is overpowering and stings the palate.  I like bitter beer, but something about this beer bothers me.

What a looker. It gets heavy in a hurry, but still a favorite of mine. While I love the draught for what it is, this one just goes down good, and fast. The best partner for any black & tan I've ever had, it's right up there on my list with mother's milk.

Hoppy aroma when I opened the bottle. Light creamy head. Bitter finish. Palate is creamy but not as much as the regular Guinness Stout. But what can I say? If you like stout, you like Guinness. Okay, so I do.
A pretty close impersonation of the superior Guinness on draft. More bitter though, less creamy.

I much prefer this to Guinness Draught. Feels a bit lighter but makes up for this in flavor. It's toasted and bitter and does not have the sweetness of the Guinness Draught, which has always got in the way and bothered me.
This is what real stout is meant to be. A thick, perpetual head, lots of chocolate and hops in the perfect blend. This is truly "The beer you've been practicing for."

this is a beautiful, beautiful beer. it's really striking in the glass. deep dark rich opaque reddish brown with a great fluffy tan head that lasts *forever*. aroma is nice and woody and roasted. the lace on the glass is so fantastic that it's kind of making me fall in love with this beer.


and then i tasted it. it's not bad, necessarily. just disappointing. i had such high hopes after seeing and smelling it, and this beer definitely did not live up to them. there's not much flavor until the finish, and that flavor is unbalanced; burned malt and the hop is just...not quite right. 


overall, certainly not a bad beer, and as a life-long guinness hater, i was pleasantly surprised to have a guinness with hops, but not anything i'd seek out again.

This beer is excellent.  Toasted flavour, very smooth going down, and not very bitter.  This beer is black as the night, with a decent sized everlasting light-brown head.  Nice lacing, too.  The finish is a little more bitter than when actually drinking it.  It leaves that bitter, toasted taste in your mouth - more than the original, but it is not harsh.  A very lively dark beer, with great flavour!

Dark brown. Off white head. A little funky corn-nut aroma (butterscotch?), touch of coffee, lot of chocolate. Seemed to get sour as it warmed. Actually surprisigly good (especially with the roast chicken I had (but not with the vanilla ice cream I had later)).
A little too bitter for my tastes but overall not too bad.  Enjoyed it more other times that i have had it.
A stronger version of the regular guinness. Nice chocolate taste with a little more hops than the other.Goes down smooth with a bite free finish.

Pretty good, but I guess I have succumbed to the whole nitrogen trick. Pours flat with a small dark head. Creamy enough as the malt rocks. It is like those well worn slippers that are super comfortable and easy to wear, but you stay away from using them in public.

I love this beer,  The taste is hard to define. It has hint's of dark chocolate (not sweet chocolate)and coffee. This is a beer you take your time drinking. Chugging this like it was a Natty light would be an injustice. It's best when not ice cold but rather around 50 F. The head was rather unimpressive though. Also it is rather expensive @ $8.99/ 6 pk.

I must confess.  I've never liked Guinness.  I got a bit daring today, and got a 6 pack of the extra stout in bottles.

I think that I've decided to drink it "the right way" (according to me).  I poured it chilled (not ice cold) into my wide-mouth Trappistes Rochefort glass...  I was pleasently surprised!  It's dark and bold with an oily, oaky flavor, as the description says.  The flavor is smooth and less bitter than I remember, with a slight bite.  Malt, chocolate, and a hint of extra hops that aren't in the regular stout.  I'm pretty impressed, but I'm still not sure what all of the Guiness hype is about.  Maybe I caught it at the wrong time, since they apparently make this stuff in Canada now.  Regardless, it's pretty good.  I need to go back and try to rerate the regular stout.
Has a musky aroma, and just like the description says, an 'oaky flavor'.  Oily mouthfeel, no problem with the finish.  Decent stuff, but I prefer something more "Rogue-ish".

This brew poured a medium creamy long lasting dark brown head of small to large sized bubbles. I t had a malty coffee aroma and a pitch black stout body. It has a heavy coffee flavor just like the stouties expect and is very smooth with no bite.
very dark with excellent uniform head, kind of a burnt caramel taste, heavy body with lots of malt. excellent Irish Stout

Typical black Guinness, smells like it too.  Not quite as thick a head.  Hmmm... this is turning out to be a disappointing 100th beer on my list.  It's much more plain than Guinness Draught.  There's more of a slight wood flavor, the commercial description says oak.  Some bland coffee hints too.  Watery as well.  Just weird, it misses that nice creaminess of the draught.  So sad... oh well, happy 100 to me!

This is not your father's Guinness. It is now made in Canada, and is no longer imported into the USA from Ireland. It has lost
it's appeal to such a degree that I have sought to replace it as my everyday beer. Back in the mid 80's, I worked in a liquor
store / warehouse, and the owner got Guinness by the truckload. It was the original Guinness too, from Ireland, not this
watered down crap from Canada. The original Guinness had a coal black color to it when poured, a dense, tan head that lasted
to the end of the glass, and plenty of hop aroma & bitterness. This crap they call Guinness from Canada has none of these
attributes. It is watery, dark brown instead of black, no head to speak of, and they have changed the variety of hops as well.
The original was 7.5% ABV, and this crap from Canada is only 5% ABV, so you can't tell me it is the same beer, cause it's just
plain not. Guinness had better wake up & realize they have lost their "target audience" and are losing more everyday. Believe
me, I've drank enough original Guinness to float a battleship, and the crap you buy today isn't even in the same ball park as the
original. Until they start importing it from Ireland again, I won't be drinking any more of this drain cleaner.

Old rating for the Irish version is gone...?  But luckily I just sampled the Canadian stuff for the first time - or well, maybe thats not so lucky, because this is clearly not the same beer, nor is it even in the same league as that beer.  Looks much the same though: deep dark mahogany with full fluffy tan haed.  Aroma lightly roasty, with a light roast flavor and dry finish.  No particular character.  Some astringency and plastic apparent unless fully up to drinking temperature.  So avoid the current recommendations from Guinness that it should be chilled for at least 3 hours - of course, even without the off-flavors, a beer of this style should not be drunk that cold.
Earlier Rating: 4/26/2000 Total Score: 4.5
Actually, I like the bottled extra
stout better than the canned draught.
It doesn't look as good in the glass, but
its strength and roasted malt flavors
are more present.
I know I'm in the minority in my
Guinness preference.

The Canadian version. Imagine Guinness brewed by Labatt's You have Guinness taste with Labatt's taste. Not a very appealing combination. You have all the same burnt and roasted aromas and flavours, you have the bitterness. But now you have the carbonation and the filmy feel of a Blue added to it. Half decent but not great. I will avoid it in the future.

Okay, this beer arrived a very dark brownish black color nd formed an off white head with little lace.  It had an aroma malt, smoke and chocolate.  The flavor was of malt and chocolate.  The body was creamy and the finsh was chocolate with some smoke present.

So. . .much. . .coffee!  Don’t get me wrong, but aren’t there supposed to be other things in this beer?  I'm not even particularly fond of coffee.  I get a finishing bitterness and roasty smell, but other than that, it’s all coffee.  Kinda creamy but thin.  Head didn't stick around like it was supposed to.  I don’t remember it being like this, but I can’t say where the last one I had came from.  I have to agree with most other raters, though--whatever they’re doing up there in Toronto, this isn’t how I thought it should be.  Disappointingly one-dimensional.
I do prefer the draught, but this version has even greater taste/aroma complexities.  The smokiness comes out in the nose, and the oiliness i remember wasn't there but otherwise the texture is rich.

Big mocha head atop black body.  Aroma is medium sweet, malty and roasty.  Taste is malty, roasty up top, some coffee, and mildly sweet.  Finishes with pleasant bitterness.  The beer has nice creaminess, full body, and some chewiness.  I prefer this to Guinness' regular stout.
A good, but not great, stout. I like this better than the nitro charged Gunness, but there are better stouts out there. Still, a fine stout and certainly one worthy of trying.
On draught in St. Charles, Illinois.  Rich, dark, dancing appearance, thick head, strong nose of bitter chocolate, the standard in smoothness.
A rich, coffee-like taste that lingers for just the right amount of time.  You can't go wrong with a Guinness.

It taste like coffee and I'm not a fan of coffee.
.....................
A very fine beer from a very commercial brewer. Pitch black in color with a rocky head that quickly dissipates. Nice aroma similar to a french roast. Good hop finish.
Is there a more beautiful-looking beer in the world than Guinness??  Aroma of coffee dominates.  The beer starts off bitter, and finishes off very, very smooth.  This is some good stuff.

Not too sweet for a stout. This beer left a somewhat pleasant aftertaste on my palate.
Nice roasted coffee flavor too.

This one is much different than the draft. Much more of a mouthfeel and lot more bitterness on the tounge. Dark as night but loses an appearance point for not having the magic of the draft pour. This was really good as a black and tan mixed with Harp lager. This was the beer that originally got me to #100. Now that I've had to re-enter everything I chose it again as #100. Its good to be back!

Stout poured a bit on the foamy side.  Aroma was there but the hop bitterness is what I enjoyed the most of this Guinness.   A 17 ounce bottle can be bought for two bucks at local liquor stores so it's a good bargain too.   I drank this one at Philadelphia's St. Patrick's Day parade.
Bottle.  Basically a black color with a foamy brown head.  A big toasted malt aroma with a roasted coffee flavor.  I find this version a little harsh and lacking in complexity and richness.

This stuff is like a meal in a bottle. Large frothy head, very dark brown color. More roasted flavors than the draft. Ends on a nice dry note. Has a little bit of sourness, maybe to overcome the malt.
What can I say, it's Guinness. Everybody has had Guinness. Really a decent brew as long as you stay away from all the widget can/bottle stuff in my opinion.
This beer is so pretty you don't wanna drink it, but you will cause it's real good.
mine said 6% on the bottle. suspiciously like Guinness Original. big very frothy head. very strong flavour and fairly smooth.
Thick, rich flavors with creamy head. Some aftertaste takes away from overall enjoyment.

VERY dark beer.  I might have had a bad pour, but the head was almost non-existant, and what little there was, was quickly gone.  Aroma was very nice with some roasty notes in it.  The first taste threw me a bit as I didnt not know what to expect.  After the second taste, I found the origin of roasty aroma.  Very well balanced beer, and very tasty.
rich chocolatey mildly hopped nose.  lighter then i remember, coffee comes late.  good hops.  when i think dry stout this is it

I enjoyed it from the bottle but was disappointed that it's actually brewed and bottled in Canada. 
It had a nice burst of flavors. Rich malt flavors abound. Very enjoyable and not the same predictable Guinness I've come to know on draught or from the widget can.

This tastes to much different than the tap or even the can that they're actually hard to compare. Does it taste a bit sweeter in the bottle? It seems so to me. Decent, if you can't get out to your local bar for a draft pint.
Rich roast flavor. Syrupy in consistancy but this is expected. No after taste, and goes down smooth. Not a beer to guzzle.
Not as fresh tasting as the draugt. It’s on the bitter side and all too heavy. It’s not what I would call bad, but I miss the creany coffee like flavors of it’s more famous counterpart.
Not a bad dry stout from Guinness.  Coffee and roasted flavor.  Smooth and carbinate with a slightly bitter finish.
More bitter and carbonated than original Guinness.  The only thing extra is some more alcohol and a higher price.  Still a pretty good beer.
Having had on tap and then trying the bottled version I will definatley stick with tap.  Found this version to be more watery than tap versions.

If you wan't to throw up drink this straight from the bottle. It is nasty. In a glass it's better. Nice black color and tan head. The taste is ok, but I've had a very bad experience from drinking this stuff straight from the bottle. Looking at it makes me want to gag.
What can you say - if you're gonna drink a Stout, look no further than Guinness. Atrue classic. Great dark color and foamy white head. Top notch.

Rerate Just does not do it for me anymore - all around boring and lifeless Original 3.8 Fond memeories of this in my youth (14 yrs old)- used to sell newspaper subscriptions door to door and the guy who took us around would reward us with Guninness - why? I don’t know! Could barely stomach it then - could not imagine how anybody would want to drink it! Now that my taste buds have matured - I can appreciate it a bit more.
