Nice dark black pour with a creamy off-white head with a decent bit of lacing. Roasty flavor, very subtle coffee undertones - bit of a chalky aftertaste. Sours a tad bit near the end - but overall, still a winner.
One of my first "real" beers so long ago. Roasty smokey nose, black, bitter stout.
Flatter than the regular with no creamy head and bitterness that has no body to balance it.

Beautiful black color, huge tan head that laced around the glass, a little thiner than the extra stout, I still prefer the draft (of course), but if I can't have it on draft then give it to me in the can, but still an excellent stout

Earlier Rating: 11/22/2001 Total Score: 3.9
Good stout, better out of the can if you can't get one on tap.
Strong flavor and impressive dark color.  Flavor was better when served at room temperature.
Not as good as draught style.  A smooth, smoky stout that doesn't have much body to it.  Even when it's lukewarm it tastes COLD, which is interesting.
Amazing beer. Great color, great taste. Somewhat bitter aftertaste but not bad. Gorgeous beer.
great dark body.long lasting head. smooth taste with a mild aftertaste......
Pours a deep black with a tan head.  Bitter and very roasted like burnt coffee.  This is the king of the Irish stouts
The new Guinness Draught Bottle is a vast improvement on this one. .........
Not as good as guinness stout.  Needs nitro.  Higher ABV and some more depth of flavor would be nice.
I like this one better than their draught style! very nice roasted barley flavor!! mmmmmhhhhhh
Guinness is a nice standard stout, but it definitely lacks the complexity and flavor of some microbrew stouts out there.

I still don''t understand the fixation with this. The draught is tasteless, and this only adds a few extra dashes of roasted nastiness. I thought the bitter was unpleasant and that yeasty, malty, roasted whatever-it-is just sat at the back of my mouth jabbing my tonsils with some implement of bad taste. I do appreciate the fact that the extra stout tried to actually have some flavor (unlike its watery brethren) but it was, sad to say, unsuccessful.
is not the same since they started brewing it in cananda, but still solid. from the pub is the best way to enjoy this brand though
I find this a lot more enjoyable than regular Guinness in any shape or form.  Bitterness is the only difference I really see here besides more apparent carbonation than draught/tap versions.

Thin and bitter. Loses some creaminess when not on draft. Still black as night, but no cool cascade effect on the pour. Holds a small tan ring of head and leaves some lacing. Slight more bitter than the draft version, especially in the aftertaste. Some tang and plenty of roast.
Black as night and tastes like half beer and half coffee.  Will wake up the ol'' tastebuds.
Very black in color with rather large long lasting head.  Aroma of black cherry and malt.  Taste of old coffee.  Tangy on the finish with a rather unpleasant aftertaste.  Seems pretty unrefined.
Not bad.  Very roasty and bitter.  Little flavor aside from the bitterness though.  Too thin.  Great foamy head.
Canadian version:Very poor interpretation...................................

This is a good stout. It is smooth on the palate, and well balanced with flavor. It has a nice, dark look to it with a good head. 
Earlier Rating: 12/23/2002 Total Score: 2.6
Bottling really killed this beer. It is much better on tap.
Why did I even try to drink this out of the bottle.  Why do they even bottle it this way.  This is a beer that needs to come out of the can with the widget (if you must), or preferably on tap.
it had a coffee flavor to me.. im not a big fan of it but it was tolerable..

I used to say that I couldn''t stand Guinness. Then I was invited to a Guinness Event in downtown Chicago. That changed my mind. It was free beer and food along with info on Guinness. Granted its not a beer I am going to have one after the other at a bar, but is sure goes good with a good meal.
This is my favorite version of Guinness Stout...............................
This comes across as lighter than I remember the old Extra Stout.  Very enjoyable fruitiness over considerable dark malt heft.  Good at parties.
ok..i love guinness. and out of all the forms of guinness..besides draught...this is the best.
Not as strong as regular Guinness, definitely roasted but not "stout" like the name implies.

More character than regular Guinness, but not an exceptional stout. Very roasty and creamy; unfortunately that is about all that can be said about this beer. Pretty monodimensional. It is not bitter at all, contrary to what the label may claim.

I didn't used to like it, but I had a lot over the summer and I can't live without it anymore.  I love the color and the puzzling consistency.  It's thick, but almost watery when it goes down.  Hints of bitter coffee.  Really an excellent stout.

I like the original bottled version, before nitro, a lot.  I prefer the smoothness of the tap style, but this is great, especially when you''ve been working hard and want to sit down with a beer.  It hits the spot for me.

Seems to be almost the same as the can. Still has a good full flavor.
Earlier Rating: 12/1/2002 Total Score: 3.7
Stick with the original.

Not quit as good as the regular draught but still fairly good.
Earlier Rating: 5/24/2002 Total Score: 3.7

swilled many pints before I realized that other breweries make stouts, too.
Earlier Rating: 11/25/2002 Total Score: 3.5
quite different from the canned draught version, actually.  Fuller bodied - not as quaffable as draught.  Some lingering, burnt bitterness that is not a bad thing at all.
What can I say?  You can never go wrong when it comes to a good pint of Guinness!  Extra stout is just plain good!

brownish black appearance which does not let in even the smallest partical of light, frothy dark tan head...nutty, soil-like earthy aroma...bitter first impression, peanut-skin/salty/roasted and bitter flavors intertwined with dryness in the finish but still managing to leave a salty-nutty presence lingering on into eternity, I prefer a sweeter stout, but not bad for a dry stout

A good beer, but not as good as draft.  This is more bitter, more hoppy, just plain more.  It is not as nicely balanced as on tap, although it is still quite smooth.  If you like stouts a lot, I''m sure you''ve had it and probably liked it.

Very dark brownish black, entirely opaque. Initially, an exceptional brown head that leaves an island of foam in the center of the glass. Lacing is spotty and brown. Overall look reminds me of a rootbeer float. Much more flavorful than Guinness Draght--hoppier and maltier. Pleasant sweet malty aroma and flavor combined with a distinct bitterness from the hops. Leaves a slight sticky feel on the tongue and tastes like it might have spent an extra week or two on the boat over. Overall, an excellent beer.

another winner from these guys my opinion there the best out there in the lower end of the price scale
Earlier Rating: 11/6/2002 Total Score: 4.3
it''s just so damn good.I''ve been a guinness addict ever since my first pint
A superior stout that has a smoothness most should envy. A perfect brew on many levels.

It has been a while since I have tried this so take this with a grain of salt.  It is very similar to the draught, but much crisper and bitter.  Overall I did not like it as much as the draught.  The problem is that I now cannot drink the draught without getting sick...
This was a decent brew, a free beer I found in my fridge. Nice taste with balanced bitterness. Has a slight roasted coffee after-taste.

i can''t believe i''ve never rated guinness. mayhap cause i''m always knee up to a bar minding my own beeswax...anyway, what could i possibly say. i''ll let my numbers speak for themselves. only a beer lover will love guinness. (and i love it even though i''m a bit tired of it)

100% blind rating.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting.

Body is black (not opaque, flashlight tested).

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, molasses, husks), trace hops (herbs), with a light note of black tea.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately to heavily bitter, slightly husky.

Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

The only way to fairly rate Guinness is blindly; there is simply too much negative and positive bias, hype, etc. to rate this if you know what you’re drinking.
Far above and beyond the draught can I had.  Dark, thick, and strong-flavored with coffee/mocha.  An excellent stout and easily one of my favorite dark beers ever.

This beer is very dark -- almost black -- in color with a thick, brown loamy head that lies on top of the beer. This beer is brewed in Ireland and was originally known as a Porter. It is brewed using malt, barley, roasted barley (which gives it its dark character) and hops. The beer is conditioned in a second yeast fermentation before it is bottled. For a beer that has a solid, stout taste, it surprises me that the alcohol content is only 4.3% -- lower than Anheuser-Busch’s Budweiser, for example.

March 02:Looks great, of course, though I prefer the pour of the draft can or on tap; flavor is more intense and bitter than other versions I've had, though the nose is surprisingly weak.  More wine-like, syrupy, and coffee-like simultaneously.

I walk into the little market by my house to pick up some milk, and lo and behold, in the cooler, they are stocking bottles of this stuff (St. Patrick's Day must be coming up, eh?).  This store caters to the Busch and Miller High Life crowd, so seeing Guinness Extra Stout was surprising.  The cashier rang it up, looked at me and said..."Is this beer?".  I assured her it was (she needed to know to hit the "beer" key on the cash register.).  I give this perfect marks for appearance.  No, it doesn't give the show the nitro can or draft do, but it looks incredible in the glass with a brown, candy-like foam head and pitch blackness staring from the pint glass.  Nice roasted malt taste, light hop twang, and overall a bit more warming than regular Guinness.  Good stuff.

There is no singular experience that can compare to the unique pleasure of a fine mug of Guinness (except maybe an actual draft pint!!!).  It is a bit pricey, but it is worth it.  I would MUCH rather pay $9.00 for a 6 of Guinness than get a KEG of any American pilsner.  A wine drinker would rather pay a high price for a fine wine than drink Mad Dog.  Same thing for beer drinker with any taste!!  This is not a mud ridin' col-beer to drink!!  If you want to experience one of the 3 Great adult pleasures, start it off with a 6 of these!

I tried it out of the bottle after I tried the new Draft from the can that they started making.  This didn't have the head retention, or the same spunk as that does.  Still the same beer, just without some of small things that are the difference between a good beer and a great beer.
A true classic that every beer drinker will eventually try. Always smooth and dry and never overbearing. Try it with chips and salsa!
MUCH better than the canned or draft version. This stuff actually has taste.
Better than the can, but only when served warm..............................
Just about the best I've had.  Great flavor and it really packs a punch.  If you haven't tried it, do so.
A classic.  The best thing about Guinness is that pretty much everywhere you go you can find it.  It's nice to have a standard choice besides Bud and Bud Light.

Although very different from draught Guinness it represents the standard Irish or Dry Style Stout. I prefer the nitro pour draught anyday myself. The bottled version presents more aggressive with the burnt malt taste and hop bitterness. Perhaps due to the CO2 carbonation instead of the Nitro. Decent brew if you like the strong stout flavor.
I don't like this from a bottle: Slightly bitter............................
Exellent stout. The more I drink it the better I like it. The best stout I've tried so far.
Oh yuck, yuck, yuck. Motor oil could be an alternative. Tastes odd. It does get some points for maintaining some Guinness-like qualities.
Overall a very good stout.  It's a little more bitter than it's cousin draught, and not quite as smooth, but a very good beer none-the-less.

Guinness in the bottle is terrible!  I like bitter, but this is just the wrong kind of flavor and without the smoothness of nitrogen bubbles Guinness loses a lot of it's flare and definitely it's smooth quality.  If you haven't had a bottle, try it once just to say you have and you'll also have a higher level of appreciation for Guinness on tap or in the can.
OH YEAH !!!  Absolutely delicious.  Pleasing to look at and even better to drink
I don't particularly like Guinness from the bottle.  I find it far to bitter and would likely choose other beers over Guinness if only offered the bottle.  It's great on tap or from the can.

Guinness is by all means one of the best stouts out there, and I would much rather have it out of the bottle vs. the can any day.  Primary reason, I like the sharp-burnt taste with less of the fine cream taste that I find the can gives.
